HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Long lines outside the best colleges are likely to get longer.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IT'S the season for choosing colleges and, by tradition, time to lament the astounding cost of America's elite private institutions. Astounding is no exaggeration: tuition at the Ivy League schools and their competitors has increased fivefold in the last two decades, nearly double the rate of inflation.
The most common explanation is that brand-name colleges are isolated from the market forces that keep the price of a Camry within shouting distance of the price of a Taurus -- and the price of both within the budgets of middle-income Americans. But Gordon Winston, co-director of the Williams College Project on the Economics of Higher Education, paid for by the Mellon Foundation, offers a radically different perspective. The scarcest resource at the high end of higher education, he argues, is talented students, rather than money. And the competition for these students dramatically favors schools that already enroll the best and brightest, creating an unbridgeable quality gap between the typical college and what he calls "the snooties." 
 Colleges cannot be analyzed like ordinary businesses, Mr. Winston argues, because they do not seek profits. And a good thing, too: in 1990-91 the average four-year private college or university spent $10,600 a student and got back just $3,400 in tuition and fees. Williams, where Mr. Winston teaches, charged an average of $11,500 for services that cost $40,000 to deliver. So while money matters, colleges obviously have something else in mind.
One goal is attracting better students. Brand-name schools with hefty endowments offer the prestige, superior education and amenities the "customers" crave, generating long queues for admissions. But unlike profit-seeking businesses, colleges do not take excess demand as a signal to expand. Expansion, after all, would leave less subsidy available per student, undermining the institutions' efforts to attract the very best.
The excess demand, reflected in rates of rejection as high as 88 percent at Harvard, feeds on itself. For starters, it validates perceptions that the colleges are the best, much the way long lines outside restaurants reassure first-time patrons that they have chosen wisely.
More important, Mr. Winston suggests, good students are a key part of education, creating the environment for learning that has as much to do with the results as the teaching. Thus a college able to choose from a huge pool of applicants can sustain quality without outspending less prestigious institutions. And success begets success, increasing the pool of students seeking the most value for a tuition dollar.
This is not quite the end of the story. Rich, aspiring second-tier schools -- for example, Emory University in Atlanta -- use discounts to lure students otherwise bound for the snooties. Indeed, Rice University in Houston garnered a place among the elite by charging no tuition at all.
But for all the schools' efforts, Mr. Winston notes that the pecking order as measured by popular perceptions has not changed much. And while a handful of contenders may wait in the wings, schools that are already members of the inner circle have the cash to fight back with discounts of their own, should they see the need. In short, Mr. Winston is convinced that the top tier of higher education is what the economists Philip Cook of Duke and Robert Frank of Cornell call a "winner take all" market -- that is, a few dozen colleges and universities will increasingly distance themselves from the run of the mill.
Most people would probably not be troubled by the prospect. After all, elitism rooted in achievement rather than birth is as American as 30-year-old bond traders driving Ferraris. But Mr. Winston worries that the unusual incentives for colleges make it unlikely that the elite will ever open their doors to larger numbers.
Over the next decade, he estimates, college enrollment will increase by 10 to 30 percent. But private schools, which currently spend two or three dollars for every dollar they recoup in tuition, have powerful reasons to hold the line on size. More ominously, Mr. Winston argues that much the same pressures are now at work at the best state-supported universities.
Some first-rank state universities, he notes -- notably those in California --are acutely aware that legislators are in no mood to offset the dilution of subsidies, should they decide to expand enrollment. Others, notably the University of Michigan, behave more and more like private schools as the proportion of their income from private sources rises.
All this implies that it will become ever harder to get into top-ranked schools, private or public. And with growing scarcity may come diminishing tolerance for admissions policies that weigh diversity along with merit: if affirmative action raised hackles in the 1980's and 1990's, watch what happens when a third more students are competing for the same number of places in class.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Rate of Expansion Slackens in Region

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The New York City regional economy continued to expand in April, but at a significantly slower pace than was the case through most of last year, a national business group said yesterday.
The report, by the National Association of Purchasing Management, which surveys its members about changes in corporate outlook and spending on everything from raw materials to office chairs, said its business conditions index slid slightly in April to 50.9 percent from 51 percent in the preceding month. 
 The April figure was the weakest month-to-month change since February 1996, and only the second under 51 percent since June 1995. Anything under 50 percent is considered a contraction, while anything over 50 percent indicates business expansion.
The association's report said that the nonmanufacturing side of the local economy showed signs of a contraction in April but that a speeding of business activity among manufacturers kept the index in positive territory. The index of future economic outlook by the group's members in the region also suggested continued growth, improving slightly, to 67.4 percent, from 64.6 percent in March.
Last year, purchasing managers were more optimistic. In 6 out of 12 months in 1996, the outlook index for the region was over 70 percent, the association said.
 KIRK JOHNSON

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Broadly Higher, Buoyed by U.S. Output Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose modestly yesterday, bolstered by a report that the United States economy grew in the first quarter at its fastest pace in more than nine years. The strong figures on the gross domestic product partly offset the effects of a report Tuesday that showed unexpectedly mild labor costs.
Traders said the output data increased the possibility that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates at its May 20 meeting. Higher rates tend to enhance a currency's value. 
 Speculation on a rate increase was heightened further after the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, Jack Guynn, told a business group in New Orleans that the first-quarter G.D.P. growth was "faster than most of us had expected." Mr. Guynn is a voting member of the Fed's rate-setting committee.
Jan Alvarez, senior foreign exchange trader at Corestates Bank in Philadelphia, commented on the data: "They're strong numbers, so we're looking at a stronger dollar. The robust growth tells us the Fed will hopefully raise rates at its next meeting."
Yesterday, the dollar touched an intraday high of 127.13 Japanese yen before settling in New York at 127.06 yen, up from 126.87 late Tuesday. The dollar settled at 1.7303 German marks, up from 1.7243.
The dollar also strengthened against the British pound, which retreated to $1.6237 from $1.6316, partly on uncertainty surrounding the outcome of Britain's general election today. Although the Conservatives are expected to lose power to the Labor Party, questions among some about Labor's margin of victory raised the possibility of an indecisive government. "If there's a slim majority for either party, and it's likely to be Labor, it would be harder for the new government to govern," said Michael Malpede, foreign exchange analyst at the Refco Group in Chicago. "That put some pressure on the pound."
The dollar's advance against the yen was muted by speculation that the Japanese central bank would intervene to keep the yen from weakening further. Tatsuya Enomoto of Sumitomo Bank in New York said the dollar had been indirectly restrained, as well, by the yen's strength against the mark.

HEADLINE: Terrorism's Worldwide Toll Was High in 1996, U.S. Report Says

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
International terrorist attacks killed 311 people worldwide last year, one of the highest death tolls recorded, the State Department said today in its annual report on political terror.
Nearly 200 of those deaths were the work of the Tamil Tigers, a separatist group in Sri Lanka, the report said. 
 Once again, Iran, Iraq, Libya, North Korea, the Sudan, Syria and Cuba are on the State Department's list of nations that sponsor such attacks. But the report said that only Iran, by assassinating dissidents abroad and supporting violent groups, was directly linked to any of the terrorist bombings and killings last year.
No international terrorists struck the United States last year, the report said; it made no mention of the midair explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800 off Long Island in July, which killed 230 people. The Federal Bureau of Investigation is still not sure what caused the disaster.
And no attack anywhere in the world last year came close to the April 1995 explosion that killed 168 people at a Federal office building in Oklahoma City. A United States Army veteran with far-right views is on trial in Denver in the case.
"Domestic terrorism," the report said, "is probably a more widespread phenomenon than international terrorism today," taking a far higher toll in nations like Sri Lanka, Algeria, India and Pakistan as well as the United States.
Still, 24 American citizens died in international terrorist attacks last year. Nineteen were killed in the June 25 truck bombing at an American military base near Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. Five more died in bombings and shootings in Israel.
The Dhahran attack remains unsolved. "Eventually, we are going to get to the bottom of this," John Lewis, the F.B.I.'s assistant director for national security, said today.
The 296 international terrorist incidents recorded in 1996 represented a 25-year low, and most were minor blows against commercial targets that killed no one. The deadliest attacks were carried out by the Tamil Tigers of Sri Lanka. The group carried out the biggest bombing of 1996, an explosion in downtown Colombo, the capital, that killed 90 people in January, and it blew up a commuter train in July, killing 70.
The second-deadliest group of 1996 was the Islamic Resistance Movement, better known as Hamas, whose most militant factions want to establish an Islamic Palestinian state in place of Israel. A Hamas suicide bomber blew up a bus in Jerusalem on Feb. 25, 1996, killing 26 people, including 3 Americans. A second struck a Tel Aviv shopping mall a week later, killing 20.
By the State Department's definition, nations cannot commit acts of terrorism, only "subnational groups or clandestine agents" who carry out "politically motivated violence" against innocents. If a nation's air force bombs civilians, that is not terrorism; if civilians blow up a plane, it is.
But nations can sponsor terrorist groups and agents. The seven nations on the State Department's terrorism list are barred from receiving United States military and economic aid or importing American-made items that can be used for military purposes.
Still, the report said, there was no evidence directly linking Cuba, Iraq, Libya, North Korea, the Sudan or Syria to acts of state-sponsored international terrorism in 1996. Only a Presidential order can remove a nation from the terrorism list. Only one nation -- Iraq -- has ever been removed. That decision, in 1982, came while Iraq was at war with Iran, and it was reversed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Good Profits Spur Stocks, But Aid Case For Rate Rise

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average moved to within striking distance of its all-time closing high yesterday on the back of better-than-expected corporate earnings and relief that the economy's strongest quarterly growth in nine years has not led to a surge in inflation.
With the results in from most of the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index, overall profits are about 3.7 percent above forecasts, according to I.B.E.S. and First Call, two companies that monitor earnings performance, continuing a string of 21 quarters of increases. And the first quarter's increase in wages and compensation turned out to be less than expected. 
 But that good news, which helped spur the remarkable April rally in the stock market, could have another side: The strong economic growth that helped produce the better-than-expected earnings could be just what prompts the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again, even if the inflation news is still subdued. After all, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has made it clear the Fed wants to be pre-emptive, acting before inflationary pressures are clearly apparent.
Put another way, the stock market seems to be following interest rates, and even better-than-expected earnings will not be enough to give stocks a lasting lift as long as there is upward pressure on rates.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company and one of the more optimistic equity strategists going into 1997, summed up the difficulty in the outlook with this question: "The quarter was good, but is it going to result in another move by the Fed to raise interest rates?"
And Ms. Cohen raised another issue that may have to be resolved before the stock market can break out of its current trading range and move to significantly higher levels: comfort with the prospects for 1998. Investors, she said, will first have to be reasonably confident that earnings will be positive next year and that the economy will continue to grow moderately while inflation remains in check. "I think it's a little early for that," she said. Her current forecast for 1998 is an 8 percent increase in earnings, but other forecasters are seeing less growth and some are forecasting declines.
This may all seem like irrelevant babble right now, after the Dow Jones industrial average has jumped 9.7 percent in the last two and a half weeks and finished yesterday just 76 points from the previous closing high of 7,085.16, reached on March 11.
But the questions about the outlook for the stock market have not really changed, even with the relief from inflation worries brought by the Employment Cost Index for the first quarter, which came in with a lower-than-expected increase of six-tenths of 1 percent . Or with some signs that the sharp growth of the first quarter, when the economy grew at an annual rate of 5.6 percent, may be slowing.
The key unanswered question is whether the Fed will move to raise rates again, maybe as soon as the May 20 meeting of its policy-making committee. Given the surprising selloff after the first interest rate increase in March -- one that seemed to be fully expected by investors -- another one could rock stocks again.
Before the Fed thinks it can hold its fire it will need to see that the economy is growing at a slower pace than it did in the first quarter. While there are some signs of slowing, according to Robert V. DiClemente, the chief domestic economist at Salomon Brothers, there are not enough yet. "It is still a go for May 20," he said of the prospects for a rate increase by the Fed.
Comments last week by a Fed governor, Laurence H. Meyer, appear to bolster the view that a slowdown great enough to keep inflationary pressures in check has not yet occurred, though they came before this week's reports. While the Employment Cost Index was in check during the first quarter, the gross domestic product price deflator, another gauge of inflation, rose 2.3 percent in the first quarter, above the 1.5 percent pace in the last quarter of 1996.
Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company, shares these concerns about the market's current prospects.
He has raised his overall earnings forecast for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index by $1, to $45 a share. But to him that just means that the economy is getting stronger, which will prompt the interest rate increases by the Fed that he predicts will, again, knock the stock market for a loop. And this time, he said, there will be a steeper decline than the 9.8 percent swoon that followed the first Fed rate increase on March 25.
Consequently, he has been selling into this "wonderful rally," last week raising the cash position in his model portfolio to 8 percent from 5 percent and looking forward to raising it again soon. "You should enjoy this and sell into it," he said.
Ms. Cohen, however, is encouraged by the strong earnings reports of the first quarter and the economic news of the last three weeks. There has been good news on several fronts, she said.
Even with this year's rise in the dollar, which is up 9.8 percent against the Japanese yen and 12.2 percent against the German mark, overall earnings have not been reduced significantly.
There are signs, she said, that the economy may have ended the first quarter on a weaker note than it began. And she said, inflation remains restrained.
Price data issued yesterday by the Chicago Purchasing Management Association reinforced that belief and helped the stock market rally after it had fallen on the report of the surprisingly strong economic growth in the first quarter. Ms. Cohen also said that interviews with companies have shown that the rise in labor costs was not yet putting pressure on prices.
But because not all of the major sectors of the economy have reported, she would not say whether she was lifting her earnings forecast for the whole year, which was for an increase of 10 percent. She has said that the Dow will rise by about as much as earnings, or to around 7,050, a point it first hit in February.
"The last three weeks have followed a pattern I would like to see," she said. "But we need to watch forthcoming data closely," especially the April employment report due tomorrow and retail sales later this month.
And, she added, "the Fed will still be meeting May 20" and "we still need investors to be comfortable with 1998."

HEADLINE: Peter Coleman, 77, Governor of American Samoa

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Peter Tali Coleman, a native of American Samoa who was its first popularly elected Governor, from 1978 to 1985, died on Monday in Honolulu. He was 77 and a longtime resident of Pago Pago, the capital of American Samoa.
He had liver cancer, Agence France-Presse reported. 
 Mr. Coleman, a lawyer, was appointed by the Eisenhower Administration as Governor of the unincorporated territory in 1956, and held the office until 1961. After becoming the first popularly elected Governor in 1978, he was re-elected in 1980. He was prevented by the territory's Constitution from running for another term in 1984, but five years later he was again elected Governor, serving to 1993.
He also was the founding chairman of the territory's Republican Party, serving from 1985 to 1988.
American Samoa consists of seven small South Pacific islands, with a total area of 76 square miles, and is 2,300 miles southwest of Hawaii. It is the most southerly of all lands under United States sovereignty, and has been under the jurisdiction of the Interior Department since 1951. Its population was 46,773 in 1990.
Mr. Coleman was born in Pago Pago to William Patrick Coleman and the former Amata Aumua. After serving with the Army in the Pacific in World War II, he received a bachelor's degree in economics from Georgetown University in 1949, and later received a law degree from Georgetown.
Mr. Coleman was a Pacific area analyst at the Interior Department in Washington in 1951 and 1952; a public defender, planning officer and customs officer in American Samoa from 1952 to 1955, and the territory's Attorney General in 1955 and 1956 before being appointed Governor.
From 1961 to 1965 Mr. Coleman was district administrator of the Marshall Islands, part of the United States-administered Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands, and was the Acting High Commissioner of the Trust Territory when he resigned in 1977 to run for governor.
Governors appointed by Washington served in American Samoa until 1977, when a plebiscite in the territory mandated its first election for governor. Mr. Coleman defeated his Democratic opponent, Aifilili P. Lutali, after a campaign centered largely on economic issues.
Mr. Coleman's influence extended well beyond his home islands. A champion of regional cooperation, he was a co-founder, in 1980, of the Pacific Basin Development Council.i In 1980, he and the Governors of two other United States possessions in the Pacific, Guam and the Northern Marianas, joined with Gov. George R. Ariyoshi of Hawaii to draw up a $1.4 billion, five-year economic development plan for their islands.
Among Mr. Coleman's survivors are his wife of 55 years, the former Nora Stewart, and 12 children: William Patrick, Peter Talifiliga, Milton John, Amata, Bruce Joseph, Charles Ulualofaigna, Richard James, Paul Vaelaa, Barrett Francis, Alan David, Sina Ellen and Limonmon Mary.

HEADLINE: Goldman Says It Will Buy Asset Adviser

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
In its latest move to expand and diversify its asset management business, Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Commodities Corporation, a managed futures, currencies and commodities investment firm.
Terms of the purchase were not disclosed, but people familiar with the transaction said that Goldman was paying about $100 million for Commodities, a subsidiary of Stockton Holdings Ltd., a privately held company based in Bermuda. 
 The purchase is the third that Goldman Sachs Asset Management, the firm's global asset management division, has made in less than a year. Last fall, Goldman bought CIN Management, one of the largest managers of British pension funds. And in January it purchased Liberty Investment Management, with $5 billion in its portfolios.
The Commodities Corporation, based in Princeton, N.J., was founded in 1969 by a group of economists and investors, including Paul A. Samuelson, the Nobel laureate. It has about 100 clients and manages a little less than $2 billion in assets. The firm oversees a variety of independent managers investing money in the commodities and currency markets for wealthy clients and institutions.
Many Wall Street firms, seeking steady fee income, have tried to strengthen their asset management businesses by going after firms with strong presences in the stock and bond markets.
But in buying the Commodities Corporation, Goldman, Sachs is sending a different message, executives in the futures business said.
"The real news here is that one of the sharpest firms on Wall Street has just made a fairly public entry into a business that has always been considered tangential," said Burt Kozloff, president of Select Advisers, a Greenwich, Conn., firm that represents four commodity trading advisory firms.
"When I see Goldman going into the managed futures business, it leads me to believe there is promise in this area," Mr. Kozloff said.
The Commodities Corporation has been the training ground for a number of prominent traders, including Paul Tudor Jones and Bruce Kovner, and retains its relationship with them by doling out money for them to manage.
"Commodities Corporation has a number of managers who run money for them and may run money on the outside," John P. McNulty, co-chief executive of Goldman Sachs Asset Management, said. "They don't see them as a threat at all, and maintain very good relationships with those guys."
Goldman, Sachs already has a commodity business, J. Aron & Company. But Mr. McNulty said the Commodities Corporation is not in a complementary business.
"What it does is different from J. Aron, which provides markets to clients as a dealer and also does some trading for its own account," he said.
The Commodities Corporation runs two funds. One invests money for clients in Japan and Europe and the other for American investors.
Over the last decade, the fund for foreign investors has returned an average of more than 20 percent a year, Mr. McNulty said. The return on the other fund has been a few percentage points less.
With the acquisition, Goldman becomes the third Wall Street firm to own and operate a managed fund business. Merrill Lynch & Company and Dean Witter, Discover & Company offer similar services.
Along with these other firms, Goldman will market the funds to institutions and wealthy individuals as a diversification tool as well as a way to reduce overall risk.
To date, that sort of argument has done better with foreign investors than it has in the United States. But use of managed futures is gaining credence with institutional money managers in this country.
The acquisition of the Commodities Corporation, which is subject to approval by various Federal regulators, is expected to close in about three months. When it does, Goldman will have approximately $110 billion in assets under management.
That figure is twice what it was a year ago, but still leaves Goldman, Sachs far short of competitors like Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley Group Inc. in the asset management business.

HEADLINE: Many Stores Found to Sell Cigarettes to Minors

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Last week, a lanky 17-year-old with a silky smooth face, turned-around baseball cap and knapsack visited Liberty International, a convenience store in the Bronx, to buy cigarettes and test a state law that forbids the sale of tobacco to minors.
He had no problems purchasing cigarettes at that store. Or the next store. Or any store, for that matter. 
 "He was like Ken Griffey Jr.; he went 5 for 5, including a cigar," said Jose Maldonado, New York City's Consumer Affairs Commissioner. "I was shocked. These retailers should be ashamed of themselves."
The youth was among eight high school students who helped city inspectors conduct an undercover sweep that led to 15 citations -- including 11 three-time offenders whose tobacco sales licenses may now be revoked.
The sweep, conducted April 22 to 24, was the fourth such raid in the last year as part of the city's "Three Puffs and You're Out" campaign against retailers who sell tobacco to those under 18.
Under state law, tobacco sellers cannot sell to anyone under 18 and must request photo identification from customers who appear younger than 25.
Sellers must also post signs stating that it is illegal to sell tobacco products to minors.
Merchants who violate the law face citations and fines of up to $100 per violation, as determined by the Department of Consumer Affairs and the Health Department.
A second violation carries a penalty of $500. A third violation carries a $1,000 fine and possible one-year suspension of the merchant's tobacco sales license.
Since 1994, the Department of Consumer Affairs has conducted undercover operations that have resulted in 20 revoked licenses and the collection of $196,000 in fines.
In the latest, all but 3 of the 47 stores surveyed were previously cited. Of the 11 stores found in violation a third time, 4 were in Manhattan, 3 in Queens and 2 each in Brooklyn and the Bronx.
There was one encouraging statistic. When the raids began in 1994, more than 60 percent of stores surveyed were found to be violating the law; in the most recent sweep, 30 percent were violators.
"The key here is not to destroy a business or a business's economic well-being," Mr. Maldonado said. "The key is to send a strong and unequivocal message that you can't profit at the expense of a young person's life."

HEADLINE: Media More Likely to Show Women Talking About Romance Than at a Job, Study Says

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
Across a broad range of media, in films, in television, including commercials, and in magazines for teen-agers, women are more likely to be shown preoccupied with romance and personal appearance than they are having jobs or going to school, according to a new study released today by Children Now, a children's advocacy group based in Oakland, Calif.
The study, conducted by Dr. Nancy Signorelli of the University of Delaware, for Children Now and the Kaiser Family Foundation, also showed that despite the fact that women make up a majority of the population, most characters -- 63 percent in movies and 55 percent in television -- were men. In music videos, 78 percent of performers were men. 
 But the study did find that women in television shows, and especially in movies, were portrayed as "using intelligence."
"Television clearly makes an impression on kids today, whether it's what they think they should look like or the qualities they associate with men and women," Matt James, senior vice president of the Kaiser Family Foundation, said in a statement accompanying the study. "The media is a powerful tool that can either reinforce negative stereotypes or present strong role models."
The study was released in conjunction with a conference in Los Angeles on Children and the Media. It is believed to be the first to look at representations of women across a spectrum of media.
"What we are seeing is a constant, cumulative, omnipresent picture," said Lois Salisbury, president of Children Now. "And it's hard to get away from. A girl could mute the ads on her television set, but still get it on the program. She could turn off her television, but she's going to get it at the movies. She could decide just to read, but she would have to boycott most popular magazines for girls."
The study was conducted in fall 1996 and reviewed 23 top-rated television shows, 15 movies, three weeks of top 20 music videos and 4 issues of leading magazines for teen-age girls: YM, Sassy, Teen and Seventeen.
On television, the study found, 41 percent of men were shown working, as opposed to 28 percent of women. In movies, the difference was more striking, with 60 percent of men and 35 percent of women shown working.
In both television and films, women were more likely than men to talk about romantic relationships.
In magazines for teen-agers, 35 percent of articles were about dating, while only 12 percent discussed school or careers, and 7 percent discussed sex, including sexually transmitted diseases and unplanned pregnancy. Only 3 percent of articles focused on drugs and smoking.
In movies, women were more likely than men to have their looks commented upon, and in all media, women were more likely than men to be perceived as thin or very thin.
In a national survey conducted by Lake Sosin Snell & Associates that accompanied the study, 400 boys and 400 girls, ages 10 to 17, were asked whom they most admired on television. The top 10 selections for boys were all men, including Michael Jordan, Tim Allen and Bart Simpson. But 8 out of the top 10 girls' choices were also men, including Will Smith, Martin Lawrence and Jonathan Taylor Thomas. The girls also named Oprah Winfrey and Rosie O'Donnell.
Still, the pollsters found it good news that women in film and television were shown as intelligent and as problem-solvers. In movies, 69 percent of women were shown using their intelligence, and in television, 34 percent. Self-reliance was stressed in 35 percent of female characters on television and in movies, and in 28 percent in magazines for teen-agers.
"We were looking at whether characters thought things through quickly," said Nancy Signorelli, who helped design the study, "whether they were proud of what they did know, and were not playing dumb."
Ms. Salisbury cited Grace in ABC's "Grace Under Fire," as an example of an intelligent, self-reliant character.
"She is a single, working-class mom raising a couple of kids," Ms. Salisbury said. "The show constantly shows her struggling with boyfriends and economic problems, and solving them."
Dr. Jane Brown, a professor of Journalism and Mass Communications at the University of Carolina, who has studied how girls use media to define themselves, said of the study: "Girls are looking for role models who are powerful, in control of their lives and have some purpose. Now there are more powerful women in the media -- Roseanne on television, for instance. But girls are still looking for role models, and they're hard to find."
"We are where we have always been," Ms. Brown continued. "We are finding the same preoccupations among girls, with being attractive enough to lure a male. Women are seen primarily as sex objects. That is what we were concerned with 20 years ago."

HEADLINE: Blair or Major? Britain Is Choosing Today

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 30

 BODY:
Britain's election campaign came to an end tonight with the refashioned Labor Party of its young leader, Tony Blair, maintaining its substantial lead in the polls and threatening a rout of the long-dominant Conservative Party showing the wear of 18 years in office.
While the possible change of administration from Conservative to the newly centrist Labor Party would not mean a radical change in the way Britain is run, a victory of the proportions being predicted would significantly shift the country's political landscape. 
 The Labor Party approaches election day unified, full of fresh energy and disposed to take center stage, while the Tories are divided, depleted and facing a bruising and distracting struggle for leadership of the party if they lose.
"I understand why some people may find the argument for change attractive," Prime Minister John Major, 54, said at a news conference at party headquarters today. "Eighteen years is a long time," he said, sensing the obstacle he has been unable to overcome in the six weeks of electioneering. "The electorate knows us warts and all."
Six weeks is also a long time for a British election campaign -- the last one of that duration was in 1918 -- and Mr. Major had scheduled it that way in the hopes that with enough time the public would start to credit his Government with the country's economic recovery and return the Conservatives for a fifth term.
Everyone with an opinion at the outset thought the tactic would surely reduce Labor's lead, if not overcome it, but the numbers never budged and Mr. Major's opponents put the extra time to their own use, convincing the voters worried about Labor's convulsive past that responsible "New Labor," as Mr. Blair calls it, was here to stay.
Under Mr. Blair, 43, the Labor Party has been profoundly transformed, abandoning its trade union, statist past and becoming a champion of entrepreneurship and individual enterprise. The goal of the project has always been to make Labor, a party that has never succeeded in holding office for more than one term, into an acceptable mainstream alternative to the Conservatives, who have governed Britain for 35 of the last 50 years.
Mr. Blair has visibly gained confidence and stature in the last six weeks, and Mr. Major has seen his leadership undermined by members of Parliament caught in sexual and petty corruption episodes and candidates defying his "wait and see" position on Britain's ties to Europe.
Meanwhile Labor was running a campaign using American promotional and organization techniques crafted to be disciplined, non-provocative and low-risk. Labor some time ago ceased to be the party of cloth caps, beer and sausages, and, as the campaign wore on, even its signature red color became soothing purple.
As strait-laced as their candidate, campaign workers made pledges of abstinence for the duration of the campaign, and the strategy manual preached "remind, reassure and reward," with uppercase first letters. It was recited by campaign aides with no evident self-consciousness.
Today Mr. Major expressed his frustration with the stylized campaign's apparent success, saying voters should not fall for "the false attraction of a well-packaged marketing scam." He also said that the prosperity under the Tories was "too good to give up" and that "one cross in the wrong place on the ballot paper tomorrow could wreck everything we have achieved together."
Mr. Blair ended his campaign the way he began it, with a visit to a school, in keeping with his handlers' eagerness to stress his commitment to improving education. Then he went to his constituency of Sedgefield in Northern England, where he said at his political club that the country now had "24 hours to build that great, decent British society."
In the last election, five years ago, the Tories ground down Neil Kinnock, then the Labor candidate, with well-timed charges about the party's unstated plans to raise taxes and succeeded in the final days in frightening voters away from Labor.
This year Labor cut off that line of assault by first attacking Mr. Major for having raised taxes himself during his term in office and then pledging that Labor would stay within Tory spending limits for the next two years and not raise income taxes for the next five.
But perhaps the most effective turn of the tables occurred over the issue of pensions. Earlier this year the Conservatives presented a daring plan to start shifting the growing costs of pensions from the state into private accounts for young people. Existing pensioners were specifically exempted from the proposal.
Labor, caught unequipped with any credible approach to the problem of how to finance pensions, turned it to their political advantage. They asserted, with scant evidence, that the Tories were posing a threat to everyone's pension. In a country with as many people living on pensions as Britain, that is an incendiary charge, and the Tories found themselves on the defensive with Mr. Blair posturing as the protector of the aged.
The Tories reacted with fury, and Mr. Major was reduced to accusing Mr. Blair of telling "damnable, scurrilous, bald-faced lies." It was a replay of 1992, with Labor suddenly commanding the political high ground and Tories on the run.
In aping many of the Conservative positions on cherished initiatives of theirs like privatization of utilities, Labor has succeeded in stealing the Tories' most defensible campaign argument, stewardship of Britain's finances.
"It's all about image in terms of the ability to manage the economy effectively," said David Sanders, professor of politics at Essex University. "The reason the Conservatives are in so much trouble is that they have lost that reputation, while Labor have managed to present themselves as a plausible set of economic managers."
One indication of the calm with which a Labor victory is being anticipated is evident at the London stock market. Five years ago a possible Kinnock victory took average prices down 17 percent. This year, with Labor far in the lead the whole campaign, stocks rose 9 percent.
Today the bookmakers William Hill refused to accept any further bets on the election because of what it said was the certainty of a Labor victory. The last time the company closed its books on an election was in 1979, when Margaret Thatcher began the longest unbroken stretch of one-party rule in Britain this century.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Graphs/Photos: "AT A GLANCE: Britain's Day of Decision"
 
The Players and Their Parties
 
The Conservative Party has been in power since 1979, and John Major, 54, has been Prime Minister since he succeeded Margaret Thatcher in 1990. Once unified and formidable at election time, the Tories now suffer from deep divisions over Britain's relationship with Europe and face a leadership struggle if they lose today.
 
Founded by trade unions at the turn of the century, the Labor Party long believed in big government, nationalization of industry, and taxation to redistribute wealth. But under Tony Blair, 43, and his two predecessors Neil Kinnock, leader in the 1992 election, and John Smith, who died in 1994, Labor has become a centrist party that endorses free markets, entrepreneurship and privatizing utilities.
 
The Liberal Democratic Party is the third party in Britain, successor to the various alliances and parties like the Liberal Party and the Social Democratic Party that have tried to occupy the middle ground between Labor and Conservative. Its leader since 1988 has been Paddy Ashdown, 56. It is the only party to propose a tax increase of 1 percent, for education, and is the most open to Britain's further integration in Europe.

HEADLINE: Russia Is True to West, in Its Fashion

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 30

 BODY:
When President Boris N. Yeltsin wants to play the nationalist card he simply rolls out the red carpet for the United States' most vexing rivals and bitter adversaries.
In recent weeks, Russia has ostentatiously turned toward the East, inviting officials from China, India and Iran. Mr. Yeltsin has posed for the cameras hugging the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, and Russian officials have boasted of fashioning a "multipolar world" in which the United States would no longer be the dominant player. 
 The Kremlin's aim is, in part, to tweak the United States, which many in the Russian foreign policy establishment resent for promoting the expansion of the NATO alliance and winning the cold war.
But for all the symbolism, Russia's talk of a new strategic partnership with the East is more theater than substance. Even when they are not awaiting the American Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright, who arrives here on Thursday, Russia looks mostly to the West and the West's financial institutions, like the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, for money, technology and acceptance.
That was underscored this week when Anatoly B. Chubais, Russia's First Deputy Prime Minister and a leading reformer, flew to Washington to seek the I.M.F.'s blessing -- and financing -- for Russian economic reforms.
And despite its vocal opposition to NATO expansion, Moscow is still seeking an accommodation with the Western alliance. The focus of Ms. Albright's visit will be a proposed NATO-Russian charter.
Though substantial differences remain, Moscow's calculation appears to be that NATO's expansion is inevitable and that the charter should be concluded and used to play up Russia's importance in world politics.
It was Mr. Yeltsin, not Western leaders, who urged that the charter be concluded and signed by Russian and NATO nations on May 27, well in advance of the July meeting of NATO nations when the alliance plans to invite East European nations that were once part of the old Soviet-led Warsaw Pact to begin the process of becoming members.
To be sure, the Yeltsin Government has several motivations in turning to the East. Politically, it enables Mr. Yeltsin to play to nationalist sentiments at at home.
Yevgeny Primakov, the former Russian intelligence chief and Middle East specialist who was appointed Foreign Minister before last year's presidential election, abandoned the pro-Western tone of his predecessor Andrei V. Kozyrev. Addressing nostalgia for the days of Soviet power, Mr. Primakov emphasized Russia's relations with other former Soviet republics as well as Asian and Middle Eastern states.
Economics is a factor as well. China is a growing market for Russian arms.
India is also an arms customer and a potential buyer for Russian nuclear technology. The United States has urged Russia to drop its plans to sell two nuclear reactors to India, arguing that it breaches a 1992 agreement among nuclear suppliers. But Russia has defiantly insisted that it will proceed with the multibillion dollar sale.
Iran, which is treated as a pariah by Washington, is also a market for Russian weapons and civilian nuclear technology.
To bolster its beleaguered nuclear establishment, Russian has agreed to sell Iran a nuclear power plant despite Western warnings that the project will help Teheran's program to develop nuclear weapons. Russia, however, has been careful not to completely defy Washington. It has promised to turn off the arms spigot with Iran once existing contracts for conventional weapons are filled.
Iraq is attractive to Russia because it has oil, which Russian companies want to help develop. Iraq also has substantial debts to Moscow, which will not be repaid unless international sanctions against Baghdad are lifted.
Russia's turn toward the East reflects more general foreign policy considerations, as well. Russia no longer has the global role the Soviet Union played, but it remains a regional power and the contacts with Asia enable Moscow to maintain a measure of influence abroad.
But while playing the Asian card may feel good, it is not a strong hand. Russia's need for economic investment, for technology, for inclusion in Western institutions is deeper than the gains in may receive from feting Chinese or Iranian leaders.
Nor does the overture to the East strike a powerful chord among much of the Russian public, which craves Western goods and which remains deeply skeptical of Islamic states like Iran and of the Chinese.
More important, as concerned as American officials are with Russian arms sales to China and Iran, few in the West take Moscow's tactic of turning to the East too seriously.
"At various points, Soviet and Russian foreign policy have turned to the East," observed a senior Western diplomat. "But these are relatively short-term phenomena. Russia realizes that its key interests require it to stay engaged with the West."

HEADLINE: Clinton and Gingrich View Hong Kong as Test for China

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
President Clinton pronounced himself "quite satisfied" with the assurances on the future of Hong Kong he received today from the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, but said he was waiting to see if China's words matched its actions.
The House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, warned today that China's favorable trading status depends upon how Beijing handles the British colony's transition to Chinese rule. 
 Clinton Administration officials have said repeatedly that they regard the way China handles its reassertion of sovereignty over Hong Kong on July 1 as an "important benchmark" for the larger United States-China relationship.
But for a widening coalition in Congress, in an atmosphere where China is viewed as a rising rival to American power, the transition is seen as a litmus test for the entire relationship with Beijing and a way to hold Mr. Clinton's feet to the fire.
Mr. Qian spent the last three days here meeting Administration officials and Congressional leaders with two purposes, American and Chinese officials said: to prepare for the state visit this autumn of the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, and to reassure the Americans about Beijing's commitment to preserve the autonomy and free market of Hong Kong.
Mr. Qian met President Clinton for 40 minutes today, discussing issues ranging from Hong Kong to China's growing trade surplus with the United States, now nearing $40 billion by some accounts. White House officials said that Mr. Clinton made an "especially strong presentation" to Mr. Qian on "the need to redress and reduce any barriers to freer trade."
Better market access is the American requirement for China to join the World Trade Organization, and Mr. Clinton told Mr. Qian that "were the Chinese in a position to make a bold proposal, we'd be in a position to make a bold response," a White House official said. He said the United States still hoped that agreement could be reached with China this year on the terms of its membership in the organization.
On Tuesday, Mr. Qian said that under China's rule "the democracy, freedoms and human rights enjoyed by the Hong Kong people will be more extensive" than under British colonial rule, which introduced more freedoms only in the last few years. He promised that Hong Kong would have autonomy "unmatched in the world" and would be governed solely by local officials approved by Beijing.
Asked about Mr. Qian's assurances today, Mr. Clinton said: "We had a good discussion about Hong Kong, and he assured me that China intended to observe the terms of the agreement of 1984 that they made with Great Britain and that the United States supported back then. I was quite satisfied with what he said. And I certainly hope that it will reflect Chinese policy."
Mr. Gingrich, in a speech today, was able to be more direct, given his position as Speaker of a Republican-dominated House and his own recent trip to China and Hong Kong. If Beijing did not live up to its commitments to preserve democracy, human rights and a market economy in Hong Kong, he said, "there would be serious long-term damage to our relations" and China's relations with the rest of the world. On the other hand, he said, "if Beijing handles the transition well, it will substantially brighten its future relations with the United States."
Speaking at the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Mr. Gingrich said explicitly that he supports legislation to renew China's most-favored-nation trading status for only three to six months. That would allow Congress to monitor the transition in Hong Kong and debate renewal again in September or December.
Under current legislation, the President must certify annually that China deserves to retain its low-tariff trading status with the United States. Congress then has 60 days to pass a law overturning his certification and then to override his veto, should that be necessary.
Despite the furor over China, if all goes well with Hong Kong Administration officials do not believe Mr. Clinton will need to use the veto this year. Mr. Clinton's spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, indicated skepticism today that Mr. Gingrich's proposal to shorten the renewal would pass. Asked to comment, he said: "We'll just see if it goes anywhere."
Mr. Qian has publicly denied allegations, attributed to unnamed officials at the F.B.I., that officials at the Chinese Embassy in Washington talked among themselves about giving money illegally to influence the American election campaign. Mr. McCurry confirmed that the F.B.I. Director, Louis Freeh, briefed Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, about the bureau's inquiry on Monday, after the White House discovered that the bureau had first briefed legislators.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1215 words

HEADLINE: Audits Indicate Misuse of Funds By Aid Agency In Harlem

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
Over its 23-year history, the Harlem Urban Development Corporation received almost $100 million in state funds to help rebuild Harlem. Millions of dollars were spent on lawyers, hundreds of thousands went for telephone calls around the world and perks like cellular phones and cars, and hundreds of thousands more are still unaccounted for.
And when the agency was dissolved two years ago, state officials say, it had not produced a single major commercial project. 
 Internal audits released yesterday by the Pataki administration portray an agency with few controls, where state money sloshed freely with little regard for contracting procedures or documentation. One lawyer who had a contract for $28,750 wound up being paid $171,591. Some employees were classified as "consultants" by the corporation, which failed to withhold as much as $1.5 million in state and Federal taxes from their paychecks.
The revelations of the inner workings of the development corporation, which for a generation was the prime hope for re-development in Harlem, has prompted a criminal investigation, an official in the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday. The State Commission of Investigation is also examining the agency's activities.
The Harlem agency has been the target of periodic criticism over the years, but yesterday's report was by far the most comprehensive and most damning portrayal of its efforts. And while the audit did not single out individuals for criticism, it was likely to come as a political blow to some prominent Democratic politicians who were closely identified with the agency, including Representative Charles B. Rangel.
Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said the audits he released showed "mismanagement and a lot of wasted dollars."
Mr. Gargano said signs of trouble were apparent for years in audits that were publicly available. The Pataki administration replaced the development corporation with a new entity, the Harlem Community Development Corporation, that is monitored directly by the Empire State agency.
But some former members of the development corporation's board contended that the audits were politically motivated. "I have no idea what the findings are based on," said Mr. Rangel, who was a major force in the organization during its entire life. "You have a bunch of Republicans going through the files of a defunct organization run by Democrats."
Mr. Rangel said he pushed for the release of the audit after some details appeared in the press earlier this year. "If someone abused public funds," he said, "I think they ought to be brought in and investigated."
He said he had no day-to-day involvement in the corporation. "I don't read any audits," he said. "I just bring the money home and assume we can get good people to do something. If that wasn't done, I don't want to hear about it 23 years later."
Donald J. Cogsville, who was the president and chief executive officer of the corporation, declined to comment, saying he has not received copies of the material released by state officials.
Among the 33-member board were many prominent politicians who were ex officio members, including the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, and H. Carl McCall, now the State Comptroller, who was a State Senator.
Leland Jones, Ms. Messinger's spokesman, said that she had sent representatives to the meetings and that there were no indications of the allegations of widespread mismanagement in the materials released yesterday.
But City Councilman Adam Clayton Powell Jr. said the problems were clear to him during his three years on the board. Mr. Powell, a political opponent of Mr. Rangel, whom he called "the 500-pound gorilla over H.U.D.C.," said, "Too much money was spent, and there was not enough to show for it."
State officials said the Harlem development corporation operated independent of the major state development entity, now the Empire State corporation, receiving its money directly from the State Legislature and subject to little review.
William J. Stern, who headed the state development corporation under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, said the Harlem agency operated independently because "it was considered a kind of political turf for the Harlem pols -- it was their thing, so to speak." He said politics, not development strategy, gave the Harlem corporation its independent power. "They gave people jobs," Mr. Stern said. "I think it was a pork-barrel operation. I said so at the time. I didn't see any economic development."
The audits released yesterday by the Empire State corporation harshly criticized a wide swath of the Harlem corporation's operations.
The reports said the corporation "repeatedly and exclusively gave noncompetitive contracts to a limited group of vendors, consultants and contractors." Then, the memo said, it managed the contracts poorly.
For example, in 1995 the corporation paid J & L Enterprises $485,000 for expenses related to managing a city parking garage that had been built by the corporation. But state officials charge that between $150,000 and $200,000 represented either services that were never delivered or overcharging for services. Among the expenses described as unnecessary were $1,775 in legal fees and approximately $2,000 a year in telephone bills.
In addition, a 1990 city audit of the garage operations determined there were hundreds of thousands of dollars missing or misappropriated. And the city, in a lawsuit filed last year, claims the Harlem corporation failed to pay the city $2.8 million in rent.
Although the parking garage, on 125th Street, is one of the corporation's development successes, it also represents its unfulfilled promises. The garage was supposed to be the foundation of the Harlem International Trade Center, which was never built. While the agency did provide funds for the renovation of housing in Harlem, help lure small businesses to the area and aid in the renovation of the Appollo Theater, it was not seen as having been a force for large, wholesale rehabilitation.
Indeed, state officials said, the corporation spent three times as much on personnel, overhead and consultants as it did on its capital budget. One lawyer, Jeff Greenup, was hired on a contract to perform legal services for the corporation in addition to serving as counsel to the corporation's board, "an apparent conflict of interest," the state memorandum said. The corporation's auditors, Mitchell & Titus, entered into a contract "not to exceed $78,000" in 1995, but wound up billing $237,000 for that year. Another company was hired to perform data entry work, and one person was paid $90 an hour, including travel time from Connecticut.
Even the corporation's office and petty cash fund did not escape the auditors' scrutiny. About $22,000 was spent for a staff retreat at the Concord Resort Hotel in October 1994. Another $1,650 was spent for waxing and washing the corporation president's car.
After the election of Mr. Pataki, the board hired a lobbying firm for $44,000 to help negotiate the changing political waters. But the new Governor dissolved the agency and the lobby contract became another expense that state officials said was unjustified.

HEADLINE: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;
Sonics Sputtering Again In Round 1

BYLINE: By TOM FRIEND 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, April 30

 BODY:
The 3-point line may be the ruin of him either that, or Shawn Kemp's clock radio -- but, then again, George Karl has struck this sorry pose before. His Seattle SuperSonics have again saved their worst for the first round, and four crises in four years confirms there is a hole in their infrastructure.
Karl has a four-guard offense to solve, not to mention the erosion of a certain power forward, and he has 24 hours to do so. Last June, his team was trapping Michael Jordan into oblivion, but now the Sonics' coach is afraid to trap Kevin Johnson or Jason Kidd, for fear of an early summer. The seventh-seeded Phoenix Suns lead this three-of-five-game series, 2-1, and Karl is resorting his lineup, snipping at the referees and dialing his agent. 
 "I'll put it in my contract that I don't coach the first round," he said today on the eve of Thursday's crucial Game 4.
The Sonics own the Pacific Division title, won 57 games, have averaged 55 victories over the past five seasons and are about to go out in the first round for the third time in four years. They may have pushed the Bulls to six games in last season's league finals, but that was only a month after they lost a first-round home game to Sacramento, recovered to win the series in four and then celebrated with Dom Perignon.
This time, there may be no escape. It is either Kemp's fault for sleeping through meetings and practices, or center Jim McIlvaine's fault for not living up to his $33.6 million contract, or guard Nate McMillan's fault for tweaking his knee, or center Sam Perkins's fault for averaging 4 points in this series, or guard Gary Payton's fault for not erasing Phoenix's soon-to-be-retired Johnson.
It is either Suns Coach Danny Ainge's fault for designing the offense of the 21st century or Rex Chapman's and Wesley Person's fault for draining about every 3-point shot in sight, but the best moment for Seattle in this odd series was Kemp falling on Johnson's left ankle late in Tuesday's night's Game 3.
Johnson -- who Karl complains gets every referee's call when he drives to the basket -- sprained the ankle, spent today at an acupuncturist and will decide at game time on Thursday whether he can play.
"If I were in Vegas, I'd bet he'd play," Karl said. "Anyone want to put any money on it?"
Phoenix's other calamity Tuesday night was forward Cedric Ceballos's courtside collapse. He spent the night in a local hospital, was ruled to be dehydrated and was expected to play -- again not to Karl's surprise.
In fact, other than Game 2's mirage of a 44-point Sonic victory, Karl has spent this series in a self-professed purgatory. His contract runs one more season -- at which time he will probably retire and wait for Dean Smith to quit the University of North Carolina -- and it appears no one will beg him to stay.
He has complained openly that players are celebrities now and that the game is entertainment now, and that even one of his "best, hardest-working guys" knows the shoe deal of every player in the league. The game has changed, economically and esthetically, and he can barely tolerate it.
For instance, the Suns have a four-guard offense that is foreign to every team in the league. "In the East, they walk it up, throw it in the post and play inside out," Ainge said today. "We play outside out."
The 3-point line is apparently too close for Phoenix to pass up. Chapman made nine 3-pointers to win Game 1, Person made six to win Game 3, and Ainge admitted today: "That 3-point line is not there for decoration. So, we've got to use it."
Seattle, meanwhile, is too big to chase Phoenix's whippets and has fallen into the dangerous trap of taking too many 3's itself. Kemp had only one fourth-quarter field goal in each of the Sonics' losses, and he is the one who was supposed to seize Jordan's throne this season.
Instead, Kemp missed three weeks of training camp to protest McIlvaine's contract, and he has suffered from what some team officials describe as depression. He has missed flights, meetings and practices, and has done nothing to change the Sonics' image as a troop of loose cannons.
Payton, who scored 34 points in Game 3, is, incredibly, their most reliable player, and this is the same extrovert who nearly fought former teammate Ricky Pierce during another first-round loss, to Denver, in 1994. Karl, it turns out, has been more baby sitter than coach the last four years, and appears ready to turn in his pacifier.
"We're fine," the Sonics' president, Wally Walker, said. "Of course, if we lose the series, we're not fine."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Growth Soars to 5.6% Rate With Inflation Modest
Powered largely by free-spending consumers, the economy grew at a 5.6 percent annual rate during the first quarter. It was the biggest advance in nearly a decade and came in well ahead of forecasts.
The Clinton Administration claimed credit for the continued robust growth, which has been accompanied by modest inflation, but acknowledged that it was surprised by the strength of the results. [Page B12.] 

Administration officials predicted that the surge would help drive down this year's Federal budget deficit to the lowest level in more than 20 years. [A1.]
 
Stocks Extend Their Rally
Stocks continued to rally, as strong corporate profits apparently outweighed in traders' minds any inflationary implications of the report on economic growth. The Dow industrials roared back above 7,000; since April 11, they have gained 9.7 percent, reversing the biggest downturn in more than six years. Other indexes also rose, with broad measures strongly positive. [D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities rose, with the yield on the 30-year bond falling to 6.95 percent, from 6.98 percent on Tuesday. [D18.]
 
Keyboard Verdict Is Overturned
A judge threw out a $5.3 million verdict against Digital Equipment, setting back plaintiffs who seek damages from computer keyboard makers for injuries to users. The judge said new evidence suggested that the crippling wrist injury suffered by an executive secretary was most likely caused by a muscular condition in her neck. [D4.]
 
Goldman, Sachs to Buy Firm
Goldman, Sachs agreed to acquire the Commodities Corporation, a managed futures, currencies and commodities investment firm, reportedly for about $100 million. [D4.]
 
$460 Million Deal for Insurer
The insurer Conseco, continuing a string of acquisitions that helped its earnings more than double in the first quarter, agreed to buy a unit of Leucadia National for $460 million. [D5.]
 
U.S. Investigates Cellular Bidding
The Justice Department is investigating accusations that bidders for cellular telephone licenses may have illegally manipulated recent auctions. [D2.]
 
Black Employees Sue U.P.S.
Sixteen black employees filed a discrimination suit against United Parcel Service, saying they had been angered by racist graffiti and blocked promotion paths. [D4.]
 
Teledesic's Task Is Daunting
Teledesic, despite awarding Boeing a $9 billion contract for 250 satellites, faces years of challenges to its ambitious plan to establish an "Internet in the sky" to deliver high-speed voice and data communications globally. [D4.]
 
Saatchi's New Ads for Delta
Saatchi & Saatchi introduced its campaign to promote Delta Air Lines' new trans-Atlantic business class -- in effect, a polished version of the pitch Saatchi used recently to win the overall Delta account. The ads feature a recurring image of a lone passenger inside a minimally appointed fuselage made to look like a private room. Advertising. [D7.]
 
An Agreement on Meat Trade
American and European negotiators reached an agreement on meat inspection standards, but were unable to resolve their differences over the handling of poultry. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Now Pursue Big Alcohol Just Like Big Tobacco;
The Price Factor

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Colleen J. G. Clark (letter, April 28) says she is unaware of valid data demonstrating that higher cigarette taxes lead to less smoking. Our research demonstrates that there is a strong negative relationship, particularly among teen-agers. 
 A 1981 National Bureau of Economic Research study by Michael Grossman, Eugene M. Lewit and Douglas Coate found that a 10 percent increase in the price of cigarettes reduces the number of youth smokers by 12 percent. Our 1996 research suggests that a 10 percent increase in price would reduce the number of teen-agers who smoke by 7 percent and would reduce the daily number of cigarettes consumed by teen-agers by 6 percent.
Our study implies that if the proposed 43-cent increase in cigarette taxes were enacted, the number of teen-age smokers would fall by 16 percent.
 
MICHAEL GROSSMAN
FRANK J. CHALOUPKA
New York, April 29, 1997
 
The writers are, respectively, a professor of economics at CUNY Graduate School and an associate professor of economics, U. of Illinois.

HEADLINE: Mayor Expects Record Surplus For Fiscal Year

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that New York City would finish its fiscal year with $800 million more than his budget experts predicted less than a year ago.
The surplus -- largely the result of soaring profits on Wall Street -- gives the Mayor another chance to propose new spending plans and cuts in taxes when he presents his election-year budget next week. He said he wanted to devote some of the surplus to new spending on education and law enforcement, two areas that voters are likely to scrutinize during the mayoral campaign. 
 In general, the Mayor said, he would allocate the extra money by following a formula that he first discussed in January, dividing it up roughly evenly between what he described as "three pots": new spending, tax cuts and actions to reduce future budget deficits.
"What we are going to do with this is be very disciplined about it," he said of his plans for the surplus, the highest in the city's history.
The Mayor's announcement of the surplus in his $34 billion budget immediately drew attacks from the Democratic mayoral candidates, who contended that he had engaged in a cynical strategy of salting away money that he was now channeling toward politically popular programs and tax reductions. The candidates said no amount of new spending could wipe away the impact of the budget cuts that had been made by Mr. Giuliani earlier in his term.
And even as the city's current fiscal picture has brightened, the outlook for the next few years is more discouraging. City Hall anticipates a deficit of $1.4 billion in the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1. The surplus in the current fiscal year will help reduce that deficit, but city budget officials predict that the gap will still be more than $1 billion in the coming fiscal year because the Mayor plans to use some of the $800 million surplus for spending and to replace revenue lost to tax cuts.
Administration officials said, therefore, that in the budget that Mr. Giuliani is to announce next week, he will order at least $750 million in cuts at city agencies to try to close the impending deficit.
For now, though, the unexpected surge in revenues is allowing the Mayor to direct extra money to new programs and proposed tax cuts -- initiatives that he often announces with fanfare at campaign-style events. He has, for example, been barnstorming from school to school in recent months to promote his new reading initiatives, which he is financing in part from some of the extra revenues.
And this week, he has been publicizing plans to eliminate the fare for passengers on the Staten Island ferry and to stop requiring riders to pay an additional fare to transfer between buses and subways. The city is coordinating both initiatives with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
The new revenue, in other words, is providing the Mayor with a respite from the gloomy days earlier in his term when his budgets made history not because of their surpluses but because they had some of the steepest cuts in programs in decades.
The size of the surplus for the current fiscal year has more than doubled since January, when the Mayor projected that it would be $391 million. By law, the Mayor presents his preliminary budget in January, which he revises before issuing his executive, or final, budget in May. The executive budget then requires approval by the City Council.
The surplus for the current fiscal year, which ends on June 30, is the largest in the city's history in dollar terms, officials said, and among the largest when measured as a percentage of city spending.
The size of a budget surplus is sometimes related to growth in the economy, but it can also be manipulated. Officials can deliberately underestimate their projections of tax revenues when they are shaping the city budget early in the year, so that the actual amount of money that comes in will seem larger than expected. Hence -- a surplus.
That practice is not uncommon in mayoral election years, according to budget experts. But Giuliani administration officials denied indulging in such maneuvering, saying the additional revenues had genuinely surprised them. City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, a Democrat who has often clashed with the Mayor, said yesterday that he agreed with the administration.
"No one predicted the boom on Wall Street," Mr. Hevesi said. "There is no evidence that the Mayor was lowballing last year's numbers in order to create a political boon with the numbers this year."
The Democratic mayoral candidates were skeptical, saying hefty cuts in previous years helped free up the new money.
"This election-year surplus is generated at the expense and on the backs of working New Yorkers," said Clint Roswell, a spokesman for Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President who is running for mayor. "It's very clear that this was a four-year political calculation."
Responding to the announcement of the surplus, the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said he supported the Mayor's plan for more education spending, and he championed the Council's proposals for tax cuts, which are in part intended to help small businesses in several emerging industries, including high technology. "The challenge we face is how to invest these resources to best prepare the city for continued economic growth," he said.
When the Mayor announced in January that the city would have a surplus of $391 million -- an estimate that has now jumped to the $800 million -- some independent budget eperts complained that he was not devoting enough of that money to deal with the city's long-term budget problems.
They said he was planning to spend too much of the surplus on new programs and to make up for lost reveneus from tax cuts.
Asked about the budget experts' assertions, the Mayor said, "They will criticize it, and for the good of the people of the city, I will ignore it, because if I paid attention to it, we wouldn't be in such good shape."

HEADLINE: Debt Relief for Model Countries

 BODY:
The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund recently agreed for the first time to write off some loans to one of its borrowers, Uganda. Uganda is special because of a decadelong policy of pro-growth economic reform. But the importance of the decision goes well beyond a single African country. It means that the bank and the fund have at last put into effect a policy to reward poor, highly indebted countries that are serious about reforming their economies.
Impoverished, indebted countries, especially those in sub-Saharan Africa, cannot escape poverty under the weight of their external debt payments. Oxfam International, an advocacy group that lobbies hard for debt relief, estimates that 20 percent of government revenues in these countries goes to debt payments. Mozambique -- where 25 percent of children die before the age of 5 from infectious diseases -- spends twice as much paying off its debt as it does on health and education. Ethiopia spends four times more on debt payments than it does on health care. 
 Unconditional debt relief, which would reward irresponsible economic policies, is not the answer. The United States and some of its allies pushed for debt relief for countries that undertook pro-market reform, including prudent budget, monetary and trade policies. Last fall the bank and the fund agreed. They promised to write off enough of their own loans to eligible countries so that debt payments would be brought down to affordable levels. The initiative assumed that creditor governments would write off about 80 percent of their loans to such countries. But negotiations stalled over instituting the plan.
The deal announced last week broke the logjam. The bank and the fund rewarded Uganda for its exemplary track record by reducing its official debt to near the lowest level -- about twice the value of its exports -- allowed under last year's initiative. Uganda will be required to wait only one year for the debt write-off. Oxfam criticizes even this short wait because Uganda will suffer a needless additional financial drain. The bank agreed to provide Uganda additional money over the next 12 months to ease the pain, but the fund could also chip in to prevent Ugandans from suffering unnecessarily.
The Uganda deal should encourage other poor, highly indebted countries. The initiative anticipates, for example, helping countries that have large budget deficits, so that they would not be forced to impose crippling tax hikes to qualify for debt relief. The Uganda agreement also recognized in principle that countries forced to wait for debt relief will need additional help in the interim. Finally, the bank and the fund promised to move quickly on other eligible countries -- probably Bolivia, Burkina Faso, Guyana, Mozambique and, eventually, up to a dozen others.
Oxfam worries that the World Bank and the monetary fund will impose excessively harsh waiting periods on other debtor countries and provide insufficient interim relief. These are valid concerns, which the bank and the fund can ease by swiftly moving on to other eligible countries and providing packages at least comparable to Uganda's.
