HEADLINE: An Economy Confounding The Experts

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
The stunning 5.6 percent annual rate of growth in the first quarter surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts and confounded assumptions of a few months ago that the economy would slow in the new year.
The gain, which translated into an increase of $96.1 billion in gross domestic product during the quarter alone -- an advance roughly equal to the total output of the Norwegian economy in an entire year -- reflected heavy spending by consumers and businesses alike, partly as a result of warmer-than-usual weather. 
 The gain brings the economy's inflation-adjusted output to an annual rate of $7.09 trillion.
"Consumers have jobs, incomes and confidence," Everett M. Ehrlich, Under Secretary of Commerce, exulted in an effort to explain the increase.
Although the Clinton Administration claimed credit for the robust growth, and continued modest inflation, it acknowledged it had been caught off guard by the new figures.
"Although we had known that retail sales were strong, we were still surprised to see consumption grow at nearly twice its normal pace," said Janet L. Yellen, chief economic adviser to the President.
After initial concerns that the booming economy could fuel inflation and higher interest rates, the securities markets decided yesterday that the report was not particularly worrisome, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose above the 7,000 mark to its highest close in more than a month.
Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities, explained investors' reaction by saying, "The overall bet the markets are making is that this economy will slow to sustainable rates before we do serious damage to the inflation outlook."
Indeed, some early signs of April performance suggest that the economy has now begun to slow. That process may well be spurred by the huge buildup of inventories that accounted for 1.7 percentage points of the first-quarter growth. The size of such inventories implies that production cutbacks lie ahead when consumer demand slackens, as it must, economists said.
The consumer spending binge seemed driven mainly by a 6.4 percent rate of increase in disposable personal income. Shoppers did not need to dip into savings: the savings rate was unchanged, at 5.1 percent.
Analysts said unusually good weather had contributed in some measure to the strong first-quarter growth, in effect inspiring activity that otherwise would not have occurred until spring. Business investment contributed strongly to the growth, rising at an 11.9 percent annual pace, which more than doubled that of the final 1996 period.
Foreign trade, however, was a significant drag on the economy: Americans took advantage of the strong dollar to buy huge amounts of imported goods that otherwise might have been produced here, while the nation's exporters found foreign buyers somewhat less receptive. Trade drag approximately offset the extra growth from inventories.
Today's report, by the Commerce Department, suggested that inflation remained well in check. The price index for gross domestic purchases -- what United States residents pay -- rose at an annual pace of only 2.2 percent in the first quarter, from 2.6 percent at the end of last year.
Analysts were divided about the implications for the Federal Reserve, which in March raised short-term interest rates a quarter of a percentage point. The dominant view seemed to be that one more tightening of monetary policy was likely, probably on May 20, at the next meeting of the Fed's policy-making arm, the Federal Open Market Committee.
The Government's report on the April job market, to be issued on Friday, will be crucial to that decision, the analysts said.

LENGTH: 1321 words

HEADLINE: VIGOROUS ECONOMY EXPECTED TO EASE DEFICIT IN BUDGET

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
The economy grew at its fastest pace in more than nine years during the first quarter, the Government said today, and Administration officials predicted that the spectacular surge would help drive down this year's Federal budget deficit to about $75 billion, its lowest level in more than 20 years.
The good news on this year's deficit came as the White House and Republicans sought to work out the final details of a bipartisan plan to balance the budget by 2002, and is likely to make it easier for negotiators to bridge their remaining differences. After negotiations broke up late tonight, officials said that a deal could be reached as early as Thursday but warned that there were no guarantees because enough divisive issues were still on the table. Faced with considerable unhappiness within their own ranks about the emerging compromise, leaders of both parties mapped strategies for selling any deal to their members. 
 Yet despite such progress, achieved in a series of meetings between negotiators late Tuesday and through today, the prospects for winning Congressional approval were complicated by a bitter dispute between Democrats and Republicans in the Senate. They were fighting over legislation that would provide $5.5 billion in emergency disaster relief to residents of 23 states, including those who lost their homes and businesses to floods in North Dakota and Minnesota in the last few weeks. [Page A15.]
The budget negotiations centered on how much freedom Republicans would have to dictate what kinds of tax cuts any budget would include, with Democrats insisting that the Republicans not be free to enact tax reductions that would primarily benefit the wealthy. There were also continuing discussions about how much the Clinton Administration was willing to give up in spending on domestic programs.
With the outlines of a deal becoming clearer, opposition among liberal Democrats appeared to be growing, with members of both parties estimating that as many as two-thirds of the 207 House Democrats had deep reservations. Republicans also remained concerned about keeping their conservative wing from opposing any deal. "We've made good progress over the last couple of days and we made more today," Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, said tonight. "Everyone is working furiously, but we're not there yet."
In the midst of the partisan maneuvering, today's figures on first-quarter economic growth and on the size of this year's deficit were good news for both sides. The Commerce Department said the economy grew at an annual rate of 5.6 percent during the first three months of the year, its fastest pace since the fourth quarter of 1987 and far above the expectations of economists. [Page A15.]
Despite some concern that the economy might be growing at a rate that would ignite inflation, stock and bond prices both rose, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing at 7008.99, up 46.96 for the day. Analysts said the strength in both the stock and bond markets came in part from hope among investors that a budget deal was near.
The new deficit estimate, calculated by the Treasury Department after tallying April's tax receipts, is far lower than even the most optimistic projections of recent months. It puts the deficit at its lowest dollar level since 1980 and at its lowest point relative to the size of the economy since 1974. It is the clearest evidence yet of how far the nation has come in shoring up its fiscal condition even without a bipartisan agreement to balance the budget.
White House officials declined to comment on the new estimate, which began circulating among Government officials today. But they said they expected the deficit to be substantially lower than they had previously projected, for the fifth year in a row.
If the Treasury's estimate holds up, the deficit for the fiscal year ending on Sept. 30 would be less than 1 percent of the nation's total economic output. The deficit last year was 1.4 percent of economic output. It has not been below 1 percent since 1974, when it was 0.4 percent.
A lower deficit this year would very likely lead to smaller-than-expected deficits in coming years, making the size of the problem facing the budget negotiators somewhat more manageable. In its last official forecast, in January, the Congressional Budget Office predicted a $124 billion deficit for this year, rising to $188 billion in 2002. In February, the Administration projected a $125 billion deficit this year. Last year's deficit was $107 billion, the lowest since 1981.
The lower-than-expected deficit this year would also make it easier for the negotiators to compromise on the economic assumptions they use in predicting future deficits. Over the five-year period covered by the negotiations, the Administration's assumptions are slightly more optimistic than those from the Congressional Budget Office, and a willingness by the Republicans to adopt the White House's figures would go a long way toward closing the gap between the two sides.
Budget analysts said the deficit was falling because of a surprising surge in tax revenues, generated partly by the unexpectedly strong growth of the economy.
So far this year, tax revenues are about $50 billion higher than the Administration had expected. There was a similar unexpected surge last year. Although analysts are not certain of the reason for the shift, they suspect that the economic numbers are being driven by increased taxable earnings among small businesses and a growth in the amount of compensation given to workers in forms that are not subject to regular withholding, including bonuses and stock options.
Officials involved in the budget talks said the parties were $50 billion to $100 billion apart today in eliminating the deficit from a budget expected to total around $2 trillion in 2002.
But the continuing disputes had as much to do with ideology and politics as with numerical differences. After hearing from Administration officials over the last several days that a deal would give them victories in areas like providing health coverage to more uninsured children and restoring welfare benefits to legal immigrants, some Congressional Democrats contended that they could win on those issues without a budget deal -- and do so without giving the Republicans big victories on issues like tax cuts and reducing the growth of Medicare spending.
Democrats were also insisting that any deal include explicit provisions about how any tax cut would be divided. Negotiators have generally agreed on a net tax cut of around $100 billion over five years. Key Republicans like Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, have said the $100 billion figure would be adequate to finance cuts in the capital gains and estate taxes. But they are insisting that the budget deal give them freedom to write this year's tax bills as they see fit.
Democrats want the budget deal to limit any tax cut on capital gains so that it largely benefits homeowners, small-business owners and farmers. Liberal Democrats have long argued that a broad-based capital gains tax cut is a giveaway to the wealthy, who own most of the nation's assets.
The budget deal under discussion would provide around $150 billion for tax cuts over the next five years, offset by as much as $50 billion raised by closing loopholes and extending existing taxes that would otherwise expire. The growth of Medicare spending would be cut by $105 billion to $125 billion. Spending on domestic programs would be reduced by a compromise figure between the $46 billion President Clinton proposed in his budget plan earlier this year and the $118 billion in cuts Republicans have been seeking.
The two sides would also incorporate more optimistic economic assumptions into the plan than Republicans had been willing to accept.

HEADLINE: From the Battery to the Bronx, New York Seeks Corporate Sponsors

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
In an ambitious bid to turn New York City into a brand name, the Giuliani administration has chosen a leading marketing agency to help the city get corporate sponsors for things like playgrounds, snack bars, litter baskets and even police patrol cars, officials said yesterday.
City officials have also asked representatives of Lincoln Center, the American Museum of Natural History, Broadway and other private cultural institutions to consider joining them in seeking sponsorships, which industry experts say could raise tens of millions a year from companies willing to pay to be an "official" product or service of New York City or one of its institutions. 
 "The city of New York in and of itself is an enormously valuable trademark -- maybe one of the most valuable in the world," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday. "The idea of being able to derive revenues from that is, I think, a very creative one and a very good one. Other cities have done it and they have derived substantial revenues for it, and they are not nearly as well known as the city."
Under the plans, a company like Coca-Cola might pay to be the exclusive drink sold at all city-run concession stands, purchase signs on trash cans or underwrite an annual concert in Central Park. An automaker like Ford might pay to call its Crown Victoria model the official patrol car of the New York Police Department.
Other cities have made small forays into an area of marketing tied largely to the sports world. Los Angeles County's beaches have an official suntan lotion and an official bottled water. Buffalo has an official health-maintenance organization and an official paint. And state-run colleges and universities have moved heavily into sponsorships, typically selling exclusive rights to provide drinks on campus to Coke or Pepsi-Cola, or letting Nike or Reebok buy the rights to provide all apparel for athletic teams. But no municipal effort has approached what is contemplated in New York, according to Lesa Ukman, editor of the IEG Sponsorship Report, a trade newsletter. Managed effectively, she said, New York's sponsorship program could approach the fund-raising potential of the Olympic Games, which charges major corporations up to $40 million over four years for the right to use the five-ringed Olympic logo.
City officials, confirming a report of the plan in yesterday's New York Post, said the city wanted only large deals, trying to get at least $1 million from each sponsoring company.
"It's very important that at the end of this process, we'll have a very valuable asset for the city in terms of revenue, of economic development, and for promotional purposes," said David Klasfeld, chief of staff in the Mayor's office of economic development and planning.
A five-year contract being negotiated with the International Management Group, which represents sports stars and other celebrities, would cover at least the Departments of Parks and Recreation, Transportation, Sanitation and General Services, which buys vehicles and other equipment for city agencies. Other agencies like the Board of Education could also sign on, a city official involved in the talks said.
Critics called the city's plan commercialism run amok. "Democratic institutions like cities should be off limits for private corporate sponsorships," said Robert Weissman, a lawyer at Ralph Nader's Center for the Study of Responsive Law. "They shouldn't be auctioned off to the highest commercial bidder. Cities, and what they stand for, are supposed to represent the governed, not just those who can pay to earn city endorsements."
But administration officials said they were sensitive to such criticism. Sponsors will not be offered the right to print the seal of the city on their products; ads in public places will be kept to a minimum, and renaming city streets or buildings for corporate sponsors is out of the question, officials said.
"We're never going to change Central Park to 'Budweiser Park,' " an aide to the Mayor said.

HEADLINE: A Shift to Rigorous Tradition Gains Influence in Judaism

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
To draw a sellout crowd to Madison Square Garden, not for sports or rock music, but to celebrate the reading of a religious text, is no mean feat.
Yet on Sept. 28, one Orthodox Jewish organization says it will do just that by sponsoring a gathering for men who have completed the study of the entire Talmud, the Jewish civil and religious law, by reading a page a day for 2,711 consecutive days, or nearly seven and a half years. The organization, Agudath Israel of America, says it expects 70,000 people to buy tickets, enough to fill the arena and other sites nationwide, to be linked by satellite broadcast. 
 By its scale alone, the event points to a trend within Orthodox Judaism, often discussed among its leaders: the increasing visibility and influence of organizations like Agudath Israel, which has a rigorously traditional approach to the religion, at the expense of a once-dominant moderate wing. This shift within the smallest of Judaism's three major branches threatens to strain its relations with the other two, the Reform and Conservative movements, and to highlight the religious divisions among Jews.
"Within Orthodoxy, there's a sense of being pulled to the right," said Samuel C. Heilman, professor of Jewish studies and sociology at City University of New York.
In a larger sense, the rise in self-confidence and assertiveness on the Orthodox right reflects developments in other faiths, like Christianity and Islam. As many people worry over a steep moral decline in society, the most conservative religious movements, building barriers between themselves and the broader cultures, have grown in influence.
In addition, with the erosion of the old American ideal of the "melting pot," it is far easier for people to assert a distinctive cultural or religious identity in dress and behavior.
The Orthodox, who strictly observe Jewish law, are about 7 percent of an estimated 5.5 million American Jews, according to the 1990 National Jewish Population Survey. Forty-two percent of Jewish adults identified with the liberal Reform movement and 38 percent with the Conservative movement, which seeks a middle ground. Most of the rest claimed no affiliation.
The Orthodox are a diverse group, from self-contained, Hasidic sects to people who balance religious observance with careers on Wall Street or in Washington. Still, leaders often speak of two camps, the "modern Orthodox," or "centrists," and the right wing, or ultra-Orthodox. Sociologists say the ultra-Orthodox group is smaller, but it is growing.
The two groups part company over divisive issues like these: how much value to place on secular education; how closely to cooperate with non-Orthodox Jews, and what religious role to give women.
Citing a need for Jewish unity, Orthodox moderates have often found ways to work with their non-Orthodox counterparts. But the Orthodox right has tried to avoid seeming to support forms of Judaism they believe violate religious law.
For decades, modern Orthodoxy was dominant, inspired by Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik, who taught at Yeshiva University in New York and contended that one could be devoutly observant while holding a worldly outlook. But the modern Orthodox position has eroded, hastened by the growth of Orthodox religious schools, or yeshivas, many built and run by the right wing. Many modern Orthodox young people have become doctors, lawyers and other professionals, Professor Heilman said. "Who's left to teach in the day schools? The right-wing community."
Rabbi Moshe Sherer, the president of Agudath Israel, agreed that most yeshivas were "directed by the so-called right wing." That means that modern Orthodox children sent to religious schools have teachers with far more traditional views.
"These parents wake up one day and find their sons are in the right wing," Rabbi Sherer said. "The sons swing the parents over to this world."
"Years ago, we were written off," he added.
When he joined the group in the 1940's, he said, friends saw "no future in that type of Orthodoxy." But, he said, "it's a growth stock today."
"In the spiritual world," he added, "I find the rich are getting richer.
As the ground within Orthodoxy shifts, rabbis in its modern wing speak of colleagues "looking over their right shoulder," to avoid offending more traditional Jews..
In January, an Orthodox rabbinic board in Queens ruled that women's prayer groups violated Jewish tradition. And in March, the small Union of Orthodox Rabbis declared that the Reform and Conservative movements were "not Judaism." The statement came as Israeli Orthodox political parties pushed a law barring government recognition of conversions to Judaism conducted by non-Orthodox rabbis in Israel.
The two largest Orthodox groups, the Rabbinical Council of America and the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, said in newspaper advertisements that the statement offended the "Orthodoxy of inclusion."
The Union of Orthodox Rabbis fired back with advertisements that quoted the biblical verse Joshua 5:13, in which an angel asks Joshua, "Are you on our side or are you on the side of the adversary?"
Rabbi Irving Greenberg, president of the National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership, and an outspoken figure on the Orthodox liberal edge, said the Orthodox community was "polarizing" -- the right was growing by drawing followers from an increasingly muted center.
Like other conservative movements, the Orthodox right wing has benefited from an antipathy to popular culture. In a speech in December, reprinted in The Jewish Sentinel, Professor William B. Helmreich said the right had the advantage of, among other things, charismatic leaders, a higher birthrate, better political organization and the unease Orthodox Jews felt about "moral laxness in society."
"People need to find new restrictions to prove how religious they are," said Professor Helmreich, a sociologist at the Graduate Center of City University.
The restrictions are more obvious today than 30 years ago. For the ultra-Orthodox, for example, television is off limits.
Sociologists say that as the standards for Orthodox living are raised higher, the less observant fall away, perhaps joining non-Orthodox branches of Judaism, while the most committed remain, further reinforcing the right's standing.
Traditionalists, too, have benefited from the rise of pride in ethnicity over the past three decades.
Rabbi Avi Shafran, a former yeshiva teacher and Agudath Israel's spokesman, said that as an adolescent in the 1960's, he felt self-conscious wearing tzitzit, the fringes that, in the Book of Numbers 15:38, God told the Israelites to attach to "the corners of their garments."
But after he encountered a black man wearing a dashiki, a tunic modeled on African tribal garments, he decided, he said, that cultural distinctions could be a source of pride.
"I made sure people could see my yarmulke," he said, adding, "We got a lot of security out of the black liberation movement of the 1960's."
The divisions within Orthodoxy have lately come under scrutiny in Jewish publications. Last June, Moment magazine described the rise of a "more fundamentalist" leadership among the Orthodox and even reported that some modern Orthodox families in Baltimore bused their children out of town to avoid ultra-Orthodox day schools where preschoolers were separated by sex.
Still, some Orthodox leaders say the talk of greater power on the right is overstated.
"What we're seeing," said Rabbi Rafael Grossman, the Rabbinical Council's president, "is not a more influential right, but a more vocal right."
Rabbi Grossman added that he believed the modern Orthodox wing was growing, too. Within the last decade, he said, 54 schools have been founded within the modern Orthodox fold.
Rabbi Norman Lamm, president of Yeshiva University in New York, said he believed tensions within Orthodoxy were lessening. He cited fewer right-wing criticisms of his institution, long regarded as a bulwark of modern Orthodoxy.
"A few years ago," Rabbi Lamm said, "they would savage us with a truculence that seemed to exceed itself each time."
People on both sides of the debate point to the Orthodox birthrate to suggest that, whichever movement becomes dominant, Orthodox Judaism will become far more important in America. The National Jewish Population Study found that Orthodox families tend to be larger, with an average of 2.4 children, compared with 1.9 among the non-Orthodox.
"That's a pretty significant difference," Egon Mayer, professor of sociology at the City University of New York, said, adding, "1.9 is below replacement level."
But Professor Mayer cautioned against relying too heavily on those statistics, because people can change their minds about religion. He pointed to the survey's finding that fewer than one-third of Jews who said they were raised Orthodox still considered themselves to be that.
Some say they expect economic pressures to push the right wing into the modernist camp. Under this scenario, ultra-Orthodox communities, unable to survive on yeshiva teachers' earnings, will persuade more men to seek careers in secular professions, creating a class disinclined to cultural separatism.
Rabbi Sherer disagreed, saying, "In Agudath Israel, we have hundreds of attorneys, hundreds of doctors, hundreds of professors."
Professional success was "not a goal in itself," he added, saying that religious study "is the beginning and end of our lives."

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 1 about differences among Orthodox Jews identified the speaker in a verse from the Bible, Joshua 5:13 incorrectly. The question, "Are you on our side, or are you on the side of the adversary?" was spoken by Joshua to an angel, not by an angel to Joshua.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Broadly Lower After a Surge vs. Yen Fizzles

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell broadly yesterday after an overseas rally against the Japanese yen fizzled and United States manufacturing data cast doubt over an expected increase in interest rates.
The dollar rallied as high as 127.47 yen in Tokyo -- its highest since August 1992 -- before heavy selling by Japanese exporters and life insurers and unconfirmed rumors of looming Bank of Japan intervention brought the rally to a halt. 
 "A lot of the short-term and interbank traders were expecting a decent run-up once we broke above 127.15-30 yen and the fact of the matter is it didn't go much higher and the Japanese were heavy sellers," said David Gilmore, a partner at the market consulting firm Foreign Exchange Analytics. "That has taken the wind out of the dollar's sails."
Trading was thin yesterday, with many European markets closed for May Day. In New York, the dollar settled at 126.51 yen, down from 127.06 yen on Wednesday. The dollar fell to 1.7217 marks from 1.7303.
Dragging the dollar down further in New York trading was the release of the April index of the National Association of Purchasing Management, which fell to 54.2 from 55. The data suggested a slight slowdown in manufacturing output and reinforced the notion of a strong United States economy devoid of inflation.
"Over the last couple of sessions, we've had numbers come out which suggested that perhaps the inflation component of the U.S. economy is not as high as the market had feared," said Audrey McNiff, a vice president in foreign exchange sales at Goldman, Sachs. "This led the market to believe that the potential for interest rate rises is less than expected."
Expectations that the Federal Reserve would again raise interest rates at a May 20 meeting had fueled the dollar's recent rise.
In other trading, the pound was steady as Britons went to the polls. The pound strengthened slightly to $1.6242, from $1.6237 Wednesday.
Against the Canadian dollar, the dollar fell sharply, hurt by diminished prospects for higher United States rates. The Bank of Canada intervened in the market twice yesterday to cool off the rally in the Canadian dollar. It settled at 72.09 United States cents, up from 71.6 United States cents on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: It's Spring Fever: Art Has a Date With Its Lovers

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
AS the art world prepares for the important spring auctions of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art that begin next week in Manhattan, it is speculating about just how much nerve -- and how many millions -- the serious collectors will muster.
Economic indicators like the stock market and real estate sales point to quite a lot. "When people have money, they're going to spend it," said Christopher Burge, chairman of Christie's in America. "We're in that moment of the art cycle. People are hungry to buy things of top quality." 
 In addition to the usual offerings -- nice, middle-range Picassos and Monets, Cy Twomblys and de Koonings -- the sales at Sotheby's and Christie's over the next two weeks also include some major masterpieces. They are what may well infect buyers with the kind of old-fashioned auction frenzy that made these sales a popular spectator sport a decade ago. Art experts say there is even serious museum interest in a few of the best works, something that hasn't been seen for several years now.
Of the estimated $400 million worth of art, which can be viewed at the auction houses beginning this weekend, by far the most notable works come from just a few estates. The most important estate is that of John Langeloth Loeb, the Wall Street magnate, and his wife, Frances Lehman Loeb. Their collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings, to be auctioned at Christie's on May 12, includes $80 million worth of works by artists like Cezanne, Manet and Toulouse-Lautrec. Proceeds from the sale are to finance the newly organized Frances and John L. Loeb Family Fund, which will support programs in education, health, art and public policy. Christie's has gone all-out in promoting the collection, with a hard-bound catalogue in its own slipcase.
Mr. Loeb, who died in December at 94, and Mrs. Loeb, who was 89 when she died last May, began buying art in the 1950's and 1960's from well-known New York dealers, especially Knoedler & Company.
The collection has three major stars. The first is Cezanne's "Madame Cezanne Seated in a Yellow Chair" (1893-1895), a portrait of the artist's wife in a red dress in a corner of the artist's Paris studio, one in a series of four he did of his wife. The others are in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago and the Sao Paolo Museum of Art in Brazil. While Christie's has not officially put an estimate on the painting, experts there expect it to sell for about $25 million. The Loebs bought the painting at Knoedler in 1956 for $125,000.
Another prized Cezanne they acquired at Knoedler is the landscape "View From L'Estaque" (1883-1885), depicting the bay of Marseilles from the village. The Loebs paid $728,000 and gave Knoedler another landscape in exchange for it; the painting is expected to bring $8 million to $10 million.
The third star in the collection features one of the great self-portraits of the 19th century, "Manet With His Palette" (1878). Like an Old Master painting, the work has the artist posed against a rich brown background, with an intense stare and a paintbrush and palette in his hands. Christie's experts estimate the painting may bring $15 million. The Loebs bought the portrait for $176,800 at the celebrated London sale of the collection of the New York investment banker Jakob Goldschmidt at Sotheby's in 1958.
Months before Christie's announced it had won the Loeb collection, the auction house had obtained works from another important collector's estate, that of Jacques Koerfer, a German businessman whose heirs have been selling portions of the holdings -- stunning examples of works by artists like Picasso, Vlaminck and Modigliani -- for three years now. This is the third round of Koerfer property and it, too, comes in a special catalogue, titled "Important Paintings and Sculpture From a European Estate."
The current selection, which is being sold on May 14, includes Picasso's "Torso of a Young Girl With a Pitcher" (1906), a Rose Period portrait of the artist's mistress Fernande Olivier. Christie's estimates it will sell for $5 million to $7 million. Another star piece is Mondrian's "Composition No. III" (1929), an exquisite abstract composition from one of the artist's most desirable periods. Not only is it in excellent condition, but it is also in the artist's own frame. Christie's estimate is $3 million to $4 million.
Of the two auction houses, Christie's has captured most of the plum property. "People like being in good company," said Franck Giraud, who heads Christie's department of Impressionist and modern art. "Sellers don't want to have art that competes, but at the same time, they do like their art to be sold in the company of other important works."
But Sotheby's does have a handful of notable paintings in its Impressionist and modern sale on May 13. Modigliani's "Jeanne Hebuterne Wearing a Hat" (circa 1919) is one of the artist's finest portraits, depicting a woman with an elongated neck and vacant, almond-shaped eyes. It is expected to bring $8 million to $10 million. Another important work at Sotheby's, which is being sold by the heirs of the French dealer Paul Durand-Ruel, is an 1899 Degas, "Dancers." The brightly colored scene is considered to be among the artist's best late pastels, and is expected to fetch $5 million to $7 million.
Also up for sale at Sotheby's are works from Henry Moore's personal art collection, which is being sold by his daughter, Mary Moore. The group includes paintings and drawings by Cezanne, Degas, Millet, Seurat and Corot, as well as many of the artist's own sculptures and drawings, including the 1927 "Mask," an early greenish-gray stone carving expected to sell for $100,000 to $150,000.
Sotheby's is also selling works from the estate of Florence and Richard Weil, St. Louis collectors who had a taste for 20th-century art. One of the best paintings in this group is Picasso's 1927 "Head and Guitar," which is expected to bring $1 million to $1.5 million.
"Three or four years ago, all we would get is estates, but now there are a lot more discretionary sellers," said Alexander Apsis, head of the department of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby's.
That is not the case with contemporary art. Experts at Sotheby's and Christie's report that it is still difficult to put together strong sales in this field. Yet along with some pieces that have been for sale all too recently, both houses have managed to cobble together auctions that offer a few very good works.
"I purposely put together a smaller sale that is a little different," said Tobias Meyer, who is Sotheby's head of contemporary art worldwide. The contemporary sale on Tuesday will be the first in New York for Mr. Meyer, who has led Sotheby's department in London for five years. He brings an international sensibility, putting in the auction some works of European taste that would traditionally only be found in London sales.
The first 11 offerings in the auction are primarily from the 1980's and 90's and are being sold by the Boston Children's Heart Foundation. (The collection was formed by Dr. Bernardo Nadal-Ginard, a Boston cardiologist who is now serving a one-year prison sentence for misappropriating money from the nonprofit medical foundation, which conducts research on heart disease in children.) The works are by an avant-garde group of trendy artists like Kiki Smith, Matthew Barney, Robert Gober and Jeff Koons. It is expected to attract a small but passionate group of buyers.
Sotheby's sale also includes works from the estate of William C. Janss, a California real estate developer. One of its stars is Mark Rothko's "No. 19" from 1960, which is expected to sell for $1.8 million to $2.2 million. By far the most important work in Sotheby's contemporary sale is de Kooning's "Untitled," from 1947, which the auction house expects to sell for $2 million to $2.5 million. No one knows how a work by de Kooning, who died in March, will be received at auction. Often, right after an artist dies, so does his market, but not always; in Andy Warhol's case, prices skyrocketed.
Christie's also has an important de Kooning in its sale on Wednesday: "Amityville," a 1971 painting with brilliant scoops of color and wide brush strokes that also carries a $2 million to $2.5 million estimate.
Two other noteworthy paintings at Christie's are examples of early Pop Art. Roy Lichtenstein's "Blang" (1962), one of the artist's war images, carries a $3 million to $4 million estimate. The other, also from 1962, is Wayne Thiebaud's "Bakery Counter," which is among the largest of the artist's early still lifes and shows rows of multicolored pastries. It is estimated at $650,000 to $850,000.
Christie's contemporary sale has one single-owner collection: 22 sculptures belonging to Douglas S. Cramer, a television producer. Among the artists whose works he bought over the years are Joel Shapiro, Ellsworth Kelly and Jim Dine. Some pieces are from his personal collection and others are from a foundation he established last year to support the visual arts. (Proceeds from works sold by the foundation are going to the foundation.)
"I've tried to make this a well-rounded sale," said Neal Melzer, head of Christie's contemporary art department in New York, "to offer collectors everything from Pop Art and New York School to Minimalist and important 1980's works."
 
Where to View the Art
Viewings of contemporary art begin this weekend at Christie's and Sotheby's in Manhattan. Viewings of Impressionist art begin next weekend. Admission to viewings and auctions is free (free reserved tickets are required for evening sales). Christie's is at 502 Park Avenue, at 59th Street. Information: (212) 546-1000. HEADLINE: Playing Poker in Zaire: Rebel Leader Holds the Aces

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 1

 BODY:
If President Mobutu Sese Seko and the rebel leader Laurent Kabila meet on a South African ship on Friday as scheduled, the encounter will be a first between two men whose fates have been loosely linked for three decades but whose destinies are now streaking in opposite directions.
For Mr. Mobutu, 66, a dictator of almost mythic stature who has been reduced by cancer to a pallid shell, Friday's meeting supposedly offers as dignified a way out as possible at this late date for a man whose army is defeated and whose power is now all but gone. 
 With his health visibly failing by the day and his adversary leaving little room for niceties in a drive for power that is but a few days from its goal, the question most were asking today was whether Mr. Mobutu would leave Zaire on Friday for a final voyage.
The South African President, Nelson Mandela, is to accompany his Zairian counterpart from Pointe-Noire, a Congo coastal city, to the shipboard meeting. But several diplomats and associates of Mr. Mobutu say that once Mr. Mobutu leaves Zaire, whether or not he ever makes it to the rendezvous with Mr. Kabila, a hospital bed somewhere abroad, certain exile and death await him soon afterward.
Mr. Kabila's rebels are reportedly within 150 miles of Kinshasa and are closing in on Mr. Mobutu's palatial residence in the far-northern city of Gbadolite. People close to the President say Mr. Mobutu's Versailles-like palace in Gbadolite has been emptied in recent weeks, with most of its contents flown to Morocco, which suggests that that country may be a final refuge.
Members of Mr. Mobutu's inner circle deny what for them is unthinkable: that the only leader most Zairians have ever known is near death, or is even contemplating giving up power and going into exile.
But asked if his gravely ill father should be attending to his health rather than clinging to vestiges of power, Mr. Mobutu's 27-year-old son, Nzanga, said in an interview today: "Yes, that is the most important thing. And he is concerned."
"The media focus on Mobutu not doing anything for his country, but he has done many things, and his legacy will be the unity of Zaire," Nzanga Mobutu, who is his father's official spokesman, said in what sounded distinctly like a summing up of a life and a career that are ending.
While the struggle to define Mr. Mobutu's legacy gets under way, Mr. Kabila's ascension has created another sort of industry: predicting how this lifelong revolutionary will rule Africa's third largest country, and just as important, how he will fare.
A meeting Tuesday between Mr. Kabila and Bill Richardson, Washington's representative at the United Nations and President Clinton's special envoy here, produced few firm answers, but left the lingering feeling that the 56-year-old revolutionary remains trapped in an obsolete past.
"He was talking a lot about big projects, roads and industries that the state will create," one member of Mr. Richardson's delegation said, using the word Maoist to describe the sketchy program. "Even state agriculture. I just told him that it won't work."
Mr. Kabila's victory in a seven-month war came at the cost of deals cut with neighboring countries, each with grievances against Mr. Mobutu and Zaire. The recent massacres of Rwandan Hutu refugees near Kisangani, in eastern Zaire, apparently by Rwandan Tutsi forces that have formed the backbone of Mr. Kabila's army, have already badly tarnished his reputation.
The massacres have raised troubling questions about who is in charge of the rebels' Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of the Congo, and whether the movement, a shadowy collection of disparate interests and influences, can remain united once in power.
Rwanda was Mr. Kabila's first sponsor in this war, but was quickly joined by Uganda, Burundi, Zambia, Zimbabwe and Tanzania. Diplomats say that today it is Angola, which has been making large donations of men, materiel and especially money, that has become the foremost influence on the Alliance.
Besides an abiding hatred of Mr. Mobutu, who destabilized neighbors throughout his career, each country has its own interests in Zaire, from vengeance against the Hutu (in the case of Rwanda), to investment in the copper industry (for Zambia), to military and economic isolation of Unita in Angola, a rebel movement that has recently and uneasily joined the Government.
Add to this the inexperience of Mr. Kabila's leadership team, many of whom have only recently returned from years of exile, and a political class in Kinshasa that is unlikely to swallow Mr. Kabila's brand of one-party leadership for long, and diplomats wonder if the rebel movement can long last in power.
Mr. Kabila's jovial and serene face offers no indication that he is bracing for a tough time ahead, but his associates told diplomats this week that they are already considering moving Zaire's capital away from Kinshasa in order to insulate their leader from unrest in a traditionally contentious capital.
"You look at the competition for influence on Kabila by his neighbors and then think about the problems that await him in Kinshasa, and you can't escape the feeling that this guy is riding a tiger," said one member of Mr. Richardson's delegation. "And it could be a long time before Zaire is out of the woods."

HEADLINE: Man Blows His Hand Off in Booby-Trapped Apartment

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
A Bronx man who booby-trapped his apartment with homemade bombs accidentally blew his left hand off yesterday morning, the police said, prompting the evacuation of dozens of families from the area while the remaining explosives were dismantled.
The man, John Saperstein, 36, an unemployed construction worker, set off one of the bombs in his apartment at 1054 Longfellow Avenue in East Tremont shortly before 8 A.M., the police said. Neither the woman Mr. Saperstein lived with nor their 18-month-old daughter was hurt. 
 At Lincoln Hospital, where he was taken for surgery, Mr. Saperstein told the police there were two more bombs in the apartment, officers said.
But the police found four more explosive devices in the apartment, which was cluttered and squalid, said Assistant Chief John W. Scanlon, the commanding officer of Patrol Borough Bronx. One device was rigged with translucent fishing wire and was primed to explode when the wire was tripped; another was hidden in a flashlight; a third was in a small container the size of a shotgun shell, and a fourth was hidden in a box of baby wipes, he said.
Just what Mr. Saperstein -- who has a criminal record dating back to 1983 for weapons possession, disorderly conduct and drug possession -- was doing with all the explosives puzzled investigators. "There's no indication he was involved in any group," said a police investigator, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "There were no rantings or anarchist writings of any kind."
But a man who was visiting the neighborhood said that in the one conversation he had with Mr. Saperstein, Mr. Saperstein mentioned various right-wing organizations. "He started mentioning the Patriots of America and the militia and I said, 'Oh, I've got to go,' " said David Lao, 37, who was visiting from Fort Reilly, Kan.
Mr. Lao, a civilian employee on a military base, said that Mr. Saperstein had quizzed him about plastic explosives."He started talking about C-4 and Semtex and automatic weapons," he recalled. "I was like, 'Hey man, back off.' "
Neighbors were startled by the noise of the blast, and by the news that one of their neighbors had apparently been concocting explosives on their tree-lined block of row houses just off the Bruckner Expressway.
"At first I thought maybe a car had backfired," said Fabian Hamlet, 36, who lives next door. "Then I saw fire trucks going by and I thought I'd be nosy, so I went outside. That's when I heard it had been a bomb, so I got everyone out of my house."
Other neighbors, including several children, said that Mr. Saperstein sold them fireworks and weapons. "Last year he sold me about $30 worth of ashcans and M-80's," said Edward Oserio, 24. "He also sold kids lipstick knives, knives disguised as lipstick tubes, and knives inside pens."
A 14-year-old boy displayed a razor blade in a duct-tape case. "John gave me this," said the boy, who gave his name only as Roger.
As special container trucks waited to cart the explosives off to the Police Department's firing range at Rodmans Neck, neighbors, some still in their pajamas, waited to be allowed back into their homes. The Red Cross gave dinner to about 20 families and set up a shelter at nearby Public School 75.
The authorities said that Mr. Saperstein may have learned how to make incendiary devices while working for his family's construction company in New Jersey. Tucked in among the garbage, baby food jars and cans of cat food that littered his apartment, they found bullets, hypodermic needles and several books on explosives, including "The Anarchist Cookbook," they said.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE: THE CUTS;
Negotiators Move to Rein In Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
The budget deal shaping up on Capitol Hill would significantly restrain the growth of spending on Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security, further reducing the Federal deficit. But lobbyists for the elderly and governors of both parties said today that they found parts of the agreement unacceptable.
Under the agreement, as outlined today by negotiators of both parties, millions of retirees would face higher Medicare premiums and would receive somewhat smaller Social Security checks in future years than they would get under current law. 
 In addition, Federal spending on health benefits for poor people under Medicaid would probably be capped for the first time, a radical change in a program that has been open-ended since its creation in 1965.
The negotiators also said they had accepted President Clinton's proposal to shore up Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund by shifting much of the cost of home health care to another account, which pays doctors' bills. But contrary to Mr. Clinton's suggestion, Republicans insisted that home health costs be financed by higher premiums, and they have apparently prevailed.
Congressional experts estimate that this change would eventually add $8.70 to the monthly Medicare premium, which is now $43.80 and is already expected to rise to $51.50 by 2002 under current law. Elderly people with incomes below a certain level, perhaps $30,000 a year, would not have to pay the extra premium for home health care.
Representative Pete Stark of California, the ranking Democrat on the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said he could not vote for the budget blueprint in its current form. But he offered to help the Republicans write their proposal to increase Medicare premiums.
"We'll win back the House if they do it," Mr. Stark said. In last year's election campaign, Democrats battered Republicans for proposing Medicare cutbacks, and Republicans acknowledge that the attacks hurt them.
Congressional Republicans and Clinton Administration officials said they had tentatively agreed to reduce projected Medicare spending by $115 billion, or 8.5 percent, over the next five years, splitting the difference between them. Mr. Clinton had originally proposed to cut Medicare spending by $100 billion in that period, but later increased his offer to $105 billion. The Republicans had sought savings of $125 billion.
The proposed changes would keep Medicare's hospital trust fund solvent until 2008 but would not address the huge fiscal problems that will face the entire program after baby boomers start to retire in 2011.
The emerging budget agreement would also shave perhaps four-tenths of one percentage point from the annual cost-of-living adjustment in Social Security and other benefits. Supporters of this proposal said it would partly correct the overstatement of inflation that many economists perceive in the Consumer Price Index.
Dan J. Schulder, a lobbyist for the National Council of Senior Citizens, said the developing budget agreement was "a bad deal for seniors."
John C. Rother, chief lobbyist at the American Association of Retired Persons, which has more than 33 million members, said:
"The authors of this agreement are cutting Medicaid. They're raising premiums for Medicare beneficiaries. They're cutting Social Security cost-of-living adjustments based on the Consumer Price Index. Those changes all affect low-income people.
"At the same time, they're cutting taxes on estates and on capital gains to benefit the better-off. This is income redistribution in reverse. It makes us more unequal as a society."
The budget negotiators have agreed to cut projected spending on Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for low-income people, by $22 billion to $24 billion, or 4 percent, over the next five years.
The negotiators assume that much of the savings will be achieved by setting firm limits on Federal spending for each Medicaid beneficiary -- a "per capita cap," like the one Mr. Clinton proposed in February.
The National Governors' Association joined advocates for the elderly and for children in denouncing this proposal today. They said the proposal undercut efforts to expand health insurance coverage of children.
A letter to Mr. Clinton signed by 41 governors says, "We adamantly oppose a cap on Federal Medicaid spending in any form."
As for Medicare, budget negotiators said they were determined to curb its spending on home health services, which has exploded in recent years, rising to $16.7 billion in 1996 from $3.3 billion in 1990. Medicare patients treasure the benefit because it allows them to receive care in their own homes, rather than in a hospital, a doctor's office or a nursing home.
Home health agencies are now paid a separate amount for each visit, based on their costs, and there is no limit on the number of visits. Under the plan being devised in Congress, those agencies would receive a fixed amount of money for all the visits to a patient in a given period, perhaps four months. If they provided the services for less than that amount, they could keep some of the savings.

HEADLINE: Problems Aside, Washington Seeks to Be Host of Olympics

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
In the same week that District of Columbia officials said 11 public schools would be closed and the widow of a slain city policeman pleaded for the death penalty for police killers, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. announced today that Washington would seek to be host for the 2008 Summer Olympics.
"We deserve it," Mayor Barry said. "This is the place to be." 
 Surrounded by members of the Greater Washington Exploratory Committee at a news conference, Mr. Barry said the city had officially entered the bidding by sending a $100,000 check to the United States Olympic Committee, which will select the American candidates. Washington will now compete with several other cities, including Baltimore, Cincinnati, Houston, New York, San Francisco and Seattle, that want to be the site of the first American summer games after the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta.
The 2000 Summer Olympics have been awarded to Sydney, Australia; the 2004 Summer Olympics will be awarded in early September, and no American city is bidding.
Unlike its competitors for the 2008 honor, Washington is a city inundated with serious problems despite the presence of the Federal Government. Years of fiscal mismanagement at the local level led Congress to create a financial control board, which has been the real seat of power in the city government since 1995. And the board has slowly begun to improve the school system, police department and other city agencies.
Enormous work remains, however, and the amount of it is only underscored with every new crisis.
In recent months, nothing has rocked the city more than the killings of three metropolitan police officers, and the control board's support of efforts to save money in the school system by closing up to 18 schools.
Last Saturday night, as an off-duty city police officer, Robert L. Johnson Jr., sat in his car with his partner, two men approached, the police said, and one shot both officers, killing Officer Johnson and wounding the other, Sgt. Paul Shelton. The police have arrested Maurice A. Douglas, 22, charging him with first-degree murder, and are still looking for his 17-year-old accomplice, whom they have identified as Dominic Gibson.
On Wednesday, Tracie Gibson, whose husband, Officer Brian T. Gibson, was fatally shot as he sat in his car at a traffic light in February, appeared before a Senate subcommittee and, referring to her husband's killer, said: "This person gave my husband the death penalty. I don't think he deserves anything less."
On Monday a board of trustees appointed to run the public schools ended weeks of deliberations and announced that 11 schools would be closed across the city and that two others would be razed and rebuilt. The announcements angered hundreds of parents, who complained about the disruption the changes would cause for their children.
Mr. Barry was asked how a city suffering with problems of such magnitude could win the favor of Olympics officials, who will decide late next year which -- if any -- American city would bid for the 2008 Games. (A spokesman for the United States Olympic Committee, Mike Moran, said some committee members preferred waiting four or eight years more before trying to bring another summer games to the United States.)
Mr. Barry sidestepped the question, instructing reporters to recognize the positive aspects of Washington, like a new arena under construction for the city's National Basketball Association and National Hockey League teams.
Besides, the Mayor added, steering thoughts to a hoped-for, problem-free future, "We're talking about the year 2008, and I won't be. . . . Well, I won't say that."
Mr. Barry, 61, has declined to say whether he will run next year for a second consecutive term -- and fifth over all. Because a Washington mayor can serve only two consecutive terms, Mr. Barry could only be mayor in 2008 if he takes a term off.
Mr. Barry sounded every bit the city's First Cheerleader in ticking off the economic benefits that would accrue to Washington with the Olympics, and assuring regional residents that the nation's capital would never play a supporting role to a bid by Baltimore.
He also said that the entry fee was raised by private interests and that all bidding costs -- which could exceed $30 million for the American candidate city, Mr. Moran said -- would be borne by private sponsors.
While many officials and community leaders hailed the effort, others found it insulting, when so many city agencies are struggling.
"The idea that they might spend money for the infrastructure to build all that stuff is unbelievable to me," said Delabian Rice-Thurston, director of Parents United, a group that works for quality education. "It's one of those bizarre things that always seems to happen here. I'm not surprised. But if we get it, it would be infuriating."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Rally for 4th Straight Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Government securities market rallied for the fourth straight day yesterday, as a string of reports suggested the economy might be cooling enough to allow the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates on hold when it meets to set policy on May 20.
Also giving support to bonds was steadfast optimism among some investors that Congressional leaders and the President were close to reaching an agreement to balance the Federal budget. A balanced budget shrinks the deficit, which means the Government would have to sell fewer bonds, making existing securities scarcer and more expensive, with lower yields. 
 The 30-year bond rose yesterday by 16/32, to a price of 96 13/32 to yield 6.91 percent, down from 6.95 percent on Wednesday, and the lowest yield since 6.88 percent on March 12.
In light of this week's market- friendly data, some market participants are not looking for any surprises on the strong side for today's jobs report, and that may have stimulated more buying. The market consensus is for a gain of 200,000 jobs, but analysts believe the key will be the unemployment rate and hourly earnings figures.
The initial unemployment claims for the week ended April 26 rose by 28,000, to 347,000. Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said that 347,000 was the highest reported initial unemployment claims figure since the start of the year, when claims data were distorted by the Christmas and New Year's holidays.
Ms. Schaja said there were no surprises in the figures for March income and consumption. "Personal income rose 0.6 percent, only slightly more than we had expected," she added. "As suggested by last month's employment report, this increase was largely due to a 0.7 percent rise in wages and salaries." January and February income growth was revised downward one-tenth of a percent. Consumption rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March, with strength coming from each of the durables, nondurables and services sectors.
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its index of business activity fell marginally to 54.2 in April from 55 in March, indicating continued strength. Ms. Schaja said, "The details of the report indicate that while the economy remains strong, inflation remains quiescent," she said. A reading over 50 is an indication that manufacturing is expanding.
Moreover, the details of the report indicate that the labor market remains tight. The prices-paid component in the report, a measure of inflation, dropped to 49.6 from 50.9.
In the construction data, also released yesterday, the Commerce Department reported that spending during March slipped only marginally by two-tenths of a percentage point following a sharp gain of 2.1 percentage points in the month before, indicating that construction activity remains robust.
But Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., predicts that construction will not stay hot for a number of reasons, among them, that new- and existing-home sales were off slightly in March and that reported high levels of first-quarter home sales partly reflected accelerated demand by home buyers, who feared mortgage rates would rise; thus those sales borrowed from subsequent demand.
Mr. Harris said that while the Mortgage Bankers Association reported yesterday morning that its index of home purchase mortgage applications rose 3.6 percent in the week ended April 25, the smoother monthly or quarterly averages are less volatile for a better idea of general index trends. The average home purchase index level through the first four weeks of April is 179.8, which is lower than the 191.1 average for the first quarter. "Thus," he said, "the home purchase mortgage applications index is beginning to recede to a level consistent with the recent flattening in construction contracting and our expected second-quarter slowdown in housing."
In when-issued trading late yesterday the three-year note to be auctioned next week was offered at a price to yield 6.41 percent, down 2 basis points from the previous day, and the 10-year note at 6.69 percent, down 3 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
The New Face at No. 10: Anthony Charles Lynton Blair

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 1

 BODY:
When Tony Blair was 11, his father, a lawyer and university lecturer in the northern English city of Durham, suffered a disabling stroke, and the boy thought his world had "fallen apart." By Mr. Blair's account, a man who had been "very ambitious, successful, a go-getter," was stilled and speechless, and the son was uncomprehending.
Mr. Blair told this affecting story to a conference of his Labor Party in Blackpool in October in what was a strikingly confessional moment for a British politician and particularly for one as discreet and guarded as the new 43-year-old Prime Minister of Britain. 
 Some people, aware of the comparisons often made between the telegenic young British leader and President Clinton, dismissed the telling of the tale as "American style," a pejorative in British political commentary.
But the audience was rapt, and they were Mr. Blair's objective. Younger and more middle-class than people who had sat in the delegate seats at any past Labor convention, they were there because of his remarkable makeover of their party. Yet he still worried they might attribute his success to style rather than soul, might think that things came too easily to Tony Blair, might wonder whether he understood that life could be a struggle.
He told of how the family finances suffered and how his mother took three years to teach his father to walk and talk again. And then he came to his point. "I don't pretend to you that I had a deprived childhood," he said. "I didn't, but I learned a sense of values in my childhood."
As deft as he has been in turning the clattering old Labor Party, loser of four straight elections, into a clean-running engine of victory, he is eager for people to believe it runs not on some synthetic concocted in campaign laboratories but on conviction and values.
He is stepping into the leadership of the country after a safety-first campaign aimed at assuring the voters of Middle England that the party has been defanged. He has talked of his admiration of the purposefulness of the major player in British politics of his lifetime, Margaret Thatcher, and suggested that he was heir to her brand of movement politics. But while she prepared a real revolution in 1979, he has so far mixed a recipe for maintenance of the status quo.
All this has left him vulnerable to the judgment that he is packaged goods rather than the real thing. In the last weeks of the campaign the word "passion" got a lot of air time in the Blair campaign.
His early struggle with his father's illness aside, Mr. Blair's life story is not the fable of a born dragon slayer.
Born in Edinburgh on May 6, 1953, Anthony Charles Lynton Blair was educated at Durham Choristers, Fettes College in Edinburgh, known as the Eton of Scotland, and Oxford University, where he studied law.
The discipline over himself and his party that he was to display in later years was evident even then. He confined his rebelliousness to growing his hair long, wearing 1970's fashions and singing in a rock band called Ugly Rumors.
His biographer, John Rentoul, says he was "discreet about sex, abstemious about drugs and earnest about rock and roll." A male acquaintance once said he was the kind of person who you'd suspect might press his jeans.
Before Oxford he spent a year in London, where he drove a van, moved equipment for musical groups, worked in the basement of a department store and slept on the sofas of friends.
"It was one of the best things I ever did," he said in an interview in The Sunday Times Magazine last weekend. "It taught me about how other people lived, the real world, if you like," he said with the guilelessness that some find disarming and others cloying.
After college he became a lawyer in London, nursing a vague interest in public affairs and swapping sentiments about a classless society and reformist politics with friends but more concerned, because of the experience that had befallen his family and by his own admission, in guaranteeing his own personal security.
He joined the Labor Party with less passion for its causes of nationalization and trade union power than uneasiness with its narrow-band membership and core Socialist focus. One of his first acts as a party member was to write a paper urging the party to try to understand the appeal of the liberal Social Democratic Party.
In 1980 he married a fellow lawyer, Cherie Booth, who has gone on to become one of London's best-known attorneys. The couple have three children: Euan, 13; Nicholas, 11, and Kathryn, 9.
Mr. Blair's first attempt at running for office was an unsuccessful by-election in 1982 for a seat considered unwinnable for Labor in Beaconsfield, west of London. A year later he went north to Sedgefield, near Durham, and gained the seat he still holds today.
His posts in Parliament put him in touch with constituencies he would one day try to make the broad base of what he calls the "New Labor" Party -- trade union people whom he tried to ease into recognition of their diminished power, law enforcement officials who acquainted him with the appeal of law and order to crime-ridden neighborhoods and businessmen and financiers in the City of London with whom his years as a lawyer made him comfortable.
He made his way on intelligence, energy, charm and discipline. Politics itself, the dealing and trading and smoky-room wrangling, held less appeal. To this day, he will often put the word "tribal" before the word "politics," an indication of his feeling that it is more divisive than unifying.
Mr. Blair's progress toward becoming the ambitious and focused person who has taken over British public life was clearly gradual.
Geoff Gallop, an Oxford classmate from Australia, didn't spot it in college but remembers encountering a man who had taken on resolve when he saw his old friend in 1992. "Power can fizzle out very quickly if it's not accompanied by a natural authority," he said, "and it was flowing from him."
When Labor lost its fourth straight national election that year, its leader, Neil Kinnock, resigned, replaced by his deputy, John Smith. When Mr. Smith died in 1994 the leading candidate to succeed him was his right-hand man, Gordon Brown, a Scottish economist with a brilliant mind but dour public image.
Mr. Blair let it be known that he thought he stood a better chance of uniting the party behind the mission of winning. In the old Labor Party, it would have been time for a blood-letting. In New Labor the moment called for a civilized settlement, and it took place in a place typifying the dark-suited, mobile-phoned personality of the refashioned party -- the minimalist Granita restaurant in Islington, the neighborhood that is to London what the Upper West Side is to New York.
Mr. Blair was chosen, and, with Mr. Brown as his right-hand man, set out to pick up the pace of reform that had been set in motion by his two predecessors. He wrote nationalization out of the party's constitution, reduced its dependency on trade union money and turned it into the champion of the guy trying to get ahead. His iron-hand rule enriched his reputation for strong leadership, while his ability to state party objectives in broad and non-threatening ways earned him the nickname of "Tony Blur" from enemies but brought tens of thousands of new members into the party.
One of them is his father, Leo, the onetime chairman of the Durham Conservative Association. Last year he left the Conservative Party, and today he cast the first Labor vote of his life.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

HEADLINE: Manufacturing and Construction Slow a Bit

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
Manufacturing activity grew at a slower rate in April than the month earlier, although the economy continued to grow for the 72d consecutive month, the National Association of Purchasing Management said today.
In a separate report, the Government said that the pace of construction spending slowed in March as a decline in commercial construction offset an increase in home building and public projects. A third report showed that more American workers applied for state unemployment benefits last week than in the week earlier. 
 The purchasing managers' association said its factory index declined to 54.2 last month from 55 in March. The decline was smaller than expected. Readings of 50 or more mean manufacturing is expanding.
The manufacturing report also showed that the price index, considered by some an indication of the inflation rate, fell to 49.6 in April from 50.9 in March.
Analysts say the outlook for manufacturing may not be as favorable as it was at the start of the year. For one thing, strikes at some auto plants of the Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation have caused shutdowns across the industry. A resulting drop in auto production is expected to hurt sales, as are higher interest rates, analysts said.
Also, 14,300 workers in nine states have walked off the job at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.
The report on construction said that spending fell two-tenths of 1 percent in March, to $600.1 billion at an annual rate. In February, construction spending rose a revised 2.1 percent, in contrast to the decline of 2.3 percent reported originally.
Residential construction spending, which makes up almost half of the total, rose 1 percent from a month earlier. Spending on public projects, like schools, prisons and sewer systems, rose nine-tenths of 1 percent. But spending on commercial projects, like factories and warehouses, fell 2.3 percent.
The report on jobless claims showed that first-time claims increased by a larger-than-expected 28,000 last week, to a seasonally adjusted 347,000.
The four-week average for new claims, which removes some of the volatility from the weekly data, rose to 330,500, from 321,750 a week earlier.
Rick MacDonald, an economist at MMS International in Belmont, Calif., said the increase was "likely to be related to the temporary effects of the floods and strikes seen through April." That means "the labor market remains stronger than the total claims figures would usually generally indicate," he said.
Flooding in North Dakota and Minnesota put thousands of people out of work during April.

HEADLINE: 3 On-Line Services in Accord on Abusive-Billing Complaints

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
In another blow to the mixed reputation of computer on-line services, three of the nation's biggest providers have entered into a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission over complaints of abusive billing and marketing practices.
America Online Inc.; Compuserve Inc., a unit of H & R Block Inc., and the Prodigy Services Corporation, a unit of International Wireless Inc., while admitting no violations of Federal law, have agreed to disclose more fully the terms of their so-called free trial offers and to make it easier for consumers to cancel the services. 
 The three services also promised to end the practice of automatically debiting customers' checking accounts for the cost of monthly service without obtaining advance approval.
In addition, America Online, the largest service, must establish a consumer education program about the use of electronic payment systems, which many on-line services use to bill their customers directly.
America Online must distribute at least 50,000 brochures warning consumers about the dangers of automatic debit payment programs and their right to contest disputed charges.
Spokesmen for each of the three companies said they had long ago ceased most of the practices addressed in the F.T.C. settlement, but today's action formally requires the on-line services to avoid such policies permanently. The F.T.C. voted 5 to 0 to approve the settlement, which carries no fines and does not require the companies to pay any refunds.
But the settlement further tarnishes the image of the new industry that offers consumers and businesses a telephonic doorway to cyberspace. Internet access -- now offered by more than 1,000 companies, has been marred by service blackouts, slow data transmission, unexpectedly high costs and questionable sales practices by some providers.
The F.T.C. sought the settlement after receiving thousands of consumer complaints.
David Medine, a senior staff attorney in the agency's bureau of consumer protection, said that the Government did not seek financial penalties because the companies had already created refund programs for disgruntled customers.
Mr. Medine also said that it was virtually impossible to calculate potential overcharges for the three companies' 12 million customers.
He said that the F.T.C.'s goal was to stop deceptive practices and to require much more extensive disclosure of the terms of on-line service contracts.
"The focus here was to get the whole industry on board with a set of acceptable practices, because this is a new industry and it was important to get in relatively early to set the ground rules for the future," Mr. Medine said.
He added that the on-line services could continue to offer free or low-cost introductory offers. "But they must clearly, conspicuously and unavoidably tell you what you must do to cancel," Mr. Medine said.
Kate Delhagen, senior analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., said that the settlement would alter the industry's marketing practices only modestly, but for the better.
"This move is about full disclosure," Ms. Delhagen said. "It's good for consumers, and absolutely essential as the on-line market begins to sprawl into mainstream America."
Tricia Primrose, spokeswoman for America Online, said that the company had reached an agreement with the F.T.C. last fall on some of these issues. She said that the standards for billing, disclosure and marketing in the settlement announced today should be applied industrywide.
"Ultimately, that's in the best interest of consumers," she said.
America Online earlier this year stopped another billing practice challenged by the F.T.C. The company had added 15 seconds automatically to every Internet connection and rounded up all usage to the next minute.
Thus, a 2-minute-and-46-second call, with the 15 seconds tacked on, becomes a 3-minute-1-second call, which is rounded up and billed as 4 minutes of usage.
Ms. Primrose said all calls are now billed for their exact duration.
Compuserve, in a statement, said that it had not violated any law and asserted that the F.T.C.'s concerns with Compuserve "were minor compared to other industry players."
A company spokesman, Steve Conway, said the company was already complying with most of the provisions of the settlement. "We're happy to take the extra steps at this point," Mr. Conway said, "and we're also glad we had a voice in helping define the regulations."
Mike Darcy, director of public relations at Prodigy, said that the company had already "changed our ways."
"We've been in compliance with these conditions since October 1995," Mr. Darcy said. "We see little financial downside to the business. This is much less costly than litigation."
America Online, based in Dulles, Va., has eight million subscribers. Compuserve, based in Columbus, Ohio, has about three million customers, while Prodigy, of White Plains, has one million subscribers.
