HEADLINE: Consumer Still the Big Spender

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The national economy has just turned in its best performance in nine years, and the American consumer's surprisingly exuberant spending is the main reason. In no other six-month period in this decade have increases in consumer spending been as large as they were in the six months through March.
Consumer spending grew at an annual rate of 4.9 percent from September through March. The last time the six-month rate climbed higher was in 1988, the height of the last expansion, when it reached 5 percent. Consumers, always big players in the economy, have assumed a bigger role than usual in the robust economic growth of the last two quarters. They spent particularly for computers, clothing and health care, but without cutting back on autos, housing, dining out, airline travel, furniture, appliances and recreation. 
 Economists, somewhat surprised, are trying to explain why Americans have been so free with their money. The reasons they come up with suggest that the spending rate will slow.
A mild winter and early Easter encouraged more shopping than usual. Big income tax refunds have helped; many people found they could go to a bank, or to H & R Block, the tax preparer, show their tax returns and borrow against their anticipated refunds. A strong dollar helped, by keeping down import prices. The finance arms of auto companies cut car loan rates by two or three percentage points, to encourage sales. Mortgage rates, having declined last year, are only recently beginning to rise. Sharply rising stock prices made people feel wealthier. And consumer borrowing is at very high levels, having risen particularly among lower-income households.
Computers accounted for the biggest rise in consumer spending in the second quarter, nearly 15 percent of the increase, and apparel was uncharacteristically close behind, at 12 percent.
"There was a long period when people did not purchase apparel, so there was some pent-up demand, and this has now been released and satisfied," said Jay Meltzer, director of LJR Redbook Research, which tracks apparel purchases. "Apparel is a deferrable expenditure, and people felt squeezed and worried about downsizing. But finally they spent the money, and I doubt apparel expenditures will continue this strong."
Layoff announcements are still at high levels. And for most middle-income Americans, wages have not risen by more than the inflation rate in this decade. But those at the upper end of the pay scale are gaining ground and now, for the first time in this six-year expansion -- one of the longest on record -- people at the low end, earning less than $30,000 a year, are getting wage increases that on average exceed the inflation rate. A rise in the minimum wage is a factor, but so is an expanding economy.
"Our most recent surveys show that these workers at the low end have more favorable views of their employment situation," said Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Consumer Surveys. "And feeling a little better, they are spending more."
This is not unusual in an expansion. As the unemployment rate falls and labor shortages develop, employers traditionally turn to low-end workers -- hiring a waiter earning $6 an hour, for example, into an $8-an-hour job operating office or factory equipment, and training the person for the work.
"The benefits of economic growth have finally filtered down to the lower-income folks," said Richard Freeman, a Harvard labor economist. "What is surprising is that it has taken so long for the first stage to kick in. That has happened earlier in past recoveries."
Job growth has also encouraged spending, particularly among those who had not worked before or for a long time. "You get more spending from people getting a salary for the first time than from people only getting a raise," said Joel Prakken, a partner at Macroeconomic Advisers Inc., an economic consulting and forecasting firm.
But Mr. Prakken and most other forecasters expect the current second quarter to be weaker than the first, partly because consumers will spend less. Debt levels, they reason, are too high, and already some statistics show consumers pulling back. Higher mortgage rates are likely to take their toll on home construction and sales, as well as home furnishings, another strong item over the winter months. Auto sales are also beginning to weaken a bit.
Stock prices, which rose so much in the first quarter, are not likely to keep up the pace, diluting the wealth effect. Income tax refunds are winding down now, of course, and advanced payment of this year's estimated tax is now under way, cutting into disposable income. And job growth has to level off, in Mr. Prakken's view.
"It can't keep growing like this," he said, "or in a few years' time the participation rate" -- the number of working-age Americans in the labor force -- "will be out of sight."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Developer Is Trying to Meet Strong Demand for Large Apartments

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Demand for family-size condominium apartments is outstripping the supply in Manhattan's hearty for-sale market, with one developer combining units in his newly built 25-story residential tower to help close the gap.
At the Richmond, a 121-unit condominium on the Upper East Side, 20 of the residences with three or fewer bedrooms, ranging from 738 to 2,200 square feet, have been combined to create larger apartments, many with four bedrooms and 2,300 to 3,500 square feet. 
 The developer of the $40 million project, at the former Morgan Manhattan warehouse at Third Avenue and 80th Street, is a partnership between the Continuum Company of Manhattan, whose president is Ian Bruce Eichner, and a pension fund that Mr. Eichner declined to identify. Part of the building was the subject of long-running legal challenges to plans by Toys "R" Us to build a store in the building's basement, first and second levels. The plan was contested by neighborhood groups and ultimately rejected last December by the New York State Court of Appeals because it violated city zoning regulations.
When the Richmond was started in 1994, there was a demand for large apartments, but Mr. Eichner said he and his partner "were unwilling to build them because the market was just coming out of the real estate downturn." Instead, the apartments were built so they could be combined, he said.
Demand is expected to remain strong if mortgage interest rates remain reasonable, said Corinne R. Pulitzer, senior vice president and assistant director of sales at Charles H. Greenthal Residential Sales Corporation, a Manhattan brokerage.
Adrienne Albert, president of the Marketing Directors Inc., another Manhattan brokerage, said, "The bigger the home, the bigger the price tag, the smaller the opportunity to buy." Prices are also rising, Ms. Albert said.
Data compiled by her firm show that in January and February of this year there were 140 condominium apartments sold on the Upper East Side, up from 76 sold during the same period in 1996.
The rapid pace of sales at two other condominium projects in the neighborhood underscore the demand for large apartments. At the Knickerbocker, on 72d Street and Second Avenue, all 75 apartments were sold at the end of a five-month sales campaign that began in May. A 916-square-foot one-bedroom apartment cost $362,500, and a five-bedroom with 3,434 square feet cost $2.4 million. The project was developed by the Jack Parker Corporation of Forest Hills, Queens.
At the Siena, on 76th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues, all 72 apartments were sold out at the close of a five-month sales program that began in September. A 697-square-foot one-bedroom apartment cost $260,000 and a five-bedroom apartment with 4,075 square feet cost $3.15 million. The project was developed by Rose Associates in partnership with Quinlan & Field Inc. and the Brodsky Organization.
Other condominium projects are also being planned, including one by the Parker Organization. Industry sources said the site would be at 67th Street and First Avenue.
And Trevor Davis and Aby Rosen recently acquired the Cottages, a low-rise development of eight 1930's-era apartments overlooking a garden on Third Avenue between 77th and 78th Streets. The partners are formulating a plan for a high-rise condominium on the site that they said would maintain the character of the courtyard community. Several neighborhood groups are lobbying to preserve the entire complex.
Though Mr. Eichner purchased the former warehouse in 1994 for $11 million -- he then sold the retail condominium to Toys "R" Us for $5.7 million -- the Richmond got off to a sluggish start. Among the reasons were securing financing in the early days of the market's rise, a lengthy renovation process and "the uncertainty and unhappiness" that came with the two-year legal battle, he said.
The community group -- Neighbors "R" Us -- won the battle against the retailer by successfully challenging the validity of the store's building permit. Eli Zabar, who owns E.A.T. and the Vinegar Factory, both popular East Side market-cafes, is under contract to buy the retail condominium. Mr. Zabar is not sure how much, if any, of the retail space he will use for his businesses.
Joyce Matz a spokeswoman for Neighbors "R" Us, said of the sale, "I have not heard any objections to Zabar going in there as long as that store is within the zoning -- because that is what our fight was all about."
Mr. Eichner said that since the court decision in December, contracts have been signed for 53 apartments, compared to the 40 sold in the six prior months. Of the 27 apartments left to sell, contracts are pending on eight, he added.
In the year since sales began, prices for the smaller apartments rose to $285,000 from $190,000 and prices for the largest went to $2.1 million, from $1.7 million. Monthly common charges are $411 to $1,897, and monthly real estate taxes are $416 to $1,916. Amenities at the building, designed by Schuman Lichenstein Claman & Efron of Manhattan, include a sun deck and doorman.

HEADLINE: Albany Finds Tax Revenue Goes Up Again

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 1

 BODY:
In the latest evidence that the region's economy continues to grow at a robust pace, Gov. George E. Pataki said today that the state has collected $500 million more in tax revenues than his budget officials had anticipated just weeks ago.
The announcement marks the third time in two months that the administration has revised upward its projections for tax collections, and means that the state has at least $1.36 billion in surpluses that can be used either to expand programs or avoid budget cuts next year, Mr. Pataki's estimates show. 
 It also comes a day after New York City officials announced that they also had a growing surplus, now $800 million. State officials say that like the city, they have benefited from conditions on Wall Street, where larger than expected bonuses have swelled revenues. They said that the state's personal income tax revenue grew by almost 12 percent in 1996, the largest increase in eight years.
Democrats greeted today's news enthusiastically, saying it shows that the economy is healthy enough to justify spending significantly more than Mr. Pataki has proposed in the $66 billion budget plan that he unveiled in January. In that proposal, the Republican Governor called for reducing spending for higher education, health care and an array of other programs.
"As time goes by, they are finding that our projections were very accurate," said Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, who has accused Mr. Pataki of underestimating available revenues. The Democrats have called for increasing spending on schools, state colleges and Medicaid, the health care program for the poor and middle class.
But aides to Mr. Pataki warned that the additional money should not be spent helter-skelter, and urged the Legislature to enact many of the cost-saving measures that Mr. Pataki has proposed, particularly for Medicaid.
"The Governor has repeatedly urged the Legislature to avoid a repeat of the mistakes that hurt New York during the late 1980's and early 1990's," said Patricia Woodworth, Mr. Pataki's budget director.
The Republican Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and the Democratic State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, echoed Ms. Woodworth's concerns.
"We are convinced that most of this is being produced on Wall Street, and that is a volatile sector of the economy," Mr. McCall said. "There is no reason to predict that it will continue to produce revenue at this pace. We hope it will, but you can't count on that."
Mr. Pataki contends that the Assembly Democrats, who have passed their own version of a budget, are proposing to spend $5 billion to $6 billion more than his budget proposal. But Mr. Silver said the Democrats are calling for adding only about $700 million to the Governor's plan, an increase of 1 percent.
Despite the fighting over revenue projections, today's announcement virtually insures that this year's budget fight will be mainly over how to spend more, not how to allocate cuts, as was the case in Mr. Pataki's first two years in office.
But though glad tidings about revenues might have been expected to improve the chances for a quick resolution to budget talks, few elected officials here expect that to be the case this year, since the budget talks have become mired in the battle over changing the state's rent laws.
Most legislators predict no progress in the budget talks until the debate over rent control is resolved, and most do not expect that to happen before June 16, the day those laws are scheduled to expire. The new budget should have been enacted by April 1, meaning the budget is now 30 days late. This is the 13th consecutive year that the spending plan is overdue.
The Legislature passed a temporary budget last month that will expire on May 9. Mr. Silver said he would advocate passing a two- or three-week extension of that budget to keep state agencies running. During that time, he said he would urge the Republican-controlled Senate to pass its own version of a spending plan and then appoint a joint Senate-Assembly conference committee to negotiate a compromise.
"The Senate has several options," Mr. Silver said. "They can pass the Governor's plan or the the Assembly's. Or pass one of their own. They choose to do nothing."
But Republicans contend that the differences between the two houses are too great to be worked out in a conference committee.
Mr. Pataki also expressed deep pessimism about the budget talks. "There have been staff discussions, but I have to say very unproductive ones at this point," he said today. "There has been no real progress on any real issue concerning the budget."

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
A Booming Economy Made It All Much Easier

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
In the end it cannot be Democrats or Republicans who are credited for coming up with a plan that balances the budget by 2002. It won't even be Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin or the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, though their opposing teams played the leading roles.
Instead, it is the unpredicted and phenomenal strength of the economy that brought the deficit figures down to levels that no one could have imagined even six months ago. So by the time the two parties figured out how to solve -- albeit temporarily -- one of the most vexing problems of the last decade, it was no longer such a vexing problem. 
 "The fact is that a lot of the deficit solved itself," President Clinton's former Labor Secretary, Robert B. Reich, said today. "It was the one solution that no one thought of."
The new projection for this fiscal year's deficit, $75 billion, amounts to scarcely 1 percent of the gross domestic product. That is a significant piece of change, but on the economic screen it barely rates a blip.
In Europe, nearly all the major economies are trying -- largely unsuccessfully -- to contain their deficits to within 3 percent of their national economies. Japan, which once lectured American politicians about the global evils of big budget deficits, is watching in horror as its own deficit soars to new heights.
But Washington's good luck, in the form of unanticipated revenue pouring into the Treasury, carries with it a dark warning. Because the deficit was not higher, the pressure came off both parties to make the truly painful cuts that everyone had initially thought would be needed to reach balance by 2002. (After 2002, the deficit increases again, though modestly under current projections.)
And if the economy falters in the next five years, the failure to make those cuts could come back to haunt both parties, because it sets the stage for a deficit surge. In fact, Washington's biggest budget problem these days centers on the one figure that no negotiators can whittle down. Interest on the debt accumulated over the last 20 years -- especially the huge run-ups of the late 1980's.
Consider this remarkable statistic: If Washington did not have to make its annual interest payments on that debt, the Federal Government would be running a surplus this year of $172 billion, or half the cost of paying Social Security benefits. Instead, those interest payments will cost the Government $247 billion, or $20 billion less than the entire defense budget for the country.
In their more candid moments, both Democrats and Republicans concede that the strength of the economy has given both parties a tremendous amount of running room.
"I don't think there is any question that the strong economy has helped tremendously in getting a budget that gets to balance in five years," Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, said today after leaving an Administration briefing on the almost-completed budget deal. "And I think they are making some decent decisions. But the low deficit means that they haven't had to make some of the toughest decisions.
"Oddly enough, if the deficit today was higher, it might have forced a more comprehensive reform of entitlements, and it would have made people take a harder look at the Pentagon budget. And it probably would have cooled some of the Republican ardor for tax cuts."
Instead, the Republicans got a tax-cut package that they can crow about, including cuts in some areas that the Administration has time and again insisted make little economic sense.
For example, the final package appears to include a major reduction in estate taxes. Under the plan being hammered out this evening on Capital Hill, the first $1.2 million in inheritance would be exempt from any Federal tax. Now, the first $600,000 in inheritance is excluded from taxation.
Just a week ago, at lunch with economic reporters here, Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers dismissed Republican calls for cuts in the estate tax as "pure selfishness," because the exclusion primarily benefits the richest Americans. Only 30,000 Americans pay inheritance tax every year, Mr. Summers said, though the tax brings in $20 billion a year to the Treasury. He was compelled to retract the remark when Republicans protested.
One Administration official said the cut in the estate tax was "an example of the kind of cut we could come to regret" in a downturn.
The Administration has reason to hope that the low deficit will itself help keep the economy rolling along. It was Mr. Rubin's strategy back in 1993 to keep the bond markets happy by cutting the deficit and cutting it again. That, in turn, kept interest rates low. And the low interest rates helped fuel much of the economic growth that the United States has enjoyed in the last four years.
But it is not a formula that anyone, especially Mr. Rubin, expects to last forever. And when the flood of extra revenue stops, the annual quarter-trillion-dollar interest payments on the debt will still be there. Any real plan to balance the budget permanently will have to deal with that problem next.

HEADLINE: A Change at 10 Downing Street

 BODY:
It has been a long time between jubilant pints for British Laborites. When Labor last ruled, for those Americans who may have forgotten, Ronald Reagan was not yet President, Michael Jordan was in high school and "The Deer Hunter" won top honors at the Academy Awards. That was 1979, the year Margaret Thatcher's Conservatives swept into office, presaging Mr. Reagan's victory in America a year later. Twice more the Iron Lady was unbeatable, and her successor, John Major, scored a fourth straight Tory triumph five years ago. Yet this election season his party was visibly tired and deeply divided over monetary union with Europe.
So it was no surprise yesterday that Britons turned to Tony Blair's Labor Party, by overwhelming margins. The surprise was that Labor, historically prone to stumbling, turned the tables so effectively on the likable but rattled Mr. Major. Mr. Blair's "New Labor" shed its doctrinaire image and depicted the Conservatives as the party of high taxes and dour ideology, and as the enemy of opportunity -- and did so effectively despite sustained growth and prosperity for much of Britain under the Conservatives. 
 For Americans this has a familiar ring, and Mr. Blair, at 43 the youngest British Prime Minister since 1812, is in some respects very like another Oxford man in the White House. A fine debater, exuding energy and charm, the Scottish-born Laborite wore his hair long in the 1970's, married a high-voltage fellow lawyer, Cherie Booth, and moved so nimbly to the middle he earned the nickname "Tony Blur."
Victory won on such cautious terms has its price. If the economy eventually dips, it will probably be on Mr. Blair's watch. Having promised to reduce taxes and advanced so few concrete proposals, the Laborites can hardly claim a mandate for innovative government. By contrast, Britain's useful third party, the Liberal Democrats under Paddy Ashdown, proposed a 1 percent increase in taxes solely for education, the kind of investment Britain surely needs to remain competitive in a high-tech global economy.
Still, having surprised doubters with his sure-footedness as a campaigner, Mr. Blair may prove an effective leader in Downing Street. Within his party he has shown impressive skill in building as well as expressing a fresh consensus. That is precisely the skill he needs if he is to restore hope and a cease-fire in Northern Ireland, realize greater self-rule in Scotland and Wales and, above all, redefine British purposes and interests within a uniting Europe moving toward a single currency.
Mr. Blair starts with a strong hand, including an unequivocal victory fairly won, and the world's friendly curiosity about the appealing new leader in the oldest of elective Parliaments.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE: THE NEGOTIATIONS;
Clinton and Congress in Accord On Budget, Except for Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
White House and Congressional negotiators agreed today on nearly all elements of a plan to balance the Federal budget in five years, but failed to reach a final deal largely because of continuing differences over tax cuts.
The emerging deal would give Republicans many of the tax reductions that they have insisted on and the White House the spending that it sought for President Clinton's priorities, including education, health insurance for children and welfare. 
 The two sides compromised on scaling back Medicare and agreed to a small reduction in the cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security and other Government benefits.
The President and his staff were in almost constant contact with Republicans throughout the day, as Congressional Democrats fumed on the sidelines, angry about not being consulted more closely and fearful that the deal would give away too much to Republicans.
As the day wore on, the Administration and Republican leaders said that they were still optimistic that the final pieces would fall into place but that they were also wary that their delicate compromise could melt if there was not a breakthrough soon on the remaining issues.
By late tonight, people involved in the process said they were making progress on the main sticking point, a dispute over how specific the agreement would be in apportioning the tax cuts. The Administration, goaded by Congressional Democrats, sought assurances that the cost of the tax reductions would not explode in the five years after the five-year period covered by the agreement.
But Republicans were resisting the White House's demand to put limits on specific types of tax cuts, including a reduction in the capital gains tax, and said they were reluctant to grant the President assurances that his proposals for tuition tax credits would be adopted in just the way he wanted.
After two years of bitter partisan warfare that led to shutdowns of the Government and ultimately helped revive Mr. Clinton's political fortunes, the two sides hammered out a framework that encompassed compromises on nearly all these issues that had divided them:
*Spending for domestic programs would decline $68 billion over five years after accounting for inflation, $20 billion more than Mr. Clinton had first proposed. But the deal would contain provisions for $32 billion in new spending on initiatives that the White House had demanded, including expansions of health insurance for children, student loan programs and restoration of welfare benefits for some legal immigrants. The deal would also include the President's proposals for tuition tax breaks.
*Taxes would be cut by $135 billion over five years, paid for in part by $50 billion in revenue increases from closing loopholes and extending existing taxes that would otherwise expire. The money would be allocated in a yet-to-be determined way between reductions in the capital-gains and estate taxes, credits for families with children and several smaller initiatives.
*The growth in Medicare spending would be cut $115 billion over five years, roughly splitting the difference between each side's most recent offers. The growth in spending for Medicaid would be cut $24 billion.
*Military spending would increase about $23 billion, equivalent to a cut of more than $80 billion after accounting for inflation.
*The Government would revise its formula for calculating cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security and other benefits recipients to reduce spending by tens of billions of dollars over the next five years.
Neither side has specified yet how big the adjustment would be, but they would be limited to technical changes by the Bureau of Labor Statistics to address the growing consensus that the Government's main inflation gauge, the Consumer Price Index, overstates increases in the cost of living.
That the two sides were so close to a deal was a result of not just a willingness to compromise, but also good economic news that over the last several years has helped push the deficit steadily lower, making the size of the problems facing the two parties that much smaller.
Although the deal, if completed, would probably have substantial economic benefits for the nation, it also represents a much broader effort at adapting the priorities of both parties to new realities, the need for a Democratic President and a Republican Congress to work together and the need of both sides to satisfy the demand of a global economy for increased fiscal austerity.
Republican leaders and Administration officials rushed around Capitol Hill to sell the package to their parties, and there appeared to be enough votes from Republicans and centrist Democrats to insure passage. But there was little doubt that liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans found the deal unacceptable.
About a dozen conservative Republicans complained that the deal did not go far enough in cutting taxes, slashing spending on domestic programs and reducing the size and influence of the Government.
Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, likened the compromise to a dead fish. "You set it on the table for three or four days," he said, "and it will begin to stink."
House Democrats lashed out at the White House for keeping them in the dark about the details of the negotiations. And they argued that the White House was handing Republicans the opportunity to translate the broad budget agreement into the nitty-gritty of tax and spending bills completely on their terms.
Administration officials acknowledged that they were at risk of not meeting the President's commitment that any budget deal would have to win the support of a majority of the Democrats in both the House and the Senate.
"We want to get a majority of Democrats on board in the deal," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman. "We won't have them to begin with, and obviously you're beginning to hear some of the criticisms and concerns before we have had the opportunity to make the case for whatever the agreement is."
Senate Democrats seemed generally supportive. But a large contingent of House liberals appeared quite likely to vote against the deal, despite a concerted effort by top Administration officials, including Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, Franklin D. Raines, the budget chief, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin to win them over in a series of meetings.
Part of the Administration's message was that Democrats were never going to get everything that they wanted.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Money Is Tight at Hospitals

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Time is running out to find a permanent way to reimburse hospitals for treating the uninsured, representatives of the state's 26 urban hospitals said yesterday. The Hospital Alliance of New Jersey found that the institutions themselves are in precarious health because the hospitals are now spending almost as much as they take in, Suzanne Ianni, the organization's executive director, said. 
 The hospitals spent $407 million on charity care last year and received $300 million from the state, said Sister Jane Frances Brady, the president of St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in Paterson. The Legislature voted to reimburse hospitals from the unemployment compensation fund, but only through the end of this year.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Small-Business Awards

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
The New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, the civic and business organization, presented its annual small-business awards yesterday to the restaurateur Danny Meyer and two companies, Doubleclick, an Internet advertising network, and Cellularvision USA, a wireless communications company.
The owner of Union Square Cafe and Gramercy Tavern, Mr. Meyer was singled out for his success in the restaurant world as well as his work to improve the Union Square neighborhood and for the campaign against hunger. 
 Doubleclick was honored for its growth since its founding last March by Kevin O'Connor. The Manhattan firm, which now has nearly 100 employees, links advertisers and Web sites to match a company's ad with an audience.
Cellularvision USA, with 100 employees in Manhattan and Brooklyn, was cited for its initial public offering last year on the Nasdaq exchange. It went public after receiving a Federal license to provide wireless telecommunications, including Internet access, television subscriptions and local telephone service.
 LISA W. FODERARO

HEADLINE: Surprising Central Park, Nature's Pied-a-Terre

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

 BODY:
EVERY year, some 15 million people visit Central Park. That may be an impressive number, but not when you consider that about 20 million people live in the New York region and about 25 million tourists visit annually. That means that every year, 30 million people don't go to Central Park.
Outside of illness, agoraphobia and incarceration, it's hard to imagine why so many would miss out on the chance to escape from the noise and stink of the city without leaving the city. Is it that, at an expanse of 150 city blocks, the place is too big and intimidating? Or is it that the park's winding paths are too frustrating for the busy New Yorker used to the city's efficient linear grid? Or are urban dwellers, at heart, a tribal bunch, sticking to neighborhood shrubbery from tiny Tompkins Square Park to capacious Prospect Park? 
 Whatever the reason, this very subjective guide to some of the best, most unlikely and most useful spots in Central Park should help those unacquainted with its 843 acres stake out a favorite patch of grass and those who visit daily find something new to explore. Each number below corresponds to a number on the map on page 26. (Some highlights are shown at left.) So clip this and put it next to your picnic basket, Rollerblades, bike, tennis racket, guitar, beach blanket, jogging shoes, dog leash, sketchbook, pipe, Hacky Sack, play monologue, brass knuckles or whatever it is you take to Central Park.
 1. BEST PLACE TO SEE A GHOST: Janet and Rosetta Van Der Voort were sisters whose father was so overprotective that he rarely allowed them to leave their parkside home unaccompanied. They were free only to go to the 59th Street Pond in the southeast corner of the park, where they ice-skated in the winter, and a few other places. The sisters grew so close as they grew older that they spurned all potential suitors, dying as spinsters. But, as legend has it, the Van Der Voort sisters, decked out in the same red and purple outfits they wore more than 100 years ago, sometimes return to the pond to figure-skate, in the summer as well as the winter, haunting parents on Central Park South who continue to keep their daughters prisoner.
 2. BEST PLACE FOR ASPIRING NURSES: Ghosts aren't the only creatures haunting the 59th Street Pond. Teen-age Roller bladers turn up in abundance, shunning the disco dancing and backward-riding of the skating area between the Mall and Sheep Meadow. Instead, they prefer more dangerous stunts, like riding down the handrail that leads to the water from the path on the south side of the pond. More often than not, they don't make it to the bottom without falling off. Watching these riders tempt fate can bring out the internal grandmother in everyone. So if bandaging cuts or watching trick riding is an interest of yours, here's a perfect place to gawk.
 3. BEST PAY PHONE: If you're going to go to Central Park and really need to be doing work or making contact with the outside world, why not do it in a way that leaves no doubt about where you are? With circus music blaring in the background and children squealing with delight, the pay phone on the side of the old 90-cents-a-ride carousel (mid-park at 65th Street) offers the perfect way to leave an exciting answering machine message. The view of people bobbing up and down on the backs of wooden horses also provides distraction for a boring call. For a quieter, less colorful environment, try the pay phone at the Dairy visitor center nearby, which also sells the best maps of Central Park.
 4. BEST PLACE TO PRETEND YOU'RE A STAR: Central Park Summerstage's concert program (mid-park at 72d Street) has traditionally been among the best music series in the city, soldiering on despite fiscal crises and the noise complaints of sensitive neighbors on Fifth Avenue. Rarely is a bad band booked, and often the best acts in the world, from places as diverse as Haiti and Okinawa, are flown in to play, with no admission charge, to a jubilant crowd. But when the music's over and the stage is unoccupied, the area is just a big, empty, penned-in playing field crowned by an unoccupied stage. Clamber onto it and sing, dance, juggle, read poetry or make funny. See if you've got what it takes. Never again will you stand as the potentate of such a vast, unpopulated, open-air space in Manhattan.
 5 and 6. BEST PLACES TO READ: For those who don't need to sunbathe and just want a comfortable place to curl up with a book, the area around the boating lake at 72d Street (No. 5) offers comfortable perches and a romantic view. (It also offers the best places to smooch.) Try walking behind the benches at Bethseda Terrace and sitting on the steps that lead directly into the water. Or cross to the other side of the lake via the Bow Bridge and scamper across the giant rock formation to the east. Here, the park recedes into the background, and you can read alone and undisturbed, sitting on the edge of the water.
If you're thumbing through Shakespeare, disregard this advice and sit on a bench in the Shakespeare Garden (No. 6) at 79th Street, where only flowers and foliage mentioned in his plays have been planted. But be forewarned: this pollen-filled hillside is also the best place to irritate allergies.
 7 and 8. BEST PLACES TO LEARN HOW NOT TO MAKE A NUISANCE OF YOURSELF ON IN-LINE SKATES: Even for those who have never tried it before, in-line skating is a cinch. It's stopping that's difficult, and pedestrian-terrorizing neophytes unschooled in the art of braking have given the entire population of Rollerbladers a bad name. Recognizing that conserving Central Park means teaching skaters how to stop without grabbing onto trees or crashing into bushes, the Parks Department has thoughtfully instituted a skating patrol that holds free stopping clinics at Women's Gate (No. 7, at 72d Street and Central Park West) and at Inventors' Gate (No. 8, at 72d Street and Fifth Avenue). On weekends from 12:30 to 5:30 P.M., capable volunteers teach the latest techniques in deceleration.
Skates and lessons are available on weekends at Wollman Rink, at 62d Street. One-hour classes are held every Saturday at 9:30 A.M.; the cost is $15, which includes skate rental, but reservations are necessary 24 hours in advance. (Without skate rental, the lesson costs $12.) Reservations: (212) 369-1010, extension 15.
 9. BEST MICROCOSM OF AN OCEAN: Manhattan may be lacking in beach-front property, but that doesn't keep hobbyists from owning boats. They've just been scaled down, like a Manhattan apartment in relation to a comparably priced one elsewhere. Every Saturday from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. at the Kerbs Model Boathouse, on the east side of the park at 74th Street, members of the Model Yacht Club of Central Park bring radio-controlled boats and have a miniature regatta. For many, these $1,000 toys are serious business. So watch (the vessels as well as their owners). But don't disturb these junior captains, they can be a cranky lot.
10. MOST CONSIDERATE GESTURE: The ice cream and drink stand just to the north of the Kerbs Model Boathouse may be the only snack shop that caters to dogs as well as humans. On the floor near the tables someone has placed a big yellow bowl with the words "The Pet" on the side. Inside is all the water your pet can lap. There is a theory that this free service is a method of keeping pets from drinking out of the yachting pond.
11. BEST PLACE TO GET LOST: With some 63 miles of serpentine paths, Central Park is not for city slickers trying to get somewhere. It's for those trying to get lost. And one of the best places to do this is the Ramble, mid-park at 77th Street. The Central Park designer Frederick Law Olmsted envisioned the Ramble as "the perfect realization of the wild garden." But the wilderness has taken over his garden, and all kinds of trampled plants, fallen trees and dense overgrowth line the intricate network of climbing and falling paths. Nonetheless, there are great boons of aromatic sassafras, sweet gum and black cherry trees.
12. BEST VIEW: Where else in Manhattan except Belvedere Castle (mid-park at 79th Street) can one climb just two flights of stairs and have a bird's-eye view? Long a favorite spot for ornithologists, the ostentatious roof of the building offers prime viewing of dozens of baseball and soccer games in progress, Shakespeare in the Park and all kinds of cardinals, warblers, hawks and, um, pigeons. The castle is also home to the park's best visitor center, the Henry Luce Nature Observatory, which sells binoculars and bird-watching books in addition to offering microscopes and magnifying glasses for children to examine rock, plant and animal-hair samples.
13. MOST EFFICIENT PLACE TO SUNBATHE: With spring weather so varied and unpredictable this year, it's been difficult planning enough sunbathing time to get rid of winter pallor. In addition, whenever the sun shines, the Sheep Meadow grows much too crowded to make lying out relaxing. So why not try lying on the less-populated grassy banks of the Metropolitan Museum of Art? It's not just the sloping hill that makes this an ideal place for tanning, it's the reflective glass sides of the museum, which maximize the intensity of the sun.
14 and 15. BEST PLAYGROUNDS: There are many different strata of playgrounds in Central Park. There are spartan ones with swings and slides. Then there are fanciful ones, like the Alice in Wonderland statue at 75th Street that doubles as a jungle gym. But the queen of playgrounds is the Timberform, those log constructions that connect slides, balance beams, tire swings, mesh bridges and more into a giant fun fort. The best of these are at 84th Street, next to the Met (No. 14), and at 86th Street, on the west side of the park (No. 15). Both have similar features, like knotted ropes for children to swing on.
The advantage of the one near the Met is that it has checkers and chess tables that parents can use to amuse themselves, and the Timberform is a little more elaborate. The play area on the west side, though, has a better attached playground for toddlers, with turtle statues to climb on and a cube with sides of low, wide slides. Make sure you come to the right place, because the west side playground lies only 50 yards away from a disheveled swing area that ranks as the park's worst playground.
16. BEST INTRODUCTION TO POSHNESS: Manhattan may not be the first place that comes to mind when one thinks of genteel lawn sports, but the city boasts one of the biggest croquet organizations in the country. On weekends at Bowling Greens, near West 69th Street, sportsmen and women decked out in white hunch over wooden mallets, perspiring from concentration more than exertion as they knock small balls through wickets. This is the home of the New York Croquet Club, which begins its season tomorrow. The club is not as exclusive as it sounds: beginning on May 13, it will be offering free introductory clinics on Tuesdays at 5:30 P.M. Information: (212) 369-7949.
17 and 18. BEST PICKUP SPOTS: Grab a pair of jogging shoes and enter the park at Engineer's Gate, at 90th Street and Fifth Avenue (No. 17), the starting point for most joggers who make laps around the giant reservoir. Then stretch. Stretch for as long as it takes to find an unaccompanied man or woman who interests you. Everybody knows the loneliness of the long-distance runner, so make a little jogging small talk (don't ask for a cigarette) and then volunteer your services as a running partner. It doesn't matter if you're not in shape. Just pick somebody who appears to have the same stamina level. It's a good indicator of compatibility as well.
For those who can work on the fly, pickup artists say that the road encircling Central Park is a good place to meet skaters and joggers. Asking something as dumb as "So, how many times have you been around?" has been known to work. If you time your conversation carefully, by the time you reach the intersection of East Drive, just below 72d Street (No. 18), you can persuade your new friend to take a break at the rest area there and have a less breathless discussion. If the object of your desire is on a bicycle, this is also a good place to signal him or her to pull over to talk. Finally, if a more sedentary sport is your style, the New York Croquet Club (see No. 16) also gets high ratings as a singles club.
19. CHEAPEST AND MOST EXPENSIVE CONSUMER ITEMS IN THE PARK: Central Park was designed some 140 years ago as a garden of contrasts, where the poor could escape the claustrophobia of their tenements and the rich could parade their fine horses and carriages. This spirit still survives in the tennis building that presides over the courts on the west side of the park at 96th Street. Here, gustatory paradise is only a nickel away. Jars of lollipops, chewy candies, licorice and gum sit on the counter of the tennis desk for 5 to 15 cents apiece. For those more interested in continuing the Central Park tradition of parading their finery, brand-name tennis outfits and rackets lie two steps and $200 away.
20. BEST PLACE TO BUY A SODA FOR STREET PRICE: Central Park offers a textbook example of the economic principle of scarcity. The deeper one ventures into the park -- away from the land of corner delis and bodegas -- the more costly the price of sodas, juices and those sugar-water drinks that come in flavors that combine two or more fruits. But for the dedicated bargain hunter, in the indoor rest area of the North Meadow Recreation Center (mid-park at 97th Street) stands a lonely soda machine. It is generally ignored by those who use the rappelling wall or play basketball, handball and squash nearby. But at 75 cents a pop, it's a bargain.
21. BEST PLACE TO CONTEMPLATE THE MEANING OF LIFE: Follow the paths that circumscribe the pool on 100th or 103d Streets to where the water narrows into the Central Park Loch. At the first waterfall, you'll find that alongside the cascade are shelves of rocks. Come alone, because they're built just for one. Take a seat facing eastward with your back to the waterfall. As the verdant green blots out the sun, the sound of falling water shuts out competing noises, and a sensuous mossy smell fills the air. Close your eyes and relax. You're not in Manhattan anymore. No, you're alone with nature. And nature is your friend, its water carrying your problems downstream. Do you feel better now?
22. BEST PLACE FOR A WEDDING: A relationship, it has been said, is like a garden. With diligent and tender care, it grows and it blooms; but the moment it is neglected, it begins to wither. So what better place is there to get married than the most diligently and tenderly cared-for garden in Central Park? At the Conservatory Garden, at 105th Street on the east side, you can exchange your vows inside a frame of pink, purple, russet and white leaves as a fragrant floral cocktail fills the air. The garden also boasts many shrouded, shaded fountains and benches for guests to wander off to. For distant or unpopular relatives, there's a remote balcony where they can observe the wedding from on high without interrupting it. Information on arranging a wedding: (212) 360-2766.
23, 24 and 25. BEST PLACES FOR A PICNIC: In days of yore, the hilltops in the northern end of the park were ideal places for Revolutionary War and War of 1812 forts. The only problem was that by the time New Yorkers got around to constructing forts, the wars they were meant to protect the city from were usually just weeks away from ending. So there's no bloody legacy at these places, and most of the forts are long since gone, making the grassy, stone-ledged sites of Nutter's Battery (No. 23) and Fort Clinton (No. 24), both on the east side of the park at 107th Street, good snacking spots for small groups. They also offer a great view of Harlem.
For those who prefer sitting on benches, there are a dozen or so picnic tables atop the Great Hill on 106th Street (No. 25) on the west side. Perhaps because it takes a little work to get there, the area is usually sparsely populated.
26. BEST (AND ONLY) BEACH: Proof that Central Park is as man-made as the skyscrapers that surround it comes in odd inconsistencies like this tiny beach. Looking like a large yellow blanket that somebody dropped in the dirt, it lies on the Harlem Meer on the east side of the park at 107th Street. No more than 50 feet wide, it offers fine, yellow sand to grind between your toes. Often, braver and heartier park denizens can be found wading into the water from this mini-beach. A wiser way to use this water is by fishing: the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center at the Meer lends poles without charge. If you want to swim, try the hideously designed Lasker Rink and Pool at the southeastern corner of the Meer. But you'll have to wait until swimming season begins on July 5.

Shows and Gardens
 
"NORTHERN EXPOSURE." Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, Fifth Avenue at 110th Street. A display on the history of the upper park and Harlem during the Revolutionary War and the War of 1812, with photographs, maps and models. Sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy. On view through June 22. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Information: (212) 860-1370.
 
BLOOMING FLOWERS, TREES AND SHRUBS. Conservatory Garden, Vanderbilt Gate, Fifth Avenue at 105th Street. A six-acre formal garden with thousands of tulips, daffodils, lilacs and crab apple blossoms. Open daily, 8 A.M. to dusk. Tours every Saturday at 11 A.M. Information: (212) 360-2766.
 
HENRY LUCE NATURE OBSERVATORY, Belvedere Castle, mid-park at 79th Street. A permanent installation on the plants and birds that are found in the park. Open Tuesday through Sunday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Information: (212) 772-0210.

More than 50,000 fish, including bass, catfish, golden shiners and bluegills, can be caught and then returned to the Harlem Meer, an 11-acre lake. Fishing allowed April through October, Tuesday through Sunday, 11 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. Bamboo poles and bait are provided by the Central Park Conservancy. Information: (212) 860-1370.

HEADLINE: Up With Their Rents! Albany Aims at the Rich

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

 BODY:
Raoul Felder, divorce lawyer to the rich and famous, fought like a bull to hold on to his rent-regulated apartment overlooking Central Park. In a white-glove building on Fifth Avenue, it was his three-bedroom home of 18 years. He could stand at his windows and gaze upon New Jersey here, Queens there, all for $4,000 a month.
But, under the luxury decontrol laws that many believe will be expanded in a compromise settlement of New York's rent regulations battle, Mr. Felder lost. His apartment, resplendent with a remodeled kitchen, was deregulated, and his rent nearly quintupled. So, rather than pay $18,000 to $20,000 a month in rent, he bought a triplex penthouse on Sutton Place. He now concedes he probably should have done that long ago. 
 "I was hardly a victim," Mr. Felder said. "Yes, I was very angry, because I had the advantage of rent stabilization for so many years and it was a fabulous deal. But the truth was, there was no reason for me to have it. I was absolutely using the system because it was so easy to do. And, in truth, the Fifth Avenue apartment was too small."
For the last few years, New York City landlords have sought with frequent success to dethrone those who could be seen as the welfare queens of the rent control debate: the Raoul Felders, Mia Farrows and Dick Cavetts who have enjoyed a benefit meant for that majority of regulated tenants who are poor or working class.
In Albany, behind closed doors, these wealthy tenants are the real targets of many politicians who are negotiating to preserve the rent control system by weeding out the abuse. Publicly, the politicians speak of all or nothing, of killing rent protections entirely or preserving them for all. Privately, they talk most about two options: expanding vacancy decontrol -- the deregulation of an apartment when the tenant leaves, which now exists only for rents above $2,000 -- and expanding the luxury decontrol system to include the affluent and not merely the very rich.
If luxury decontrol is to be expanded, real estate experts say, there are problems with the language of the law and kinks in the system that need to be fixed. But at its base, in their estimation, the luxury decontrol system has been working as intended. Although most cases, like Mr. Felder's, have been contentious, few have ended up in court. Instead, the thrusts by landlords and parries by tenants have typically culminated in heated, typically Manhattan-style real estate negotiations. In almost all cases, tenants have had more than acceptable options once they lost their rent controls. Many if not most tenants have remained in their apartments, paying the much higher rents they could have afforded all along.
Tenant and landlord advocates say that if Albany does expand the three-year-old luxury decontrol system, it should change the system's kinks, because they have created inequities and absurdities and, unaddressed, are likely to create more.
For instance, tenants who, confused by the paperwork, do not complete their forms properly or on time, find their apartments deregulated by default, whatever their income. One tenant lost his regulated rent because he failed to sign the form.
On the other hand, those with very high incomes can retain their lower rents if they pay less than $2,000 a month, be it for a pied-a-terre or an $800-a-month penthouse apartment on Central Park West. (They do exist.) The law covers only regulated tenants who earn over $250,000 a year for two consecutive years and who pay more than $2,000 in rent.
That universe is quite small. While New York State housing officials say they have no idea how many very wealthy tenants there are in rent-protected apartments, the Census Bureau, at the request of The New York Times, tabulated the information for the first time yesterday. According to those statistics, 3,840 tenants with incomes over $250,000 enjoy rent protections in New York City, or 0.35 percent of the 1.1 million regulated tenants. How many of those pay rents of $2,000 or more is not known.
That number presumably includes what landlords say are the scores, if not hundreds, of diplomatic residences that are rent-regulated. New York State, however, has decided it cannot deregulate these residences. The apartments are usually leased by the countries the diplomats represent; neither countries nor diplomatic personnel file local tax returns, so the state considers their income unknowable.
"It's ridiculous," said Robert D. Goldstein, a lawyer whose firm, Borah Goldstein Altschuler & Schwartz, has represented landlords in deregulation actions against Spain and Libya. "I can't imagine that there's a country that wouldn't have an adjusted gross income of more than $250,000 a year."
By the end of last year, building owners had deregulated 1,404 apartments of wealthy tenants. But they had tried and failed to win state approval for deregulating almost twice that many, often because of a bureaucratic problem when the authorities cannot find a tenant's New York State tax returns -- the document they have decided to use for income proof -- because a name or an address is recorded differently on different forms. (State officials say they cannot use Social Security numbers because it would violate Federal privacy laws.) So the tenants get to keep their lower rents.
"Ultimately, about 15 percent of my cases are dismissed because the state can't match the tenants' names, as given to them by the tenants, to any New York State tax returns," said Jeffrey Turkel, a real estate lawyer who represents landlords in deregulation cases for Rosenberg & Estis in Manhattan.
While some affluent tenants have succumbed to their landlords' attempt to decontrol their rents without a fight, most have bought themselves an average of one year or more at low-rent levels by contesting the deregulation.
"Some will just give up the ghost and say you've got me," said Arnold Goldstein, the president of Samson Management and acting chairman of the Rent Stabilization Association, a landlords group. "But with most people, we've all been doing what I call a minuet over money."
When the state orders an apartment deregulated, some tenants in cooperative buildings buy their apartments. Others, like Mr. Cavett, agree to pay higher rents, often by negotiating a graduated increase to market rent levels. Most wealthy renters have invested heavily in their apartments, treating them as if they owned them, and do not want to lose their homes.
"If you've already poured $150,000 into a place, the idea of paying an extra $3,000 a month is still a good deal," said Robert Goldstein, whose firm has handled more than 1,000 deregulations.
Unlike tenants whose lower rents sometimes subsidize the laying down of marble over bare wood floors, most tenants in rent-regulated apartments scrape by on less than $30,000 a year.
Many tenant advocates do not think that there should be any means test tied to rent protections, saying that the system was not designed to give subsidies to individuals but to keep housing affordable.
"Granted, at the $250,000 level, these are not people who are going to be homeless," said Michael McKee, a leader of the New York State Tenant and Neighbors Coalition. "But once you establish a means test, there will always be an attempt to lower the threshold."
Indeed, proposals for expanding luxury decontrol call for lowering the income threshold and lowering or eliminating the rent cutoff. Under the most ambitious proposal, tenants with household incomes of $100,000 annually -- which Mr. McKee calls "nothing in this city" -- would lose rent protection regardless of how much rent they pay. If there is a compromise settlement, however, it is more likely that the income threshold will be $150,000 or $200,000 and that the rent cutoff will be lower than $2,000, but not eliminated.
The other option under consideration is expanding vacancy decontrol. Now, landlords can deregulate apartments with rents at $2,000 or over when they are vacated. By the end of 1996, 1,350 apartments had been deregulated that way.
Most building owners have taken a blitzkrieg approach to deregulating their luxury buildings on the Upper East Side and Upper West Side of Manhattan, where rents are highest. They have tried to lift the rent controls on every apartment renting at $2,000 or more, essentially asking tenants to prove that their income is not high enough.
Even some tenants who do not make enough money to be deregulated find the process unsettling, especially older, long-term tenants.
"Tenants are annoyed with the paperwork," said Gary Jacob, executive vice president of Jacob Management. "They'll say to me, 'I've already told you I don't make that kind of money. Are you calling me a liar?' "
Building owners and their lawyers do have many tales of tenant lies, the lengths to which wealthy tenants have gone to hide their income and keep their rent protections. Because the law specifies incomes of $250,000 or more for two years, they say, some simply arrange for their income to be divided so that $245,000 is reported one year and $255,000 the next. Some owners say that some husbands and wives are claiming to live separate lives, one in the city, one in the country home, to split their income.
Mr. Jacobs told of one Upper East Side tenant who amended his tax return to include a capital gain loss on stock that had become worthless, bringing his income $10,000 below the threshold. He kept his lower rent.
Mr. Turkel, the lawyer, told what he termed a cautionary tale of another wealthy man, who fought the lifting of protections on his grand apartment on Fifth Avenue through every level of appeal. In 1994, when he lost his first bid, the man could have bought his apartment for $800,000. Instead, he did so this year, for $1.3 million.
When the state ruled that Spain and Libya could keep the rent controls on their official residences because they did not file New York State income taxes, the landlords tried another tactic. They went to Federal court to try to prove that the apartments were not the primary residences of Spain or Libya. (Rent protections exist only on primary residences).
Both nations' representatives ended up in real estate negotiations with their landlords. Spain bought its apartment. What happened with Libya could not be determined.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 3, 1997, SaturdayMay 10, 1997, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about luxury decontrol rules for rent-regulated apartments referred incorrectly in some editions to the percentage of tenants with rent protections in New York City who have incomes over $250,000. According to an analysis by the Census Bureau, there are 3,840 such tenants, or 0.35 percent of the roughly 1.1 million regulated apartments -- not 0.003 percent.
A front-page chart on May 2 about rent regulation referred incorrectly to the apartments described. There are 1.1 million rent-regulated apartments in New York City; that is not the total number of rental apartments. In addition, the chart gave an incorrect percentage for the units occupied by families earning $100,000 or more. About 5 percent of the rent-regulated apartments not 8 percent, are in that category.

HEADLINE: Now It's F.D.R.'s Turn

BYLINE: By Geoffrey C. Ward; Geoffrey C. Ward is the author of three books about Franklin Roosevelt: "Before the Trumpet," "A First-Class Temperament" and "Closest Companion."

 BODY:
As of today, each of the three Presidents whom American historians routinely rate most highly has his own oversized memorial in the nation's capital. It took George Washington 86 years to reach the Mall. Abraham Lincoln had to wait 57 years. F.D.R. made it to the Tidal Basin in just 52.
Washington was sui generis, of course; he invented the job. And at first glance, his two ablest successors seem wholly dissimilar. The Roosevelt estate, high above the Hudson River at Hyde Park, was very far in every sense from the log cabin on Nolin Creek in Kentucky where Lincoln was born. 
 Lincoln had never managed anything larger than a two-man law office when he became President; F.D.R. had helped run the Navy Department in wartime and was twice Governor of New York. Lincoln was plagued by melancholy; Roosevelt remained so relentlessly sunny, despite paraplegia and the pressures of 12 years in the White House, that one dazzled aide said he seemed to have been "psychoanalyzed by God."
Yet the two had much in common. Each was hugely ambitious. Lincoln declared himself a candidate for state office at 23, before he owned so much as a suit of clothes. F.D.R. was just 25 when he began outlining for friends the path he planned to follow to the Presidency.
Both believed that the United States had a unique part to play in the world and that the Presidency was, as Roosevelt said, "pre-eminently a place of moral leadership." Each found solace in the conviction that he was merely the instrument of a higher power whose purposes were unknowable but who was nonetheless active in the affairs of men.
Both were denounced as unprincipled for failing to move as fast or as consistently as their more ideologically inclined contemporaries would have liked. "Lincoln was a sad man because he couldn't get it all at once," Roosevelt told a friend. "Nobody can." In the interest of getting all they could, both Roosevelt and Lincoln were often accused of being too clever by half.
Above all, they were masterful politicians who managed to overcome seemingly insurmountable obstacles to win power -- polio in Roosevelt's case, abject poverty in Lincoln's.
Along the way, each learned hard lessons about the value of keeping one's own counsel, the pace at which public opinion can be shaped, the strategic uses of delay and flattery and the miraculous power of patronage to change men's minds.
We've heard a great deal about the sins of "career politicians." Everything would run more smoothly, we are told, if government were just placed in the hands of gifted amateurs, distinguished men and women who would contribute a limited amount of their valuable time to bringing efficiency and objectivity to government, then return to their real jobs to give someone else a chance.
But the achievements of Franklin Roosevelt and Abraham Lincoln are the most vivid possible refutation of that notion. When the survival of this country was most seriously threatened -- by domestic enemies during Lincoln's watch, and, when Roosevelt was at the helm, by economic disaster and the crippling self-doubt it fostered, and then by foreign enemies -- the American people wisely turned to men who had devoted their whole lives to politics.
In that sweaty, sometimes squalid world, they had mastered the essential skills of Presidential leadership. Had we turned to amateurs, no matter how well-intentioned, in those anxious times, government of the people, by the people, and for the people might long since have perished from the earth.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Chas. B. Slackman)

HEADLINE: Foreign Business Investment Grows in Ukraine

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your April 9 news article "Ukraine Staggers on Path to the Free Market" misrepresents the situation regarding the Government of Ukraine's purchase of domestically produced grain, as well as my association with United Energy Systems. It also gives the impression that foreign companies are fleeing Ukraine, instead of entering in ever-increasing numbers. 
 You quote an American businessman as saying that the Government of Ukraine last fall confiscated all grain produced in Ukraine.
In fact, the Government decided early last year that it needed to purchase grain to insure that the Ukrainian people would have enough of this staple. The Government bought five million tons at an average price that was close to world prices, not at the lower price you cited. Any business person was free to buy the rest.
The article repeats charges that I used a stake in United Energy Systems to reap millions of dollars. These charges are false. I have no stake in U.E.S.
Ukraine is far from being the economic disaster that you portray. Foreign investment now stands at about $1.5 billion. From 1995 to 1996 foreign investment in Ukraine increased by 50 percent. According to the United States Department of Commerce, within the same time frame total foreign imports into Ukraine increased by 21.5 percent.
To improve access by foreign investors, an Advisory Board on Foreign Investments was created in March. This board is headed by President Leonid Kuchma and includes top Ukrainian leaders as well as representatives of many multinational corporations. The board allows foreign companies and Ukrainian leaders to work together to create a more hospitable climate for foreign investment.
 
PAVLO LAZARENKO
Prime Minister
Kiev, Ukraine, April 25, 1997

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies on Jobless Data And Swiss Remark on Strength

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied yesterday, overcoming early weakness after a Swiss central banker said he was not concerned about the currency's strength and the Labor Department reported the lowest jobless rate in 24 years.
The combination of healthy American employment data and remarks by Bruno Gehrig, a member of the Swiss National Bank's governing board, pushed the dollar to its highest weekly closing levels against the mark and yen this year. 
 Mr. Gehrig told reporters at an appearance in Switzerland that "I'm not worried about the high dollar at all." He also said Switzerland's own weak economy made it unlikely that interest rates there would rise anytime soon.
Traders said Mr. Gehrig's remarks surprised the market and caused a sharp selloff in the Swiss franc that led to weakness in most other currencies against the dollar, reversing its decline earlier in the day.
"The Swiss thing kind of got the ball rolling," said Bob Houck, vice president for foreign exchange at the Norwest Bank Corporation in Minneapolis. "Any time you see a comment for a stronger dollar, that's just kind of a green light to buy it."
The pound initially fell, then rebounded, in the aftermath of the Labor Party's landslide victory over the incumbent Conservatives in Britain. The pound's comeback indirectly helped bolster the dollar against the Japanese and German currencies, but sterling ended slightly weaker against the dollar.
In New York, the dollar settled at 126.57 yen, up from 126.51 yen on Thursday and up 9.2 percent for the year. The dollar cost 1.7293 marks, up from 1.7217 and up 12.2 percent for the year. The dollar cost 1.4715 Swiss francs, up from 1.4695. The pound cost $1.6210, down from $1.6242.
After strengthening on the Swiss central banker's remarks, the dollar retreated briefly on the Labor Department's report that the economy created only 142,000 jobs in April, lower than anticipated.
But the dollar's advance quickly resumed as traders focused on other elements of the report depicting healthy growth, notably that the jobless rate fell to 4.9 percent from 5.2, the lowest since 1973.

HEADLINE: Lode of Brazilian Nationalism: A State Mine Goes Private

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 1

 BODY:
The unexpected court-ordered delay in the Brazilian Government's sale of of shares in its state-owned mining company, after a barrage of legal challenges backed by popular protests, called upon ideas and images that many South American leaders had taken for dead as they moved toward privatizing their economies.
A Government sale of 45 percent of the voting shares of the state-mining company, Vale do Rio Doce, from which the Government expected to earn $5 billion, had been set for Tuesday. But the sale, billed as the largest privatization ever undertaken in South America, was blocked by an injunction issued by a court in Sao Paulo. The judge said he would reconsider the case next week. 
 [Reuters reported on Friday that Judge Democrito Ramos Reinaldo from the Superior Court of Justice had said he would consider the case over the weekend and might have a decision on Monday. The Government then rescheduled the sale for Monday, and indicated that if it had to keep rescheduling on a day-by-day basis, it would do so.]
Most analysts expect the sale to take place ultimately. The question is when. In the meantime, the Government is trying to signal to investment companies its commitment to the sale while facing a daunting task in trying to overcome widespread popular opposition.
At a protest in front of the stock exchange this week, a 15-year-old student, Mateus Torres, showed up wrapped in a banner bearing the likeness of Ernesto (Che) Guevara, the Cuban revolutionary gunned down in Bolivia in 1967. Others spoke of foreigners taking over the country's resources.
"The sale of Vale is the first step toward the internationalization of the Amazon," read one placard.
"If Vale gets privatized, in five years it would be in the hands of foreigners," complained Jonas Alves Correa, 62, a retired employee of the Banco do Brasil, which is also Government-owned. "Vale is the pride of Brazil."
Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a former Finance Minister, is believed to be the only South American leader ever elected solely for controlling inflation. But the economic restructuring he says is needed has encountered problems in recent weeks, as it touches issues like civil service protections and state ownership of mining rights, once considered sacrosanct.
"All of this is relating to something that's very deep in Latin America, and that is nationalism," said Roberto da Matta, a professor at the University of Notre Dame in South Bend, Ind.
While the principals of the two groups bidding for the mining company are Brazilian, many protesters predicted they would sell their holdings after the five-year minimum ownership now required.
That prospect appeared to tap deep fears, even though the protesters, some observers noted, had little in common with those who own the majority of the country's wealth, and who would presumably benefit from keeping the world's biggest mining company in Brazilian hands.
In a front-page editorial on Thursday, the influential Globo newspaper said the objections were based on obsolete notions.
"The auction of Vale do Rio Doce probably marks the last appearance of an idea which had a much longer career than it merited: that something is only 'of Brazil' if it belongs to the state," it said. In the 1970's -- an age of "omnivorous multinationals" and "incompetent national companies" -- that made sense.
"But today the reality is much more complicated," it said. "Vale is of Brazil when it pays taxes here and creates jobs here. And invests here and brings dollars instead of selling them outside."
Some here said the proposed sale had become a heated issue because beyond the privatization lay other changes that would erode the protections Brazilian workers had come to expect from the state.
"The tradition of protecting special interests is very strong in Brazil," said Walder de Goes, a political analyst in Brasilia. "When you have a set of reforms that threaten them, they strike back."
Mauricio Reveco, a specialist in Latin American privatizations at Salomon Brothers in New York, agreed. "It's not really an issue of Vale remaining in Brazilian hands, but it facilitates opposition to complain that Brazilian natural resources will be taken over by foreigners," he said.
Opposition politicians turned to Brazilian courts, Mr. de Goes said, because they did not have the votes in the Brazilian Congress to block the sale. Along with the Brazilian Bar Association, the Omsbudsman's office and labor unions, they filed more than 100 legal actions around the country, successfully seeking a judge who would issue an injunction to prevent the sale.
A squad of Government lawyers failed to overcome the challenges, even after the stock exchange was kept open hours after its normal quitting time to accept bids.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Budget Agreement Gives Treasuries a Lift

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
It was a clean sweep for the bulls in the Treasury market this week. Although prices slipped early yesterday in response to the mixed labor report, after posting significant gains through the week on data that suggested the economy might be slowing, they rallied again in the afternoon on news that President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders agreed on a balanced budget plan.
A balanced budget would shrink the deficit, meaning the Government would have to sell fewer bonds. That, in turn, would make existing securities scarcer, sending prices higher and yields lower. 
 The 30-year bond rose 16/32 yesterday, to 96 29/32, yielding 6.88 percent, down from 6.91 percent on Thursday and down 26 basis points, or more than a quarter of a percentage point, for the week.
Traders noted, however, that the market was limited on the upside ahead of the Government's quarterly refunding next week, as the Treasury prepared to sell $29 billion of three-year notes on Tuesday and 10-year notes on Wednesday.
Some investors were beginning to suggest that the Fed might not need to raise short-term rates much further, while others said the odds in favor of a rate had improved from 70 percent to even.
One thing that clouded the outlook for Fed monetary policy was yesterday's report that the unemployment rate fell to 4.9 percent last month, the lowest since 1973, from 5.2 percent in March. But the economy added only 142,000 nonfarm jobs, and average hourly earnings fell unexpectedly by 1 cent.
"While the slower pace of job creations was greatly heralded by credit market investors, everyone is keenly aware of the fact that nothing in this report truly signaled a complete easing of tight labor market conditions," said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio. "If the Fed expressed concern when the unemployment rate equaled 5.2 percent, one can be sure that the new 4.9 percent figure is definitely not going to unleash any new resurgence of complacency."
Discussing the outlook for Fed action, Mr. Chan added, "It's clear that their apparent intention to raise short-term rates one or even two more times in 25-basis-point increments before the end of the year is very much alive."
He added that with the latest three-month moving average of nonfarm payrolls still hovering near 200,000, it was still pointing in the direction of higher-than-expected growth. "And when one realizes that labor unrest and weather problems may have understated actual conditions," Mr. Chan said, "one can understand why the market was able to deliver only a lukewarm response to the overall report."
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a research analysis firm, said the economy was slowing as expected, but low unemployment would keep the Fed wary and make market participants cautious.
"For the Fed, this morning's report was a mixed bag" Mr. McCarthy said. "On one hand, slower growth in employment and declining wage pressures indicate an economy that is not in danger of overheating."
On the other hand, he said, the lowest unemployment rate in 24 years has to be a cause for concern because in 1973, when unemployment was below 5 percent for most of the year, the inflation rate soared from 3 percent to 8 percent.
Mr. McCarthy pointed out, however, that there was an Arab oil embargo in 1973, and average hourly earnings were rising by 6.5 percent.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the yet-to-be-sold three-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.40 percent, and the 10-year note, 6.67 percent.
