HEADLINE: An Uneven Budget Agreement

 BODY:
Hours after the Government announced that the nation's unemployment rate had fallen below 5 percent for the first time in 24 years, President Clinton and Republican leaders crowed that they had produced another piece of historic economic news -- an agreement to erase the Federal budget deficit by the year 2002. The plan appears to have clear sailing in the Senate and only marginal opposition from liberals in the House. But it is too early to tell how much praise is warranted.
Balancing the budget in 2002 is a modest achievement because a roaring economy has brought the deficit down to a level that poses no financial threat. What must be determined is whether the plan will leave large deficits looming in the years after 2002. There are reasons to fear the worst. The plan's tax cuts will escalate over time. It also leaves the long-term financial plight of Medicare largely untouched. But the worst feature of the agreement is its unfairness. It cuts spending programs that are in large part designed to bring disadvantaged workers into the economic mainstream, to pay for tax cuts that go overwhelmingly to the wealthy. 
 Discretionary spending is cut by about 10 percent by 2002. That is much less than what the two sides were debating earlier in the week. Yet the cut permanently buries almost all of Mr. Clinton's training, education and investment initiatives that he promised in 1992 would be centerpieces of his economic development strategy.
The agreement would cut Medicare payments to physicians by about $100 billion, a temporary respite that does little to thwart the upward spiral of costs over time. Medicaid is cut, for hospitals that treat the indigent, also without reforming the plan for the future. The plan makes no progress in accelerating corrections in the Government's gauge of inflation -- the fairest way to cut the deficit because it reduces Social Security benefits and raises tax collections to their proper levels.
The plan cuts taxes by about $85 billion through 2002 and by an additional $165 billion during the five years thereafter. None of the proposed tax cuts -- for capital gains, estates, college tuition and children -- make economic sense. None are carefully targeted to spur savings and investment. All will mostly bypass the poor, and the capital gains and estates measures will enrich a tiny tier of families atop the income ladder.
There are also virtues. The plan will extend health coverage to many uninsured children, reinstate government assistance to some disabled immigrants and create more workfare slots for childless adults who would otherwise be cut off from food stamps by last year's welfare law. The biggest plus is what the plan does not do -- whack discretionary spending, as under previous Congressional plans, by 25 percent or more.
The remarkable spectacle yesterday was how many politicians lined up in support. Senate Republicans appear firmly behind the agreement. So is Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader. In the House, only liberals were muttering misgivings. But there is a long path between yesterday's celebrations and actual legislation. What the White House and Congressional leaders must show is that the agreement does not push the deficits into the future or cut spending on valuable discretionary programs. If they meet both these tests, then there is at least some payback -- though no excuse -- for the uneven treatment of rich and poor.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Mexican Chief Turns Down U.S. Requests On Drug War

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 2

 BODY:
Three days before President Clinton's first visit here, President Ernesto Zedillo today strongly rejected two proposals by American law enforcement officials aimed at improving security for United States drug agents in Mexico and at detecting police corruption. He characterized the proposals as outrageous encroachments on Mexican sovereignty.
There can be "no further discussion" of a request that American anti-drug agents receive official permission to carry sidearms in Mexico for their own security, Mr. Zedillo said. And he dismissed a proposal that American officials administer polygraph tests to Mexicans applying for sensitive posts in the country's troubled anti-drug agencies. 
 "That's ridiculous!" Mr. Zedillo said. "Imagine if I told President Clinton that we want to have a hearing in Mexico to accept his Attorney General! I mean that's ridiculous."
The timing of Mr. Zedillo's statements and the vehemence with which he made them suggested that he was moving to pre-empt any United States arm-twisting for breakthrough agreements on anti-narcotics issues during Mr. Clinton's visit, especially since domestic critics of Mr. Zedillo have said he has cooperated too meekly with the United States Government.
"There is a line that's been drawn very strongly, and that is our sovereignty," Mr. Zedillo said.
In an interview with five American reporters in the presidential office here overlooking a grove of jacarandas, ablaze with purple blossoms, Mr. Zedillo also vaunted Mexico's economic recovery and said he would express to Mr. Clinton next week his view that only through extended development here can the flow of illegal Mexican migrant workers to the United States eventually be slowed.
"Historically," he said, "it's clear that no matter what you do, as long as there are differences in economic development, then the incentives will be powerful enough that people will go around purely legal barriers."
Most of today's questioning focused on narcotics issues, however, and Mr. Zedillo appeared eager to spell out Mexico's positions in advance. He said he intended to "mention again" Mexico's displeasure with Washington's annual certification process, under which Congress has required the State Department to issue report cards on other nations' anti-narcotics efforts.
"We've been outspoken on certification because we reject the concept," Mr. Zedillo said. "We believe it violates certain principles of international law. This, of course, I will mention to President Clinton again."
Measuring his words, Mr. Zedillo seemed to suggest that if the American Congress ever attempts to impose sanctions on Mexico, he might suspend all drug cooperation. "The moment this process has a consequence in Mexico -- any material or practical consequence -- then we will have to review the whole situation," Mr. Zedillo said.
Mr. Clinton's visit comes at a time when the Mexican economy is growing, and opinion polls show that Mexican workers are beginning to sense improvement. Partly as a consequence, Mr. Zedillo's own popularity is at one of the highest points since his December 1994 inauguration.
In contrast, Mexico-United States relations have soured in recent months, with American lawmakers and others lashing Mexico for pervasive corruption among its drug agents, and Mexicans hitting back with attacks on recently-passed United States immigration laws, seen here as harshly unfair to Mexican migrant workers. "Recent relations have been not too smooth," Mr. Zedillo said.
In this context, he took care to distinguish Mr. Clinton and his statements, which he characterized as friendly to Mexico, from the criticisms of the Mexican Government by American lawmakers and others, which Mr. Zedillo called "noise."
"If any president has been respectful of our domestic life, its been President Clinton," Mr. Zedillo said.
Since 1992, American drug agents operating in Mexico have been prohibited from carrying sidearms, although most of them wink at this rule, with the acquiescence of successive United States ambassadors. But after a series of murders last fall of Mexican officers who had been working with American agents, United States law enforcement officials requested anew that agents here be officially licensed to carry sidearms.
Thomas Constantine, director of the Drug Enforcement Administration, told Congress in February that Mexican Attorney General Jorge Madrazo Cuellar had told him Mexico "was looking at that and thought they could reach a solution."
Mr. Zedillo's statements today were his first on this issue, and they appeared to close it.
"I've told my people, whatever we can do to cooperate more, lets do it," he said. "But when I'm told that some people in the U.S. Government would like to see their agents armed in Mexico, I say no! The answer is no! No further discussion! Let's look for ways in which those people can be well-protected in Mexico, but we simply will not allow that. And that's that."
A D.E.A. spokesman, asked to respond to Mr. Zedillo's comments, said: "The firearms issue is of concern because of security concerns for D.E.A. agents in Mexico. However, D.E.A. is not currently involved in any ongoing negotiations."
Mexico's anti-drug programs all but collapsed in February, with the discovery that Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, the anti-drug chief, was on the payroll of the country's major trafficker.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Statements by Clinton and Congressional Leaders on the Agreement

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the statements of President Clinton; Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, and Speaker Newt Gingrich in announcing the agreement between Democrats and Republicans yesterday on balancing the budget, as provided by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:
 
President Clinton 
 Good afternoon, everyone. For more than four years now I have worked hard to pursue a strategy that would keep our economy growing and creating opportunity for the American people: giving people the chance to be rewarded for their labors and also imposing upon ourselves the discipline necessary to prepare for the future and to relieve ourselves of a lot of the problems that had been accumulated over the last several years, especially the deficit.
Now we have reached agreement, in broad but fairly specific terms that I am satisfied will do that, with the Republican leaders today, that would balance the budget by 2002, continue to increase our investments in education, in science and technology, in medical research, require us to continue to show great discipline in other areas and to continue to downsize some Government operations.
It would invest in doing what I think is important to be sure that we can move people from welfare to work who are going to be required to go to work. It would expand coverage to millions of children who presently do not have health insurance. It would restore cuts to benefits for legal immigrants who are in this country who have sustained injuries and other problems for which they would otherwise be eligible for benefits. It will extend the life of Medicare and secure the integrity of the Medicaid program between now and 2002. It will be the first balanced budget in three decades.
It's a good thing that it's coming today, when we learn that our unemployment rate had dropped to 4.9 percent for the first time in 24 years.
We know that we have the biggest decline in inequality in our work force since the 1960's, and we've seen our economy produce the largest number of new jobs since 1993 ever produced in a four-year period. That happened because a lot of the people standing up here with me right now had the courage to vote for a plan to bring the deficit down in 1993 and get the interest rates down and investments up.
This agreement will help us to finish the job. I have spoken several times over the last several days with Senator Lott and with Speaker Gingrich. I want to thank them personally for negotiating with me openly, candidly and, I'm convinced, in complete good faith. . . .
Let me give you just some of the details very quickly:
The plan will protect Medicare, extending the life of the trust fund for a decade, extending new benefits for annual mammograms and diabetes screening. Home health will be shifted from Part A to Part B. And there will be a modest premium for home health services, being phased in at $1 per month, a year.
Second, and perhaps most important, this budget meets my goal of making education America's No. 1 priority on the edge of the 21st century. It will have the largest increase in education funding in 30 years. It'll have the largest increase in Pell Grant scholarships in 20 years. It will help us to make sure that every 8-year-old will be able to read, every 12-year-old can log onto the Internet, every 18-year-old can go into college. I am very, very pleased that it will also include, in the tax-cut portion, aid to help people go on to college and to finance college education.
Third, as I said, it will extend health insurance to five million uninsured children. This is a major breakthrough in our efforts to move toward coverage for all Americans.
Fourth, it will give businesses incentives and work with mayors to hire people from welfare to work. It will also, as I said, address the concerns I raised in last year's law, restoring benefits to disabled legal immigrants and moderating excessive cuts in food stamps, along with giving the states a reserve so that if people would be unjustly cut off food stamps because they simply cannot go to work, the states will be able to avoid malnutrition and real harm to those people in these cases.
Fifth, it will protect the environment, providing funds to clean up 500 of our most dangerous toxic waste sites, cleaning up toxic sites in urban areas and adding resources for environmental enforcement.
Sixth, it includes tax relief for the American people, but -- thanks to the rules of the Senate and the agreement of the leaders -- the tax relief will be limited, and we'll know the dollar amount not only for the first five years, but for the second five years following, so that we will not run the risk of having an explosion in the deficit as a result of unintended leaks in the tax program, so that when we tell the American people we're going to balance the budget, we know we can keep it balanced, and we won't get ourselves back into the difficulties we've seen over the last 15 years. . . .
Everyone will find something that he or she disagrees with. Everyone could find something that he or she wishes were in the budget. There is no perfect agreement. But as I said, we know America is more prosperous when we have fiscal discipline, when we invest in our future, and when we do it in the right way. We have evidence of that.
It'll never get any easier to do this job. Senator Lott made that point to me on the phone the other night. He said, "You know, when you're doing well, it's easier to balance the budget than it is when you're not. This is not going to get any easier. We have to do it now." And I said, "I agree with you, and we are going to do it."
So I ask Americans of all political parties and all philosophies to look at this plan, give it your support. Let's balance the budget and get on about the new business of preparing America for a new century.
Speaker Gingrich
This is a very historic -- and I think for those of us up here a very emotional -- moment. This is a tremendous step forward for all Americans. Intermediate School 125 from the Bronx is visiting the Capitol today. There are many other young people, here in this Rotunda, at this press briefing. Their lives will be better, their economic future will be greater, their chance to earn a living, to have take-home pay, to buy a house will be better because of the agreement, on a bipartisan basis, that we reached today with the President. This is a great moment for our children, our grandchildren and our country. And we are proud to be part of that.

Senator Lott
Last November, when the American people re-elected Republican majorities in both the House of Representatives, while returning President Clinton to the White House, they sent a message to official Washington. The message was clear: Work together to finish the job of balancing the budget and ending the era of big Government. We listened to the American people. We listened to the American people, and the budget agreement we have reached responds to their call.
It is a compromise agreement with the principles of the President and the Congress being incorporated into what we have outlined in this budget agreement. It had to be that way; it had to include Republicans and Democrats in the Congress, House and Senate, and the President. That's the way our Government works.
But it is not a compromise on our principles. On the contrary, it keeps the faith with our children and their children to end the worsening burdens of national debt. It achieves a steady annual reduction in the Federal budget. Year after year, it comes down. And, ladies and gentlemen, for the first time in my service in Congress and that of Pete Domenici, who has worked on it for so many years, we will have a guaranteed balanced budget for the American people by the year 2002.
Through this budget, we will reach balance by cutting spending, not by raising taxes, ladies and gentlemen. Under this budget agreement, official Washington must learn to make do with less, while Americans will keep more of what they earn, and they will be able to save it and invest it in their own families. Families with children will finally get that child tax credit that they have been waiting for, so that they can do more on their own for their children. This budget vindicates our long Republican effort to preserve and protect Medicare for current and future generations, for my 83-year-old mother and for our 26-year-old and 29-year-old son.
This budget will foster the kind of enduring economic growth that means more good jobs and more opportunity and more freedom, especially for those who have been on the economic margins of our society. Because of what we do here today, this country can look forward to an era of prosperity, rooted not in the ambition of Government, but in the hopes of individual Americans. Even beyond the impact of lower taxes, which we have in this agreement, the consequences of a balanced budget will be nothing short of revolutionary in individual lives of the American people.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE: THE DEMOCRATS;
Despite Angry Colleagues, Clinton Unites His Party

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
On Thursday evening, with a budget deal imminent, Bill Clinton was once again being accused of treason by the liberal wing of his party.
In an angry two-and-a-half-hour session, Democrat after Democrat from the House told the President's chief of staff, Erskine B. Bowles, of their many problems with an agreement that they believed would undercut some of their party's basic principles. 
 But less than 24 hours later, Mr. Clinton was able to lance the Democratic anger, with the help of a fiscal bonus from a strong economy that allowed some last-minute additional spending and with Vice President Al Gore pushing particularly hard to address a Medicaid issue that might have left him vulnerable to a Democratic primary challenge.
So Mr. Clinton, surrounded by subdued Senate Democrats who were on a retreat in Baltimore, today somberly announced the five-year deal that he hoped would come into place as the legacy of his second term. "We have reached agreement in broad but fairly specific terms," he said. "It will be the first balanced budget in three decades."
For Mr. Clinton, the moment was a triumph, a bipartisan breakthrough on an issue that has bedeviled Washington for years. He has worked closely with Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, who kept distrustful Republicans at the negotiating table. And in the last two years, Mr. Clinton has pulled the Democratic Party along with him to support the goal of eliminating the deficit, once the province of Republicans.
"I think we've got a good shot of getting a majority of both parties in both houses" to vote for the budget, Mr. Clinton said today, "which has been my goal from day one. And if it happens, America will be much better off." Even Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, who had been expected to lead the liberal charge against the budget plan, said that he was "encouraged at the movement toward addressing Democratic concerns," although he left open the question of how he would vote.
But several Democrats said privately that while Mr. Clinton would most likely get a majority of Democrats in both houses to support the plan, the Democrats' feeling that they had been largely shut out of the negotiating process had left them bruised and mistrustful of Mr. Clinton. The President's advisers predicted that the bad feelings would abate.
As a result of the turmoil, it is as unclear as ever whether Mr. Clinton, the only Democratic President to be re-elected to a second term since President Franklin D. Roosevelt, will succeed in reshaping his party in his own image or whether he will have less sway as he looks toward his legacy and House Democrats look toward the next election, in 1998.
For Mr. Clinton, the agreement to balance the budget culminates a process that began two years ago, after the Republicans seized control of Congress for the first time in more than half a century. In June 1995, with a Presidential election before him and a Republican political strategist counseling him to stand equidistant from the two political parties, President Clinton broke with Congressional Democrats to endorse the Republicans' call for a multiyear plan for a balanced budget.
Having co-opted the Republicans on the issue of fiscal integrity, Mr. Clinton turned the subsequent debate to how to balance the budget -- focusing on protecting traditional Democratic constituencies on Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment. The Republicans overplayed their hand in 1995 and tried to push through their own budget plan by twice shutting down the Government. In January 1996, they walked out of the budget talks.
That kept Mr. Clinton from ever having to make a deal that could rupture his party and left Democrats free in 1996 to campaign both on the theme that they wanted to balance the budget and on the refrain that they wanted to "protect" Medicare and Medicaid.
But this year, after Mr. Clinton failed to bring a Democratic Congress into office with him, his interests and those of Congressional Democrats threatened to diverge. Most of the advisers who had once served as Mr. Clinton's ties to Congressional Democrats left at the beginning of his second term, including Leon E. Panetta, the chief of staff who had previously served in the Congress and been the House Democrats' budget negotiator.
He was replaced by Mr. Bowles, a less ideological businessman whom Republicans praised this week as essential to bringing about an agreement even as Democrats sparred with him in closed-door caucuses.
One frustration of the Democrats was Mr. Clinton's decision to negotiate with the Republicans this spring, instead of forcing them to go through the traditional process of drafting and voting first on their own budget plan. With an eye toward next year's Congressional elections, Democrats wanted such a program set out in public so that they could force votes that would show them to be more supportive of popular domestic programs than the Republicans.
But White House officials say Mr. Clinton decided that the time was ripe to negotiate after Republican leaders made conciliatory comments this spring about scaling back the size of the tax cut they wanted and being flexible on an economic assumption.
Mr. Lott said today that the turning point in four months of negotiations had come when Mr. Clinton had become personally involved in the talks several days ago.
By midweek, negotiators had the outlines of a deal that gave Republicans many of the tax reductions they wanted, including cuts in the capital gains tax and the estate tax. The White House had most of the spending it sought for the President's priorities, including for education and for health insurance for children, to mitigate some reductions imposed by the welfare bill Mr. Clinton signed into law last year.
But it was soon clear that this was not enough for many House Democrats, who were incensed by the plan's call for savings in programs for the elderly and the poor at the same time that taxes were being reduced for some of the nation's wealthiest people.
Last night, Mr. Clinton's budget team reconnoitered in Mr. Bowles's office, aware that the White House risked losing a majority of House Democrats and looking to use a windfall caused by the improving economy to bring together more Democratic votes.
Mr. Gore himself, officials said, insisted though his chief of staff, Ronald Klain, that some of the money be used to remove a cap on Medicaid spending that the plan had envisioned.
Billions of dollars more were put into transportation. In consultations with lobbyists for the elderly, they decided to reduce the saving from the Medicare program. And they eliminated any legislative change in the cost-of-living index for Social Security recipients.
As his aides worked, Mr. Clinton personally called half a dozen House Democrats.
This morning, he telephoned Mr. Lott and Speaker Newt Gingrich to say he still was not satisfied that their tax cuts would not balloon after 2002 to reopen the deficit. By midday, he had a promise of a written assurance, and the agreement went forward.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE: THE BENEFITS;
Budget Negotiators Soften Impact of Cuts for Elderly

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
The economic windfall that put billions of additional dollars into the budget pot allowed negotiators today to soften the impact of their proposed cutbacks in Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security.
The last-minute revisions went far to assuage the concerns of the elderly, whose lobbyists said tonight that the agreement reached by President Clinton and Congressional Republicans had improved substantially in the last 36 hours and was now more acceptable to them. 
 Among the changes they applauded were the scaling back of an increase in monthly Medicare premiums to $1 from $8, the removal of a cap on Medicaid spending for the poor and the moderation of a proposed change in the Consumer Price Index that would have lowered Social Security and other Government benefit payments.
The budget negotiators said they had softened the effect of their plan on beneficiaries after adopting more optimistic economic assumptions, which produced higher estimates of expected revenues in the coming decade.
Martin A. Corry, director of Federal affairs at the American Association of Retired Persons, which has more than 33 million members, said tonight, "We want to get more details, but it appears that the package improved markedly in the last 36 hours."
Here are some highlights of the budget-balancing agreement, as provided by Congressional leaders and Administration officials:
*Projected spending on Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, would be reduced by $115 billion, or 8.5 percent, over the next five years.
*Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, now expected to run out of money in 2001, would remain solvent until 2008.
*The cost of home health care services, which has soared in recent years, would be shifted from the hospital trust fund to a separate Medicare trust fund, which pays doctors' bills. To help cover these costs, Medicare premiums, now $43.80 a month, would be gradually increased over the next five years. But beneficiaries would not have to pay the extra amounts if their family incomes were less than the official poverty level ($9,491 for an elderly couple) or as much as 20 percent above the poverty threshold.
*Projected Federal spending on Medicaid, the health program for low-income people, would be reduced by 3 percent, or $16 billion to $17 billion, over the next five years. Most of the savings would be achieved by cutting special payments to hospitals that serve large numbers of indigent patients.
At the last minute, negotiators dropped their plan to impose firm limits on Federal spending for each Medicaid beneficiary -- a "per capita cap," which would have saved $9 billion from 1998 to 2002. President Clinton had proposed such a cap, but it was vehemently opposed by governors of both parties and by advocates for children and the elderly.
The Federal Government would earmark $15 billion to $17 billion in the next five years for new initiatives to provide health insurance for children. The goal is to provide coverage for five million youngsters, or half of the nation's uninsured children. Budget negotiators did not say whether the money would be used to expand Medicaid, to provide lump-sum grants to the states or to finance some other approach.
Medicare would offer several new preventive health benefits, to help detect diabetes, colorectal cancer and breast cancer. Mr. Clinton proposed these benefits, and Speaker Newt Gingrich enthusiastically supported the proposal on diabetes.
Starting in 2000, the annual cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security benefits would be reduced slightly, compared with the amounts that would be paid under current law. Budget negotiators said this change would save perhaps $10 billion to $15 billion from 2000 to 2002. It is justified, they said, because many economists believe that the Consumer Price Index, used as a basis for computing the cost-of-living adjustment, overstates inflation.
House Republicans said the proposal would lower the cost-of-living adjustment by 0.1 to 0.25 of a percentage point -- less than $2 a month for a retired worker receiving the average Social Security benefit of $745 a month. Under the budget agreement, Congress will not legislate a specific cut, but assumes that the Bureau of Labor Statistics will make the appropriate "corrections" in the Consumer Price Index.
Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, said it was fortunate that the budget negotiators had dropped the idea of a cap on Medicaid spending because "that proposal wouldn't have flown anyway," given the opposition of governors and health care advocates.
Jose M. Zuniga, a spokesman for the AIDS Action Council, a lobbying group for people with AIDS, said, "We are thrilled that the Medicaid cap has apparently been dropped." But he said, "We are still concerned about the other cuts in Medicaid."

HEADLINE: Donald and Marla Are Headed for Divestiture

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
The moral of this story is that money can't buy happiness.
O.K., maybe that's not the moral. The moral is that great sex does not guarantee enduring love. 
 Well, that's probably not it either. But certainly the lesson to be taken from the news that the marriage of Donald J. Trump and Marla Maples is on the rocks has a great deal more to do with money and sex (not to mention power and fame) than with happiness and love.
Neither Mr. Trump, 50, the real-estate developer fond of having his name emblazoned on his holdings, nor Ms. Maples, 33, a model and sometime actress, chose to speak publicly yesterday -- a veritable news article in itself -- but the future former spouses issued a terse joint statement confirming their decision to separate, which was first reported in The New York Post.
"After a long relationship and a three-and-a-half-year marriage, we have decided to separate, as friends," the statement said.
The friendliness apparently extends to some business arrangements. Ms. Maples, a former beauty pageant contestant from Georgia, is expected to honor her commitment to be the host of the Miss Universe Pageant on May 16, which is to be held in Miami. Mr. Trump, along with CBS, owns the pageant.
The statement went on to make a distinctly uncharacteristic request: that the news media leave them alone. No mention was made of an impending divorce, the possibility of a reconciliation, a prenuptial agreement or the couple's 4-year-old daughter, Tiffany.
Mr. Trump, whose real estate empire includes Atlantic City casinos and New York City properties including the Trump Tower and the brand-new Trump International Hotel and Tower at 1 Central Park West, has a net worth estimated from $450 million, by Forbes magazine, to as much as $2.5 billion.
Mr. Trump is "really married to his business anyway," a person familiar with his portfolio and marital situation said yesterday, adding that the separation was Mr. Trump's idea and that it was happening now for reasons of economics. The prenuptial agreement, the person said, which would pay Ms. Maples $1 million to $5 million in the event of a divorce, is to expire within 11 months, after which she would be entitled to a settlement based on a percentage of Mr. Trump's net worth.
If his net worth is really $2.5 billion, "even if she were to get a small percentage, a small percentage is a lot of money," the person said.
This person, who insisted on anonymity, said Mr. Trump would live at the new building on Central Park West at Columbus Circle, Trump International, and that Ms. Maples would live temporarily at Trump Tower. Eventually, Mr. Trump will buy her a new apartment "in a regular, non-Trump building," the person said, adding that Tiffany "will be taken care of."
No third party is involved, the person said.
Mr. Trump, this person said, "has been forced economically to act."
"It would be a huge mistake to do otherwise. Unless you're married to someone you have 1,000 percent surety in, you just can't do that."
After meeting in 1988, Mr. Trump and Ms. Maples conducted an on-again, off-again, very public affair -- her declaration that sex with him was the best she ever had was only the most memorable headline-grabber -- that hastened the disintegration of Mr. Trump's first marriage.
Many friends of the couple were button-lipped yesterday, but some other acquaintances weren't.
"I couldn't believe my eyes when I saw the headlines in the paper this morning," said Liz Smith, the gossip columnist, referring to The Post, in which her own column had not a word on the matter. "I saw them at a benefit Wednesday night, and they looked very happy."
Chuck Jones, Ms. Maples's former publicity agent, who was released from prison last fall after his conviction for stealing shoes and undergarments was overturned, sounded a little pleased.
"I brought them together, and I take credit for breaking them apart," Mr. Jones said. "I won't tell you what that means."
Ms. Maples had already given birth to Tiffany when the couple married on Dec. 20, 1993, in a wedding attended by 1,000 people, whose guest list included O. J. Simpson, Howard Stern, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Rosie O'Donnell.
Mr. Stern, not usually known for his prudence, declined, through a spokesman, to comment yesterday, even on the subject of his own prophecy fulfilled.
"It's probably in bad taste, but I give it four months," he had said at the wedding.

HEADLINE: Clinton Hails F.D.R. At Memorial's Opening

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Hailed by President Clinton as "the greatest President of this great American century," Franklin Delano Roosevelt was placed alongside Washington, Jefferson and Lincoln in the nation's political pantheon today with the opening of a sprawling outdoor memorial honoring his leadership during World War II and the Great Depression.
"He electrified the nation, instilling confidence with every tilt of his head and boom of his laugh," Mr. Clinton declared in opening the 7.5-acre memorial devoted to the 32d President, who was chosen four times by American voters in the century's direst era. "His was an open, American spirit, with a fine sense for the possible and a keen appreciation of the art of leadership." 
 Sunshine poured across the Dakota red granite and roaring waterfalls of the $52 million memorial as Mr. Clinton snipped the opening ribbon. The memorial presents an unusual peripatetic approach to the life and times of Roosevelt -- from his signature call for "a rendezvous with destiny," etched now in stone, to the playful bronze statue of his dog Fala.
An hour after the President moved through on crutches, the public burst upon the grounds, searching out inklings and memories. Instantly, ordinary Americans were snapping pictures of themselves grinning alongside sculptured wraiths from the Great Depression.
Some sent the cash register whirring in the new F.D.R. memorabilia shop, buying wartime videos and enlistment posters, even before the first tableau about hardscrabble America could be reached. Others paused to wonder at a graceful statue of Eleanor Roosevelt, the first First Lady to be so honored in a national memorial. In one of the fine-tunings in the final rush to opening, her statue, hailing her as the first United States delegate to the United Nations, had to be minutely reset so that she leaned closer to the people.
"I planted trees for Roosevelt in the C.C.C.," said 79-year-old Francis E. Stueve, spry and exuberant amid the tourist buzz as he recalled the Civilian Conservation Corps. "I was at Pearl Harbor when the Japs attacked -- strafed the butter dish right off the mess hall table. Roosevelt deserves every bit of this."
War and hard times seemed a world apart on the breezy, brilliant day that saw several thousand guests and tourists gather for the opening, including Roosevelt's goddaughter, Princess Margriet of The Netherlands. Recalling Roosevelt's pride in his Dutch ancestry, the Princess presented bouquets of a new orange-toned rose named for him.
Despite Roosevelt's stated preference for a simple desk-sized memorial slab, which was placed outside the National Archives after his death in 1945, a determined, bipartisan memorial drive saw its effort realized today after a 42-year campaign. It included three design competitions, numerous delays, and $10 million in donations from the public, about a fifth of the cost.
"The America he built was a memorial all around us, from the Golden Gate Bridge to the Grand Coulee Dam; from Social Security to honest financial markets," Mr. Clinton declared of why the project never seemed particularly urgent across the last half-century.
The memorial, described by its designer Lawrence Halprin as a "walking environmental experience," overlooks the Tidal Basin, where the cherry blossoms bloom, and the east bank of the Potomac, with its vista of Arlington National Cemetery. The memorial is a mix of Depression and wartime images amid gentle outdoor scenes. The granite setting is laced with Roosevelt quotations, but David Roosevelt, the President's grandson, said the effect was to honor "not a man but an era in this nation's history."
Roosevelt is depicted grandly surveying the nation, seated and caped, war-weary but determined in a larger-than-life-sized statue.
"He did a good job," said Herman Cohen, an 82-year-old war veteran from Brooklyn, who savored his Commander in Chief's monumental place in the nation's history.
Among the early visitors was a group of disabled who celebrated the fact that President Clinton and others have begun calling for a clearer depiction of Roosevelt as wheelchair-bound. They were particularly curious about a replica of a wheelchair, cleverly designed by Roosevelt from a plain kitchen chair. It was on display in the gift shop, but not as a permanent part of the memorial.
President Clinton, reviewing Roosevelt's accomplishments, cited the latest unemployment figures to make the comparison that while 1 in 4 Americans was out of work in 1932, fewer than 1 in 20 is now.
"It is a strange irony of our time that, here at the moment of our greatest prosperity and progress in so many years," Mr. Clinton continued, "at this time where the pinnacle that Roosevelt hoped America would achieve, and our influence and power has come to pass, we still strangely fight battles with doubts, doubts that he would treat with great impatience and disdain."
Mr. Clinton, who has been criticized by some for ending the Federal welfare program for children that Roosevelt began, made no direct allusion to his own record. But he said, "The great legacy of Roosevelt is a vision and a challenge, not a set of specific programs but a set of commitments -- the duty we owe to ourselves, to one another, to our beloved nation, and increasingly to our fellow travelers on this small planet."
The President celebrated "F.D.R.'s famous flexibility of mind," and slapped the podium for emphasis in recalling how Roosevelt would not tolerate doubts.
"I ask you to remember what he was writing at Warm Springs when he died, that last speech," Mr. Clinton said. He then quoted Roosevelt's parting advice to the nation: "The only limit to our realization of tomorrow will be our doubts of today. Let us move forward with strong and active faith."

Hatfield and Senator Daniel K. Inouye joined Vice President Al Gore and his wife, Tipper, and First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton and President Clinton at the opening ceremonies. HEADLINE: News Analysis;
The Mantra For 1997: It's the Best Of Times

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
When it comes to economic news, it does not get much better than this.
Unemployment, the Government concluded today, fell below 5 percent for the first time in nearly a quarter of a century. Economic growth in the first quarter of the year, at 5.6 percent, was nearly double the predictions. 
 And in striking the broad outlines of a budget deal, Democrats and Republicans engaged in the kind of budget negotiation no one could have anticipated a year ago: haggling over what to do with an unexpected surge in Government revenues that, according to a Congressional Budget Office estimate that raced around Capitol Hill this morning, could bring an extra $200 billion to the Treasury over the next five years. (In minutes, they found several things to do with it.)
Spurred on by the dedication today of the Franklin D. Roosevelt memorial on the Mall, people in Washington even began talking in overarching terms about today's economy as the fulfillment of a grander vision.
"If we were in 1945 now on the day F.D.R. died," Michael Beschloss, the historian, said today, "and we tried to imagine the best scenario for a half-century later, this would be it: unemployment this low and a country that is at the center of an interdependent world economy."
Herbert Stein, the chairman of the council of economic advisers in the Nixon Administration, said today, "I remember when we held a press conference around this time in 1972 and I said what we had was the best combination of economic numbers in history -- and then I amended that to say I meant the Christian era of history." But the numbers then, he added, were reached somewhat artificially, with the benefit of price controls. "I think the numbers are even better now," he added, "because they are purer."
But good economic news always has a way of making people nervous, and this time is no exception.
The political impact of prosperity has been clear here this week. It has forestalled some truly difficult political choices as the White House and Congressional leaders raced to put together the budget package.
With the extra $200 billion in hand (the fact that it was a projection, and a rough one at that, was considered a small detail), both parties were able to sidestep a politically unpopular recalculation of the rate of inflation, a recalculation that would effectively lower the increases for Social Security recipients and other beneficiaries of entitlement programs. Most of the evidence suggests that the current inflation rate is significantly overstated.
But the political reality is that the good times helped Washington avoid a face-off with the politically powerful groups that represent the elderly, led by the American Association of Retired Persons.
The longer-term risks of celebrating good times, though, are harder to measure.
Countries have a way of convincing themselves that they have found the magic formula, to the point of ignoring disturbing signals of trouble -- Japan in the late 1980's comes to mind.
Markets have the same tendency. The Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, never stops reminding his aides that Wall Street traders -- he once was one -- move from extremes of optimism to extremes of pessimism even faster than politicians do. Every new sign of economic expansion, profit growth and budget peace only fuels what Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, termed "irrational exuberance" -- because the news makes exuberance seem a lot more rational.
And perhaps it is more rational. "Looking at the last 20 or 25 years, what has recently been going on is one hell of a lot better -- well significantly better -- than virtually anybody thought possible," said Charles L. Schultze, who headed the Council of Economic Advisers in the inflation-ridden days of the Carter Administration.
"If you had told me and 90 percent of my colleagues just three of four years ago that you could push the unemployment rate down to below 5 percent, and inflation would have for all practical purposes no uptick, we would have said that you are just plain wrong," he said.
Mr. Schultze has identified only one of several recent economic guesses that have turned wrong.
The Treasury and the Congressional Budget Office were not even close in predicting the kind of revenue that has flowed into Washington, the logical consequence of economic growth rates that were also underestimated. Of course, that is the kind of mistake everyone likes to discover. "The scary part," said one Treasury official early this week, "is that if you can't make good guesses six months out, what does that say about our ability to project a balanced budget five years out?"
Naturally, all this good news leads to the natural question: Can it last?
Perhaps the better way to put that question is whether the Federal Reserve will let it last, or whether Mr. Greenspan thinks the heat will come out of the economy of its own accord.
The conventional wisdom, naturally, is that the decline in the unemployment rate will force the Fed's hand when it meets on May 20, even without evidence of inflation.
Nonetheless, the bond markets, perhaps looking to the long term, decided this afternoon that maybe a budget deal was not such a bad idea after all. Worries about the Fed were put aside, and interest rates dropped after the news flashed across screens around the world.
That was exactly the reassuring vote of confidence the White House was looking for, whether the deal President Clinton announced was the best to be had or not.

HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE HITS 23-YEAR LOW

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
America's unemployment rate dropped in April below 5 percent, a level not seen since December 1973, when Richard M. Nixon was President, the Government reported today.
A startling three-tenths of a point decline in the jobless rate pushed it down to 4.9 percent, as factories recorded a new peak in overtime hours and the economy continued to advance at a healthy pace. While there were signs that the rapid economic growth of recent months was slowing, the evidence of further gains on the job front convinced many economists that the Federal Reserve remained on track to raise interest rates at least one more time, probably at its next meeting on May 20. 
 "Our economy is now the strongest it's been in a generation," President Clinton said, reflecting his view not only of the dazzling labor market but also of Wednesday's report that the first three months of this year posted the fastest growth, a 5.6 percent annual pace, since 1987. Indeed, several experts said the United States was enjoying a rare combination of low unemployment and low inflation not regularly experienced since the 1960's.
Instead of being frightened that the tight labor market would bring severe anti-inflation measures by the Federal Reserve, financial markets took today's report in stride. And with the help of the agreement between the White House and Congressional leaders to balance the budget, the stock market closed with strong gains that capped one of the most spectacular weeks on Wall Street in years. The Dow Jones industrial average closed today at 7,071.20 -- within just 14 points of its record high -- and the Nasdaq composite index of mostly technology-oriented smaller stocks posted even better gains.
As the first broad gauge of the economy's performance last month, today's labor market report was eagerly anticipated by analysts. Payrolls grew by a moderate 142,000 and average hourly earnings actually edged down slightly after two hefty increases.
"We are well within that lucky range where workers are receiving well-deserved real wage increases but there are still no signs of inflationary pressures," Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said in a statement.
Private analysts expressed relief at the various relatively soft spots in the Labor Department's report, including the fact that about half the improvement in the jobless rate came from a decline in the work force.
"I think the economy is now slowing of its own accord," said Martin Regalia, economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce. He said the Federal Reserve could probably not ignore such a low unemployment rate and would raise rates again this month but could then stop tightening monetary policy.
The decline in the unemployment rate to under 5 percent -- not seen since around the time of the first Arab oil embargo -- was something that tens of millions of workers in their 30's and early 40's had never experienced.
The jobless ranks dwindled by 430,000, benefiting all major demographic groups, but especially adult women and blacks. Regionally, the improvement was concentrated in the South and West. For women, the unemployment rate dropped to 4.4 percent from 4.7 percent and for blacks the rate eased to 9.8 percent from 10.7 percent.
The low jobless rate presented a still greater challenge to the many economists who had long contended that inflation would begin to accelerate if unemployment fell much below 6 percent, a condition that has now prevailed for more than two years.
Average hourly earnings, a fairly erratic measure, eased 1 cent in April after increases totaling 11 cents in the first three months of the year.
The tight job market also seemed likely to aid the nation's effort under the new welfare law to move recipients into paid jobs.
"If you can't do welfare-to-work at 4.9 percent, when in the world would you do it?" asked Jack Faris, president of the National Federation of Independent Business, a voice of small companies. He said that dire job loss predicted by conservatives and many of his own members as a result of raising the minimum wage last autumn did not occur because of tax breaks and other benefits enacted at the same time.
The Labor Department's survey of households, on which the jobless rate is based, showed a job gain of 209,000 -- a solid number but down sharply from the spectacular gain of 745,000 in March. The jobless rate shrank as well because of a rare recent decline in the labor force of 221,000.
Typically, a rapidly expanding economy pulls back into the work force many less skilled or less motivated people who might have dropped out but who now see renewed job prospects. Today's results hinted that this pool might finally be drying up after a long spell of buoyant labor force growth.
The report also showed a drop of nearly 300,000 in the category of the newly jobless, those out of work less than five weeks, and a further 29,000 decline in those idled for more than six months.
The department's survey of employers, meanwhile, showed a second consecutive month of subdued payroll growth. The 142,000 increase was not only less than expected but it was also calculated after a downward revision that cut the March gain by 36,000, to 139,000.
Put another way, payrolls expanded less than half as fast in March and April, taken together, as in January and February. But analysts noted unusual weather patterns this year that defied accurate adjustment for seasonal variation.
Construction jobs, for example, benefited from warm February weather but suffered from subsequent bad weather and contributed to a decline of 44,000 jobs in April. Last month, health services and engineering and management services added 34,000 and 29,000 jobs, respectively, while all major components of the finance, insurance and real estate category contributed to a total gain of 23,000.
On the other hand, factory jobs eased 14,000 despite five hours of weekly overtime for those working. That was the greatest amount of overtime since the Government began tracking it in 1956. The lost jobs were mostly in the motor vehicle industry, where there was a strike involving 3,500 workers as well as some temporary plant shutdowns to control inventories.
Over all, the workweek for the private sector contracted by 18 minutes, the report also showed, contributing to a decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 139.6, in the index of aggregate weekly hours.
Another sign of economic slackening, analysts said, was a third consecutive monthly decline in the proportion of industries adding jobs, now 54.2 percent, down from a recent peak of 63.1 percent in October.
The Northeast and Midwest had virtually unchanged jobless rates last month of 5.4 percent and 4.1 percent, respectively, while the rate dropped seven-tenths of a point in the South, to 4.7 percent, and three-tenths of a point in the West, to 5.7 percent.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL 3-7
 
Blair Takes Over At 10 Downing Street
Tony Blair, the leader of Britain's Labor Party, entered 10 Downing Street to the jubilant cheers of flag-waving supporters, and in keeping with his campaign of restrained expectations, promised them "a Government of practicable measures in pursuit of noble causes." 1
 
Former Prime Minister John Major asked the Conservative Party to pick a new leader soon and spent a sunny afternoon watching cricket. 7
 
Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, won a parliamentary seat from Northern Ireland in the British elections, as did the party's second-ranking official, Martin McGuinness. Neither man will take up his seat, however, because Sinn Fein policy precludes them from taking the required loyalty oath to the British Crown. 7
 
No Meeting of Zairians
Diplomatic efforts to bring President Mobutu Sese Seko and the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, together for shipboard talks fell through when Mr. Kabila stood up his rival, refusing to fly to the vessel for security reasons. Mr. Kabila's decision came after the meeting, which was expected to transfer power between the two men, had already been delayed for several hours by Mr. Mobutu. 1
 
Russia Cedes Point on NATO
Russia dropped a major demand on limiting NATO's military forces, improving the prospects that the two sides will meet a May 27 target date for completing an agreement between the alliance and its former adversary. 3
 
River Crests in Manitoba
Residents of Winnipeg, Manitoba, watched the flooding Red River reach its crest without overwhelming the city's main lines of defense. Around 24,000 Canadians in small towns south of the city have been forced to leave their homes since the floodwaters crossed the border with North Dakota. 4
 
Mexico Rejects U.S. Proposals
President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico rejected a proposal that would allow United States drug agents to carry arms in Mexico, and another that would let American officials administer lie-detector tests to Mexicans applying for sensitive posts in Mexico's anti-drug agencies. 4
 
Talks On North Korea Set
American, Japanese and South Korean officials are to meet in Tokyo next week to try to find a way to get North Korea to attend peace talks. Japan's Foreign Ministry said the meeting would also address severe food shortages in the North. President Clinton has said the West would provide large-scale food aid and help North Korea rebuild its economy after it entered peace talks. Red Cross officials from the two Koreas will meet in Beijing today to discuss relief aid for the North. While withholding major government assistance, South Korea has lifted a ban on civilian food aid to the North. (AP)
 
NATIONAL 8-13
 
Budget Deal Is Reached, With Help of Windfall
The Clinton Administration reached agreement with the Republican leadership on a plan to balance the Federal budget in five years, using a last-minute financial windfall from a strong economy to help forge a deal that could alter the nation's economic and political landscape. 1
 
Less than 24 hours after the liberal wing of his party was once again accusing him of treason, President Clinton was able to lance the Democratic anger, with the help of the fiscal bonus that allowed some last-minute additional spending. 13
 
Assuaging Budget Concerns
Lobbyists for the elderly applauded some of the last-minute revisions in the budget plan. Among them were the scaling back of an increase in monthly Medicare premiums to $1 from $8, the removal of a cap on Medicaid spending for the poor and the moderation of a proposed change in the Consumer Price Index that would have lowered Social Security and other Government benefit payments. 12
 
Member Leaves Texas Group
Four days after a member of the Republic of Texas secessionist group was returned from jail to the group's mountain compound in return for two hostages, he walked out of the cramped trailer there and surrendered to state law-enforcement officers. "I had to get out of there," the authorities quoted him as saying. "I couldn't take it anymore." 8
 
White House to Appeal Ruling
The White House said that it would appeal a ruling by a Federal court ordering it to turn over to Whitewater investigators notes taken by Government lawyers of conversations they had with the President's wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton. 10
 
2d Soldier Guilty in Killings
A jury convicted a second white former Army paratrooper on murder and conspiracy charges in the killings of a black couple in North Carolina in 1995. The former soldier, Malcolm Wright Jr. of Lexington, Ky., was found guilty of two counts of first-degree murder and one count of conspiracy to commit first-degree murder in the deaths, near Fort Bragg. 10
 
Roosevelt Memorial Opens
Franklin Delano Roosevelt was placed alongside Washington, Jefferson and Lincoln in the nation's political pantheon with the opening of a sprawling outdoor memorial honoring his leadership during World War II and the Great Depression. Arguments in Tobacco Case
A jury heard closing arguments in the trial of a wrongful-death suit against R. J. Reynolds Tobacco. The case is being watched closely by Wall Street for its potential effect on tobacco stocks. 8

A Brooklyn grand jury has cleared two police officers in the killing of an unarmed man whom they shot after he entered a stolen car they had under surveillance in East Flatbush, prosecutors said. Jobless Rate Drops Sharply
America's unemployment rate dropped below 5 percent in April, a level not seen since 1973, when Richard M. Nixon was President, the Government reported. A startling three-tenths of a point decline in the jobless rate pushed it down to 4.9 percent, as factories recorded a new peak in overtime hours and the economy continued to advance at a healthy pace. 1
 
When it comes to economic news, it does not get much better than this. And yet good economic news always has a way of making people nervous, and this time is no exception. 37

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Clinton and Republicans Agree to Balance Budget
The Clinton Administration and the Republican leadership agreed to balance the Federal budget in five years. Facilitating the deal, which could alter the nation's economic and political landscape, was a decision by the Congressional Budget Office to slash its deficit estimates for coming years. 
 Both sides claimed victory. President Clinton cited new spending for education, health insurance for children, welfare benefits and other programs, while basically protecting Medicare. Republicans gained a big tax cut, including a reduction in the capital gains tax, and were successful in scaling back overall domestic spending. [Page 1.]
 
Jobless Rate Tumbled to 4.9%
The nation's unemployment rate dropped a startling three-tenths of a point in April to 4.9 percent, a level not seen since 1973, as factories recorded a new peak in overtime hours. Payrolls grew by a moderate 142,000, and average hourly earnings edged down slightly after two hefty increases, showing an absence of inflationary pressure. [1.]
 
Bulls Sweep Treasury Markets
The bulls made a clean sweep in the Treasury markets this week, with prices rising and yields falling as data suggested the economy was not advancing too rapidly. The 30-year bond rose 16/32 yesterday, to 9629/32 , yielding 6.88 percent, down more than a quarter of a percentage point, for the week. [40.]
 
GPU Considers Sale of Nuclear Unit
One of the two units of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, the site of the nation's worst nuclear accident, may be put up for sale, the owner, GPU Inc., said. The unit that had the accident, which led to a partial meltdown on March 28, 1979, was permanently shut down. The adjacent unit -- the one to be sold -- has been operating steadily and has received good performance ratings by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. [39.]
 
G.M. Cuts Electric Car Leases
Seeking to get more of its limited-range electric cars on the road, General Motors lowered the lease rates for the vehicle, the EV1, which was introduced in Southern California and Arizona in December, by 25 percent -- still $399 to $549 a month -- and agreed to help pay for quick construction of 50 public charging stations. [38.]
 
Boeing Accused on Defective Parts
The Justice Department accused Boeing of knowingly allowing defective parts to be installed in hundreds of Chinook military helicopters, two of which crashed. Boeing denied the accusation. [38.]
 
Arguments Made in Tobacco Case
In an overflowing Florida courtroom, lawyers for both plaintiffs and R. J. Reynolds Tobacco presented five hours of closing arguments in a wrongful-death trial that is being watched closely on Wall Street. [8.]
 
Tiny Fractions for Big Board Stocks
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange, where stocks have been traded in increments of 1/8 of a dollar -- 12.5 cents -- for the Big Board's entire history, began trading in half-sized increments -- 1/16 , or 6.25 cents. There were even some trades at 1/32 , or increments of 3.125 cents. Two third-market firms instituted the change; prices on the floor must still be quoted in eighths. [38.]
 
Dollar Rallies Against Yen and Mark
The dollar rallied after a Swiss central banker said he was not concerned about the currency's strength, and the Labor Department reported a plunge in unemployment. In New York, the dollar settled at 126.57 yen, up from 126.51 yen on Thursday and at 1.7293 marks, up from 1.7217. [36.]
 
Gasoline Futures Prices Tumble
Gasoline futures prices tumbled on signs that production and imports were keeping supplies ample in the United States. On other markets, soybeans rose. [36.]
 
Brazilian Sale Seen, Despite Delay
Despite this week's unexpected court-ordered delay in the Brazilian Government's sale of shares in its state-owned mining company, billed as the largest privatization ever undertaken in Latin America, most analysts expect the sale to take place ultimately. The question is when. News Analysis. [4.]

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE: NEWS ANALYSIS;
The Giving And Taking

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
As a political matter, the budget-balancing accord announced today was a substantial accomplishment for a Democratic President and a Republican-led Congress.
The President accepted the Republican principles of tax cuts for the rich and the middle class and abandoned the Democratic theme of protecting Medicare from cuts at all costs. In return, he got some extra money he wanted for education and welfare. 
 Republicans got their tax cuts for families and investors and some savings in domestic programs. But they dropped the plans they had in 1995 and 1996 for crippling Medicare and Medicaid, abolishing Government departments and agencies, expanding the military and relaxing environmental protections.
So the accord claims enough of the middle ground that it may actually hold up over the years. But history shows that budget deals are always tenuous, partly because the rank and file does not participate in the negotiations and thus cannot be counted on for the painful votes to come, and partly because times change so much over a few years that commitments cannot be kept.
The agreement struck today is, after all, only a skeleton. Later this year, the politicians must face questions of flesh and blood. Will Republicans really vote for bills this year that appropriate much more money than they want to spend for education and the arts? Will Democrats vote to abolish taxes on million-dollar inheritances and to lower taxes on capital gains when three-quarters of the taxes on investment profits go to taxpayers with annual incomes of more than $200,000? Will the President who blasted Republicans mercilessly during last year's election campaign for wanting to cut Medicare now spend the rest of the year rounding up votes for lower Medicare payments and higher premiums?
It is much easier to talk generally about such matters, as was done today, than it is to vote on them specifically.
"Keep in mind," President Clinton cautioned in Baltimore this afternoon, "this is an agreement. It still must be embodied in law."
Further, experience shows how politically risky it is for a President to work around lawmakers from his own party and strike a deal with the opposition party.
That is what happened in 1990, the only other time a President has negotiated a budget deal behind closed doors with leaders of the opposition. Then, President George Bush agreed with the Democratic Congress to raise taxes.
He never recovered from the perception that he had forsaken the bedrock Republican principle of no new taxes. That was an important element in his election defeat two years later.
Of course, Mr. Clinton is not running for re-election the way Mr. Bush was. But he does have more than three and a half years left in his term. The Republicans conducting the Congressional hearings this summer on campaign finance practices will almost certainly not cut him any slack because he worked with them on the budget. But Democrats on whom the President must rely for support at those hearings may still have their noses out of joint because of the way they were more or less locked out of budget deliberations.
The most important history lesson may be that five-year promises are hard to keep. Politicians have often pledged frugality one year and then reneged in later years when the belt-tightening really began to pinch.
Ever since 1978, when legislation was approved stating that spending "shall not exceed" receipts, one law after another has been enacted promising a balanced budget. And every one so far has been abandoned when the time came for actual families and companies and interest groups to pay higher taxes or give up Government services.
This time, as President Clinton said today, "the growth in the economy made it easier than it would otherwise have been."
Indeed, the strong economy led to tax receipts in April so much larger than expected that the deficit this year is now forecast to be just $75 billion, only 60 percent as large as the Government projected just three months ago when Mr. Clinton's budget was published.
That leads to this caution: The budget agreement is predicated on the idea that the economy will not falter in the next five years. But good times cannot last forever.
Since economists began keeping reasonably reliable records after the Civil War, the longest period without a recession in the United States has been 8 years and 10 months -- from February 1961 until December 1969. The economy has now been expanding for 6 years and 2 months, since March 1991. If it continues to grow steadily until October 2002, the period covered by the budget agreement, the economy will have gone without a recession for more than three years longer than has ever happened before.
Maybe that will occur. But just Thursday night, the budget negotiators learned that they had $200 billion more than anticipated because of re-estimates by the Congressional Budget Office that took account of the unusually strong economy.
If small, unexpected changes for the good can lead to that much more revenue, then imagine the damage that big changes for the bad, like a recession, can do. If the economy turns sour -- or even if growth is just a percentage point or two lower than expected -- today's agreement will not lead to a balanced budget.
And here is another caution: politicians have the propensity to put off the hard choices. That gives them the option of changing their minds.
In the five-year budget plan Mr. Clinton submitted to Congress in February, 75 percent of the deficit reduction was scheduled for the last two years. That would have allowed many of the spending cuts to be set aside if they became too painful.
Neither the White House nor the Congressional committees would reveal today how much bitter medicine in their agreement had been put off until the later years. The final calculations have not been made, officials at both ends of town said.
But this bears watching next week. In any deal, savings will appear larger in the later years because of annual compounding. But if the final numbers show that more than 60 percent or 65 percent of the savings are to occur in 2001 and 2002, then the credibility of the entire arrangement will be subject to question.
