HEADLINE: Question After Hong Kong: Is Taiwan Next for Beijing?

SERIES: WAITING FOR CHINA: Jitters in Taiwan

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: KAOHSIUNG, Taiwan

 BODY:
As champions of the Taiwan independence movement, Wesley J. D. Yu and his family have built a political dynasty in this seaport city, where harbor cranes soar above a horizon of cargo containers stacked along a vast waterfront. It is a vista that evokes the economic vibrancy of this island off China's southeastern coast.
But these days Mr. Yu, a provincial assemblyman, also speaks with surprising frankness about the possibility that Taiwan might some day reunite with its longtime enemy China -- especially after Hong Kong returns to Chinese sovereignty on July 1. 
 "Just as the United States is a confederation of states, maybe we could be confederated with mainland China," he said recently, striding across the broad concrete pier of Kaohsiung port where cargo ships were hoisting their loads.
"We have to be more realistic, and not just talk in theories," he continued, ticking off the conditions that would have to be fulfilled. "We want our own military, our own foreign policy and our own officials. We have to have our dignity and our security. And China has to give us a promise that they will not use force to reunify. They have to change their policy, and then maybe we could reunite."
Mr. Yu spoke like a man sure of his terms, but who also knew that the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule would start a clock ticking, counting down to a political reckoning for the 21 million people of Taiwan, who are asking: Are we next?
Nearly five decades after Taiwan became the exile home of Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist Government, the end of colonial rule in Hong Kong this year, and in Macao in 1999, has reawakened the prospect that Beijing may soon set a deadline for union with Taiwan.
This long-deferred question has suddenly become one of Asia's major security concerns.
For the people of Taiwan, but also for the United States, whether the island's fate is settled through peaceful negotiation or under the threat of force from Beijing will help determine the level of Asian instability in the future. And as was demonstrated little more than a year ago when missiles were fired toward Taiwan from the mainland, it could draw the United States into a direct confrontation with China.
As the weeks count down for the people of Hong Kong, there is no keener audience watching every step of Beijing's management of the transition than the one here.
"In Hong Kong, they have no choice but to accept their fate, but Taiwan is different," said Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, of which Mr. Yu and his family are prominent members.
"However, we believe Chinese pressure on Taiwan is going to become greater and greater, and all the people in Taiwan are really worried."
Taiwan today is an island of contradictions. Politically, the supremacy of the governing Nationalist Party, long committed to reunification with the mainland, is being undermined by a growing independence movement. President Lee Teng-hui, the first native Taiwanese to lead the party, has more closely allied himself with separatist voters as a way to straddle the island's politics.
And economically, an army of Taiwan business executives is investing on the mainland despite Government efforts to curb the two societies' growing interdependence.
 
American Military Pulled Out in 1979
When the Communists chased their army into the sea at the end of the 1945-49 civil war, the exiled Nationalists used dictatorial rule to turn this mountainous island into their fortress. Their efforts were backed by an American security guarantee that included basing tactical nuclear weapons here in the 1950's.
But in 1979, the American military left as Washington switched its diplomatic recognition to Beijing and adopted a Taiwan policy of "unofficial" relations and low-key military assistance to insure the island's defense.
In the last decade, Taiwan has evolved into a thriving democracy and an economic powerhouse very much in charge of its own destiny. Taiwan today, modern and free, seems a nation in everything but name.
Just south of the port at Kaohsiung lies a sprawling oil refinery that supplies 80 percent of the gasoline in Taiwan, which has among the world's highest densities of automobiles.
"If mainland China fired one of these new missiles into that refinery, the whole island could come to a standstill," said Wang Chien-shien, a respected political figure who quit the Nationalist Party after 36 years to help form the New Party, dedicated to clean government and eventual reunification with the mainland.
Last year China held belligerent military exercises in the Taiwan Strait and fired missiles to target zones just off Kaohsiung and Keelung, Taiwan's main ports. That prompted Washington to send two aircraft carrier battle groups in a show of American resolve to preserve the peace.
The region remains jittery after the crisis of 1995-96, set off when President Clinton granted President Lee a visa to visit the United States, an act Beijing believed was intended to encourage the pro-independence bent that Mr. Lee has indulged.
 
The Old Policy Was Just to Wait
Since 1972, when President Nixon began the process of re-establishing relations with Beijing, the question of Taiwan has been deliberately deferred. The strategic readjustment that downgraded Taiwan's status in the world was founded on the expectation that, in time, the two societies would be drawn back together.
Today, the concept of "one China" and the policy of deferral are under challenge. The tide of the pro-independence movement, now supported by a quarter to a third of Taiwan's electorate, is so strong that it threatens to overtake a majority of the island's municipal governments in elections this year and wrest control of the national legislature from the Nationalists by 2000.
To hold on to power, President Lee has courted the pro-independence faction to the point that many members of his own party doubt his commitment to reunification, and defections from Mr. Lee's party are now legion.
"I think in President Lee's mind he supports Taiwan independence," Mr. Yu said. "But he cannot say it; he can only act on it."
 
If Independence Gains, Will Beijing Act?
The danger in the next one to two years, Mr. Wang says, is that as Taiwan's internal politics continues to drift toward a pro-independence majority, Beijing's rulers will feel the pressure to act.
"If the independence party has a big win, what is China to think other than Taiwan is going for independence?" Mr. Wang asked. "China will say, 'We cannot wait anymore; we have to do what we have to do.' "
When Deng Xiaoping, then China's senior leader, crafted the "one country, two systems" guarantee for Hong Kong, his goal was to reassure the British Government and the colony's residents that they could maintain everything they had worked for even as China's red flag was hoisted over the territory.
Now, Deng's heir, President Jiang Zemin, is offering the same deal to the people of Taiwan, who seem less willing to buy it. Mr. Jiang has pledged, as Deng did, that Taiwan could keep and maintain a separate military, and he has suggested that one or more Taiwan leaders could come to Beijing to serve in top positions, including the Chinese vice presidency.
That proposal was met with deep skepticism, both by the Government and other political parties.
"It didn't excite people here," said Alice Kao, a prominent New Party legislator.
"Hong Kong is a colony; it is not a sovereign state," said Chao Jen-ho, a former special assistant to President Lee and now secretary general of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation. The foundation was the vehicle Taiwan used to open the first political dialogue with the mainland in 1993, only to see that dialogue shut down by Beijing in retaliation for Mr. Lee's visit to the United States in 1995.
There is now a flood of investment on the mainland by entrepreneurs from Taiwan. Thousands of companies have plowed more than $20 billion in investment into businesses on the mainland, often sending their money through bank accounts in the Cayman Islands or other offshore money havens to evade Government detection.
The economic integration between Taiwan and the mainland is the same kind of bonding that has connected Hong Kong and mainland Chinese industrialists, creating a common interest that will provide a force for stability after July 1.
Many economists argue that Taiwan investment on the mainland, together with investment from Japan and the West, creates pressure on China to open its markets further and to establish the rule of law. Taiwan, they point out, may soon enter the World Trade Organization and cannot hope to exclude mainland China from its market it if does so.
The most aggressive of Taiwanese investors may be Wang Yong-ching, 82, chairman of Taiwan Plastics. Earlier this year, he announced that he was going ahead with plans to invest $3 billion in a power plant in Fujian, the Chinese province that faces Taiwan across the strait and whose people speak a common dialect with the Taiwanese.
Not only did the island's pro-independence forces attack Mr. Wang's investment plan as playing into Beijing's strategy of offering "economic enticements," but President Lee also invoked national interests in forbidding the venture.
"Our policy is still to discourage businesses from going," said Su Qi, the Government spokesman in Taipei. "We are now trying to hold back the biggies like Taiwan Plastics, and we have put our foot down."
In public, Mr. Wang has acquiesced, but his associates say he is secretly going forward, channeling his funds through offshore subsidiaries because he believes that investment on the mainland is the best way to connect Taiwan with the global economy.
"He says he is an older man than President Lee, and he has not time to play these games," a close associate said. Mr. Lee is 75.
 
Waiting for Congress Of Communist Party
In the interregnum between Hong Kong's assimilation and whatever awaits Taiwan, the people, the Government and the military seem to be preparing for the next crisis.
One important milestone will be the 15th Communist Party Congress, which convenes this fall. If President Jiang is affirmed as Deng's clear successor, he may also emerge with a mandate to make a new offer -- or demand -- to Taiwan. "People are very conservative about making any predictions before the 15th Party Congress," said Ms. Kao of the New Party.
Meanwhile, Mr. Lee is strengthening his hand to respond to whatever challenge the mainland hands him. Next month, a constitutional convention will enhance his powers, giving him the right to dissolve Parliament in a crisis.
And Taiwan's military is rapidly adding high-technology weapons to its arsenal.
Ordinary Taiwanese seem to regard the whole drama with cynicism or indifference, a mask for their deeper concerns.
"People here feel like they have been walking on a tightrope for two to three years now," said Andrew Yang, whose research organization analyzes relations between Taiwan and the mainland. "So they are already up there, practicing their balance all the time with great risk. They are working without a net."
"But the effect is that practice increases your confidence in your skill," he added.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE: THE CALCULATIONS;
The Negotiators Forgo A Cut in Inflation Index

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Congress and the Clinton Administration backed down yesterday, declining to impose on the nation an outsized reduction in the Consumer Price Index as part of their budget agreement. Instead, they decided simply to accept a future change expected to be made in the index, the nation's best-known inflation measure, by the statisticians and the economists who calculate it.
Some of the nation's most powerful figures, including Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, had embraced the view that the index overstates inflation by more than a percentage point. 
 A reduction by that amount would have eliminated billions of dollars in Federal outlays tied to the index, thus easing the task of reaching the budget agreement.
But the negotiators for the two sides decided not to legislate any change in the index, an option they had considered until yesterday. Rather, the economic assumptions incorporated in their agreement anticipate a small cut in the index, in keeping with a change the technicians are likely to make anyway.
"My reaction is that any step in the right direction is a good thing, but there is still a lot of bias left in the C.P.I.," said Michael J. Boskin, a Stanford University economist who headed a commission, appointed by the Senate Finance Committee, that had recommended a big adjustment, arguing that the index overstated inflation by 1.1 percentage points.
Mr. Boskin's hope had been that the nation's economists would publicly endorse the findings of his panel, itself made up of five prominent economists. That would have greatly helped Congress and the Administration to make downward adjustments in Social Security benefits and other Federal outlays pegged to the index, since they could have argued that they were doing so for technical reasons and not largely for the sake of cost-saving expediency.
But the consensus of economists in support of the Boskin commission's findings never materialized. And the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, which calculates the index each month, said that while it agreed with the commission in principle, a number of the panel's findings documenting its conclusion were empirically unsound.
In the end, negotiators for Congress and the Administration found ways to come up with a balanced-budget agreement without having to embrace the commission's politically touchy recommendation, which was staunchly opposed by powerful lobbying groups like the American Association of Retired Persons.
"There was considerable uneasiness among Democrats and some Republicans about a legislated C.P.I. change," said one Democratic Congressional aide.
The Boskin commission had argued, in effect, that value judgments were a necessary tool in calculating the index. It said the Bureau of Labor Statistics failed to take quality improvements of products sufficiently into account and also failed to allow for the "substitution effect."
The commission reasoned that if a motorist, for example, pays an extra two cents a gallon for gasoline at a self-service pump that accepts the motorist's credit card for payment, that two cents pays for a quality improvement: the convenience of paying by credit card. The two cents therefore should not be counted as inflation, the commission held, the sort of conclusion the bureau challenged as statistically difficult to defend.
The commission also noted, correctly, that the bureau failed to allow for substitution. If romaine lettuce, for example, rises in price while iceberg lettuce does not, then people buy more iceberg and less romaine to acquire enough lettuce at roughly the same cost. The bureau currently notes in its calculation of the index only the price increase for romaine, not the shift in purchases to buy enough lettuce without spending more.
The bureau is experimenting now with a mathematical formula designed to estimate this substitution effect, going forward with the research although a few economists argue that the formula is itself a flawed concept. The outcome of the research is to be announced late this year, and, if it yields results, they will be incorporated into the calculation of the index in early 1999.
Hewing to this schedule, the budget negotiators incorporated into their economic estimates the effects on Government spending of a 0.15-percentage-point reduction in the index starting in 1999, guessing that this will be the adjustment the bureau actually makes in January or February of that year.
"That is their estimate, not ours," said Brent Moulton, the bureau official heading the research. "The only estimate we have given is zero to 0.25, and we don't have any more precise estimate at this point."
The shift from romaine to less expensive iceberg lettuce is called substitution within a single category. The bureau has also gathered data on another recommendation of the Boskin commission, to allow for shifts across categories: when the price of beef rises, for instance, consumers buy less beef and greater quantities of less expensive chicken or fish, to maintain the same standard of living without spending more.
But bureau officials say that accommodating for shifts across categories would be a lot harder to incorporate in the index on a month-to-month basis.
The political stakes in this dispute are great, of course. Various Federal and state subsidies for the poor, as well as pensions for retirees, rise in tandem with the Consumer Price Index, which is also used to adjust tax brackets.
But there is another process in play that is also sensitive: the gradual shift in the index from a measure of price changes to a measure of how much additional money a person or household must spend to maintain a given standard of living.
That involves value judgments that the Boskin commission and some politicians are more willing to embrace than are the bureau and other experts.
Further, the commission found itself criticized for failing to incorporate quality deterioration that adds to the cost of living -- the cost of security devices, for example, to protect a home against rising crime.

HEADLINE: About New York;
From Welfare To Workfare, A Dead End

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
BEFORE Yolanda De Jesus got her workfare assignment recently, she had high hopes for her high-tech background. Maybe she would get a chance to use the computer skills she had learned in school or the managerial experience from her last job at an office machine company.
She wound up sweeping trash in a housing project. 
 "I have skills that take me higher," she said. "But that's all they had to offer."
She fashioned her own version of welfare reform. She left the trash patrol after one day and enrolled in a computer class offered by the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, or Sobro. She's gambling that she will have learned enough new skills to land a job before the welfare office cuts her benefits because she refused her workfare assignment.
The Human Resources Administration is punishing her "for not going through their program and taking it upon myself for going to school," she said at Sobro's center on East 149th Street. "Welfare reform doesn't help you get educated. When you do it yourself, you break the rules."
Ms. De Jesus is part of the surge in welfare recipients seeking help with interviewing techniques, resume writing and word processing, as they navigate the transition from dependence to self-sufficiency. Many of them arrive with new-found anxiety after workfare assignments that lead nowhere, said Plinio Ayala, the director of operations at Sobro's training center.
"This whole push for workfare has created a sense of urgency," Mr. Ayala said. "The competition out there is a lot stronger. People on public assistance with minimal skills are competing against high school grads and college grads. We're having a tougher time matching people with jobs."
TOUGH times are all around, it seems. Each day, people wander into the group's office looking for some program to help them get a job. Some are referred by the welfare agency. Others, like Ms. De Jesus, take the initiative themselves and sort out the consequences later.
Yet administrators at Sobro wondered why some of their clients were yanked out of their training programs to report to workfare assignments that relied little on any skills they already had. While their clients could have appealed to stay in class, they said, at least 100 of them had left during the last six months when the city's Work Experience Program beckoned.
"One elderly woman dropped out of our program and was forced into the Work Experience Program," said Deborah MacFarlane, Sobro's vice president for education and employment. "We begged H.R.A. to put her in a hospital, put her anywhere. No. They put her on the Major Deegan."
Nevertheless, Ms. MacFarlane's group was able to find jobs for 1,000 people last year, a figure she thinks could increase if Sobro had more time to train individuals. Instead, she said her Job Club program for women on welfare was cut by the city to four weeks from eight.
"There's a direct correlation between length of training and the starting wage," Ms. MacFarlane said. "The problem is that welfare mothers are expected to get a job in the shortest amount of time with the least experience, the highest expectations and the highest need."
TEN women sat in cubicles in a nearby classroom, phone books open next to folders of resumes and classified ads. The women in the Job Club make up to 90 calls a day to potential employers. It's known as cold calling, which in their case probably describes the reception they get. Not one has found a job.
"We called every number in this book, and whenever they say they're hiring, we ask if we can send our resumes or come in for an interview," said Jewel Frye. "They say, 'We don't have nothing. No. Thank you.' I ain't heard yes yet."
The women arrived here after six-month workfare stints. They start another program at Bronx Community College next week.
"I'm running in circles," said Darlene Bates. "They want me off welfare. I'll get off when I find a job. All I want is to find a job and give welfare the boot."
Her friends chimed in: there are no jobs.
Victoria Baez ducked into the room. She had once been among them; now she works at Sobro. She knows there are jobs.
"But the majority of jobs are minimum wage," she said. "How could you tell somebody with four kids to work for minimum wage? If welfare cuts you off, you have to pay rent, electric and everything else. Is it going to be worth it to get off welfare?"

HEADLINE: Anchoring a Future In Atlantic City;
Convention Center Leads Effort To Broaden the Revival of a City

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, May 1

 BODY:
Atlantic City's new convention center opened this week, a muted steel, glass and sand-colored granite structure as long as six football fields and as wide as two that officials hope will be the key to transforming the city into a place travelers will want to visit for more than just a day of gambling.
Equipped with high-speed Internet connections, a video conferencing system and 275 miles of fiber optic cable, the building is the most technologically advanced convention center around, convention planners say. It has a total of 610,000 square feet of exhibition and meeting space, and it is the 11th-largest convention center in the country. When all the walls on the main exhibit floor are opened, the convention center will have 500,000 square feet of contiguous open space, more than any other hall in the Northeast, including the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York City. 
 But even this cavernous space with its sun-splashed atrium will be hard-pressed to contain the vaulting ambitions of the city and its casino operators as they look to it to boost the $3.8 billion dollar a year gambling industry and increase the tourist traffic in this 44-block-long city.
For the gaming industry, the convention center is part of an attempt to expand the Atlantic City gambling market, now dominated by people who live within 250 miles and drive in for the day. It is a market that most analysts concede is nearly tapped out. From 1995 to last year, gambling revenue grew a scant 1.76 percent, well below the rate of inflation.
For the city, the $268 million convention center, with a built-in train station connecting it to Philadelphia 55 miles to the west and an adjacent 500-room, noncasino hotel, is the leading edge of more than $7 billion in new construction planned over the next five years. That work is expected to add half a dozen theme-oriented, resortlike gambling hotels to the city's current 14 casinos. The long-depressed city hopes to re-emerge as a resort and vacation destination as attractive for longer stays as Las Vegas and Orlando, Fla. It hopes to edge its way back to the resort status that it had from the 1870's to the 1950's, when people flocked there to promenade on its boardwalk and take in the ocean views.
"The convention center will draw visitors and conventioneers," Mayor James Whelan said in an interview. "But just as significantly it will dispel the reputation we have had for a long time as a place where it is impossible to get anything done. This is done, and that ought to send a message to the development community."
There are, nevertheless, signs of conflict between the differing realities of the casino and convention businesses. In recent months, several New Jersey groups like the state bar association and the dental society, which are used to holding meetings and conventions in the casino hotels here, have complained that meeting space has been converted to gambling space as the casinos fiercely compete for customers.
In addition, they said, weekend meetings have become all but impossible because the casino hotels refuse to set aside prepaid rooms. The hotels would rather give away the rooms to high rollers, who drop thousands of dollars at the gaming tables. As a result, the New Jersey State Bar Association will be holding its 1998 convention outside Atlantic City for the first time in 93 years, said Jay Greenblatt, the association's incoming president. He said that the convention would move to East Rutherford and that the group would consider returning to Atlantic City if the market changed in its favor.
But today, on the first of three days of events marking the opening of the convention center, touring school children stared wide-eyed at the colorful and huge fish that hung high in the atrium and at the 27, two-foot-square whimsical medallions arrayed high along the atrium wall depicting crabs, sea horses, snails and the like. Workmen polished the floors and railings, and waiters set up a vast dining area for a formal dedication and black tie gala on Friday while exhibitors readied the main halls for a show addressing convention planners.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and retired Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf demonstrated the center's communications capabilities in a second-floor meeting room by holding a video conference on the subject of leadership with high school students in Newark and Jersey City.
Even Miss America, Tara Dawn Holland, who was crowned last September in the city's old Convention Hall on the Boardwalk, was impressed. To the early chagrin of Miss America pageant officials, the new center was not outfitted to handle the televised pageant, which is as emblematic of this city as salt water taffy. But Miss Holland observed that the old convention hall would remain and be refurbished for future pageants. "It's gorgeous," she said of the new center. "But, of course, the Convention Hall has fond memories for me."
In a city where legalized gambling has had a mixed record of keeping its promises of improving life for the 38,000 residents, the coming of the convention center was almost universally applauded.
Even past critics of the casinos and other city development plans, like Ernest D. Coursey, a City Councilman whose mostly black district abuts the convention center, were willing to give the center a chance. He noted that it had displaced one black housing complex and was threatening a larger black community on its northern border, but he added, "It is a beautiful building, and we look forward to it and hope that Atlantic City residents who remain will be treated just as well as the conventioneers and tourists we are attracting."
Joseph Dougherty, the owner of Dock's Oyster House, said that he had watched the ranks of restaurateurs along the city streets thin as casino hotels proliferated, their restaurants and shops aimed at keeping gamblers close to the slot machines and gaming tables.
"But conventioneers don't confine themselves to the casinos," he said. "So I think it will be tremendous for our business."
Marshall E. Murdaugh, 56, the executive director of the Atlantic City Convention and Visitors Authority, which operates the center, said that 290 trade shows and conventions were already booked for the center between now and 2007.
Among convention planners the center was an instant hit, said Gary LaBranche, vice president of the American Society of Association Executives. It is the "most technologically up-to-date," he said, catapulting Atlantic City to the top of the second tier of convention cities that are much larger.
"That's not a bad place to be in what is a seller's market now with the first-tier cities turning conventions away," he said.
Mr. Murdaugh, who prior to coming to Atlantic City served as president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau promoting the Javits Center and other New York City locations for conventions, agreed that the shore city was well-positioned. Even though the Javits Center has more square feet of exhibition space overall -- 900,000 to Atlantic City's 610,000 -- Mr. Murdaugh said that the new center had the feel of "an urban center without the urban hassles." And because the construction costs were so much lower than convention sites in New York and Philadelphia, the cost of an Atlantic City convention is lower. To highlight its advantages over its nearby neighbors, Mr. Murdaugh is marketing the center as "America's new northeast business address."
Still, the problem of hotel rooms for conventioneers is a cloud. Only 10,000 hotel rooms exist in the city now, although there are plans to increase this number to 27,000 in the next five years. Some of this is being partially financed by $175 million that will be turned back to the casinos over the five years from a tax they pay annually to the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority.
Marvin Roffman, a gambling analyst with Roffman Miller, an investment firm based in Philadelphia, noted that the business culture of the city was different from Las Vegas, which Atlantic City seeks to emulate. In Las Vegas, with 101,000 hotel rooms and a wealth of entertainment, retail and services in hotels, gambling operations make up 55 percent of casino hotel revenues, he said; in Atlantic City, gambling accounts for 93 percent of the revenues at the large casino hotels.
"In Las Vegas, the huge mega-casino hotels have so much, and they don't care which cash register rings up the money," Mr. Roffman said. "But it's not like that in Atlantic City, and until that changes and more hotel room are added, the city won't evolve."
Mr. Roffman and Mr. Murdaugh said that expanding the hotel space was also contingent upon working out disagreements among casino operators over subsidies to new arrivals. Some operators have threatened not to build new hotel rooms if they, too, do not get some of the tax benefits and subsidized road construction being offered to one of the newcomers, Mirage Resorts.
But Mr. Murdaugh said these problems would be worked out, and in the end, the "need for more hotel rooms will pull everyone along."

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE: THE OVERVIEW;
AFTER YEARS OF WRANGLING, ACCORD IS REACHED ON PLAN TO BALANCE BUDGET BY 2002

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration reached agreement with the Republican leadership today on a plan to balance the Federal budget in five years, using a last-minute financial windfall to help forge a deal that could alter the nation's economic and political landscape.
The pact came after years of bitter partisan wrangling, months of intense negotiations and several hours of high drama in which an astounding piece of news -- that deficits over the next five years were likely to be $225 billion lower than the Republicans had previously projected -- provided the final impetus to completing the deal. 
 In the end, that unexpected maneuvering room enabled both sides to claim victory in achieving their primary goals without undue political pain, although both the White House and the Republican leadership still had to rally support for the package within their own parties.
President Clinton argued that he had won new spending for education, health insurance for children, welfare benefits and other programs that he had made the core of his second-term agenda, all while protecting the elderly from big increases in their Medicare premiums.
"I wanted a balanced budget with balanced values," Mr. Clinton said. "I believe we have got it today."
Republicans exultantly claimed a prize that has eluded them for years, a big tax cut, including a reduction in the capital gains tax, as well as success in scaling back overall domestic spending and beginning to rein in the costs of Medicare and other entitlement programs.
"Under this budget agreement, official Washington must learn to make do with less, while Americans will keep more of what they earn, and they will be able to save it and invest it in their own families," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader.
The agreement does not insure that the budget will be balanced by 2002, because it cannot anticipate possible economic downturns or tax and spending decisions by Congress. And although the agreement won far more support today from liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans than did the outline that circulated on Capitol Hill on Thursday, it must still go through a legislative process that provides opportunities for changes and conflicts.
In a broader sense, the agreement gave Mr. Clinton a chance at a place in history as the President who restored the nation to a degree of fiscal and economic health it has not enjoyed in decades, an assertion that was bolstered by the news today that unemployment had fallen to 4.9 percent, its lowest rate in 23 years.
For the Republican majority in Congress, it was a chance to repair its image as overly partisan and obstructionist and to take home to voters a fiscal austerity package that leaves them largely insulated from Democratic attacks.
That the two sides were able to reach an agreement with so little political pain was largely a function of the strong economy, and the resulting decline in the deficit. Even without a budget agreement, this year's deficit is now expected to fall nearly 30 percent, to $75 billion, its lowest level relative to the size of the economy in more than two decades.
The Federal budget was last in balance in 1969. It began growing rapidly in the early 1980's after President Reagan and a Democratic Congress enacted tax cuts and spending increases and hit a peak of $290 billion in 1992. Since then the deficit has steadily declined, thanks in part to tax increases pushed through by Mr. Clinton in 1993 over Republican objections but primarily to a long period of steady economic growth.
The deal's major provisions, covering 1998 through 2002, include these:
*A reduction of $58 billion in domestic nonmilitary spending, about $12 billion more than Mr. Clinton had initially proposed. But the budget would provide $34 billion for most of Mr. Clinton's priority programs, including health insurance for up to 5 million children, the restoration of welfare benefits to legal immigrants and expanding the student loan and Head Start programs.
*A reduction in the planned growth of Medicare spending by $115 billion, accomplished largely through reductions in payments to health care providers. Elderly beneficiaries would have to pay slightly higher premiums. The Medicare trust fund, which would otherwise go bankrupt in 2001, would remain solvent until 2007.
*Tax cuts of $135 billion, partly offset by $50 billion in revenues from closing loopholes and extending existing taxes set to expire. The Republicans assured the White House that $35 billion of the cuts would be allocated to the President's proposal for tuition tax breaks. The remaining $100 billion would go to a reduction in the capital gains tax, a phased-in doubling of the amount exempted from estate taxes to $1.2 million and a credit for families with children.
The deal does not specify the size of the capital gains tax cut, but aides to Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who, as head of the House Ways and Means Committee, is responsible for all tax legislation, said there appeared to be enough money available to reduce the top rate to the Republican leadership's goal of 19.8 percent from 28 percent if the members of the committee agree to do so.
The cost of the tax cuts in the five years after 2002, a major impediment to a deal in the last few days, would be limited to $165 billion, a level that both sides agreed would not lead to a return of big deficits.
Although the broad outlines of the budget deal were in place by Thursday, it was completed this afternoon only after the negotiators agreed to tradeoffs made possible by the Congressional Budget Office's dramatic decision on Thursday to slash its deficit estimates for coming years.
The new projections allowed negotiators to take out politically sensitive components of the deal like a legislated change in the cost-of-living formula for Social Security and to scale back cuts to Medicare and Medicaid.
The budget office told Republicans on Wednesday that it was working on new projections that would show the scope of the nation's fiscal problems to be far smaller than anticipated. By Thursday, budget office officials had concluded that the deficit would be about $45 billion a year lower than they had previously projected, $225 billion lower over the five years covered by the budget deal.
The negotiators, however, had already decided on their own to use slightly more optimistic assumptions about the deficit. Still, the gain was substantial, $12 billion for 2002 alone.
And the news was shocking to both sides. Administration officials learned of it on Thursday from a phone call during a meeting with House Democrats. They returned to the White House to mull over the implications, with some aides saying it could scuttle the deal by causing Republicans to demand bigger tax cuts and Democrats more spending.
Indeed, when the negotiators met at 9:45 this morning in a hideaway office deep under the Capitol, there was considerable tension on both sides, participants said. The Republican team was led by Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico and Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, along with their top aides, G. William Hoagland and Rick May. Congressional Democrats were represented by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina. The Administration's team included Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff; Franklin D. Raines, the budget chief; Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin; John Hilley, the Congressional liaison, and Gene Sperling, the head of the National Economic Council.
But it quickly became apparent that both sides were willing to carve up the windfall in a way that would improve the agreement's prospects for winning bipartisan support, particularly given the negative reaction that early reports of the package had brought on Thursday from liberal House Democrats and conservative Republicans.
The negotiators decided that the new-found money gave them the chance to remove from the agreement a proposal that would have had the effect of lowering cost-of-living increases in Social Security and other Government benefits and raising taxes for some people. Both Democrats and Republicans in Congress had warned that they might have to vote against the package if it contained the provision reducing the Government's main cost of living gauge, the Consumer Price Index, to correct for an overestimate of inflation by about one percentage point. The negotiators had planned to seek legislative approval to double a 0.15 percentage point reduction in the index expected to be implemented on technical grounds by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The negotiators agreed to phase in increased Medicare premiums over seven years instead of five, and to exempt more low-income recipients from higher premiums. At the urging of Vice President Al Gore, they eliminated a per-person cap on Medicaid spending, a proposal that had drawn fire from the nation's governors and from many Democrats. And they agreed that about $8 billion in additional funding could be allocated over five years for transportation spending.
As word of the changes spread across Capitol Hill, the compromises defused much of the criticism leveled at the deal on Thursday. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, said he was "encouraged at the movement towards addressing Democratic concerns."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts said, "There's been some improvement but I still want to see more details." And in a sentiment common to many members of both parties who had watched the budget wars rage for the last several years, Senator Charles S. Robb, a Virginia Democrat, said, "This is the best deal either side could get."
 The article also referred incorrectly to a $290 billion figure from the 1992 budget. It represented the deficit that year, not the entire budget.

Here are the highlights of yesterday's budget agreement. Figures are five-year totals. Spending cuts are subtracted from what would otherwise be spent to maintain existing programs through 2002.

$135 billion in cuts, offset by some $50 billion in revenues from renewing expired taxes and closing lopholes. $58 billion in unspecified program cuts; $34 billion in new spending to extend health and disability benefits to legal immigrants and to provide free health insurance for up to 5 million poor children.
 
Medicare
About $115 billion in savings, mostly by cutting payments to medical providers and increasing many insurance premiums by $1 a month.
 
Medicaid
About $16 billion in savings from limiting payments to hospitals that serve large numbers of medicaid patients.
 
Military
About $85 billion in unspecified cuts.

HEADLINE: A Literary Pilgrimage With Diaper Bag

BYLINE: By SUZANNE BERNE; SUZANNE BERNE is a novelist who lives in Massachusetts.

 BODY:
ON a recent Saturday morning, in an uncharacteristic impulse to complicate my life by venturing somewhere rather than simplify it by staying at home, I decided to coax my family into our station wagon for a visit to Walden Pond. It's not far from where we live, and lately I have been rereading Henry David Thoreau's "Walden," which is what gave me the idea of escaping my quiet desperation at facing laundry and the dishes to reflect instead on Nature, self-reliance and the beauty of solitude. Or at least go for a drive.
Just around this time of year a century and a half ago, Thoreau, similarly disgusted with the tyranny of ordinary housekeeping, borrowed an axe and hiked down to the woods around Walden in Concord, Mass., to build himself a one-room cabin, then sat down and wrote about it. He lived alone there for two years and two months, simply and wisely, eating mostly rye and cornmeal, potatoes and rice, washing everything down with spring water. 
 It was a luxuriously austere life, rich in frugality. Eight months of food cost him $8.74, as he will tell you himself in his chapter on "Economy." Birds, ants and woodchucks were his neighbors; for news, he listened to wind through the trees, hooting owls and the freight train whistle. When he felt restless, he opened his door and lost himself in the woods.
Ah, to be Henry Thoreau for a month, a week, an afternoon! To live deliberately in a nice, quiet hut, confronting only the essential facts of life, which would not include car payments, answering-machine messages or a single product featuring Barney.
Inspired by these iconoclastic thoughts, I began gathering sweaters, coats, hats and boots together for a sojourn in the woods in muddy April, while issuing the first of several warnings required by my offspring, ages 2 and three months, before we hazard any journey, near or far. I also needed to pack snacks (apple juice in no-spill sippy cups, raisins, peanut butter crackers, bananas, granola bars), as well as a blankie, a binky, several diapers, diaper wipes, an emergency change of clothes for the younger and a stuffed elephant. All essentials.
The dog had to be leashed and dragged away from exploring her animal nature in the trash can. By the time I'd answered the phone twice, located my husband's keys and wallet, changed two unphilosophical children, dressed them and strapped them into their car seats, the sun was high in the everlasting blue sky and everyone wanted lunch. As Thoreau noted in approximately these words, and as any traveler will corroborate: She who goes alone can start today; but she who travels with her family must wait till they are ready, and it may be a long time before they get off.
But despite a morning frittered away by detail, there we were in the car at last, hurtling along Route 2 toward Concord, obeying higher laws by ignoring the speed limit. Everywhere the bud was on the tree, the robin on the wing, the snow melting in black drifts along the road. Soon enough we were turning onto Route 126, where Walden Pond lies, glinting as transcendently blue as it did in 1845. "God's Drop," Thoreau had wanted to rechristen the lake, an unexpectedly prescient name given the landfill that sprawls on the hillside across the street, circled by a couple of fat seagulls.
At 62 acres, Walden Pond is not especially large, nor is it any longer particularly pristine, even forgetting about the landfill. The pond's eastern shore is now a public beach, presided over by a bunkerlike bathhouse. In the summer herds of small children plunge, shrieking, in and out of the water, differently invigorated than Thoreau was by his dips, but invigorated still. The ice cream truck rings its bell; mothers scold their youngsters. Cigarette smoke wafts here and there, mingling with the scent of coconut oil from sunbathers crowding the sand. So much for solitude. Yet Walden remains a lovely lap of water, surrounded by woods; "a mirror which no stone can crack," Thoreau described it somewhere, "earth's eye." With maybe a cataract or two.
Times change, of course, and progress has its costs. Almost 60 years ago E. B. White, another literary hero of mine, likewise traveled to Walden Pond to catch a hint of the philosopher's life there. Instead of sleeping in a cabin, however, he spent a night at the Colonial Inn in Concord, a building once owned by the Thoreau family; for this privilege he paid $4.25, including his meals. Not much from our perspective, but Thoreau would have been appalled.
These days $4.25 wouldn't cover a Belgian waffle at the Colonial Inn, now an upscale hostelry advertising "cozy country charm" along with fax service and telephones with data ports. As we drove along, I recalled White's assessment of Walden as "a document of increasing pertinence; each year it seems to gain a little headway, as the world loses ground."
We pulled into the Walden Pond State Reservation parking lot, itself worth visiting for its reproduction of Thoreau's shingled cabin near the ticket booth, an edifice meant to provide the visitor with a sense of where he lived and what he lived for. It was closed just then; while my husband searched for a parking place, I hurried over and peered through one of the cabin's two windows to behold people peering in through the other.
Inside, the cabin boasts historical furnishings, including a wooden chair, a table, a narrow pallet and, during my visit, a plastic wastebasket and a tub of driveway sealer. Not much cozy country charm, but faithful to the spirit of Thoreau, whose idea of domestic decor was a lamp and a molasses jug. A statue of the philosopher himself stands a few feet from the cabin door, arm outstretched, gazing meditatively into his bronze palm, where an admirer has placed a candy wrapper.
It was my intention to lead my family partway around the pond to view the actual site of Thoreau's house, staked out by four granite markers. I have stopped there several times on earlier expeditions, ruminated for a few minutes, then added a stone to the nearby rock pile, as people do who want to pay material homage. E. B. White has a stone in there somewhere, too, although it was a very small pile when he made his contribution.
I'm not sure Thoreau would care for this commemorative heap, or for the eager pilgrims who come poking around his sacred haunts in sneakers and baseball hats, exclaiming over leaf-clogged coves and bullfrogs and scrubby oak trees, quoting lines from his book, hoping to recognize a place they've never been. Most depart somewhat disappointed. But then this is the inevitable curse of visiting a literary shrine: It is never what it was to you before you saw it for yourself.
Perhaps instinctively understanding this paradox, my family refused to get out of the car once established in a parking space. Both little girls were weeping and my husband wore a stoical aspect. "Go on ahead," he said, shouting to be heard. "You take a walk."
Alone?
I hesitated, something Thoreau would not have done, nor E. B. White for that matter. My babies cried louder. The dog began to bark. Would Walden have been written if Thoreau had been a family man?
For an answer, a single robin sang out from a pine branch overhead. Imperceptibly the air grew cooler; the mud looked very deep. In the distance, Walden glimmered, shimmered, more a mirage than ever.
"We'll try again soon," my husband promised, as we pulled back onto the road. The humming tires soothed our children -- a vibration of the universal lyre? -- and just as we passed Dairy Joy, they fell asleep. In the sudden hush, I could hear myself think, which is the closest I've come to the philosopher's life in quite a while.

HEADLINE: The Permanently Poor

BYLINE: By Susan Jacoby; Susan Jacoby, a freelance writer, is working on a four-generation history of her family.

 BODY:

MYTH OF THE WELFARE QUEEN
 By David Zucchino.
 366 pp. New York:
 Scribner. $25.
 
 MAKING ENDS MEET
 How Single Mothers Survive Welfare and Low-Wage Work.
 By Kathryn Edin and Laura Lein.
 305 pp. New York:
 Russell Sage Foundation.
 Cloth, $42.50. Paper, $19.95. 
 In "The Glory of Byzantium," a spectacular exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum in New York, an unforgettable icon depicts a procession of struggling souls trying to climb a ladder to heaven but always in danger of falling off into the clutches of gleeful demons. That image haunted me throughout David Zucchino's meticulous chronicle of the perilous lives of Odessa Williams, her eight adult children and numerous grandchildren. Mrs. Williams, 56, is one of two welfare mothers whose experiences are recorded in "Myth of the Welfare Queen." Mr. Zucchino, the foreign editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, who won a Pulitzer Prize for his reporting from South Africa, approached his domestic assignment among the poor of North Philadelphia in the spirit of a correspondent who recognized that he was basically a stranger to an alienated population within his own country.
"Making Ends Meet," which compares the survival strategies of welfare mothers with those of the "working poor," provides an equally disturbing statistical portrait of the kind of women whose individual lives are explored by Mr. Zucchino. The economic analysis, prepared for the Russell Sage Foundation by Kathryn Edin, an assistant professor of sociology at Rutgers University, and Laura Lein, a researcher in the School of Social Work at the University of Texas, Austin, is based on interviews with 379 mothers who receive welfare or work at low-wage jobs.
The message of both books is unequivocal: the porous barrier between welfare and work bears little resemblance to the middle-class image of a job -- any job -- as the first rung on a ladder leading out of poverty. Unfortunately, Mr. Zucchino dilutes the point by alternating between the Williams family and Cheri Honkala, a savvy welfare rights advocate known for such enterprises as setting up a tent encampment for the homeless on the grounds of the Liberty Bell. Ms. Honkala, 32, who has only one child and is off welfare by the end of the book (she makes several hundred dollars a night as a topless dancer), is clearly atypical -- in her choices and their availability.
Mrs. Williams, born in rural Georgia into a world of few choices, was chopping cotton and pulling string beans in the fields at age 5. She became one of millions of blacks who left the South in the 1950's at precisely the point when Northern cities began their long economic decline. When the Marriott Corporation announced recently that it would hire 550 workers for a new hotel, 10,000 applicants lined up in freezing weather. Implicit in Mr. Zucchino's account is the question of how the end of "welfare as we know it" can provide work for the 9,450 who couldn't be hired.
The Russell Sage Foundation researchers found that mothers with paying jobs spent twice as much a month as welfare mothers on expenses like day care and transportation and on formerly subsidized housing and medical costs. Nevertheless, many women continued to shift back and forth between welfare and work, hoping against hope to find a job leading to a career ladder rather than a wall.
Odessa Williams's 39-year-old daughter Joyce had worked for 10 years as a nurse's aide before she injured her back lifting a patient and turned to welfare. Then she enrolled in a medical data-processing training program. While she was in class, a son and a nephew began playing with matches, set fire to a mattress and seriously damaged her house. Joyce's 19-year-old daughter Iesha (already the mother of three) had fallen asleep in front of the television set while she was supposed to be watching the children. Joyce did manage to graduate from the training program, but the computerized medical job never materialized. After finding another job that paid $7.50 an hour -- but left her poorer after paying for transportation -- she went back on welfare.
The absence of rational calculation, regarding everything from fire safety to birth control, is the hallmark of lives described by Mr. Zucchino as being "utterly dominated by subsistence concerns." Yet new welfare restrictions -- especially the denial of benefits for children born while a mother is already receiving public aid -- are based on the assumption that poor women will make the rational decision that further childbearing is not in their best interest.
Odessa Williams receives approximately $1,382 a month, including welfare and Social Security disability, for her family of five (she has assumed responsibility for the four children of her crack-addicted daughter Brenda). She acquires basic household goods by methodically scrounging through trash. Recently she began preparing for Christmas by assuming the $58-a-month payments for a "Hooked on Phonics" set of audiotapes and books. And every month, she puts aside more money for other children's gifts. It is easy to see why Mr. Zucchino grew so fond of this devoted matriarch. Mrs. Williams desperately wants her grandchildren to learn, but her own education is too deficient for her to understand that visits to a public library might be just as effective as an expensive set of gimmicks promoted on television.
What is the point of yet another investigation into the lives of people whose problems sound so complex as to be irremediable? Leon Dash of The Washington Post, whose splendid 1996 book "Rosa Lee" chronicled the experience of a welfare family far more disordered than the Williamses, has argued that "we must agree on what the facts are, regardless of our political viewpoints, before we can offer those trapped in poverty a way out." "Myth of the Welfare Queen" and "Making Ends Meet" raise the disturbing further question of whether the bottom of the ladder can even be seen, much less reached, from the deepest part of the abyss.

LENGTH: 791 words

HEADLINE: The RENTOCRACY;
The Case for Rent Regulation

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts; Sam Roberts is deputy editor of the Week in Review section of The New York Times.

 BODY:
Here's where Bill Eimicke comes out on rent regulation: "Fundamentally, I have a problem with it, and I can understand anyone who believes in the United States system of capitalism would have a problem." Despite these reservations, he's for keeping some version of rent regulation -- doing away with it would be even worse. "There's more to risk than there is go gain." 
 Eimicke has earned the right to be heard on the subject. He is an unabashed liberal and Columbia University professor (and Columbia tenant) who as State Housing Commissioner during the Cuomo years administered the tangle of regulations that govern rents on more than one in three New York City dwellings. But Eimicke isn't enlisting in the crusade to scrap the system altogether.
Nobody defends the rent regulation bureaucracy that was first codified during World War II. But given some important conditions, knowledgeable people like Eimicke think the system remains defensible. Here's how they answer the arguments made against the regulatory regime loosely called "rent control."
[Only 70,000 of the city's 1.1 million or so regulated apartments are subject to the strictest controls.]
Rent control governs apartments built before 1947 and occupied by the same tenant since 1971. About a million more apartments (those built before 1973 with more than six units) are rent stabilized -- governed by somewhat looser regulations but with rent increases still subject to official guidelines. Nearly 600,000 other rental apartments are unregulated.
[Rent regulation applies citywide, but the debate about price controls largely concerns Manhattan.]
Among apartments renting for less than $600 a month, three out of four are governed by rent regulation. But in poorer neighborhoods, the market is already determined by what tenants can afford: market rents are below nominal regulated rents. In Jamaica, Queens, for example, according to the real-estate industry's estimates, market prices are about 25 percent less than the regulated rate. On the Upper West Side, though, the median rent would rise 36 percent a month if they were rapidly decontrolled. Without special protection, where would tenants on fixed incomes, the poor, the elderly and struggling artists go?
[What about all those celebrities who pay peanuts to rent cavernous apartments?]
Generally, vacated apartments become deregulated if they can be rented for $2,000 a month or more. Even occupied apartments can legally be deregulated if the rent reaches $2,000 and the household income surpasses $250,000 for two consecutive years. Maybe those thresholds are too high. Still, a tenant who earns even $100,000 but has a spouse and children to support might be hard pressed to pay 25 percent of his income on rent.
[Arguably, rent regulation is a middle-class subsidy, like lower property taxes on one- and two-family homes. But regulation is also about guaranteeing at least minimal building maintenance and services.]
There's evidence that regulation -- and the threat of mandated rent reductions -- offers great leverage over aggressively greedy landlords, managing agents and even co-op boards that might otherwise find means to force tenants out.
[Rent regulation would lapse if more than 5 percent of apartments were available. But has regulation really deterred developers from building more?]
Somewhat. But to rectify the situation, swaths of manufacturing and commercial districts would have to be rezoned to allow for housing. Also, so-called affordable housing is hard to build without subsidies or tax abatements. Plenty of higher-priced apartments are being built anyway -- and landlords may charge the first tenants whatever the market will bear. And, what the Legislature taketh away it can bring back.
[Not all economists condemn rent regulation -- even if the theoretical goal is to redistribute income in a city where diversity is a virtue.]
Writing a few years ago in The Journal of Economic Perspectives, Richard Arnott of Boston College concluded that original rent controls aside, New York's more flexible system of rent stabilization deserves another look. "Many of the claimed effects of second-generation controls are imperceptible," he wrote. "It is possible to design a set of rent regulations that results in an improvement in efficiency over the unrestricted market equilibrium."
[Yes, but the truth is that the defenders of rent regulation aren't moved by economics, only politics.]
Cynics say that in repeatedly renewing rent regulation, the Legislature has been guided largely by one equation: Tenants outnumber landlords. To which Eimicke replies: "If you're arguing that it's because the people want it, excuse me. This is a democracy."

SECTION: Section 13CN;Page 3;Column 1;Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1332 words

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Caroline Werth;
What's Up at the New Old Shubert Theater

 BODY:
CAROLINE WERTH, "a New York City kid," as she puts it, is the president and chief operating officer of the Shubert Performing Arts Center and one of New Haven's most enthusiastic cheerleaders. "You come into a city that is fun, has life, that is safe," she said.
Ms. Werth received the 28th annual Arts Manager of the Year award by Arts Management Newsletter on April 7, in recognition of organizing an effort by the theater to purchase its mortgage note. The largest contribution, $1.3 million, came from the state. 
 The City of New Haven had been paying $456,000 a year on the mortgage, money now available to the theater itself. In three years, Ms. Werth also increased non-ticket income to $800,000 largely from Connecticut-based corporations. The Department of Economic Development estimates the Shubert brings in about $30 million to New Haven, Ms. Werth says. "We are a huge tourist destination," she declared. "It is not uncommon for restaurants to request our sales numbers for the week before ordering."
Indeed, her view of the arts world is down to earth. "I see performing arts centers like neighborhood grocery stores," she explained. "Some people can go in and buy lots of things lots of the time. Some people only go in once in a while to buy a few things. But everybody has to get in there if it's going to be a successful store."
Recently Ms. Werth met to discuss the way the Shubert fits into New Haven and her plans for the Arts Center. Following are some excerpts of that conversation:
Q. Can the Shubert survive just by selling tickets?
A. By today's standards the Shubert with 1,600 seats is very intimate.Because finances, shows -- not always shows but dance performances, symphony orchestras -- only make commercial sense by playing in 3,000-seat houses. That's double the size of the Shubert.
We enjoy sold-out houses more often than not. But there is no way we could charge our customers what it's costing us every time we open our doors.
The Shubert had been running a deficit for a good long time. Last year we we raised $1 million in corporate sponsorship and annual contributed income. It wasn't enough. The gap between earned income and expenses was about $1.5 million. With the $500,000 now coming to us from the city, we would be able to see our way clear to black ink. I am very proud to say we have done it.
Q. How did you accomplish that?
A. Before we went to lobby everyone from the Governor's office on down, we looked at past and current seasons. We also looked at other comparable theaters. We went to the Office of Economic Development. They really put us through our paces. Then we went to the Governor and the Mayor This process went on for 18 months.
Yale joined in. They recognized the cultural impact of the Shubert and said, "We live here. We can't afford to see the Shubert close."
Yale really took the lead. The Community Foundation for Greater New Haven, the state and city came together to help.
Q. Why did so many people want to help?
A. The Shubert is the most distinguished theater in American theater history. It was the tryout ground for anyone who was anyone in entertainment through the 60's. It was home to all of Rodgers and Hammerstein's world premieres.
We are very respectful of this beautiful space that has all sorts of memories coming out of the walls. By today's standards it makes very little financial sense. At most Broadway houses, shows are designed to "sit down." When you take a show onto the road it is a more expensive proposition because it takes a great deal of wear and tear. It must be built to take apart. "Sunset Boulevard" is an example of a show that was just too expensive to take on the road.
Q. With the Shubert, Long Wharf, the Yale Repertory Theater and the Palace in New Haven are there simply too many theaters?
A. What sets New Haven apart is its cultural richness and diversity. We are all doing different kind of seasons. Long Wharf and the Yale Repertory Theater are creating new work and much of it travels on to Broadway and other parts of the country.
What we are doing here is everything. We are continuing the Shubert's famous legacy of doing theater, but in the last four years we have broadened our scope. We are dedicated to the notion that there's got to be something for everyone. It is not unusual to have the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater one weekend and "Damn Yankees" the next and then Wynton Marsalis, a children's musical and then "Jam on the Groove," a hip-hop show, the next weekend. There's a complete diversity in our programming. It is certainly very commercial.
Q. You are known for your substantial education and outreach efforts. Will they continue?
A. Because our programming is so diversified we have the great luxury of developing an extraordinary educational program. I have long subscribed to the idea of programming for young people with the same artists and attractions that we present to adult audiences.
I ask everyone who comes to the Shubert to think of some educational component. This season the Canadian Brass did two master classes -- one for 600 brass playing middle school students, the other for 1,600 students.
Savion Glover, the tap dancer and choreographer, did a lecture demonstration. Wynton Marsalis did the same kind of programs for 1,600 kids. Pilobolus and Jam on the Groove did classes.
Q. Are these lecture demonstrations limited to New Haven schools?
A. We are the only venue in the state that literally draws from Westchester County to Springfield, Mass. We have to accommodate the New Haven schools first but we have been adding additional programs. We do educational student guides, and materials and visits. We have an advisory group, the Educational Committee to help us.
Q. How do you find local groups to help you?
A. There is a Community Outreach Committee involved in our Family Club. We go out and raise funds to buy tickets from ourselves. The Outreach Committee helps to determine which family-based organizations should receive the tickets. Groups range from a neighborhood watch group to a Y.M.C.A. program. The point is to help the family unit, whether it is a traditional or a non-traditional unit. We feel that theater is a terrific thing for them to do together.
We complement that program by going out into the neighborhoods. We answer questions that range from "What is the appropriate dress?" to "What is this music about?" The purpose is that by the time they come to the Shubert they feel at ease about being here.
Q. The demographics of New Haven are changing. Does that affect planning the upcoming seasons?
A. We are now embarking on an annual week of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater. We recently had Tito Puente here and we hope to have Celia Cruz and Tito Puente next fall. There is no question that we will be doing more programming to cater to our Latino community.
We have an absolutely amazing diversity of audiences here. It's funny to hear board members and Shubert regulars say, "I don't know these people. I used to know everyone."
The audiences at the Shubert are like nowhere else. It has to do with the sense of ownership people feel about this place.
Q. Aren't there going to be some big changes coming up?
A. You can't make the walls expand. I do hope someday that we will have a wonderful large facility here to also house "Phantom of the Opera"-size productions and a great hall for symphony music. Right now we are embarking on renovating and refurbishing this wonderful old theater. There will be comfortable seats. They will be a deep rose. We were careful not to change the color schemes. We wanted to use a deeper shade so everyone would know this was new, but not change the current character.
There will be new carpeting and painting. The cafeteria design will be all new next September. There are a lot of enhancements. Then we will open with Neil Simon's pre-Broadway show, "Proposals," in what we call the new old Shubert Theater.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Caroline Werth, president of the Shubert Performing Arts Center in New Haven, at the theater. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Damage Waiver: You May Need It

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
IF you are planning to drive a rental car around County Clare this summer, and you charge it on American Express, the venture may cost more than you expect. Next month, American Express will take three more countries off the list of places where its card holders can get free damage coverage in lieu of buying the rental company's collision damage waiver.
In its "F.Y.I." flier sent to card holders, a four-page document of rather small type, the company said that effective June 1, its car-rental loss and damage insurance plan would not be valid in Jamaica, Ireland or Israel. Four years ago American Express eliminated coverage for rentals in Italy, New Zealand and Australia. In New Zealand and Australia, government regulations require that the cost of the collision damage waiver be included in the rental cost, so a renter gets it automatically. The change in Italy arose because of a high level of thefts. 
 The American Express flier notes that coverage for damage or loss of a rental car consumes $1.59 of each annual fee. Questions about coverage are answered at (800) 338-1670.
At the moment, holders of gold cards from Mastercard and Visa are still covered in Jamaica, Ireland and Israel. The Visa and Mastercard gold-card fliers, unlike American Express's, do not list the excluded countries but say only that with certain exceptions, coverage is available worldwide.
Marianne Fulgenzi, vice president for media programs at Mastercard, said that her company's help-line supervisor reported no calls from card holders complaining that the credit card coverage had been rejected.
The people who spoke for both Visa and Mastercard used phrases that sounded as if the Jamaica-Ireland-Israel situation might not continue for long. Carolyn Bretschneider, a spokeswoman for Visa, said that her company is not planning any change "at this time." So people renting cars overseas, especially those making reservations in the United States, should check with their card companies to learn whether they should sign up for collision damage waivers. The Visa number is (800) 847-2911, Mastercard (800) 622-7747
The collision damage waiver, although used like insurance, was legally declared not insurance in New York State when the Insurance Department wanted to regulate it a decade ago. Other states do not require insurance licenses for the sale of the collision damage waiver, either. The small type that few renters ever read says that buying the waiver means that the renting company will not require the renter to pay for collision damage or theft of the car, providing all the rental rules are met -- traffic laws are obeyed, driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs is avoided, and the like.
 
Freeze on Credit
Emily Porter of American Express said two "business reasons" led to her company's shift: a small proportion of card holders used this benefit in the countries involved, but there was a disproportionately high number of claims there. She said the causes could include economic conditions and the state of roads, but she would not differentiate among the countries or say how long the company had been watching the claim levels.
All three credit organizations dropped Italy in 1993 because of heavy theft. Thefts, including ones carried out on the road by teams of thieves after tires were vandalized in parking spots, caused a rise in losses to the rental and card companies. The rental companies in Italy then put in a direct surcharge of $11 to $15 a day to cover theft only. The credit cards were still covering for collision damage, but when renters invoked the coverage, the auto-rental companies put a freeze on their credit cards of $5,000 to $14,000, depending on the value of the car. This freeze stayed on until the car was returned whole, and sometimes longer. People who did not have a second credit card would then be virtually unable to charge anything else during the trip, and would usually buy the collision damage waiver to avoid the freeze. American Express said at the time it dropped its coverage for Italy: "We were offering something useless."
No rental company interviewed for this article reported anything of this sort going on in Ireland, Israel or Jamaica. Meloyde Blancett-Scott, a spokeswoman for Thrifty Rent-a-Car, said that her Ireland affiliate reported a moderate but steady rise in damage there, but nothing dramatic. Lauren Garvey of Hertz said there was nothing noteworthy in Ireland. John Quirk, Avis vice president for international sales, said that his company had noticed no increased claim activity in the three countries.
 
Assessing the Damage
What is the change going to cost American Express card holders? Through the end of May, according to Alfred Celentano, manager of Europe by Car, a New York brokerage agent, a medium-sized car in Ireland will cost $179 a week without taxes; the collision damage waiver will add $15 a day, or $105 a week. Europe by Car uses Thrifty Rent-a-Car in Ireland.
Michael Wellner, owner of Kemwel in Harrison, N.Y., operates in all three places. A medium-car rental in Ireland or Israel costs "a couple of hundred dollars" a week, he said, and the collision damage waiver an average of $9 or $10 more a day, or $63 to $70 a week. In Jamaica, he said, a rental is $300 a week and the collision damage waiver $10 a day, or $70 a week.
At Avis, Mr. Quirk said that a collision damage waiver in Ireland costs $18 to $46 a day, depending on the car, a rather stiff fee. In Israel, he said the cost is $16 to $25 a day, and in Jamaica, $10 a day.
Mr. Wellner said that a rental for Italy with his company, with theft and collision insurance included, costs $275 a week for a three-passenger car, $375 a week for a four-passenger model.
When renting for himself in the United States, Mr. Wellner said, he usually buys the collision damage waiver, because the credit card coverage provides only a backup to his own auto insurance. Such coverage, described as secondary by Visa and Mastercard and excess by American Express, will pay a deductible or any part not paid by insurance the renter holds, but the impact of the collision falls on the renter's personal policy, which may increase premiums.
"Everyone would be better served if all rental rates were all-inclusive," Mr. Wellner said. "The credit card companies don't want to be in the insurance business; they don't want to handle the hassle of a desperate guy on the phone from the Frankfurt airport with a plane to catch and a car-rental company that won't let let him leave until the damage is paid for."
 
Perils Lurking in Small Type
Car renters relying on their credit cards' coverage for the waiver should read the small type carefully, and call if there is any doubt, because all companies exclude some kinds of rental vehicles, generally high-priced ones and those that carry a large number of passengers. Visa and American Express exclude coverage for such cars wherever rented; Mastercard excludes it only for rentals in the United States.
One thing not to forget: any credit card protection requires that the card be used for the rental.
