HEADLINE: NEW ENGLAND;
Haunted by Drama

BYLINE: By MARY CANTWELL; MARY CANTWELL is the author of "Manhattan, When I Was Young" (Penguin).

 BODY:
IT is good to arrive in New London on a Sunday night in a chilly April because after leaving the railroad station and the small fleet of cabs that waits outside, one walks through streets that are as barren as the moon. This is, while not a ghost town, a city of ghosts, and there is no better way to sense a spook than in silence.
Nathan Hale, whose schoolhouse, moved so often a local joke has it on wheels, haunts New London. So do whaling masters, who lived in Greek Revival houses on Whale Oil Row, and 19th-century millionaires, who built their mansions out near the lighthouse, and the sailors who thronged the city's brothels and bars. 
 So does my young self, a student in a college two or so miles and a world away from downtown, whose camel's hair coat was stolen on the only night she ever ventured into one of those bars. It was St. Patrick's Day, I wanted to drink green beer at a place named Danny Shea's and it was, during four years in New London, the closest I ever came to emulating the city's most famous ghosts. They are, of course, the O'Neills: James, Ella, Jamie and Eugene.
James O'Neill, an Ireland-born actor of remarkable good looks and a history of poverty, made his name and his fortune touring for years in a play called "The Count of Monte Cristo." His wife, Ella, also of Irish descent but born into affluence, was convent-educated, a good pianist and an aspirant to upper-middle-class comforts and conveniences. Having been given morphine after the birth of her third son (a second, Edmund, died of measles) and loving it, she was, in addition, a junkie.
Jamie, her first son, was a drunk. Eugene, the third, was a playwright who won four Pulitzers and the Nobel Prize. He had three wives, only the last of whom, Carlotta, a willing, indeed eager, martyr to literature, he found satisfactory. Two of his three children killed themselves. The youngest married Charlie Chaplin.
If we know a lot about the O'Neills, it is not only because they are catnip to biographers. Rather, it is primarily because they were catnip to Eugene, who wrote a great play about a family named Tyrone which was, in truth, a family named O'Neill. At first, he said he did not want "Long Day's Journey Into Night" to be published until 25 years after his death. But in 1952, the year before he died, he told his wife the restrictions no longer held. If things go wrong, "We've got a nest egg."
Eugene O'Neill's nest egg is set in Monte Cristo Cottage, which his father had cobbled together out of a building that seems to have been a store and dwelling and an abandoned one-room schoolhouse in 1884. At that time, there were no houses on the other side of Pequot Avenue, so the O'Neills' view of the Thames River (there is a famous photograph in the house of the men of the family sitting on the front porch) was unimpeded. But the foghorn that kept Mary Tyrone awake at night still sounds, and the fog that made the river invisible the morning I went to Monte Cristo Cottage is as Mary, for whom it was also a metaphor for morphine, described it: "It hides you from the world and the world from you."
Ella and James O'Neill sold the cottage in 1919, the year before James drew his last breath. By 1975, when the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, an umbrella organization for American theater projects, acquired it, the place was a mess. Support from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, from 1978 to 1980, paid for the bulk of the restoration. Since then, it has taken benefits, foundation funds and private donors to keep the house going, and to hear its staff speaking wistfully about what would be possible if only there were more money is to mourn America's seeming disregard for its small but priceless treasures.
Monte Cristo Cottage is the only house the O'Neill family ever owned and as such, it is no great shakes. "It was wrong from the start," Mary Tyrone says. "Everything was done in the cheapest way."
The cottage was a summer place, which may be one reason James O'Neill didn't spend much money on it. Another stronger reason may be that those who were poor in childhood are, like stray cats saved from alleys, never quite sure that the food bowl won't disappear.
Seen from the outside, however, it is charming in its porch, little tower, Victorian air and hilly, stone-walled site. Seen on the inside, it is disconcerting. Because here, right down to the green-shaded lamp plugged into one socket of an overhead four-socket lamp, is the set for "Long Day's Journey." Eugene O'Neill, whose memory was remarkably eidetic, didn't omit a thing.
It is strange to stroll through a house that is as much a matter of fiction as it is of fact, even stranger to be told that the bedroom left front was probably Jamie's and the one right front probably Eugene's because "Jamie heard Mary moving around the spare room at 3 in the morning, then pausing to listen outside her sons' doors." The people who saved and restored Monte Cristo Cottage read "Long Day's Journey Into Night" with the attention due a map.
One can also read Monte Cristo Cottage for what it says about James O'Neill. The staircase's balusters, for instance, don't go all the way to the steps but to a rail paralleling the banister instead. That's a penny-pincher's trick. But the newel post is big and baronial. That befits the Count of Monte Cristo. Ceilings upstairs are low, whereas those downstairs -- the ones for show -- are fairly high. The kitchen, demolished after the family left, was more or less tacked on.
After the cottage was sold, Ella O'Neill got rid of the furniture. But because Eugene described the living room so precisely it was easy to duplicate. Wicker chair, an oak rocker with a leather seat, the green-shaded lamp: the furniture was, if not cheap now, cheap then. Today, when summer-house chic is construed as a clever use of castoffs, the living room is curiously attractive. In Ella's day, when the more conspicuous the consumption the better, it must have seemed to her little more than a boarding house. Actually, Monte Cristo provided little in the way of board. The Tyrones took meals in the dining room; the O'Neills usually dined at a boarding house down the street.
There is one object in the living room, however, that is definitely and definitively James O'Neill's: the stoneware crock, with his name on it, that was regularly filled with whisky from a local bar and waiting for him when he got off the train in New London. His sword, perhaps the one that made the frightening clang when he played Othello to Edwin Booth's Iago, is slung in its scabbard over a fireplace in the back parlor, which, together with the front parlor, is crowded with old photographs of New Londoners, many of them the unknowing sitters for Eugene's often angry dramatic portraits. There are old theater posters, too, of a posturing, handsome James O'Neill and old theater programs. His son's life in the theater is there as well, and so is the green wicker table that was the centerpiece of the first production of "Long Day's Journey."
Upstairs, the bedrooms are small and stingy, with Jamie's painted a color known as Poison Green -- poison because in an earlier era the paint could contain arsenic, presumably lethal to bugs and any child who thought to lick it. The paint on the wall now isn't laced with arsenic and maybe it wasn't in Jamie's day, either. Just the same, it is the color he woke to every morning and must have been hard on a hangover. Eugene's bedroom is furnished with the crude desk he later used in Provincetown and at which he wrote "Anna Christie" and "The Emperor Jones," and with a surprisingly handsome desk chair that is thought to be his. Down the hall is the bathroom, and in it the marble sink at which the O'Neills washed their faces and brushed their teeth.
O'Neill set another play, "Ah, Wilderness!," at Monte Cristo Cottage but it was about the kind of family he wished he'd been raised in, the McGinleys, rather than his own. Art McGinley was his closest childhood friend, and it was he, I believe, who once spoke at my college about his chum. A rotten audience I was, having seen only "Anna Christie" and that only because I was curious about Garbo. But a few weeks ago, I watched the 1935 film of "Ah, Wilderness!," and smiled to see not only the family O'Neill wished he had, but also the house the set designers wished he'd had. This was no Monte Cristo Cottage. This was Ella O'Neill's dream come true.
In a sense, Eugene O'Neill never left New London any more than James Joyce ever left Dublin. There are bits and pieces of the town and its people -- the Yankees who snubbed the O'Neills, the whores who slept with the boys, the drunks father and sons drank with and the seamen that Eugene set sail with -- throughout a lot of O'Neill's plays. Most of the family -- James, Ella, Jamie and little Edmund -- is still in town, in St. Mary's Cemetery. A taste for symmetry has me wishing that Eugene, who is buried in Boston, were, too. But, of course, he is.
 
Down the road from Monte Cristo
Monte Cristo Cottage, a Federal landmark, is open Tuesday through Sunday from Memorial Day to Labor Day. Admission costs $4. Summer hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., and Sundays 1 to 5 P.M.; (860) 443-0051 and 443-5378.
The Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, at 305 Great Neck Road, Waterford, Conn. 06385, a few miles southwest of New London, offers performances in July and August ($10 to $12), but its schedule is just being set. Call (860) 443-5378 for information.
The campus of Connecticut College is in northern New London, a 15-minute drive from the O'Neill home. More than 700 acres of the college and its arboretum are open dusk to dawn daily. At 2 P.M. on Sundays through October, a free tour starts at the college's main entrance; (860) 439-5020.
The Lyman Allyn Art Museum, 625 Williams Street (across from the Coast Guard Academy), features Connecticut Impressionists and 18th- and 19th-century American decorative arts. Closed Mondays and major holidays. Admission costs $3; (860) 443-2545.
Ocean Beach Park, on Long Island Sound at the south end of town, has a large public beach with boardwalk, Olympic pool and miniature golf; (860) 447-3031.
There is ferry service to Block Island (860 442-7891), Fishers Island (860) 443-6851) and Orient Point, N.Y. (860 443-5281). All three carry cars.
The Radisson, 35 Governor Winthrop Boulevard, (860) 443-7000, has 120 standard rooms downtown, about 10 minutes by car from Monte Cristo Cottage. Rates: $79 to $139, through June. The Foxwoods Resort and Mohegan Resorts casinos are less than 20 minutes away by shuttle bus.
Queen Anne Inn, 265 Williams Street, (800) 347-8818, ($89 to $185, double) is a 10-room Victorian bed-and-breakfast near Connecticut College that I have not visited but that is recommended locally.
Lighthouse Inn, 6 Guthrie Place, (860) 443-8411, ($95-$255) has 50 rooms in a 1902 mansion not far from the O'Neill home.
One can get a reasonable meal at the Radisson; dinner entrees are $11.95 to $17.95. Among local favorites are Lighthouse Inn, which serves regional American and French cuisine ($19-$25), and Timothy's, 181 Bank Street, American Continental cuisine ($12.95 to $22.95); (860) 437-0526.

LENGTH: 1540 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Maybe Not on the High Road, but They Travel Well

BYLINE: By EMILY YELLIN 

DATELINE: MEMPHIS

 BODY:
JON THOMPSON, DIRECTOR OF cultural affairs for the city of Memphis, faced a challenge in Beijing a few years ago. He had to persuade the Chinese Government to allow more than 250 relics and fine-art objects out of the country for almost three years. Worse, he had to explain that its cherished national treasures were not going to some world-renowned museum.
Instead, they were to be the heart of a touring blockbuster exhibition series called "Wonders," which would open at a convention center in downtown Memphis just a few miles from Elvis Presley's Graceland. The show would then go on to Portland, Ore.; Provo, Utah, and Denver before ending up in Orlando, Fla., just a few miles from Disney World. 
 But Mr. Thompson, a genteel Southerner who also happens to be a veteran marketing man, had his sales pitch ready. Knowing China was eager to win American admirers, he began by describing a "cultural corridor," running from New York to Washington, through Chicago and on to Los Angeles, saying it was in these cities that most major arts events occur in the United States.
"So why don't we create our own countercultural corridor," he suggested, "going from Oregon to Florida diagonally across the U.S. in the opposite direction?" The Chinese were sold.
As a result, "The Imperial Tombs of China" opened in Memphis in 1995. Last Thursday, the exhibition opened at the Orlando Museum of Art, the last leg of its planned five-city tour. More than 1.5 million people have seen the show so far.
Predictably, some members of America's museum establishment are not particularly receptive to Mr. Thompson's road show. In fact, the concept of the "Wonders" blockbuster runs so counter to their notions of high culture that they may never completely accept it.
"Wonders: The Memphis International Series," which Mr. Thompson heads, was started after the city sponsored an exhibition in 1987 called "Rameses the Great." It drew 675,000 people and went on to be seen by almost eight million people on an eight-city North American tour. Then came "Wonders" exhibitions on Catherine the Great, the Ottomans, the Etruscans, Napoleon and China, all staged in the Memphis convention center. The city's seventh blockbuster, "Titanic: The Exhibition," opened last month in the basement of Memphis's largest indoor sports arena, where it will remain through September.
The "Wonders" shows have even inspired a few spinoffs. James E. Broughton, the organization's original director, left Memphis and set up a similar series of three shows on Egypt, Russia and Greece in St. Petersburg, Fla. In Jackson, Miss., another former "Wonders" staffer, Jack Kyle, staged "The Palaces of St. Petersburg" in cooperation with Russia's Hermitage Museum last summer. Attendance was more than 550,000, second last year only to the Cezanne exhibition in Philadelphia.
Unlike blockbusters that are composed strictly of fine-arts objects, "Wonders" shows combine fine art, natural history and Smithsonian-like cultural history. Every exhibition is designed to make a strong emotional impact through elaborate sets and a story line. A free audio guide is narrated by a celebrity: Leonard Nimoy for the Chinese exhibition, Lauren Bacall for Catherine the Great. Non-art objects are often a big draw, too: bricks from the Great Wall of China, Catherine the Great's coronation carriage and every item in the art-free Titanic show, from jewelry and money to a steward's jacket and a jar of green olives.
"There is a real hunger for this kind of thing in second- and third-tier cities that do not have a Metropolitan Museum on their doorstep," Mr. Thompson said.
MANY FROM THE MUSEUM world are reluctant to dismiss the "Wonders" concept totally, but they express concern that the shows may warp the public's perception of what museum professionals do.
" 'Wonders' is a great draw for the city," said Kate Gooch, president of the Memphis Arts Council. "It is kind of the Boston Pops of art. But it is not a substitute for a museum."
Edward H. Able, president of the American Association of Museums, an organization of 3,000 museums across the country, also has reservations about the "Wonders" concept. "These are one-time events that come and go," he said. "They seem to be mostly entrepreneurial activities to make money, unlike museums, which are committed to continuing programs, education, scholarship and a broader and more complex mission."
Some museum officials are also troubled by the fact that "Wonders" is an arm of local government, not a museum. John Buchanan, director of the Portland Museum of Art in Oregon, said his museum took the China exhibition last summer because of its artistic value, but he noted that the idea of city bureaucrats initiating art exchanges raises questions. "The opening salvo in these negotiations came from the governments," he said. "And that was nervous-making to my colleagues, who are used to talking curator to curator."
But to city leaders, any doubts about the shows are overshadowed by the bottom line: the tourism they attract stimulates local economies. Even when a "Wonders" show operated at a loss, which some have, the city of Memphis still earned $3.54 in tax revenue for every dollar invested, a city study showed.
That is a major reason Memphis keeps the nonprofit series solvent through a revolving $4.2 million loan. Any profit from "Wonders" ticket- and gift-shop sales is funneled back into the next exhibition. Organizers keep the expenses low by using more than 2,000 volunteers and sharing costs with other cities on the tours.
For this and other reasons, the people behind "Wonders" and its spinoffs do not apologize for their efforts. Instead, they say their work complements that of museums, and they cite a number of reasons.
Not having a permanent museum collection, they say, enables them to focus all their resources on display. They pay fees for the works they borrow because the "Wonders" organization, unlike big museums, cannot trade on prestige or the promise of reciprocal loans.
Education is a built-in part of the concept. Free study guides are sent to every teacher in the area, and thousands of children are given free tours. Shows are staged in uncommon venues only when local museums do not have enough space to handle the large exhibitions and huge crowds.
Their most heartfelt defense is that the "Wonders" exhibitions do not commercialize art; they popularize it. "I'm a populist," said Mr. Kyle, the former "Wonders" staff member. "I believe art is for the people."
He and his colleagues argue that there is nothing wrong with bringing the exhibitions to people who may never be able to afford a trip to New York, much less Russia or China, or to those who find museums intimidating.
Cheryl Reddick, who drove 12 hours from Georgia with a friend to see the Titanic show, is one of those people. "Museums are too overwhelming," she said. "With 'Wonders' you can see the whole exhibit in a couple of hours."
If nothing else, the "Wonders" concept democratizes art, said J. Carter Brown, director emeritus of the National Gallery of Art in Washington and the creator of a blockbuster of his own last summer at the Olympics in Atlanta. "I think these exhibits challenge the idea that only the priesthood can see art and the great unwashed cannot," he said.
It's a view shared by Thomas Hoving, the former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, who is credited with originating the blockbuster phenomenon when he brought the King Tut show to America in 1977. " 'Wonders' is a trailer-park blockbuster," he said. "But it's good. They reach a whole group of people who never got an art education, and it might end up drawing them into other museums. Half a generation from now, I bet there will be bunches of people who will remember 'Wonders' and say it is what got them interested in art as a child." He added, "The shows are great, not second-rate at all."
For each show, organizers recruit recognized experts to be guest curators. The Napoleon exhibit was curated by Bernard Chevallier, director of Malmaison in France, who gathered more than 175 pieces of art from 50 museums all over the world. "The people they get to curate are the top people in their fields," Mr. Hoving said.
FOR ALL THE SUCCESS OF these shows, however, a "Wonders" exhibition can still be a risky proposition. St. Petersburg is struggling with an $11 million loss on its series, mainly because of lower-than-expected attendance and a financial arrangement in which much of the gift-shop revenue went to Mr. Broughton, the original "Wonders" director, instead of to the city.
Mr. Broughton has left to form an independent company to produce similar shows for other cities. His next show will be called "Nicholas and Alexandra." Meanwhile, in Memphis, an exhibition of several hundred ancient Peruvian treasures will open next spring. An exhibition from Versailles is set for next summer in Jackson. And cities like Topeka, Kan., and Wilmington, Del., have discussed beginning their own series.
Despite challenges and naysayers, the "Wonders" concept persists. "The elitist crowd has some valid points of criticism," said Mr. Hoving. "But these shows are going to keep coming."

HEADLINE: THE CAPITALIST;
The Asian Con, Part 2

BYLINE: By Michael Lewis

 BODY:
In the mid-1980's, i sat on a Wall Street trading floor and watched the Japanese stampede the United States Treasury bond market. "How now long bond?" the customer from Tokyo would ask; the American bond salesman would giggle and then sell to him or buy from him staggering amounts of our national debt. The losses suffered by the Japanese in this activity were breathtaking. Every time the American bond market moved, it seemed, Japan lost a month's worth of trade surpluses. The American bond salesman could see this and, as a result, he was not so frightened by Japan's financial clout. Some part of him grasped that the Japanese were partly mad, and that their behavior doomed them to financial oblivion.
But to most Americans this was not so clear, perhaps because most Americans are predisposed to thinking of themselves as the innocents of global culture. When Japanese businessmen took to buying prime Manhattan real estate (Rockefeller Center!) and Hollywood studios (cultural heritage!) and famous golf courses (Pebble Beach!) the American reaction bordered on hysteria. 
 The fear was understandable; for a while it did appear that Japan might have concocted a more powerful economy than anything the United States had ever seen. But the fear was also misplaced, for it turned out that it was the Japanese who were being royally fleeced. All of Japan's most scandalous purchases ended in tears; many of them ended back in American hands. And no wonder. The Japanese had dealt almost exclusively with the most shrewd, ruthless, money-obsessed people on earth: American investment bankers, real-estate moguls and movie executives.
These days the irrational fear of Japanese money is mainly gone, though you can still read the occasional article about Japan's tendency to prevent American automobile manufacturers from selling their big sedans to Tokyo motorists. (German car manufacturers don't seem to have such complaints, but you don't hear much about that.) The fear of Japan, Inc., has been replaced by an irrational fear of Chinese campaign donations. The flow of funds out of China -- and Taiwan, Indonesia and Singapore -- into American politics has generated something of the same thoughtless response as the flow of funds out of Japan into the American economy. Just as we should have celebrated the Japanese for overpaying for our Treasury bonds, real estate, golf courses and film studios, we should be cheering the Chinese for overpaying for Bill Clinton's Presidential campaign.
That any politician must go around with a wheelbarrow begging cash from rich people is a scandal, of course. But as long as politicians must do this, far better that they do it abroad than at home.
First consider Bill Clinton. No President has ever been less likely to reward his supporters and friends -- a virtue when they want something they shouldn't have. Clinton is notoriously disloyal; he has turned betrayal into a political art form, and his natural inclination is simply to do what is best for his career.
And to further his career, Clinton needed -- or felt he needed -- to come up with millions to pay for television ads. Every dollar he turned away from China -- or Indonesia or Singapore -- was a dollar he would have had to raise from rich Americans, and their corporations.
The corporate raider Carl Lindner, who usually gives to Republicans, quietly donated more than $500,000 to state Democratic Parties in the last seven months of the Clinton campaign. As it happens, Carl Lindner wanted the Clinton Administration to argue the case for his (multinational) company, Chiquita Brands, in front of the World Trade Organization.
You can be sure that Lindner will be upset if he doesn't get what he wants. More to the point, you can be sure that he will find ways to punish the Democrats for neglecting his concerns. He can help turn other rich Americans against them. Rich Americans can forgive a President who takes money from a Chinese operative without doing something in return. But to take money so ruthlessly from a rich American -- that's a sin.
Now consider the poor Chinese, who forked over millions -- and for what? There's not much that a President can do for China -- or Taiwan or Indonesia -- without it ending up on the front page. More important, there is not much that the Chinese can do to Clinton if he stiffs them. It is easier for Clinton to indulge his inherent ingratitude when his supporters are: 1) 5,000 miles away, 2) a potential enemy of the country and 3) easily hoodwinked about American political customs: "Sorry, it will make things even worse for you if we are seen to be on your side." Indeed, of all the foreigners Clinton might have sought money from, the Chinese posed the least threat to the public interest precisely because it is so difficult to reward them.
The election laws that forbid politicians to accept contributions from foreigners make it difficult -- but not impossible -- for the Chinese to pay for our campaigns. Maybe we should change the laws and save ourselves a little money.
We are the masters of the Asian con who somehow manage to persuade ourselves that it is we who are being conned. You can be sure that the fiercest outrage during the coming hearings of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee will be directed at Asian money, and the people who asked for it. The list of those most likely to be interrogated gives you an idea of how the story will play out: James T. Riady and John Huang of the Lippo Group; Charles Yah Lin Trie; Pauline Kanchanalak, among others.
This fear of Asians isn't all bad. If riding a few Asians out of Washington on a rail helps to generate public support for campaign finance reform, well then, hitch up the ponies. Giddyap! But you can't help feeling a bit sorry for the poor Chinese suckers. They should have learned their lesson from the Japanese.

LENGTH: 3240 words

HEADLINE: The Best Seller of Byzantium

BYLINE: By Fernanda Eberstadt; Fernanda Eberstadt is a novelist and essayist. Her most recent novel, "When the Sons of Heaven Meet the Daughters of the Earth," has just been published.

 BODY:
Orhan Pamuk is sitting in his study on a hill overlooking Istanbul. Before him gleams the Bosporus, panning into the Sea of Marmara. On one shore lies the Greek-Ottoman Old City, with its sultans' palaces and Byzantine cathedral-turned-mosque. The other shore is Asia, shipyards and lighthouses. And at Pamuk's feet, cargo ships from Turkey's ancestral enemy Russia are parked in the harbor, disgorging traders from the ex-Soviet bloc who, since the collapse of Communism, have helped make Istanbul once again a multinational boom town.
Pamuk, lanky as an adolescent, graced with the almond eyes and mischievous smile of a Persian miniature, surveys this humming, jeweled city whose millennial complexities his fiction elaborates. Slyly, he says, "When I write, I take off my glasses so I can't see." 
 At 44, Orhan Pamuk is, as he reminds you with a characteristic mixture of provocation and naivete, very famous." His novels -- erudite, formally experimental yet compulsively readable -- have won him an international esteem unprecedented for a Turk. (His sole predecessor, Yashar Kemal, author of "Mehmed, My Hawk," writes tales of the Anatolian outback.) His books have been translated into 15 languages and are published by the most prestigious houses to critical glory: his latest novel,
"The New Life," just out from Farrar, Straus & Giroux, has been acclaimed by some American reviewers for the brilliance of its "post-modern metaphysics," "mesmerizing prose" and "Borgesian chiaroscuro."
But if Pamuk in the West enjoys a respectfully "literary" reputation, in his own country he is a rabble-rousing blockbuster. His five novels have each in turn sat at the top of the best-seller list in Turkey -- a nation not previously known for its serious readers. ("The New Life" at last tally had sold 200,000 copies.) Pirated editions of Pamuk's works are hawked from Istanbul street stalls; his appearance at Turkish human rights events attracts television crews; every morning he is in the newspapers being asked his opinion about the country's new Islamist Prime Minister or the threat of a military coup.
Pamuk's artistic accomplishment has been to play West against East, using the European novel's modernist tradition of formal experimentation in order to explore both his country's tangled Ottoman past and its contemporary politico-religious extremes. His books, which interleave Proustian family sagas with dervish allegories and reportage on modern-day paramilitary cults, have roused a furor in Turkey. Older Turkish intellectuals bred on Mustafa Kemal Ataturk's secularist dogma accuse him of playing with religion; Islamists accuse him of blasphemy; old-time leftists accuse him of cashing in. And meanwhile, Pamuk's new prominence in the Kurdish rights movement and his opposition to the police brutality and harsh penal codes that keep Turkey an authoritarian state threaten to alienate his popular audience. "Columnists write, 'He is a best seller; now he's selling his country,' " Pamuk says with amusement. "If you do something new in Turkey, they look at you as a pervert. The future can only come from America."
 Orhan pamuk is singularly well positioned to become the chronicler of his country's imperial neuroses. Turkey, after all, is not a conventionally third world country but a superpower that once stretched from Baghdad to the gates of Vienna, and Pamuk's own family history exemplifies in microcosm Turkey's efficient transition from a multiethnic empire to a modern nation-state.
The Pamuks belonged to Turkey's French-educated haute bourgeoisie of civil servants, law professors, businessmen. Orhan's mother's family was an old Istanbul clan of textile manufacturers; his father's father was a civil engineer who made a fortune in the 20's, when the new republic poured money into railroads. "Both Faulkner's grandfather and mine built railways," jokes Pamuk over a cup of tea in his office on a slushy January afternoon.
Pamuk grew up in an Istanbul apartment building built by his paternal grandfather and inhabited by an extended clutter of aunts, uncles, cousins -- a communal life of gossip, cards, tobacco, radio whose cultivated languors his novels elegize. The railwayman's sons, both engineers, went into various real-estate schemes, Pamuk tells me. "They were unsuccessful, I am sorry to say. All my childhood, I remember my grandmother crying, crying because this apartment building, that apartment building had been sold. My father would disappear to Paris and not call home for four days. In 10, 15 years, he and my uncle had wasted their father's money," Orhan recalls, laughing. "Today, nothing is left." His parents are divorced.
Orhan and his older brother, Sevket, were educated at the elite English-language Robert College. Sevket is today an Ottoman economic historian at the University of Bosporus. Orhan, who was expected to be an engineer, went on to study architecture -- "a prestigious, respected thing to do." The American novelist Maureen Freely, who knew Orhan in high school, says: "He was a good Ottoman boy. But then a screw went loose in his head." Orhan dropped out of architecture school and began writing novels. For years, nothing was published. This "dark" age recurs in Pamuk's talk as his formative calvary.
"When I was 22, I locked myself in my bedroom for eight years. You know Hawthorne? I was that kind of person, solitary, strange. People thought, oh, he's a failure. Once every three years my mother opened my bedroom door and said, 'Maybe you should apply to medical school.' Instead, I tore Repin's portraits of Tolstoy and Dostoyevsky out of a book and hung them on my wall."
In 1980, Turkey underwent one of its once-a-decade military coups, and Pamuk shelved a Conradian novel about a cadre of student revolutionaries who throw a bomb at the Prime Minister. Two years later -- the same year that he married his wife, Aylin, an Ottoman historian from a White Russian family -- his novel "Cevdet Bey and His Sons" appeared, to enormous success. A second novel, "The Silent House," a multigenerational saga of an Ottoman-republican family, was published in France by Gallimard.
It was with his third novel that Orhan Pamuk won truly international fame. "The White Castle," set in the 1690's at the outset of Ottoman decline, is an allegory of two look-alikes. A Venetian aristocrat, captured by pirates, is indentured to a Turkish inventor known only as Hoja (Master). Hoja, voracious for Western science, picks his Other's brain for knowledge of "them" -- Westerners -- and what "they" know. When Hoja and his Venetian servant, who have invented a war machine, join the Sultan's army on its siege of a white castle in southern Poland, the men swap identities. Hoja escapes to Venice, while the Venetian retires to Anatolian exile. Or does he? Who is really who?
"The White Castle" introduces the doppelganger theme that haunts Pamuk's work. "There's this other person who is always in a more genuine, more heartfelt, more hard-core place than you," Pamuk explains. "Even his failures are more authentic. You love him and you also want to kill him. These are my essential subjects: rivalry, jealousy, problems of domination and influence, revenge. Crucial but unworthy issues that come from growing up in an exclusively competitive childhood with a brother only 18 months older than I, and also of living on the margins of Europe. Turning around this feeling of off-centeredness. Saying, no, I am at the center. My contribution to the doppelganger problem was to give it an East-West tilt."
"The New Life" pushes even further the poignant, where-do-we-belong dialectic of isolationism and imitation that has plagued modern Turks. Its student hero has been transfigured by reading a book whose identity we never learn. In pursuit of the "new life" it reveals, he sets out on a bus ride across Turkey's Asian hinterland. Pamuk feelingly evokes the paranoid weirdness of provincial Turkey -- like America, a big, sparsely populated country where housewives, self-made millionaires and retired colonels meet in messianic conspiracies.
 We are sitting in pamuk's study. Outside is early darkness, fog and sleet, the reek of brown coal smoke. You can barely glimpse the big ships slinking along the Bosporus. It's Ramadan, and at the evening prayer call the holiday fairy lights bedecking the mosque next door are illuminated like a department store at Christmas.
Inside, Pamuk's office is a cozy sanctuary of floor-to-ceiling books behind old-fashioned glass breakfronts. In the middle sit two Art Deco desks -- one his grandfather's, the other his wife's grandfather's -- draped in green baize, at which Pamuk writes his novels by pen, in a large, legible hand. You have stepped into another century. Time is punctuated only by the prayer call and the fax machine, the latter bringing queries from Pamuk's foreign translators and invitations to international writers' congresses.
Pamuk and I are sitting on matching chintz armchair and sofa, facing the city. We have been talking for four days straight, 10, 11 hours a day. Sometimes we snatch a pot of tea from the kitchen, a handful of anise rusks. The K.G.B.-interrogation-style schedule is a tribute to Pamuk's compulsiveness: when his weary interviewer suggests a break, Pamuk says, "No, no, let's continue work." He is no stranger to obsessiveness, he admits -- it's the demon that keeps him productive. "Look, I work seven days a week, from 9 in the morning till 8 at night. I have the titles of the next eight novels I want to write. I feel myself pitiable, degraded on a day that I don't write. Turks -- who are all born poets, God is whispering in their ear -- have a dismissive phrase: he works like a clerk. I have turned this insult around: I am proud to say that I work like a clerk."
Pamuk claims he has no social life, rarely goes out, avoids the nights of raki-drinking that are a staple of Istanbul literary life. "I am not a worshiper of pagan happiness. I don't have a sunny family life; I prefer to be here in my office. Recently I discovered Elias Canetti, who says: 'It's not that I don't care about going to parties or meeting girls -- it's that the impact is too great. After one party, I can't work for two weeks.' The more uneventful the life, the more material there is. Events kill the imagination. You know Flaubert said, 'The fewer erections, the better the writing.' "
What substitutes for live encounters is the world of books -- for Pamuk, the "great consolation." His reading is feverish, encyclopedic; he cross-questions visitors about favorite authors like a boy trading baseball cards. The Contemporary American section of his library looks like a plugged-in New Yorker's shelves -- not just one but three volumes each by Mona Simpson, Harold Brodkey, Nicholson Baker.
Turkish intellectuals, while extolling Pamuk's technical virtuosity, frequently remark that his novels are "bookish." The translator Yurdanur Salman complains that Pamuk's fiction is "dry, cerebral, not a juicy, organic text." The Turkish literary critic Jale Parla notes, "His source of inspiration has been more literature than life."
Are European novels unreservedly part of his inheritance, I ask Pamuk, or does he read Joyce and Flaubert with more ambivalence than, say, an American might? Those in the "provinces" of world culture suffer from a "double consciousness," Pamuk answers. "In movie houses in Istanbul, growing up, we devoured Hollywood dramas as guides to etiquette. There would be a love scene in a restaurant, and someone in the back row would shout, 'Look, they're eating peaches with a knife and fork!' And the whole audience would go, 'Aha!'
"Things in Turkey are not shiny like in the West. There is a feeling of being off the track, forgotten. I have given so much time and energy to exploring that sadness of feeling that the life lived elsewhere is more mythic, more real than your own pale, shabby imitation-life."
This provincial curse of isolation is especially potent in the Turks' case because they were deliberately cut off from their own formidable history. After the Ottoman defeat in the First World War and the consequent dismemberment of the empire, Kemal Ataturk created the new republic in the West's image. All "Eastern" traces, including religion, were banned as backward. Ataturk outlawed the dervish sects, introduced the Latin alphabet and purged Turkish of its Arabic and Persian words. As a result, contemporary Turks cannot read their own classical texts, including a poem a hundred years old.
On the up side, Ataturk made a proud nation of a conquered remnant, offering the sole proof of a secular Muslim democracy. On the down side, he left a people with an enduring identity crisis. "Mentally trying to join another civilization, whether because of technology or a military defeat, is painful," says Pamuk. "I was raised in a community that considered itself to be Western, while the rest of the country did not seem to be. Religion for us was low culture." His sole encounter with Islam, growing up, was being taken to the mosque by the maid. "It was a place where the servants met to gossip, and I was so Westernized I felt naked taking off my shoes. This back and forth of having believed yourself to be Western, then realizing you're different; your naive way of ignoring these differences, then eventually trying to establish your own place -- this is not some metaphysical gymnastic. The whole country is suffering through the same dilemma. The simplest municipal problem -- how to design street lights or parking meters -- becomes part of the East-West debate. Then you understand that this transition state has been going on for 200 years; it is a way of life and will be for years to come."
It is this forced disenfranchisement, Pamuk suggests, that has fueled the country's rising fundamentalism, giving the Islamist Welfare Party the plurality of the national vote: "Ataturk repressed the lively heterogeneity of Ottoman Turkey's many Muslim sects." Until recently, Pamuk would have said that the growing religiosity you see among Turkey's middle classes was the normal expression of a moderate faith reasserting itself after decades of government repression. Now he's not so complacent. The sign of Islam's takeover: "Today even our scandals are religious scandals!" he jokes, referring to a dervish sect whose arrested leader has been accused of entering into one-night "marriages" with nubile proselytes.
It is Orhan Pamuk's novelistic mission both to capture the geographical schism in the Turkish soul and to reconcile it, planting Arabic and Persian words, images and stories in a Western form. His enterprise is by no means instinctual: "I have three generations of positivist blood in me; the geography of my literary heritage began with Henry James. Hegel defines 'the contingent' as that which exists but is not necessary. In my early 20's I kicked out of my fictional project anything with Islamic origins. It was only later I realized that classical Sufi literature not only existed but was necessary. I like Faulkner's describing how in his 20's he tried to write French novels, and in his 30's he turned to Mississippi. I, too, finally understood that my huge stem of a civilization was interesting, and that the whole tradition was still alive in Istanbul. To search out this civilization in broken walls, in broken faces, became my highest challenge."
 Tonight pamuk is having dinner with his old friend Jeri Laber, a senior adviser to Human Rights Watch, and several leading Turkish human rights activists. On earlier occasions I have seen him play the enfant terrible, quick-fire, high-strung, brilliantly volatile. Tonight he is all unobtrusive diplomacy, bent on making sure, invisibly, that everybody is happy.
Jeri Laber is in Istanbul for the trial of a publisher and a translator who were charged with violating Article 159.1 of the penal code, which forbids "defamation or belittling of the state security forces." The "defamation" occurred in their translation of a Human Rights Watch report, in which an unnamed United States Embassy official is quoted as referring to the Turkish Army's Special Teams, who are fighting Kurdish rebels in the southeast, as "thugs." (In the end, they received light, symbolic sentences.) There are dozens of laws in Turkey limiting freedom of expression, I am told, including those against "thoughts inconsistent with Turkey's historical values." Tonight's guests would like to see each one junked.
Pamuk, too, is involved in his own trial. This second trial involves a recently issued anthology of articles, each of which on its original publication was charged with breaking a law. Now more than a thousand people, including Orhan, have declared themselves "editors," making the anthology's publication "the largest act of civil disobedience in Turkey." If its participants are jailed, many of Turkey's most popular soap operas, music programs and newspapers will shut down.
Tonight's guests include Semra Somersan and Sanar Yurdatapan, both veterans in Turkey's human rights struggle. Yurdatapan and Orhan make a curious contrast: Yurdatapan, a hard-living, grizzled musician, movie-star handsome, has just come out of prison for the umpteenth time and seems determined to go straight back in; Orhan is self-parodically cautious, always playing the angles. Orhan and Jeri Laber are both politely making sure that the Western luminaries they hope will come for the anthology trial don't also end up in a Turkish clink.
We are dining at a White Russian restaurant, and the evening is very jolly: the whiff of prison makes everybody giggly. We drink vodka and stay till the faded blond cashier casts voodoo looks to make us go home. When we part, Yurdatapan heads for the bus station, where it turns out he is taking a midnight bus to Ankara: a six-hour flirtation with death on mountain roads that would make most teen-agers blanch. (Three months later he was back in custody.)
The next day, when I drop by Pamuk's office to say goodbye, he asks me what I made of the previous evening. We perform a post-mortem, Pamuk omnisciently decoding the delicate diplomacy at work between the American and the Turkish contingents. "Last night was bad for my writing," he admits. "Day-to-day involvement in a country's brutal politics kills the creator's soul, slowly, slowly.
"Turkey is a savage country; there is no understanding for other religious, ethnic, linguistic communities. If Jesus Christ were a Turkish policeman, he would be corrupted within 10 months. Every day shameful scandals are exposed in the newspapers, but nothing changes. I want to live in a society in which people don't get arrested for their thoughts."
I ask him, as dusk falls on the marine expanse of lighthouses and minarets, if he might live elsewhere -- expecting, I guess, for Pamuk to swear, if I forget thee, O Istanbul, let my right hand wither. I am surprised by his alacrity. Yes, he could easily move to New York or Paris. "With guilty conscience, but it's an author's job to transfer his work. I admire James Joyce in Trieste, carrying within himself the dramatic weight of Ireland. All of us Turkish intellectuals have moments of exile, feeling estranged by the coups or by this new fundamentalism. My first thought is always, how will I take my library?"

GRAPHIC: Photos: Orhan Pamuk. (pg. 35); Turks are born poets, says Pamuk, but he still writes compulsively 11 hours a day. (Photographs by Stephen Gill) (pg. 37)
