HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Downtown;
Oversupply of Office Space Is Starting to Dwindle

 BODY:
THE recently announced decisions by the Standard & Poors Corporation and the Chubb Insurance Company to commit to long-term leases totaling almost 1.1 million square feet of space in an underutilized building at 55 Water Street in lower Manhattan are drawing more attention to what has been happening downtown in the last few years.
Through a combination of an improvement in business at the financial companies that have long been the economic engine of the area, an emphasis on emerging technology companies and the ongoing conversion of some obsolete office buildings to residences, the huge oversupply of office space that was the result of the slump of the early 1990's is beginning to dwindle. 
 The vacancy rate for office space downtown in all categories has declined to 17.1 percent as of the end of March, compared to a high of 20.5 percent in 1992, according to statistics compiled by Cushman & Wakefield..
To be sure, Standard & Poors decided to move to the location only after a long flirtation with New Jersey and a tax and energy incentive package worth $23.7 million, but the fact that it chose to consolidate at that location is an indication of how the market has changed, industry executives say. S&P took 937,000 square feet, while Chubb signed up for 150,000.
"It's a vastly different world today than it was a few years ago," said Howard S. Grufferman, a senior managing director at Julien J. Studley, which specializes in representing tenants. "The vacancy rate in Class A is under 10 percent, and the landlords are starting to get more aggressive. We advise tenants to move quickly to get their deals done."
Others acknowledge that an improvement is under way but say its impact is uneven. "The pickup is isolated to the 15 best buildings," said James S. Meiskin, president of Plymouth Partners, a brokerage company. "Rents are up and concessions are down in Class A, but it is not happening in Class B and C buildings. There is an over 30 percent vacancy rate in Class C."
Nevertheless, the growth in the number of jobs in the financial sector will force companies to seek space to house the additional workers, said John M. Cefaly, an executive director in the downtown office of Cushman & Wakefield. "The private sector is expanding for the first time in a long time," he said. He said the city's plan to offer tax abatements and other incentives for development in the area was beginning to show effects.
Nevertheless, in a mixed market, it helps to have a distinguishing characteristic that makes one property stand out from the crowd. Among the approaches being undertaken are an emphasis on communications technology and aggressive updating of aging buildings in good locations.
The triangular building at the intersection of Wall, Beaver and Pearl Streets was the first investment in America by a German mutual fund, usually known by its initials, DEGI. The fund paid $16.8 million for the 75-year-old building in 1980 and put $20 million more into it over the last five years in a refurbishing that includes repairs to the roof and facade, increasing the size of the lobby from one to two stories, updated mechanical systems and new elevator cabs.
Klaus Hohmann, the chief executive of DEGI, said that buying a building with the address 67 Wall Street was a reasonable first investment for a European company. "Downtown New York and especially Wall Street is symbolic of a capitalist type of economy," he said. "I did not have to explain this address to anybody."
He said the fund decided to invest in the property during a real estate recession to gain a competitive edge over other older buildings in the vicinity and because of a long-term approach toward property ownership. "In Germany, real property is considered an asset class of its own," he said, "but in the United States it is a commodity."
The investment seems to be paying off. Despite its age, the building is 94 percent occupied and never had a serious occupancy problem even during the recession, said its property manager, David Schlang, who has been associated with it as a manager and sometime owner since 1957.
"Older buildings that have been kept up in this area do well," said Richard M. Feldman of Williamson, Picket and Gross, marketing consultant to 67 Wall. "The older ones that have not been kept up do not."
ANOTHER approach has been to emphasize advanced communications capabilities and other technical features to attract computer-intensive companies such as Internet service providers, web-site designers and other companies generally grouped under the rubric "new media." The pioneer in this regard was the Rudin family, which took a building that had stood empty for five years, and was not particularly attractive because of its low ceiling heights and small floors, and converted it into the New York Information Technology Center.
"We are basically done here," said William C. Rudin, the general partner in the renovation project at 55 Broad Street. "Within 60 days we will be finished with leasing." He said that about one-third of the companies leasing space at 55 Broad had never before had a presence in New York but wanted to be near other fledgling companies developing related technologies.
He said the company was looking for another property for a similar conversion. "We are going to have a technology district here," he said. "The city has a diamond district and a fashion district, why not a technology district?"
Mr. Rudin admits that because of the heavy investment in technology and the relatively low annual rents (an average of $17.29 a square foot, according to brokers) it will be a long time before the building produces a financial return. But by transforming 55 Broad from a building that had once been occupied by Drexel Burnham Lambert into the hub of high tech in the area, it enhances the prospects for other family holdings in the area, he said.
Certainly, the success of the project has encouraged would-be emulators. With $200,000 in marketing assistance from the city and a similar amount from the Alliance for Downtown New York, six buildings in the area are participating in a program designed to attract new small businesses that want to cut the cost of access to the Internet. Each owner is contributing $10,000 to the effort.
Called the Plug 'n' Go program, it involves pre-built, pre-wired office spaces that are leased for short terms at annual rents of $15 a square foot, a discount in a market where rents are now in the high teens to low 20's. "The concept is to fill a niche by developing a Levittown for cyberspace," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance. "These are starter homes for young companies."
Mr. Weisbrod acknowledged the program's debt to the Rudins' initiative. "There was a lot of path-setting at 55 Broad," he said. "This program would not have been possible without that success."
The reason for the short leases is that these new companies do not know if they will grow, fail or end up being absorbed by another company, said Sharon Greenberger, who manages the program for the Alliance. A typical lease, she said, is for two years and 1,500 square feet.
She said that since the program was announced in February, 20 leases, accounting for 35,000 of the 120,000 square feet involved, have been signed. The buildings are at 11 Broadway, 32 Broadway, 55 John Street, 90 John Street, 111 John Street and 90 William Street.
Having space already prepared with high capacity communications lines, such as the T-1 line, and Internet service providers cuts communications costs, said Jonathan Rudes, who helps manage 90 John Street and 90 William Street for Newmark & Company Real Estate. "It can cost about $1,000 a month for a T-1 line and $500 to $700 a month for local charges," Mr. Rudes said. "That adds up to $1,700 a month, which can be steep for a small company." In a wired building with an Internet service provider managing access to the high capacity line, the local charges are eliminated, cutting the monthly cost about in half, he said.
Mr. Weisbrod, who noted that the buildings involved in the Plug 'n' Go program were generally considered Class B, said this kind of specialized marketing and conversion of old office buildings to residences would continue to whittle away at the downtown vacancy problem. "We are ahead of where we thought we would be two years ago," he said. "The downtown area is undergoing an extraordinary transformation.

SECTION: Section 9;Page 4;Column 4;Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1205 words

HEADLINE: Habitats/164 East 91st Street;
Architects Find Right Rx For Former Medical Lab

 BODY:
THE refrigerator had a big red sticker that shouted "Caution -- Bio Hazards." There was another notice that informed anyone looking at the abandoned medical laboratory building that the lab had been licensed by the city to work with viruses and microorganisms.
"I was pregnant at the time," recalled Michele Kolb, an architect, "and -- I admit it -- I did start to worry." 
 "Our first call was to some doctor friends," added Eric Rosenberg, her husband, also an architect.
"I was getting prepared to be told that when I opened one of the cabinets I'd released some rare strain of microbe on New York City," Ms. Kolb recalled with a shudder.
When looking for a town-house bargain, many people are willing to put up with anything -- almost anything -- to get a deal. And when the couple found out that the toxic materials had been removed and their worries about deadly contamination were groundless, they did, in fact, get a deal. They paid $395,000 for the four-story, four-bedroom town house at 164 East 91st Street, between Lexington and Third Avenue.
The couple, who had been living in a one-bedroom apartment at 83d Street and Third Avenue, clearly needed to expand. Ideally, they were after a town house, so they could install their joint architectural practice downstairs and make their parenting duties more convenient. (At the time, their practice was on 26th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.)
"We wanted to eliminate the commute so Michele could care for the children and still remain active," Mr. Rosenberg said (they now have two children, Owen, 3, and Kyle, almost 1). "We had been looking for years, and somewhere along the line, we'd kind of stopped. We bought some land in Stone Ridge, N.Y.," -- in upstate Ulster County -- "and, in 1991, we built a new house." The design was a collaboration, he said, like all their work.
But one day in 1993, Ms. Kolb was thumbing through the classified advertisements and spotted a house marked "Commercial" in the Houses for Sale category.
"What caught our eye was the price: $600,000," she said. Even though the real estate market was not as heated as it is now, she said, the price still looked low: houses in that neighborhood were then priced between $1 million and $2 million. They quickly saw why the price was so low -- only they didn't think it was low anymore.
"It was a complete wreck," said Mr. Rosenberg. The place had been rented by a medical laboratory for 40 years, he found out. At one time, all the floors had been used by the lab; by the time the couple saw it, only the parlor floor was being used. On the top floor, the couple saw water leaks and water damage; they saw broken windows and the pigeons that had flown in -- "not all of them alive," Mr. Rosenberg said.
"In other words, it was the type of place that would scare most people away," he said.
But underneath the water damage and the filth was a sound building. "It didn't have sagging floors," he said.
"We learned it was built in the late 19th century," she said. "It was originally a town house with a stoop. The facade had been very ornate, with an elaborate cornice and trim; it looked exquisite on the drawings."
In 1912, the original detailed facade had been stripped away, and the house had been extended to the front property line. At some point, a so-called picture window was stoppered into what had been the parlor floor -- and the entire facade was coated in stucco. In 1955, the building had been renovated to create the laboratory.
"They had stripped it, and done a very bad Bauhaus interpretation," Mr. Rosenberg said.
After surprisingly little negotiation, the couple said, the owners accepted $395,000, but troubles soon followed -- including a lawsuit between the seller and the laboratory that delayed the sale.
The settlement took two years, during which the couple became the butt of office jokes. "It was a joke with our colleagues and friends," Ms. Kolb said. "We had done the drawings; we'd been there 100 times. It got so bad we couldn't even mention it to them. They'd roll their eyes and say, 'Sure.' "
They proved their friends wrong. They did indeed buy the property -- in March 1995. But the tenant was still there.
"They'd lost their legal standing," said Mr. Rosenberg, "and they went within a month or two without too much kicking and screaming."
During the extensive renovation -- the couple's ninth as architects -- Ms. Kolb stayed at the site, acting as their general contractor, running the job and hiring the subcontractors. Because they found skilled craftsmen and worked with them on site, the owners said they were able to do things they wouldn't have been able to afford otherwise, things such as herringbone brick-lined fireplaces.
They had to work fast, because they had to pay additional interest for their construction loan. Because of the condition of the building, no bank would give them a regular mortgage, which costs less per month. When they were finished, they were able to turn the construction loan into a residential mortgage -- and their interest went down two percentage points.
AT that point, they were also able to go to the city's Finance Department and change their tax designation, from commercial to residential -- and cut their tax bill by three-quarters. (They declined to give their tax figures.)
The couple also had to file for an amended Certificate of Occupancy, as well as a special reconsideration of the city building code to allow them to reconfigure their staircase.
In the end, the total gut renovation -- which included permission from the Department of Transportation to build a privacy fence four feet out on the sidewalk -- took five months. It included not only a new interior but changes to about one-third of the facade, chipping away masonry to make new and bigger window openings and adding steel. They shored up the building so they can add, if they wish, five more feet in the rear.
They had a strict budget -- $350,000 -- so they had to make more than a few compromises, such as the veneered, prefinished cherry floors (versus thick, solid cherry) they found at an auction for $1.25 a foot. They also found sales on bulk materials and contract overages. "If somebody ended up with 60,000 square feet of limestone, you can buy some or all of it," Mr. Rosenberg explained. They took rocks from their excavation of the ground floor and created a backyard patio.
For the six bathrooms, they used decorating tricks: They bought cheap (they prefer the word "economical") ceramic tile, but then bordered it with more expensive tumbled marble, cut into 1 1/2-inch pieces.
Although they kept the interiors streamlined -- partly because of budget, partly because of their taste -- they designed the renovation so that future owners can transform the interiors into a more elaborate prewar place. Their planning included placing the ceiling heating registers four inches from the wall to allow for the addition of crown molding. In the end, they believe they turned what had been a graffiti-covered eyesore into a sophisticated place to live and work.
"Town houses are selling in this neighborhood for $400 a square foot," Ms. Kolb said. "Ours came in closer to $200."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Huge 16-Year Smithville Project Under Way Again

 BODY:
FOR the last 16 years, construction has been on-again, off-again at the huge mixed-use project in the Towne of Historic Smithville, a rural enclave in Galloway Township in Atlantic County 11 miles northwest of Atlantic City.
Construction delays were first caused by a dispute with environmentalists concerning the 2,200-acre site, which borders a national wildlife refuge and contains streams and wetlands. A lawsuit resulting in compromise in 1986 with a new ownership resolved this matter. In 1991, the recession stalled construction, pushing the owner into default and three years later lenders holding portions of a $25 million mortgage took the unfinished project in lieu of foreclosure. 
 Now the development's residential component -- once planned for 6,800 units then whittled down to 4,000, of which fewer than 1,600 were built or started -- is moving forward. But it will have a different mix, including housing for active adults, fewer units and a new owner -- K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, the state's largest builder. The project's revival is the result of three years of discussions on how to proceed with development of the site. The negotiations involved Hovnanian, the lenders, local, state and county officials, a coalition of state and national environmentalists, and resident homeowners.
Agreements have been reached, or are being completed, to meet the concerns of each group. All say they are hopeful the project will be completed and they will get what they were promised. The site surrounds the town center, a collection of 18th-century buildings refashioned into speciality shops and restaurants. Hovnanian will buy the land in sections from Galloway Holding Company, the entity created by the lenders to sell the site. They include Core State, NatWest and First Union.
"Combining our interests was the best way to recoup as much of the face value of the mortgage" as possible, said Carl Goldberg, partner of Starbare Associates, an affiliate of Roseland Property Company, a Roseland developer. Starbare took over part of the Smithville site when it bought a pool of distressed properties from NatWest in 1993. Neither side would disclose the sales price. But industry professionals put it at about $10 million.
Under a township approved development plan Hovnanian will build 2,000 residences instead of the remaining 2,500 units that could have been built by the previous developer, a subsidiary of the Patt Organization of Hollidaysburg, Pa. At least 30 percent of the units will be part of a community that offers people 55 and over in their retirement or preretirement years recreation, socializing and someone else to do the outside maintenance. The rest of the residential component will have no age restrictions.
Ara Hovnanian, president of Hovnanian Enterprises, said his company had purchased the property because of its "appealing price" and location, near Atlantic City and the shore. With Atlantic City "seeing renewed interest, the timing was also good," he said. He was referring to the $7 billion in public and private investment planned or under way there, including the tripling of casino hotel rooms to 27,000.
Mr. Hovnanian said that having the flexibility to do both age-restricted and other housing would support so large a project, now called K. Hovnanian's Four Seasons at Historic Smithville.
The project will be the fifth active-adult community in the state for Hovnanian, and others are planned. Some 417 age-restricted units, including both detached and town houses, are expected to be completed through 1998. The estimated value of the entire project, which will be built over the next 10 years, is $300 million, said Robert H. Karen, president of the shore area region for Hovnanian.
The development is helped by signs that the market for active-adult housing in the state is strong. Among the reasons are an aging population and a healthy resale market, which enables buyers over 55 to sell their existing homes, industry analysts said.
There is also the continuing trend nationally for people to retire close to their family and friends. And William E. Becker, a Teaneck-based consultant specializing in housing for the elderly, noted a recent trend within New Jersey to build active-adult communities outside of their traditional sites, such as Ocean County, long a magnet for such housing. He said eight projects were being planned throughout the state that could produce 6,000 units over the next two years.
GETTING the Smithville project to this point was not easy since the number of groups and issues involved complicated negotiations over its future. "It was like nailing Jello to a wall," said Lewis S. Kurland, Hovnanian's attorney.
Under the agreement being worked out with homeowners the company will build the promised, but never delivered, recreational amenities and road improvements, make repairs to existing structures and tear down the 60 incomplete units that have been hurt by time and neglect. And it, along with the banks, will turn over control of the housing management to resident homeowners sooner than required.
"It is understandable that some homeowners are still upset and skeptical based on the history of the project," said Thomas D. Giachetti. He is a partner with the law firm of Stark & Stark, which is representing the Smithville Homeowners Association, as well as two individual condominium associations. "This is not a perfect solution and all the work is not done yet."
But, he added, there "is renewed hope about project's future" and that residents will see a return on their investment.
Hovnanian will also fulfill, with modifications, the 1986 agreement the environmental coalition, including the American Littoral Society in Sandy Hook and the National Audubon Society, worked out with Patt, the previous developer.
The compromise was reached after the coalition sued the state for improperly granting permits in 1981 to the original developer, Cadillac Fairview of Toronto, to build 6,800 residences, 800,000 square feet of commerical space and a golf course. The plaintiff successfully argued that the project would endanger the area's water supply and wildlife and that the runoff would harm the oyster beds in the Mullica River and the clams in the Great Bay.
Under that agreement 4,000 homes, 300,000 feet of commercial space, but not a golf course, could rise on part of the site while 1,000 acres would be left permanently open and transferred to a nonprofit entity. Patt also was to contribute $200 from the sale of each unit to pay for, among other things, the maintenance of the open space.
Though Patt built or started some 700 units, which were added to the 857 homes Cadillac had built, the environmentally sensitive acres were never transferred and the $200-per-sale contribution was never made. Hovnanian will transfer that protected land -- now a habitat for a bald eagle, an endangered species -- to an as yet-undetermined group as it develops the rest of the site and will make a similar contribution for its upkeep. The boundaries of the land still must be determined.
"Hopefully this is the final chapter," said D.W. Bennett, executive director of the American Littoral Society. Added Walter Pomeroy, mid-Atlantic regional vice president of the National Audubon Society: "It will bring closure to a battle we won 10 years ago and give us our land." And, he said, the project will be half its original size.
For Galloway Township the revamped project brings a number of positives. It puts a derailed project back on track at a lower density and with adult housing, which will not burden local schools, said Andrew S. Katz, the township manager.
Mr. Karen of Hovnanian said work had begun on the first 82 age-restricted detached homes, ranging in size from 1,200 to 1,860 square feet and in price from the low $100,000 to $160,000 range. Sales are to start at the end of May. Within a month the company expects to offer town houses with 1,100 to 1,400 square feet and priced from about $90,000 to $110,000. Plans are also moving forward on an additional 275 detached homes.

HEADLINE: An Effect, Not a Cause

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "No Need to Raise Rates Again," (Viewpoint, March 30), the economist Edward Yardeni asserted that the Federal Reserve was wrong to combat inflation at this time and that he did not support further tightening of interest rates by the Fed in May. 
 Mr. Yardeni also says that the United States economy has been prospering without an increase in inflation, because of the advances in labor productivity and other cost-cutting technologies. This is clearly possible. But the argument closes with this remark: "Our prosperity is a result of disinflation!"
Disinflation, however, is a fall in the inflation rate; hence, it describes a situation in which prices are rising more slowly over time. Moreover, in a competitive market, the behavior of prices is determined by the interaction of demand and supply.
The advances in labor productivity are examples of positive supply shocks that cause disinflation and prosperity. Disinflation, then, is the effect, not the cause, of a more productive labor force.
I would say instead that "our disinflation and prosperity are the result of advances in labor productivity." The distinction needs to be made, or else one might draw the wrong conclusion -- that the Fed should follow a policy of disinflation.
 
JOSEPH SANTOS
Newark, April 3
 
The writer is an adjunct professor of economics at Rutgers University.
 
NO MORE

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Libby Pierpont, Erik Engstrom

 BODY:
Elizabeth Hobson Pierpont, an executive recruiter, was married yesterday to Erik Engstrom, a publishing executive. The Rev. Mary T. Cushman, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. James' Church in New York.
Mrs. Engstrom, who is known as Libby, is an executive director in the investment management practice at Russell Reynolds Associates, the international recruitment company in New York. She graduated from Harvard University. She is the daughter of Elizabeth Wentworth Pierpont and Carleton Langley Pierpont of Darien, Conn. The bride's father owns a commercial real-estate company that bears his name in New York. 
 Mr. Engstrom is the president of the Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group in New York. He graduated from the Stockholm School of Economics and the Royal Institute of Technology, also in Stockholm. He received an M.B.A. from Harvard University, which he attended as a Fulbright scholar. He is a son of Alice Engstrom and Dr. Kjell Engstrom of Taby, Sweden. Dr. Engstrom retired as the managing director of the Swedish Museum of Natural History in Stockholm.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
A Machine to Call Your Own

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
YOU may be miffed about paying surcharges for using automated teller machines. But be careful if think you see a way to cash in on the trend.
As A.T.M. fees have risen, so has the number of promoters peddling the machines to individual entrepreneurs as the route to a quick fortune. Few of these deals, however, work out as promised, according to consumer advocates. 
 It makes little sense for most individuals to own A.T.M.'s because of the enormous price per machine, usually $35,000 and up, and the continuing expenses that can put an additional $35,000 a year on the tab.
"When you look at who actually buys A.T.M.'s, it's usually businesses that install them on site," said George L. Albright, president of Speer & Associates, an Atlanta consulting firm to the banking industry. "Aside from the expense, an individual owner may have a difficult time getting sponsored by a bank to get into the A.T.M. network. Without that, none of the customers could use the machine."
Such hurdles, however, have not thwarted the pitches. Advertisements inviting readers to own their own A.T.M.'s -- and promoting guaranteed returns of 40 percent or more -- have run regularly in several national newspapers.
One of these deal makers is American Business Concepts, a company based in Glendale, Calif., that says it formed in November just to take advantage of the rise in A.T.M. surcharges -- part of which go to the A.T.M. owner and part to the supplier. In a classified ad in USA Today in March, the company said anyone with $10,000 could buy a machine and "make money every time someone uses your A.T.M."
Trouble is, by the time one reporter, anyway, called American Business Concepts, the price for the machine was quoted as $15,000.. And Len Kalish, a pleasant salesman for the company, wants to make sure up front that you have the cash before continuing his pitch.
Satisfied when you say you can get the money, he goes on briefly about his daughter who is completing her doctoral work at the University of California at Los Angeles, joking that intelligence is obviously not hereditary. After chuckling to himself, he quickly outlines the economics of owning an A.T.M.
Unfortunately, virtually everything he says is wrong.
For example. you're lucky, he says, to be interested in an A.T.M. today. People couldn't own A.T.M.'s until April 1996, when Congress passed a law deregulating the industry, he says.
According to Mr. Albright, however, individuals have always been able to buy A.T.M.'s. What changed last April was that Cirrus and Plus -- the country's two largest A.T.M. networks, owned by Mastercard and Visa, respectively -- allowed their members to levy surcharges. That, of course, had nothing to do with Congress.
Next, Mr. Kalish says, if you sign up, American Business Concepts will assign you a location visited monthly by 25,000 to 50,000 passers-by. Assuming that 2.5 percent to 5 percent of them stop to use the machine, he says, that's great play for a full-service machine that costs only $15,000.
If your machine were part of a large cost-sharing network, as most large banks' are, you could break even with the 625 minimum monthly visits that Mr. Kalish has implied.
But as the owner of a lone machine you will need far more activity. How much more? Try 3,000 transactions a month, according to some consultants. And an A.T.M. priced at $15,000 may sound like a good deal. Large banks that buy in bulk seldom pay less than $35,000 apiece, with some models running as high as $110,000, although consultants say cheap knock-offs can be found for as little as $7,000.
After explaining to you how the A.T.M. business works, Mr. Kalish is ready to divulge exactly how you're going to get rich: through surcharges. These machines levy a $2 surcharge on every transaction, on which you'll clear $1.20.
That's because there are, of course, some expenses. American Business Concepts will take a 10 percent cut off the top on every transaction. The armored car service that delivers the money for use in the A.T.M. will take 5 percent. Insurance -- you need at least $2 million to cover theft and liability, Mr. Kalish advises -- should cost 2.5 percent, and the lease, well, maybe the landlord will also want another 2.5 percent off the top. But hey, it's a turnkey deal. Now, asks my salesman, when do you think you can come up with the $15,000?
You mumble politely that you can't figure out what happened to the part of the $2 surcharge that is still unaccounted for: about 40 cents. Well, he can't either.
(Repeated calls to the company for official comment on their sales information were not returned.) Mr. Kalish knows only that this is a good business and a great opportunity. He's got your address and is sending the packet by overnight mail.
One more thing, he says. You'll send the money as soon as you get this package?
You'll do that, won't you?

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROAD CHANNEL;
Ferry to Be Free, but Queens-to-Queens Bridge Is Still $1.75

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF

 BODY:
For years, residents of this small island community situated in the middle of Jamaica Bay have protested the toll they pay to travel the half-mile-long Cross Bay Veterans Memorial Bridge to the Rockaway Peninsula, a neighborhood with which they share a ZIP code and a high school. Many Broad Channel people work on the peninsula.
Last week, as Mayor Giuliani toured Queens pledging to eliminate the 50-cent fare on the Staten Island Ferry and anticipating the end of the two-fare zone, people in Broad Channel wondered what happened to the promise the Mayor made to them during his last campaign. 
 They said that while seeking their support, Mr. Giuliani promised that if elected he would consider repealing the $1.50 bridge toll. The heavily Democratic community voted overwhelmingly for Mr. Giuliani. Since the election, the bridge toll has risen to $1.75.
"That toll is 100 percent unjust," said Dan Tubridy, 48, a resident of Broad Channel who owns the Pier 92 restaurant on the Rockaway Beach side of the bridge. Mr. Tubridy said the toll cost him and other local residents about $1,500 a year, a large sum for people living in some of the most economically depressed neighborhoods in Queens. "It's the only interborough bridge in the city," Mr. Turbidy said. "You have to pay to go from Queens to Queens."
"Mayor Giuliani never made a commitment concerning the Cross Bay Bridge," said Colleen Roche, a spokeswoman for the Mayor. She added that with the introduction last year of the E-Z Pass, the windshield sticker that collects tolls electronically, the cost of the crossing dropped to 67 cents for pass-holders.
Audrey I. Pheffer, the Democratic Assemblywoman who represents the 23d District, remembers things differently. "That's a joke," Ms. Pheffer said in response to Ms. Roche's statement. "When Mr. Giuliani came to the community asking to be Mayor Giuliani, he promised to get rid of the toll. Between him and the Governor with their appointees to the M.T.A. board, it should have been gone long ago."
Once a drawbridge, the Cross Bay Bridge was completed in May 1970. When the bridge opened, the fare was 10 cents. Since then, residents have seen the tolls soar. Some increases have prompted violent protests and boycotts during which some participants were arrested.
The bridge is maintained by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, a branch of the Metropolitan Transit Authority. The income from tolls collected on all city bridges and tunnels is pooled to support new transportation projects, maintenance and to pay off outstanding bonds. Almost $6.5 million was collected on the bridge last year.
"We have been sensitive to the issue, but the bond contracts require us to charge tolls on all New York City bridges and tunnels," said Frank Pascual, a spokesman for the transportation agency. CHARLIE LeDUFF

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Giving Savings Bonds a Shot in the Arm

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FACED with dwindling sales, the Treasury moved suddenly last week to rejuvenate its savings bonds, still the world's most widely held security.
As of May 1, rates are higher, interest accrues faster, the risk of a big penalty is reduced and, believe it or not, the Government has even made things simpler. 
 "This is very positive," said Daniel J. Pederson, a private specialist who attributed much of the recent sales decline to the allure of stock funds. "Immediately, people who buy bonds will be getting an extra one to one and a half points" return.
So a $10,000 investment in savings bonds that previously would generate perhaps $450 a year will now provide $550 to $600, no small improvement for this most conservative security. Federal taxes are still deferred, of course, and like other Federal securities, savings bonds are free of state and local tax.
The terms on savings bonds bought before May 1 are unaffected by the latest changes. The interest rate on those is 85 percent of a combination of a short-term Treasury rate and a long-term rate.
Here is the new deal: The interest rate is 90 percent of the average yield for five-year Treasury securities over the preceding six months. These rates will be announced on May 1 and on Nov. 1 and will apply for the following six months. Savings bonds bought this month carry an initial interest rate of 5.68 percent.
Two years ago, the Treasury took away the guaranteed minimum return on savings bonds. Until May 1995, investors could rest assured that they would get at least 4 percent a year. Before 1986, the minimum rate was 7.5 percent. Since the variable-rate program began, sales have tumbled, probably for several reasons, including the lack of a floor, the overall decline in interest rates and the soaring returns available from competing investments like stocks and stock mutual funds.
Sales of savings bonds, which come in denominations from $50 to $10,000, fell from $17.5 billion in 1993 to $7.2 billion in 1995 and $6 billion last year. Still, ownership by 55 million Americans makes savings bonds the most widely held security.
Interest on new Series EE savings bonds, which are really zero-coupon securities because the return comes entirely from an increase in their stated value, will accrue monthly instead of only twice a year, and the interest will be compounded twice a year. This change eliminates the risk of an investor losing as much as five months' interest by redeeming a bond a bit too early, as was possible under the old system.
On the other hand, there is now a three-month interest penalty for redeeming bonds within five years, part of the Government's effort to raise the nation's woefully low savings pace, 4.2 percent of national output, less than that of many developing countries. Under the old rules, a buyer needed to hold bonds only six months to avoid an early-redemption penalty.
But the previous system had two tiers. Anyone who held bonds for less than five years received 85 percent of the average rate on six-month Treasury bills. Anyone who held bonds for longer received 85 percent of the rate on five-year Treasury notes.
With this in mind, Mr. Pederson, author of "U.S. Savings Bonds: A Comprehensive Guide for Bond Owners and Financial Professionals," suggested that people at least consider selling old bonds and reinvesting in the new, more attractive ones that will also earn interest for up to 30 years. One drawback to such a plan is that investors will have to report the interest earned so far and pay tax on it.
People who bought bonds many years ago should also dig those up. Holding bonds past their maturity date is a no-win proposition. Interest stops accruing, and an estimated $4 billion in savings bonds have stopped earning anything for their owners.
IN any event, since all savings bond returns are tied to the first business day of the month, it is almost always a good idea to buy as late in the month as possible and to redeem as soon as the proper month arrives. With careful planning, said Peter Hollenbach, a Treasury official, "you're getting about 59 days' " more interest than someone who times poorly.
In addition to tax deferral and exemption from state and local levies, the not-so-humble savings bond still allows proceeds to be applied tax free to college tuition, provided that household income is not too high in the year the bonds are redeemed. The tax break starts phasing out this year at $76,250 for a joint income tax return.
Because all Series EE bonds are marketed at half their face value and interest is pegged to market rates that change every six months, the time when they will reach full face value cannot be predicted. To provide some certainty for buyers of newly issued bonds, the Treasury said it would make a one-time upward adjustment to achieve the face value of any bond 17 years old that low rates had prevented from getting there on its own.
And the Treasury, which already has set up a home page for savings bonds on the World Wide Web (www.publicdebt.treas.gov/sav/ sav.htm), has further marketing efforts on the way. Later this year, it will introduce on-line buying with credit cards. Early in 1998, it will offer the first inflation-proof savings bonds, whose returns will be indexed to consumer prices.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
The Stronger Dollar Chases Fewer Bargains Abroad

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
IF Americans picked their foreign destinations by the breaks they get when the dollar strengthens, there would be a flood of tourists to Turkey, Ecuador, Hungary and Japan this summer.
The dollar now buys nearly 80 percent more Turkish lira, making it easier to come home with a carpet; 25 percent more sucre for Panama hats in Quito; 20 percent more forints for Herend china in Budapest, and 20 percent more yen for a kimono in Kyoto. 
 During the last year, the dollar has risen sharply against most of the world's major currencies, a move spurred by the pace of United States economic growth, the continuing good performance of the stock market and the rise in American interest rates.
In reality, the jump in the value of the dollar does not translate into the same amount of savings for Americans abroad, as hotels and restaurants raise their prices and street vendors bargain harder. Inflation in some countries can also erase the benefits of a strong dollar.
"We haven't seen a terrible increase because of the stronger dollar," said Aylin Spears, a partner in Blue Voyage, Turkish Tours and Travel in San Francisco. Many hotels are setting their prices in dollars, she said, and inflation is rising quickly enough to erode the dollar's gains.
Even so, the big move of the dollar in the last year is still cutting prices overseas. Not that falling prices make much difference to American tourists. According to travel analysts, Americans do not seem to be swayed by such currency swings in the short run.
"We don't see these types of changes being significant in a span of 12 or 18 months," said James V. Cammisa Jr., a travel industry analyst in Miami.
So, if you are traveling to the 10 favorite foreign destinations for Americans, what's in store?
Among those top 10, only Japan is also among the 10 countries against which the dollar had its best rally over the last year.
Switzerland and Spain ranked high among favorite destinations (12th and 13th, respectively, in 1995, the latest data available) as well as among places where the dollar performed the best (gaining 17.55 percent and 13.8 percent, respectively, in the 12 months through May 1.).
The dollar has appreciated in value -- but not as much -- against the currencies of France, Germany and Italy, which ranked fourth, fifth and sixth on the top 10 destinations list.
Britain, the third-most-popular destination, may be especially enticing, for those interested in seeing London with its first Prime Minister from the Labor Party since 1979. But tourists are unlikely to come for the bargains. Britain's economy has been rebounding -- a fact that did not help the Conservatives -- and so has the British pound.
In the last year the value of the dollar against the pound has shrunk 7.5 percent, lifting the price of Saville Row suits and tea and scones alike.
While rejoicing at the better values in Russia, Pakistan, South Korea and Sweden, as well as in Continental Europe, American travelers should not get too giddy. The deals are better now, but they are nowhere near what they were a decade ago.
In the early 1980's, the dollar was rushing toward record highs against the Japanese yen and the currencies of Europe. So while the 5.82 francs, 1.72 marks and the 126 yen to the dollar today look far better than the 5.18 francs, 1.53 marks and 105 yen of a year ago, think what you could have bought when the dollar equaled 10 francs, 3.45 marks and 262 yen in 1985.
This great downswing in the value of the dollar since the mid-1980's seems to have had more impact on visitors to the United States than on Americans tourists abroad. It was the sharp fall in the dollar that lead to a surge of travel to the United States at the end of the 1980's. And those foreign tourists were spending more here than Americans were spending abroad.
With that decline in the dollar, Canadian tourism to the United States shot up, rising 13.5 percent in 1987 and 77 percent from 1986 through 1991. But as the American dollar has rebounded against the Canadian dollar, the pace of Canadian tourism has fallen off. The annual number of visitors is down 21 percent since 1991, according to the Commerce Department's preliminary estimates for 1997.
Over time, however, a stronger dollar does seem to affect the choices of where some Americans go, especially if the country is already a favorite destination. Mr. Cammisa said the dollar's 60 percent rise against the Italian lira since September 1992 had clearly stimulated travel there. Commerce Department data show that in 1995, the number of Americans going to Italy jumped 12 percent.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3248 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Is Your A.T.M. Ripping You Off?

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
ASK Pat Bond about his visit to an automated teller machine near his home several weeks ago, and he will tell you how he was almost robbed -- not by a mugger, but by the A.T.M.
When Mr. Bond, a computer consultant in Bethesda, Md., who usually banks at a credit union in Virginia, punched in the amount of his withdrawal, the A.T.M. flashed a warning that it was about to deduct $3 more, the fee for using that machine. Riled, Mr. Bond hit the cancel button and walked away. 
 "The banks believe we have no choice but to pay these fees," Mr. Bond said. "Well, there is. I can still walk with my feet to a bank that doesn't charge fees."
Well, he can try.
On that day, to save the $3, Mr. Bond got into his car and drove 25 miles to his credit union. Since then, he has sometimes used his debit card at the checkout counter of the supermarket to get cash or driven to a local Citibank branch, which does not levy surcharges.
Such maneuvers are becoming increasingly common as more and more people are hit with sticker shock at the nation's cash machines, owned by banks and other companies, prompting countless on-the-spot decisions about just how much they are willing to pay for one of modern life's most cherished conveniences. To some degree, the future shape of the banking industry depends on how many people vote with their feet, and in which direction they head.
"Banks have discovered a new way to make money they didn't have before," said George L. Albright, president of Speer & Associates, a retail banking consulting firm in Atlanta. "In the past, no matter how high the fees on A.T.M.'s have been, most consumers went right on paying. We're heading toward a day when that won't be true anymore."
 For 25 years, the industry has trumpeted cash machines as street-corner liberators, freeing banks of a big chunk of their payroll costs and freeing consumers from the need to stand in line for a teller and the worry that they will be caught short of cash.
Americans have become hooked on the convenience. Last year, medium use meant 72 visits to the machines, according to Payment Systems Inc., a Tampa, Fla., consulting firm to the banking industry. Heavy users, who account for one-sixth of all A.T.M. card holders, averaged 156 visits to machines last year.
In the beginning there was no charge to use the machines, and even now it is the rare bank that imposes a fee on its customers for access to its own A.T.M.'s. But over the years almost all banks slapped on a $1 charge, known as a foreign-use fee, for going to another bank's machines. Now the levies are often $2, and climbing. One of those dollars still pays the foreign-use fee, which is split among the customer's home bank, the A.T.M.'s bank and the A.T.M. network -- Plus or Cirrus, for example. But the other money usually goes entirely to the bank whose machine was used. An exception is when an A.T.M. is placed inside a store, and the merchant may take 30 cents of the extra dollar.
That second or even third dollar, known as a surcharge, has not only riled Mr. Bond and plenty of other A.T.M. users; it has also caught the attention of Federal and state legislators, who are introducing bills to ban its imposition.
With the surcharges, A.T.M.'s have become so expensive to use that consumers can often get money cheaper from last-resort venues like check-cashing companies, places once frequented mostly by the financially unstable. No more. A New Yorker who makes a $100 withdrawal from an A.T.M. that levies surcharges typically pays some $2.50 in fees, including the foreign-use charge. That same person could use a check-cashing service and lose only 1.1 percent, or $1.10.
In fact, in this instance, A.T.M. users would even come out better by buying brand-name traveler's checks, which cost only 1 percent of the total, or $1.
The banks defend the surcharge on several grounds. They say they need it to cover the expense of installing and servicing A.T.M.'s in new "off-site" locations like shopping malls, theaters and department stores. They also say they need it to curb a good thing that has started to spin out of control: too many customers are using the machines too often to make tiny withdrawals, tying up the cash networks and adding to administrative and other costs.
But critics contend that the banks simply can not resist an easy chance to charge more money, particularly because most if not all of the surcharge, they say, falls directly to the bottom line.
"What this comes down to is people paying a double charge to use an A.T.M. and then not getting any extra benefit back," said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, who heads the Senate Banking Committee and says he will soon reintroduce Federal legislation that would ban surcharges. "That's just not right." His first bill to ban surcharges failed to get out of committee in May 1996.
In any event, the extra charge of a dollar or two is turning into big bucks for the banks. Over the next 12 months, banks could ring up as much as $1.9 billion in revenues from the surcharges, according to the United States Public Interest Research Group, a consumer advocacy organization in Washington. That is more than the 1996 sales of the Adolph Coors Company.
So much easy money is flowing in that A.T.M.'s may even become grist for pyramid schemes. Hundreds of investors nationwide have snapped up shares in the machines only to discover months later that they have been defrauded, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Last October, at the request of the S.E.C., a Federal judge placed the Western Executive Group and Cash Systems U.S.A. Inc., both of Gilbert, Ariz., into receivership after the two companies were accused by the S.E.C. of bilking more than 100 investors out of $4.5 million.
Western Executive was said by the S.E.C. to have offered investors full ownership of off-site A.T.M.'s at prices of up to $24,000 each, with promises of 17 percent to 20 percent annual returns over five years. But the money did not come from A.T.M. profits; it came from new investors, the S.E.C. said. Western Executive bought 119 A.T.M.'s and set up 41 of them, but only a handful were profitable, the S.E.C. said.
Charles R. Rietz, the former president of Western Executive, which also controlled Cash Systems, said the companies did nothing wrong. According to Mr. Rietz, Western Executive sold 203 A.T.M.'s at $23,000 each. And he contended that the companies "had some internal business problems which could have been handled on an internal basis, but the S.E.C. chose to see sinister things in our business situation."
A civil trial is expected early next year.
"The fact that you can get A.T.M. surcharges creates an opportunity for income," said David Bassham, a lawyer in the S.E.C.'s Los Angeles office. "A.T.M. schemes are a new type of fraud for us."
LEGISLATORS and consumer watchdog groups are worried about the impact of the new fees on the nation's 11,867 credit unions. Since many credit unions have only one cash machine, more of their customers are likely to visit other banks' A.T.M.'s. The groups fear that large numbers of credit union members will switch their accounts to banks or savings institutions that have extensive A.T.M. networks. That could cripple some already weak credit unions while giving virtual monopolies to large banks in certain markets.
"One thing that won't be good for consumers is for the big banks to get bigger and the small ones to get smaller," said Gail K. Hillebrand, a lawyer in San Francisco for Consumers Union, the Washington-based consumer advocacy group. "Fewer players in the market will leave consumers at the mercy of these bigger players."
That will give them the power, she said, to charge ever-higher fees and to possibly unleash new ones.
"And then there will be no place to run," she added.
Banks are already becoming more creative when it comes to levying fees. Two years ago, First Union, a banking company based in Charlotte, N.C., started charging some customers for putting money in the bank. Customers in North Carolina (and now in Virginia) pay 50 cents to use a counter deposit slip -- the kind found inside the bank and used there only for teller transactions. First Union says the charge is justified: customers who use counter slips tend to stall the teller lines and cause encoding errors, problems that would not occur if they used an A.T.M. instead.
But as controversial as A.T.M. surcharges are, they are not going to disappear any time soon. Even Senator D'Amato acknowledges that his bill to ban them is likely to go nowhere.
For one thing, notwithstanding the many Pat Bonds of the world, millions of other consumers don't notice, or don't care, when they are assessed extra fees. And some legislators say they will refuse to limit the amount of money banks make. Many of them say the consumer should pay for A.T.M. convenience; to avoid the fees, they say, A.T.M. users can seek out machines that don't charge them.
Even though foreign-use fees are almost universal, it is true that surcharges are not yet levied on A.T.M. users in every state. The surcharges are most prevalent in California, Florida and Georgia, where most banks levy them, and they are widespread in New Jersey. But Connecticut and Iowa have banned the fees on A.T.M.'s in their states, although banks based there can still impose surcharges on machines in other places. And in New York, only eight banks impose the fees. Two of the largest -- Fleet Bank and First Union -- are dwarfs compared with Chase Manhattan and Citibank, no-surcharge banks with A.T.M.'s on virtually every Manhattan corner. Both, however, charge foreign-use fees.
"Right now, it's true that New York has a lot of banks that do not charge surcharges," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, who has a bill pending in the House that would require disclosure of any surcharges on every machine. "But that may not always be the case. What's important here is that most consumers don't know when they're being charged a hefty fee for using an A.T.M. that's not owned by their bank. I'm pushing for more disclosure."
THOSE hefty fees are likely only to increase. Consider these numbers: Some 45 percent of A.T.M.'s now levy surcharges, compared with just 23 percent eight months ago, according to the United States Public Interest Research Group. And the average surcharge nationwide was $1.15 in March, up from 97 cents last September.
Three states -- Arkansas, Mississippi and Wyoming -- have capped the amount that can be charged, although in Mississippi, the cap is scant comfort to consumer advocates. Banks there can pocket a surcharge of $2, or 4 percent of the withdrawal, whichever is greater. That means that for every $100 withdrawal, A.T.M. users can pay up to $5, including the $1 foreign-use fee. A.T.M. users in Wyoming can pay a maximum of $1 and in Arkansas, $2.
Although 93 percent of all banks and savings institutions charge foreign-use fees, according to Speer & Associates, and though, according to bank consultants, the average A.T.M. user shells out $72 a year in these fees, legislators have largely left those charges alone. That is because banks have argued convincingly that these fees are meant to cover the system's expenses. For each $1 fee, the bank that owns the cash machine usually gets 65 cents, while 10 cents goes to the A.T.M. network -- like Mac, Plus or Cirrus -- to which the machine is connected, according to banking consultants. That leaves 25 cents for the consumer's bank.
Seeing the margins on the foreign-use fees as too slim, several Texas banks in 1986 became the first to impose a 25-cent surcharge on transactions at their new A.T.M.'s at shopping malls, theaters and department stores. Not only did the surcharge quickly double to 50 cents; it also spread to A.T.M.'s at the Texas banks' headquarters and branches. Then other banks started imposing them.
The surcharges were primarily confined to the Sun Belt until last April, when Plus and Cirrus -- the nation's largest A.T.M. networks -- agreed to allow their banks to levy the extra fees in most places nationwide.
This year, the average A.T.M. user is expected to pay $155 in combined fees, according to industry consultants. The fees amount to a charge of around 2.5 percent on the average withdrawal of $87 from a Plus A.T.M., according to Bank Network News, a Chicago newsletter. That is more than twice the 1.1 percent charged by New York check-cashing outlets or by American Express for its traveler's checks.
The fees add up quickly, especially for A.T.M. users in areas with a limited number of banks. But even large cities can prove troublesome. Just try to escape a surcharge in California if you do not have an account at Wells Fargo or Bank of America, but you use their A.T.M.'s. Those two banks alone levy fees on 46 percent of the state's bank machines.
Ronald Bennett, a computer salesman in Reading, Pa., started cashing checks at the supermarket with his debit card as often as possible last year in order to avoid A.T.M. surcharges, but he still wound up using some A.T.M.'s and paying $120 in fees.
"You can't always make it to one of your bank's A.T.M.'s," he said. "The banks get money from the customers because we're an easy target. But when you're talking about $120 just to get my money from the bank, that's a lot. I could have paid my Internet bill for a year with that, not to mention several months of my phone or cable bills."
A.T.M. owners often levy heftier surcharges at machines in supermarkets, hotels or theaters, betting that many consumers will pay the fees instead of leaving their groceries at the checkout counter or missing the movie in order to drive to their banks.
Surcharges are highest in places where the consumer is almost sure to stay put. In an Atlantic City's casino, an A.T.M. transaction usually costs $4.
But not every machine in a prime location carries a surcharge. For example, some 500 of the 698 A.T.M.'s in New York owned by the EDS Corporation -- the country's second-largest A.T.M. owner after the Bank of America -- do not impose one, even though the machines are at Food Emporium and Pathmark supermarkets. Surcharges at the other EDS machines are 50 or 75 cents.
Telling the expensive machines from the free ones is often tricky. The New York Public Interest Research Group found in a survey in April that several bank machines did not disclose the surcharge until after the consumer had entered the amount of the withdrawal, forcing a quick decision about completing the transaction.
Others don't tell until the transaction is over, said Representative Schumer, who added that he became so concerned about disclosure that he made it the prime focus of the A.T.M. bill he sponsored in the House eight months ago. The bill is still in committee.
"The amount of the surcharge should be disclosed before you make the transaction, not on the statement afterward," Mr. Schumer said. "It should be on the screen or in a place where the consumer can clearly see it."
In criticizing A.T.M. fees, consumer advocates are particularly angry that customers are paying for a service that is saving the banks money. A teller transaction typically costs a large bank $1.07, compared with just 27 cents for the use of an A.T.M., according to Gemini Consulting, a management consulting firm in Morristown, N.J.
"From a conceptual point of view, it makes more sense to put the surcharge on teller service," said William Gregor, a Gemini senior vice president in Cambridge, Mass. "A few years ago, First Chicago and Citibank tried it, and they received a very negative response from the public. It's not something they're willing to try again."
Only a few banks are offering no-fee A.T.M. service as a way to attract depositors. But even then, strings are usually attached.
The Bank of New York, for example, requires A.T.M. users to keep at least $3,000 on deposit to escape foreign-use fees, which it then either waives or pays on behalf of the customer.
The hidden cost to the customer, though, is the lost opportunity to earn more interest on the $3,000 somewhere else. A savings account at the Bank of New York earns only 3.9 percent interest, or $119 a year.. A customer might be better off investing in a mutual fund and paying the fees. If the fund garnered only a 10 percent annual return, or $300, the investor would still come out $109 ahead, assuming the $72 paid in average foreign-use fees each year.
It is precisely that flow into high-yielding mutual funds that makes fees necessary, the banks say. With billions of dollars moving out of low-interest saving accounts into Wall Street's money market funds, banks say they can no longer afford to give anything away. On top of that, 50 percent of all households with checking or savings accounts are money-losers for banks, according to the First Manhattan Consulting Group, a New York firm.
"Plenty of people with accounts won't have a credit card or a car loan at the bank and yet they will come in and ask the teller to check their account balance for them," Mr. Gregor said. "The banks use A.T.M. fees to make up for these money-losing accounts. And there are plenty of them."
Unprofitable accounts aside, bank executives argue that A.T.M. fees are justified. The charges, they say, keep A.T.M. users from making numerous withdrawals, a habit that costs the banks 25 cents to 45 cents a transaction depending on the volume, according to Speer & Associates.
THE economics are relatively simple. Off-site A.T.M. machines are expensive to buy and install, easily running $110,000 for a machine that is heavily armored, not counting upkeep.
To break even without surcharges, an off-premises A.T.M. needs to make 3,000 transactions a month, according to Bank Network News. If surcharges are imposed, that same A.T.M. can break even after 500 transactions.
"We call the surcharge a non-customer-use fee," said Paul J. Levine, a spokesman for First Union, which has 64 A.T.M.'s in Westchester and Rockland Counties in New York. All levy $1.50 surcharges.
"We charge the fee because it wouldn't be fair for someone to use our network and not bear part of the cost of the system," Mr. Levine said. "We've had only a very slight decline in volume when we initiated the fee, much less than what we expected."
But some consumers, like Mr. Bond, are indeed voting with their feet, as inconvenient as that may be. They are using their own banks' A.T.M.'s and tellers and moving their accounts to banks with larger A.T.M. networks.
Others are still paying the fees but are increasing the amounts of each withdrawal, thus cutting down on the number of transactions.
Carrying huge wads of cash or planning a day around getting money are understandable responses, but they defeat the whole point of putting so much metal at consumers' fingertips. When the machines first opened for business, banks expected to benefit each time a machine displaced a human teller. But consumers were also supposed to be well served.
"The way A.T.M.s are set up now, consumers still have a choice," Mr. Gregor, of Gemini Consulting, said. "If Citibank decides to charge a $10 surcharge, you can always move to Chase. What you don't want to happen is for every bank in town to charge surcharges. Then it will be like living in the Sands casino. There's one game in town. And you're losing it."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1887 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Where the Street Meets the Strip

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN-PIETERSEN 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
ALL I needed to hear was that investment guru Howard J. Ruff was going to be at "The Money Show" this past week here, the gambling mecca of the Western world. I didn't care that I would be lunching with the legendary Louis Rukeyser. I was blase about partaking in seminars where I could quiz famous forecasters like Elaine Garzarelli.
I didn't even care that there would be tons of free advice on the next hot stocks, the inside scoop on interest rates, sample newsletters and lots of useless promotional knickknacks. 
 No. I just wanted Howard.
You see, Howard Ruff and I have had a thing since I was 13 -- only Howard doesn't know it. Howard, who writes the Ruff Times newsletter, is the reason I became a trader and spent six long years on the floor of the American Stock Exchange shouting my lungs out. His 1979 chef-d'oeuvre, "How To Prosper During the Coming Bad Years," so affected me that after only three chapters I was buying canned food and stockpiling it in the basement. The bad times never came but a particularly vicious Buffalo blizzard did, during which I was able to sell the entire hoard to my parents at inflationary prices.
He's still a Gloomy Gus. Addressing the extravaganza here as one of the keynote speakers, he argued that today's stock market is "thoroughly picked over." The only stocks he endorses are overlooked small-capitalization issues, like Brighton Technologies, a marketer of computers in China, and Red Oak Hereford Farms, a meat processor in Red Oak, Iowa.
For the three days of the meeting, a period when the Dow reassured investors by soaring nearly 3 percent, I was part of the trek of the faithful. Starting on Tuesday, about 9,000 investors from 50 states swarmed into Bally's Las Vegas, rubbing elbows with their favorite prognosticators, scouting for advice and comparing the track records of their gurus against competitors.
The impresarios of "The Money Show," Charles and Kim Githler, a husband-and-wife team out of Sarasota, Fla., have been producing investment seminars since 1981, but this is the Big One, bearing out that dictum from Kevin Costner in "Field of Dreams": "If you build it, they will come."
And have they ever. What Renaissance weekends are to East Coast intellectuals, this event is to small investors. The gatherings began modestly enough as run-of-the-mill conventions in San Francisco and Orlando, Fla., but they took a new turn when Las Vegas was added to the schedule, along with the occasional expert-packed cruise to the Baltics. This year, the promoters are expecting to accommodate a total of 45,000 by adding shows in Chicago and Seattle.
What accounts for this irrational exuberance? It can't be Bally's food (at $2 a banana, no one was buying), or the fact that attendance costs next to nothing. (Actually, you have to subscribe to one of 5 financial newsletters at $49 to $235 a year to get in. Air fare and accommodations are extra.)
For the real answer, look no further than the shelves of the nearest bookstore, groaning under the weight of financial self-help books.
"Of all the big financial shows, this one's the best," said Neil J. George Jr. chief economist for the St. Louis-based Mark Twain Bank, which just merged with the Mercantile Bank. "In three days, we can interact with 5,000 to 7,000 present and potential customers in our target market -- perhaps even teach them all about trading foreign currency, a main service of ours."
Certainly there's no letup in the lava-like flow of stock market information inundating America's investing public. As the Dow marches higher, turning gutsy investors into millionaires, individuals are managing more of their own retirement money. Women are no exception. Last year 1,950 advice-hungry women made the pilgrimage to Las Vegas, up 11 percent from 1995. And 1,542 attended the 1996 show in San Francisco, up almost 30 percent from the year before.
Most of the crowd is between 55 and 65, but regardless of age, there seem to be three types of attendees, according to veteran Money Show-goer Timothy Walker of Grosse Ile, Mich.: "Those who have a lot of money, those who think they have a lot of money and those who want a lot of money." His wife, Katherine, fitting right in with her Mickey Mouse T-shirt and sequined cap, adds, "And you can't tell who's who by the way they're dressed."
One common denominator is a penchant for research -- their own. Judging from a survey of the participants that was conducted before the event, you'll never see these people giving a blank check to their local brokers, or opening discretionary accounts. In fact, they remind me of the typical Home Depot shoppers -- the weekend do-it-yourselfers. They ask a lot of questions and virtually all subscribe to one or more newsletters. Seventy-five percent use discount brokers and many belong to investment clubs. The majority say they have dabbled in option, commodity, and currency trading.
And by now, many of them have learned one of the most appealing attractions of "The oney Show:" if you go to all the seminars and panel discussions, you're bound to find support for your point of view -- whether you are a bull, bear or fence-sitter.
Here's what the bulls were saying:
Frank Holmes, chairman and CEO of U.S. Global Investors, warned, "If you're not long, then you're going to be wrong." He's investing in Russia and in technology stocks.
Elaine Garzarelli, editor of The Garzarelli Outlook, sees the Dow hitting 7,600 this year. She likes consumer services, nondurables, technology, banking and insurance and she advises steering clear of iron, steel, aluminum, and housing stocks.
And Al Frank, editor of The Prudent Speculator, a newsletter, whose model portfolio has been ranked No. 1 one over the last 15 years with a 21 percent compounded annual return, expects a summer rally. He is partial to beaten-down technology stocks and bank stocks and thinks a small interest rate cut could nudge the Dow to 8,000 by year-end.
AND what of the bears?
Geraldine Weiss, publisher of nvestment Quality Trends, another newsletter, advises putting 30 percent of your money into undervalued stocks; the rest in Treasuries and certificates of deposit.
Stan Weinstein, editor of The Professional Tape Reader, mistrusts the technology sector, would avoid aerospace plays like Boeing, and sees the Dow tumbling to 6,200 by year-end. "Only 30 percent of the stock charts are technically healthy right now compared to 70 percent last year at this time," he said.
Sitting squarely on the fence was Bert Dohmen, editor of "Bert Dohmen's Wellington Letter." In his view, "the bear market has already started for many stocks," noting that 77 percent of Nasdaq stocks were 20 percent off recent highs. Still, he's bullish on real estate investment trusts, banks and European stock markets like those of Germany, France and England.
Got all that? Who could? Fortunately, for the financially challenged, there were less weighty distractions.
Take the Nasdaq booth, where a fantastic new Web site was being demonstrated by a representative wearing funky magenta-colored glasses festooned with verdant palm trees.
Then there was Jay Baker, a buttoned-down managing director of the American Stock Exchange, patiently explaining the workings of SPDR's, an index fund that mirrors the Standard & Poor's 500, pronounced "spiders," while next door the Princeton Research Group was promoting franchises of Hubbs Pubs, a restaurant chain featuring 99 beers from around the world.
In yet another booth, conservatively dressed representatives of Lucent Technologies, the equipment company that was spun off from AT&T last year in the largest initial public stock offering ever, kept trying to hand out copies of its annual report. Attendees, however, were far more interested in World Wide Web Casinos, a stock offering of an Antigua-based outfit enabling individuals to enter a virtual casino and gamble over the Internet.
And it wouldn't be Las Vegas without scantily-dressed show girls, in this case operating overhead projectors and otherwise doing their thing for the future of capitalism. James Dines, editor of an eponymous newsletter and a noted gold bug, is convinced that the presence of show girls raises the net asset value of anything he does. But even "The Money Show" has its limits. At last year's San Francisco show, he was instructed by management to send his models home in order to "go long" additional clothing in order to "cover their short positions."
The talk of this year's show was the stunning Catherine Curran, a 6-foot-1, 18-year-old Las Vegas native, who was earning tuition money for Dartmouth College, where she starts in the fall, by handing out information for the Ultimate Cigar Company, a purveyor of cigars that went public not long ago. It needs her help badly. The stock, which trades over-the-counter almost by appointment, ended the week at $1.50, or 50 cents lower than where it started the week and a far cry from the $9.75 it was fetching in December. Maybe it was just as well that there was no easy way to punch up stock quotes in the entire hotel.
So, in the final analysis, do attendees get anything out of this?
After 200 talks, panel discussions and exhibits, this former Wall Street professional was totally overwhelmed, so I imagined that most others walked away confused, too. But that was not the case. Despite the information overload, most attendees didn't seem to have any trouble filtering out the hype and the irrelevant. David Houck of Minneapolis, a retired controller for Archer Daniels Midland, has attended the show for eight years. He comes for the stock tips. Over the years he's used information from the shows to get into Merck at $29 (now $90.875), Honeywell at $29 (now $70) and John Deere at $40 (now $46.50).
Robert Arena, a mining equipment salesman, came from Price, Utah, to learn more about options trading. Last year he was inspired by the wisdom of Bernard G. Shaeffer and subscribed to Shaeffer's Option Advisor newsletter, but has since decided to look elsewhere.This year Mr. Arena listened intently to a presentation by Kenneth R. Trester, an options expert, and if he decides he likes what he heard, he'll subscribe to Mr. Trester's Complete Option Report.
Henry and Marge Hazenberg, from Kennewick, Wash., attended their third "Money Show" in order to check out the latest investment gadgetry. Last year they subscribed to a computerized, market-timing service called Vectorvest Prographics, a computerized charting software program that analyzes and ranks more than 5,500 stocks. The couple saw the program at the show and said it "helped them to make a lot of money."
On the other hand, Tom Krenick of Henderson, W.Va., is just happy to pick up free samples of all the different newsletters.
Some find money. Others find love.
The Githlers estimate that 40 percent of attendees are single. The couple know of 12 matches made through the events. Two part-time New Yorkers, Charles and Elizabeth Holmann. met at the San Francisco show three years ago and announced a merger a few years later. Mr. Githler explains it this way: for a relationship to work, people have to be compatible on every level -- and sometimes that includes being able to sit through hourlong economic seminars.
