SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3046 words

HEADLINE: Pariahs of the City: 24 Hours in a Cab

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
AT 4:11 A.M., Tasneem Khan carefully spread a green prayer rug across the linoleum floor in his apartment in Ridgewood, Queens. Dressed in jeans, a navy blue golf shirt and a white Muslim prayer cap, he was a study in contrasts. Softly murmuring prayers in Arabic, he turned his stocky frame toward Mecca. Slowly rocking back and forth, Mr. Khan, a 35-year-old Pakistani immigrant, readied himself for a grueling 12-hour-shift as New York's work horse, pariah and ambassador to the world.
Mr. Khan, his partner Sajid, and about 20,000 other Pakistani, Indian and Bangladeshi immigrants are the new face of New York City's $1 billion-a-year yellow cab industry. Jumping from only 7 percent of the city's 41,000 licensed taxi drivers in 1984 to more than 50 percent today, according to the Taxi and Limousine Commission, the typical New York City cab driver is now more likely to be from the Punjab than from Long Island City. 
 But some New Yorkers aren't celebrating. As is common in the ritual of immigration in America, the newcomers are greeted with hostility. Fairly or unfairly, South Asian cab drivers are stereotyped by some customers as rude and unable to speak English, disparaged by fellow drivers as vicious competitors who cause accidents, and blamed for what some drivers say is a steady decline in wages and respect in what was once one of New York's prized working-class professions.
"They're part of making it worse," said Johnny Northern, who's been driving a cab since 1972. "Customers tell me they have a terrible attitude."
But 24 hours in the life of Mr. Khan and his partner, and interviews with dozens of South Asian cab drivers, reveal a group of immigrants hoping to follow the well-carved path of Russian Jews, Haitians and others who have driven cabs to gain an economic foothold in the United States. But the South Asian hacks face a new, unexpected obstacle in their scramble toward the middle class: strict new immigration rules.
On Urdu-filled CB radio channels and in Pakistani, Indian and Bangladeshi restaurants and garages, the talk is of deportation and confusion. How the law enacted last September and tougher political asylum regulations enacted in January 1995 will affect New York's South Asian community and the taxi industry as a whole remains unclear.
Mr. Khan, who took advantage of a 1986 amnesty law to get American citizenship, is one of the lucky ones. His 28-year-old partner, Sajid, who entered the United States illegally and spoke on the condition that he be identified only by his first name, faces possible deportation.
"Last month, everyone said the deportations would start on March 31, but nothing happened," said Sajid, whose family paid a trafficker $10,000 to smuggle him into the United States. "Everyone is afraid. I'm afraid too."
On Thursday, April 24, Tasneem Khan started off late. He had visited the family of his ill father-in-law the previous night, and awakened at 3:30 A.M., a half hour later than usual. A devout Muslim, he decided to catch the 4:41 A.M. bus instead of his usual 4:21 bus so he wouldn't have to rush or skip prayers.
He shares an immaculate one-bedroom apartment with his 27-year-old brother, Nadeem, who works in a newsstand in the World Trade Center. Their six sisters and parents are still in Lahore, Pakistan. The two brothers see each other for only a few minutes each day because of their conflicting schedules. Waiting in darkness and rain on the deserted corner of Madison Street and Cypress Avenue in Ridgewood, Mr. Khan boarded the Q58 bus for the 20-minute ride to his yellow chariot.
In an increasingly common practice, Mr. Khan and Sajid lease their cab for a week at a time. To get the most from their lease, the cab operates nearly 24 hours a day, seven days a week. While one man sleeps, the other drives.
At 5:05, Mr. Khan finds the cab parked on the corner where Sajid leaves it each night. He starts an engine that has been idle for no more than two hours. At 5:10, he is cruising west down the Queens Boulevard service lane, hunting for his first fare of the day.
Mr. Khan grew up in the city of Lahore in Pakistan. As a cricket player and athlete, he was depressed by the weight he put on when he first started driving a cab. Daily workouts after his 12-hour shift now keep him thin. After graduating from Punjab University in 1980 with the equivalent of a bachelor's degree in business, he entered the United States in 1981 on a student visa.
He took a few courses but quickly ran out of money. After working in newsstands in Manhattan for five years, he met a Pakistani-American woman through a relative and married her in 1990. In 1989, he started driving a cab. He used his savings from driving to open newsstands in 1990 and 1993, but both failed at a cost of $45,000 in savings and bank loans.
 
A Fear of Deportations, And a Need for Immigrants
 Mr. Khan and other South Asian drivers estimated that as many as 30 percent of the Pakistanis, Bangladeshis and Indians driving yellow cabs in New York City may be living and working under false requests for political asylum. Exactly how many South Asians could face deportation is unknown, but taxi fleet owners warn that fewer and fewer people are interested in working as cabbies. Taxi Commission officials say fears of large-scale deportations are probably overblown, but the loss of immigrant drivers could handicap an industry that has grown dependent on cheap immigrant labor.
"We are in the process of profiling how this new law will affect this business," said Diane McGrath-McKetchnie, the Taxi and Limousine Commission chairwoman. "I'm hoping it won't have any significant impact on the T.L.C., but I'm not sure about it."
At 5:17, Mr. Khan enters Manhattan, the borough where 80 percent of yellow cab fares begin or end, the commission says. For the next six hours -- at least half of his shift -- all of his fares will go toward paying $75 in fees to the Al-Ehram taxi fleet in Long Island City, Queens, from which he rents his cab and medallion. Over time, the value of a medallion has steadily risen to about $200,000, and so has the cost of renting them.
Only 35 percent of the people who own medallions actually drive cabs; most medallions are owned by large taxi fleets or investors who buy the medallions and rent them to drivers at a profit.
As Mr. Khan speeds down a deserted Second Avenue at 5:20 A.M., it is already filled with a handful of yellow cabs prowling for passengers. At one time, Mr. Khan had hoped to buy his own medallion, but now he says he plans to get out of the business. He attributes his thinning hair to stress and said the pay is not worth the hassle.
 
'We're Easy Targets,' Says a Driver Craving Respect
 Mr. Khan complains that taxi drivers are increasingly viewed with disdain in New York City. Passengers bark orders at drivers, he said, and don't treat them with respect. "We are treated worse than animals," he said, echoing other drivers' comments. "Cabdrivers are everyone's scapegoats. We're easy targets."
He turns onto 10th Street and parks at the corner of 11th Street and First Avenue. At 5:25 A.M., he rushes through an unmarked door and enters a nondescript storefront mosque for prayers. Mr. Khan tries to go every day for morning and afternoon prayers. If he has a fare, he will pray silently in the cab, as the passenger remains oblivious to what he is doing.
But Mr. Khan's religious beliefs defy stereotyping. He does not ask his wife to wear a veil and uses the money he earns to help put her through medical school on the Caribbean island Dominica. He deferred his dream of becoming a certified public accountant to support his wife's studies, and he criticizes Islamic fundamentalists. "There is nothing in the Koran that says women should not being educated," he said. "All my sisters are very well educated."
After prayers, Mr. Khan hunts for fares on the Upper East Side, picking up his first passenger at 5:59 at 95th Street and Second Avenue. As the sun begins to rise, he listens to the 6 A.M. BBC news for a reminder of home. As the city wakes, he begins speaking with driver friends over his radio. Tips on where passengers are and where traffic is snarled are exchanged.
The next three frenzied hours are spent shuttling passengers primarily from the Upper East Side and Upper West Side to midtown, where 42 percent of all yellow cab fares begin or end. He eats no breakfast, stopping only to buy a coffee at 7:10.
His one break is a fare to La Guardia Airport, after which he sits in a holding lot with other cabs from 7:38 to 8:25. Normally, he decides the wait for a fare is too long and heads back to Manhattan empty, but on this day he stays. During the wait, he stretches his legs and reads a newspaper. By 9:05, he has dropped his airport passenger off at the Plaza Hotel and is back in midtown hunting for customers.
There has been an effort to improve the performance of the taxi industry over the last four years. The previous T.L.C. chairman, Christopher Lynn, and Ms. McGrath-McKetchnie have made changes intended to improve service, like requiring all new drivers to attend classes on geography, courtesy and basic English. Last week, Police Commissioner Howard Safir announced efforts to enforce traffic laws and said that taxi drivers would be specifically targeted.
Ms. McGrath-McKetchnie said the number of serious complaints has dropped and for the first time that she knows of, the T.L.C. is receiving more letters praising cabbies for courtesy and professionalism than letters complaining of rudeness.
But cabbies complain of an increasingly competitive marketplace where car services are encroaching on yellow cabs. They say new regulations cost them time and money, and that the police frequently blanket them with expensive tickets. But Ms. McGrath-McKetchnie points to a sharp drop in robberies and yellow cab drivers killed on the job as evidence that the Giuliani administration's reforms have also aided drivers.
Many cabbies concede that their earnings rose slightly after a 20 percent fare increase in March 1996. The T.L.C. barred fleets and medallion owners from increasing the rents drivers paid for cabs by more than 14 percent to ensure that drivers received some of the increase. Despite accusations from drivers, T.L.C. officials say surveys have caught no fleets violating the cap.
Several American-born drivers blamed South Asians for making the business more ruthless. Cabbies complained of Pakistanis, Indians and Bangladeshis cutting them off and risking people's lives simply to get a fare. "The Pakistanis, the Indians and the Bangladeshis, they're the worst," said Francisco de la Cruz, who has been driving a cab for 13 years. "They drive like crazy. But all those things they do I think they have to do in order to survive."
T.L.C. officials say they detect no more complaints about South Asians than any other group. Mr. Khan, who has been driving for the last six years, agrees that the business is becoming more and more ruthless, but says South Asian drivers are no worse than others and attributes tensions to the steadily increasing price of renting taxis and medallions.
Like many drivers, Mr. Khan says the Taxi Drivers and Allied Workers Union, which represents drivers, is ineffective. He believes South Asian drivers could be a powerful force if they could unionize.
From 9:30 on, nearly all of Mr. Khan's fares consist of taking business people back and forth across midtown. Usually stuck in traffic, the day is a slow grind. For lunch, he grabs a chicken sandwich at the Pak Punjab deli on Second Avenue and Third Street, a favorite of Pakistani drivers.
He returns to the mosque on First Avenue for prayers at 1:30 P.M. Three more monotonous hours in midtown and finally at 4:39, roughly 12 hours after he started, Mr. Khan's shift is over. It has been a slow day, but tonight will be special. His wife is returning for a visit after four months in Dominica. He has driven 117 miles, had 27 fares with no confrontations with passengers or the police. After paying for leasing the cab, leasing the medallion and for gas, he will take home $80. Mr. Khan earned $6 an hour for a 12 hours a day. His average tip was 89 cents.
During the shift change, Mr. Khan, his partner, Sajid, and other Pakistanis drivers drink tea, tell stories of the day and joke for 15 or 20 minutes. But by 5:20 P.M., Sajid is on the road and Mr. Khan is on the subway on his way to the gym. Within five minutes, Sajid picks up his first fare at the corner of Washington and Jane Streets. He crisscrosses the Village, gets a fare headed uptown and then settles into shuttling passengers up and down the Upper East Side.
Sajid is tall and imposing, but he is soft-spoken and almost shy. He praises the United States endlessly and is desperate to stay here. "Why not, if you work and pay taxes for 5 years or 10 years, you can get a green card?" he asked repeatedly. "I have never taken welfare. I have worked hard. I have paid my taxes."
Like other illegal immigrants, Sajid put his life and thousands of dollars in the hands of an anonymous trafficker for the age-old goal of a better life for himself and later his family. At 21, he flew from Pakistan to Canada, entering with false travel documents provided by the trafficker.
After several days, he was abruptly driven to the American border. The trafficker did all the talking and handled all the documents. Sajid still does not know exactly how he got into the United States, but he arrived in New York in 1990 at the age of 21 with only the name and phone number of a friend from his home village.
 
In Search of the Holy Grail: American Citizenship
 Seven years later, his homesickness has eased, but he often thinks of his parents, sisters, brother and friends in Pakistan during the long hours of driving. A high-school graduate, he comes from a small farming village of 1,800 in the Punjab in north Central Pakistan.
In a country with an average annual income of $500, the $10,000 his family spent to get him to New York is a fortune. Much of the last seven years has been a long struggle to repay his family, and most importantly, obtain the citizenship that will allow him to bring his family to America.
At first, he worked in gas stations, where he received $3 an hour for a 70-to-80-hour week. In December 1991, he started driving yellow cabs without having a work authorization. The T.L.C. began requiring taxi drivers to prove they had work authorizations only last year.
He saved his money for four years, but lost $14,000 on two different newsstands he opened in 1995. He married an American citizen that same year and now has conditional status with the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which has allowed him to receive a work authorization. If officials rule that his marriage is valid after two years, he will be eligible for a green card, but he fears the I.N.S. will rule against them or that the marriage will fall apart.
"Each day my mother prays that I get a green card," he said. "If God wants to give me some help, I'll get the green card."
After the string of rides on the Upper East Side from 6 to 7:25, Sajid receives a rare fare -- a passenger bound for Forest Hills, Queens. He heads for La Guardia after hearing from friends on the CB radio that lines aren't long. From 8:31 on, he continually picks up fares that have him criss-crossing Manhattan from the Lower East Side to the Upper West Side to the World Trade Center to Washington Heights.
But at 12:16 A.M., his luck abruptly ends. He is unable to find a fare for the next half hour. Dozens of cabs circle bars, clubs and movies theaters in the East and West Villages, desperate for customers. Just before 1, he gives up and heads for the highlight of his day -- dinner at his favorite low-cost Pakistani restaurant.
In a scene reminiscent of any diner, Sajid and his cabby friends talk business and tease each other. The conversation is light, but the front page of the current issue of The U.S. Asia Times features a front-page article about 71 illegal aliens being arrested in a New Jersey perfume factory.
Most South Asians are here legally, but among the illegal immigrants and the 17,000 or so nationwide who are seeking political asylum, stories like this cause widespread unease.
 
The Odds Are Long For Asylum-Seekers
 Since political asylum rules were tightened in January 1995, I.N.S. officials say they have processed nearly 200,000 backlogged cases.
Last week, officials began sending letters to 110,000 of the asylum seekers, informing them of impending interviews and asking them to give their whereabouts.
Officials say they hope to process all of the backlogged cases within the next 18 months, which could mean the loss of thousands of work authorizations and some deportations.
"We have about an 80 percent rejection rate," said Brian Jordan, a spokesman for the I.N.S. in Washington. "Most people don't show up for the asylum interviews."
Robert Deming, a cabdriver for 16 years and a teacher at the Master Cabby New York Taxi Academy in Queens, said he has nothing against immigrants, but believes some taxi jobs must be opened up to poor Americans -- especially those who may be cut off welfare. "This is not xenophobia," he said. "I just want to see Americans supporting themselves."
With a good night already under his belt, Sajid decides to call it quits at 2:34 A.M., an hour earlier than usual. He turns on the "Off Duty" light at and heads over the Queensboro Bridge.
All together, he had driven 119 miles and had 24 fares. After paying for his expenses, he will take home $100 for a 10-hour shift. He has earned $10 an hour. His average tip was $1.04.
On the way home, Sajid bought himself a treat -- a $25 prepaid phone card to call his best friend in Pakistan.
At 3:10 A.M., he locks the door to his cab and heads for the one-bedroom apartment he shares with another Pakistani immigrant. The man, who pumps gas, just received his cabdriver license. A few miles away, Mr. Khan will soon be rising and searching for his green prayer rug. For now, the cycles and rhythms of the taxi industry, the city and American immigration roll on.

HEADLINE: The Myriad Sides Of Rent Regulation

 BODY:
THE 54-year-old rent regulatory system has grown so complex that in a 50th-anniversary report on it in 1993 the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal took 26 pages to provide a glossary of terms.
Legally, the continuation of regulation in New York City depends on a periodic finding that a housing emergency, defined as a citywide rental vacancy rate below 5 percent, still exists -- as it likely always will barring an almost unimaginable pickup in new construction, or a change in the way the rate is calculated. The periodic vacancy survey counts only "nondilapidated" rental units, and includes public housing and other governmentally assisted units, which almost always have low vacancy rates, in the calculation. 
 But the 1993 state report also states as the mission of regulation the "broad social goal" of maintaining "an adequate supply of decent affordable housing for approximately 2.5 million New Yorkers."
It is at this ideological level that the deepest split occurs. Foes of regulation say that the broad social goal would be better accomplished by a freer market, which they say would increase the housing supply, loosen the rental market, and improve existing housing through greater investment. But those who want to retain regulation say that other factors more than regulation restrain new construction, and the more important need is to safeguard the occupancy of tenants at a time of housing shortage, and prevent what they expect would be a mass exodus of middle-income people.
But the ideological issue has receded in interest before the practical issues involved in possibly far-reaching change in housing law. This year State Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican Majority Leader, says he will let the rent laws expire unless the Assembly agrees to a plan that would end regulation entirely by some fixed date for all but the elderly and handicapped. The political debate that he has set in motion has obscured the issues on which negotiation may well turn.
The pricing system gets the most attention. Most regulated apartments in New York City are rent-stabilized; tenants have leases, and landlords are obliged to offer renewal leases at a rent no higher than prescribed by a quasi-governmental body, the Rent Guidelines Board.
There are still about 70,000 rent-controlled apartments in the city -- those that were built before World War II and have been continuously occupied by the same tenant or a legal successor-tenant since 1971. In many cases these tenants are now paying more rent than rent-stabilized tenants of long occupancy, because renewal-lease increases in stabilized apartments are usually well below the 7 1/2 percent a year allowed for rent-controlled apartments.
Negotiations on the pricing system could involve either occupied or vacant apartments, or both. In its purest form, "vacancy decontrol" would allow owners to charge a market rent when renting out a vacant apartment, and then to offer, or not offer, subsequent renewal leases with no control on price except market forces. In limited circumstances this already happens.
Most recently vacancy decontrol was applied to apartments in which the first legal rent after a regulated tenant departed was $2,000 a month or more. Negotiations could involve this threshold being lowered.
Decontrol also applies currently to occupied apartments, if the tenant pays $2,000 or more a month and has gross adjusted earnings of $250,000 a year for the two years before the expiration of the lease. The $250,000 threshold could be lowered. Plainly, the rate at which the housing stock is deregulated would be quicker if it applied to apartments with tenants in occupancy. But it would also be more painful to tenants.
BEYOND prices, two other aspects of the regulatory system are notable -- their effect on occupancy rights and building operations.
Current law, for example, obliges landlords to offer renewal leases to a broad array of occupants -- not just a spouse, but any family member, broadly defined. Watering down succession rights -- for example, by limiting them only to spouses of deceased residents -- would also speed deregulation, but even more, in owners' minds, restrict the current potential for abuses -- at the cost, say tenant advocates, of forcing family members out of their long-term housing.
Rent law also has a powerful impact through its effort to keep owners from worsening building services or conditions. If a landlord is found to have reduced a service that was provided on a certain "base date," the tenant's rent can be reduced and the service may have to be restored. Protection is the intent, but the side effect can be to dampen the incentives to improve efficiency and thus lower operating costs. Several other laws govern building conditions, but the state regulatory system provides the immediate threat of rent rollbacks.

HEADLINE: Imperfect Measures;
Tests, Too, Have Their Failings

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
NEW York's Education Commissioner and Governor offered opposing views last week on an issue that goes to the heart of educational quality and opportunity in an increasingly diverse America: should the state offer its college-preparatory Regents examinations in languages other than English?
The Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, was concerned that English-only Regents exams -- which New York uses to award merit scholarships -- don't fairly test the math or science skills of the state's many immigrants. But the controversy over his proposal to offer test booklets in Spanish, Haitian Creole, Russian and Chinese is only one of many cases questioning the enormous and increasingly contentious role that testing plays in American education. 
 From S.A.T. college-admission tests to President Clinton's proposed national tests for reading and math, from public schools in New York to public universities in Mississippi, this is the golden age both of testing and of disputes over how schools test, what tests measure and how fair they are.
At a time when education is seen as the essential route to opportunity, it is not just the details of specific tests that are at issue, but the nature of what the writer Nicholas Lemann calls America's evolving meritocracy, and what the legal scholar Lani Guinier calls America's evolving testocracy: the network of standardized tests that determine access to scholarships and the best schools and colleges.
"As access to educational quality, who gets a limited number of places in schools and jobs, becomes more competitive, we're seeing many of the big social issues in American life played out on the playing field of tests," said Robert Schaeffer, a spokesman for the National Center for Fair and Open Testing, or Fair Test, which is critical of the reliance on standardized tests.
 
A Search for Standards
 Across the country, educators increasingly depend on standardized tests even as challenges to their use spread. Current controversies include the following:
* In New York, supporters of Commissioner Mills's proposal say immigrants should not be penalized since the Regents are used for both high-school graduation and merit scholarships, and students would still have to pass an English Regents test. Critics say testing in other languages would deter students from learning English.
* In Mississippi, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled last month that the state's five white public universities continue to discriminate against black students by using ACT college-admission scores to award scholarships. Of almost $6.9 million dispensed in 1992-93, $6.6 million went to whites.
* Mr. Clinton, in an effort to raise academic standards, has proposed what would be the first national tests, a reading test for fourth graders and a math test for eighth graders. They would not be mandatory.
* Despite persistent claims that standardized tests are culturally biased in favor of white males, the bans on affirmative action in California and Texas now have the potential to make those states, two of the nation's most diverse, more reliant on standardized tests than ever.
The role of standardized testing in American life is not a new issue. For decades many experts have argued against overreliance on what Ms. Guinier calls "one size fits all" paper and pencil tests. Many critics prefer systems in which students build portfolios of their work, or tests like the revised National Assessment of Education Progress, released last week, which has multiple-choice questions but also asks for written analyses of scientific experiments.
Why then are traditional multiple-choice tests more influential now than ever before?
In higher education, when the best colleges and professional schools are deluged with applicants, standardized tests like the S.A.T. are still seen as a cost-effective and time-effective way to sort applicants. Even if schools wanted to downplay test scores, the near hysteria about rankings like those in U.S. News & World Report's annual college guide, which penalizes colleges for low S.A.T. averages and rewards them for high ones, would argue against it.
In elementary and secondary education, the sense of urgency about improving educational quality has led lawmakers to insist on "objective" measures of performance as a way to gauge how effectively tax dollars are being used.
And the argument over affirmative action is regularly framed in terms of racial or ethnic preference versus merit -- with merit defined by grades and supposedly objective tests.
Many political and business interests agree that better measures of performance are needed, and that schools and students won't improve without a way to adequately assess their performance.
Diane Ravitch, a senior research scholar at New York University, said standardized tests have become increasingly valuable as looser grading standards have made high-school grades less useful.
"Tests shouldn't be the only thing," she said, "but a real meritocracy replaces inherited privilege with merit, so a poor kid with good test scores can in fact do better than a rich kid with bad test scores."
 
Mirroring Society Too Well
 But Mr. Lemann, who is writing a book on meritocracy in America, said standardized testing like the S.A.T. tended to reproduce, not negate, family background; for as long as there have been such tests, well-to-do children from families with high levels of education have done much better than poorer ones.
He argues, however, that there are limits to tests' power as arbiters of opportunity. Higher education in America is available to almost everyone, even if Harvard and Yale are not, so low test scores do not rule out a college education as in countries with make-or-break national examinations. And while success in some professions -- law, for example -- is closely linked to attending elite schools, in many other fields -- business and entertainment, for example -- it is not.
Still, like Ms. Guinier, he argues for a more sophisticated analysis of what tests measure and their fairness.
Ms. Guinier and a colleague at the University of Pennsylvania Law School, Susan Sturm, argue in a widely circulated paper, "The Future of Affirmative Action: Reclaiming the Innovative Ideal," that the question least addressed in the national debate about affirmative action and merit is what standardized tests measure and how well they do it.
They maintain that when almost two-thirds of the people entering the work force are projected to be women and members of racial minorities, the tests in use are becoming less and less reliable and fair in apportioning educational opportunity. "The existing meritocracy creates a modern-day aristocracy that gives further advantages to the already advantaged and creates barriers for those who are not," they wrote.
The issue traverses often hidden fault lines of economic class. If tests like the S.A.T. often serve to a large degree as proxies for class, radically de-emphasizing them could dramatically redefine who gets into Harvard or Berkeley -- to the disadvantage of the largely privileged students who are admitted now.
Still, Mr. Lemann says, it's essential to remember that while tests matter, the larger issues of education and equity matter more. "You can't fix education by fixing testing," he said.

HEADLINE: Caribbean Blues;
Drugs! Aliens! Washington, Wake Up

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados

 BODY:
IN the fifth year of his presidency, Bill Clinton is finally venturing into the United States' backyard, traveling to Mexico, Costa Rica and Barbados this week to meet with the heads of Caribbean nations. But as he opens what the White House grandly calls a "new dialogue," the discussion is likely to be defined, as always, by a decades-old dependency on one side and cold strategic considerations on the other.
In a region where the United States' main concern has forever been its own security, what is new is that with the end of the cold war, the threat of the drug trade and increased illegal immigration has replaced Communism as the Caribbean nations' basis for claiming American attention. 
 While the Clinton Administration's main objective is to rally support for its war against drug cartels, the small, vulnerable nations of Central America and the Caribbean are telling the United States that its lack of interest in the region has made the drug trade attractive for residents.
"The problem is that the United States has virtually ended its aid to us," said the Prime Minister of St. Lucia, Vaughan A. Lewis. "Not 'virtually,' " he added. "It has ended its aid to us for all practical purposes."
During the 80's, the Reagan Administration was a muscular presence, dispensing money, guns and advice with stunning prodigality, rewarding friends and punishing enemies. The resulting dislocations, including civil war, left the region more dependent than ever on the United States, which nevertheless in this decade has seemed less and less interested in developments to its south, and increasingly willing to let others -- the European Community in the Caribbean, the Scandinavian countries in Central America -- pick up the slack. During his first term, Mr. Clinton's most visible gesture there was an 11 hour visit to Haiti.
 
A Self-Defeating Policy
 "The U.S. interventionist policy in Central America in the 80's is fast turning into indifference," Sweden's Deputy Foreign Minister, Pierre Schori, warned last December in a speech that marked the 50th anniversary of the Marshall Plan.
"This not only lets the peoples of the region down, but it is also a self-defeating policy," Mr. Schori said.
"Migration, and particularly the illegal immigration to the United States, grows," he said. "So does the drug problem. This is a visible result of the instability and lack of development."
But where Washington responded with displays of might in the 80's, whether in Nicaragua or Grenada, the Caribbean Basin is now of strategic value only to drug traffickers with bankrolls that exceed the budgets of many countries in the region. The result, Ivelaw L. Griffith, an expert on Caribbean security issues, wrote in a recent essay published by the National Defense University in Washington, is that "security today means an economic and political response, with the military playing only a supporting role."
 
Wanted: Trade, Not Aid
 But even as the drug threat has grown, in the form of marijuana farming and the shipment of cocaine, Washington's willingness to take the steps needed to counter it has faltered. Aid to El Salvador has declined to less than $50 million a year, from more than $1 billion at the height of its civil war. In the Caribbean, American economic aid has fallen 90 percent, to $26 million in 1995 from $226 million a decade earlier.
Whether they speak English, Spanish, French or Dutch, the region's leaders recite a familiar mantra: what they really want is "trade, not aid." But on that front, Washington has been just as parsimonious.
After the United States joined Canada and Mexico in the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994, Mr. Clinton promised the small economies of the Caribbean Basin similar access. But Congress has refused to go along, while doing away with low-interest loans for development projects in the region and forcing the closing of the regional office of the Agency for International Development in Barbados.
At the same time that Washington is pressuring the countries to step up drug interdiction efforts and to allow United States ships and planes to use their waters and airspace, it is essentially leaving their small, vulnerable economies to fend for themselves.
Here in the Eastern Caribbean, Grenada provides perhaps the most dramatic example of the United States' reduced interest. To much domestic acclaim, President Reagan sent more than 2,000 troops in October 1983 to overthrow a pro-Cuban Government; he promised a "special relationship" that would transform an island of 100,000 people into a prosperous democratic state.
During Mr. Clinton's first term, though, the American Embassy in Grenada was downgraded to legation status as part of what Washington called an effort "to shift resources to Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union." Responding to that blunt reminder of its strategic insignificance, the Grenadian Government renewed its relationship with Cuba last month. It also plans to sell Grenadian passports to Chinese and Indians eager to leave Hong Kong.
"We are in trouble, we have a lot of needs, and we have not been getting support from our traditional friends," said Prime Minister Keith Mitchell.
The challenge facing the leaders who will meet with Mr. Clinton is to convince him that their nations still have "a strategic, geopolitical importance for the United States," as El Salvador's President, Armando Calderon Sol, put it in a recent interview.
He added, "If we cannot convince people in the United States of that thesis, then I must insist that the problems of the Mayan peoples of El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras are going to be in Arizona."

HEADLINE: The World;
Why Blair's Victory May Not Travel Well in Europe

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
AFTER Tony Blair's election victory for the Labor Party in Britain last week, the rest of the leftists in Europe found new reason for hope. Elections will take place in France at the end of this month, in Germany next year and soon after in other places across the continent where Socialists and Social Democrats have found themselves frozen out of power in recent years.
"We can do it, too," was the refrain, followed quickly by, "Of course, we would never think of doing what Labor did in Britain." Labor's sin, as some of its continental cousins see it, was adopting the pro-business, anti-government, tax-cutting philosophies that conservatives everywhere insist are the only way to compete in the global economy. 
 "The real winner of the British elections is Thatcherism," headlined the weekly L'Express in anticipation of a Labor landslide, referring to the distasteful (to continental leftists) ideology that former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her successor, John Major, used to transform the British political landscape and economy.
Thatcherism may have made the rich richer and the poor poorer, as its critics charge, but in income disparity Britain is little different from France or Germany; all have been subject to the same inexorable global economic forces. Britain, however, has distinguished itself from other countries in Europe in its change of thinking across the political spectrum about the welfare state.
No one doubts that Mrs. Thatcher and her party changed Britain in their 18 years in power, and that Tony Blair's New Labor now accepts most of those changes.
And no one doubts that economic change of some kind is badly needed on the continent. Unemployment in Britain is only 6.1 percent, but it is 12.8 percent in France, 12.1 percent in Italy, 11.7 percent in Germany and almost 22 percent in Spain.
But achieving consensus in European countries on what to do about it is all but impossible, in part because the party political spectrum is much more fragmented than in Britain, and because in most countries on the continent, proportional representation imposes a need for coalition government and broad agreement.
 
No Consensus
 Mrs. Thatcher absolutely despised consensus, and because of the British electoral system she won healthy majorities in Parliament even though her Conservatives never won a majority of the popular vote. Thus she was able to break the stranglehold that British labor unions had over the economy when she arrived in power, and she legislated flexibility in British hiring and firing practices. She was also able to cut British income taxes to a top rate of 40 percent -- about what Americans in the upper tax brackets pay on some of their income, but far less than what the richest pay in France (54 percent) or in Germany (53 percent).
Two decades later, Mr. Blair has accepted most of these Thatcherite prescriptions as essential for Britain to compete effectively in the new global economy.
Here in France, though, there is no such consensus. President Jacques Chirac keeps saying that businesses would hire more people to work for them if they didn't have to pay high payroll taxes that usually add 50 percent to the cost of every salary.
But according to public opinion polls, most people in France -- and not just the Socialist opposition -- oppose cutting these taxes if it means reductions in the generous unemployment, pension and health care benefits that everybody in France has thought of as a right, not a privilege, for 50 years. So far, nothing much has happened -- and that is one reason Mr. Chirac called for new elections.
 
Paralysis
 Paralysis is also the rule in Germany. "What is wrong with our country?" Roman Herzog, Germany's President, asked in a speech last weekend contrasting Germany with the United States and other countries that seem to have made the transition to the new global economy more easily.
"In brutal terms, the loss of economic dynamism, the paralysis of society," he answered. "Instead of producing decisions," debates turn into rituals," he went on. "At the end, the problem is usually put off. The status quo prevails. Everybody waits for the next subject."
Change is not totally impossible; in both Sweden and Germany, widespread sick-leave abuses have led to changes in the rules so that now you have to be sick for more than a day or two before you can start collecting sick pay. The number of illnesses suddenly fell dramatically in both countries. But it took 20 years of wrangling between store owners, retail clerks' unions and political parties right and left before Germany could agree last year on such a simple thing as a change in the country's tightly controlled store opening hours, and then it was only minimal.
To reduce unemployment, French Socialists and German Social Democrats prefer to keep regulating working hours, shortening them without cutting salaries. Critics say all that will do is spread work among people who already have it, without creating desperately needed new jobs for young people.
In both Germany and France, opposition parties say they will not go even halfway down the British road. They will not shift the burden of economic adjustment from the rich to those least able to pay -- salaried employees and workers. In Britain, such workers have little job security, but in the post-cold war global economy, they have an easier time finding jobs than their unemployed colleagues on the continent. Companies that find it too expensive to produce automobiles or refrigerators or anything else in France can build factories in Britain, Ireland, Poland or Hungary, or even farther afield.
In the interest of social peace, continental societies have long chosen to subsidize unemployment at public expense rather than send workers off on their bikes looking for jobs, like the British do. But meeting the tough anti-inflationary criteria set for the new common European currency planned for 1999 -- the Euro -- means that France, Italy, Spain and Germany can no longer easily rely on public borrowing to finance their welfare states.
The Euro may usher in a new era of prosperity, but those who would enjoy it have to endure a little pain first. Britain has already endured the pain. With its low unemployment rate and its budget deficit under control, Britain could easily meet the criteria for the Euro, if Mr. Blair chooses to join. Leaders in France and Germany, which aren't so sure of qualifying, may soon have even more reason to envy him.

HEADLINE: This Panel on the Media, The Media Want to Stop

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 2

 BODY:
Press freedom groups, concerned that the United Nations might be drawn into a renewed campaign for worldwide regulation of the news media, are lobbying against efforts to convene a world conference on communications gaps between developed nations and the third world.
The issue is expected to come up in two weeks when the General Assembly's information committee meets here. Although the United Nations information department refused to put what the third world calls a "new world information and communication order" on the formal agenda, a number of developing nations, led by Nigeria and Algeria, want to reopen the debate at the session. 
 The executive director of the Virginia-based World Press Freedom Committee, Marilyn Greene, said today that while media organizations do not deny that there are inequalities, it is not up to governments to decide what to do about them.
"Governments have no role in dictating to the press what the role of the press will be," she said. "That's what this whole thing is about."
When the remnants of the Nonaligned Movement met in Nigeria last September, officials from dozens of countries agreed that "the struggle for the new world information and communication order should be intensified in spite of the end of the cold war."
They reiterated familiar themes: Western domination of international news, biased reporting of third world events and a dearth of "zeal" among their own journalists "to serve the interests of member states of the Movement of Nonaligned Countries and other developing countries." Technological advances in communications in recent years have widened gaps, the officials said.
Some developing nations want to convene a "world seminar" in 1998 or 1999 with the help of Unesco, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
But the agency is not interested; in fact it actively opposes the idea. Its last foray into the subject cost it dearly. After a first attempt to establish something called a "new world information order" under Unesco's auspices in 1976, ensuing debates polarized its members, paving the way for the United States and Britain to withdraw in the 1980's.
At an international conference on global communications sponsored in April by the United Nations information department and the Columbia University School of International and Public Affairs, poor countries' access to high technology and journalists' use of information systems were discussed, said Anders Wijkman, assistant administrator of the United Nations Development Program, who attended the event.
Representatives of several press freedom groups, hearing that the meeting would lend support to the proposed world seminar, declined to attend and asked Leonard R. Sussman, senior scholar in international communications at Freedom House, to voice their objections in a speech to the conference.
In an interview this week, Mr. Sussman said he had told the conference that developing nations had genuine concerns about the news media in industrial nations and the runaway lead they enjoy in global communication technology. But these, he explained to participants, are separate from the desires of some government leaders to disguise control of the media as a universal cause.
"There are valid objections to the way the news is handled in the West and elsewhere," Mr. Sussman said in the interview. "But there are also some very bad cures for that. And it is these bad cures that I now see coming up in somewhat sugarcoated form."
This week, to coincide with World Press Freedom Day on Saturday, Freedom House published a study of press laws around the world by Mr. Sussman. He found that 43 countries, some of them democracies like India and Colombia, were contemplating or had introduced new legal restraints on the press. Sixty-six of 187 countries surveyed annually were rated more restrictive last year than the year before.
Leading the campaign for a new order is Nigeria's ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, who this week was listed among the 10 worst enemies of the press by the Committee to Protect Journalists. "Abacha escalated his vicious tactics to decimate the country's once thriving independent press and drive scores of journalists into exile," the committee said.
The other nine on the list are: Antar Zouabri, a leader of the Armed Islamic Group in Algeria, who has made the killing of journalists a matter of policy and who ranked first among the enemies of the press; Presidents Jiang Zemin of China and Fidel Castro of Cuba; Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan of Turkey; President Aleksandr Lukashenko of Belarus; Prime Minister Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia; President Suharto of Indonesia; Gen. Than Shwe of Myanmar, and President Sali Berisha of Albania.
A number of diplomats and journalists from the developing world said this week that they did not believe the call for international regulation of the media stood much of a chance, in part because some of its advocates are people like General Abacha and other military rulers.
Bhaskar Menon, an Indian who publishes International Documents Review, a weekly guide for watchers of the United Nations system, says the world has changed too much to revive the regulation idea.
"I think it's a dead horse for several reasons," said Mr. Menon, who worked in the United Nations information department during the first battle over a new information order.
"One is that there isn't the political head of steam behind it that there was last time around. In the 70's, the whole atmosphere was different. The cold war was on. Developing countries, after the OPEC action to raise oil prices, felt that they had a chance to really make a change in the way the world was structured.
"I don't think that you can complain that events in other countries are not covered in the media. They are covered very well. The attitude of Western journalists has changed remarkably."

HEADLINE: Senate Panel Opposes Use Of Sampling In Next Census

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
The Senate Appropriations Committee dealt a serious setback this week to the Census Bureau, ordering it not to spend money developing statistical tools to estimate how many people are missed in the census for 2000.
The committee's action, if it is upheld by the Senate and survives a veto from President Clinton, would keep the bureau from doing what it says it must do to have an accurate census and avoid the kind of huge undercount that occurred in 1990. 
 The bureau would be barred from doing a practice run on its sampling methods next year, and it might have to abandon the long form that it had planned to mail to one household in six.
"Any delay causes us problems," Martha Farnsworth Riche, director of the Census Bureau, said on Thursday, a day after the committee vote.
Acknowledging that the committee vote "reflects a concern a lot of people have," Dr. Riche said she hoped that some lawmakers would change their minds "as the debate goes on and people become more informed" about the bureau's plans.
The prohibition on sampling was inserted into a bill providing about $8 billion in emergency relief for flood-stricken communities in the Midwest. The vote against sampling was 15 to 13, mainly along party lines, with Republicans mostly against and Democrats mostly in favor.
The full Senate may consider the measure as early as Monday.
President Clinton will veto any measure that bars the Census Bureau from using sampling, said Franklin D. Raines, the director of the Office of Management and Budget. "Without sampling, the cost of the decennial census will increase as its accuracy, especially with regard to minorities and groups that are traditionally undercounted, will decrease," Mr. Raines said in a letter to Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who heads the appropriations panel.
An aide to the Republican majority on the panel said the Republican senators did not necessarily have ironclad opinions but "need more information." Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, also opposes the use of sampling, some people who have followed the debate said. A call to his office seeking comment on the issue was not returned.
In general, political analysts think that traditional census head-counting, without the use of sampling, tends to miss members of minority groups in big cities -- people who usually vote Democratic.
The rider in the emergency-relief bill says the Census Bureau may not use money "to plan or otherwise prepare for sampling." Strictly speaking, the prohibition affects spending only through the end of the current fiscal year, on Sept. 30.
But given the measure's broad prohibition, bureau officials fear that they will not be able to use innovative sampling techniques and that they will not even be able to use the regular long form in 2000. Because the demographic, housing and social and economic data collected on the long form are used to draw a picture of the general population, even though the form is mailed to only one household in six, use of the form amounts to sampling.
The 1990 Census is widely acknowledged to have missed several million people, many of them members of minority groups and many of them people who did not want to be counted for one reason or another.
To avoid a similar undercount in 2000, the Census Bureau proposes to use statistical sampling: once it had counted 90 percent of the households in a given area, it would use that data to calculate what the remaining 10 percent of the households would presumably be like.
Census officials have estimated that the next census will cost $4 billion. Without sampling, Dr. Riche said, it could cost as much as $1 billion more -- and be less accurate.
The arguments for and against sampling are constitutional, practical and social as well as political. The Constitution refers to an "actual enumeration," and some people question the constitutionality of sampling -- an issue the Supreme Court has pointedly left for another day.
Some people wonder how accurate sampling is. Still, it tends to be favored by local government leaders whose communities' Federal aid depends on how many people live in their areas.
If the sampling technique planned for 2000 had been used in 1990, California would have gained a seat in the House of Representatives, at the expense of Wisconsin.
In the Appropriations Committee vote on Wednesday, Senator Herb Kohl of Wisconsin went against his fellow Democrats and opposed the use of sampling. Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas, whose state's population includes a large number of minorities, split with her fellow Republicans and voted for sampling.

HEADLINE: Las Vegas Is Booming After City Reinvention;
Gambling Still Reigns at the Family Resort

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
Elvis, who tested the seams of his jumpsuit here when this desert city's biggest nongambling attraction was a few over-the-hill superstars, is truly dead.
Now a fake volcano spouts flames into the night, 18th-century sea battles rage across massive concrete lagoons, and dolphins give birth in hotel pools that are smack-dab in the middle of the sun-scorched Mojave Desert. Magicians no longer saw their assistants in half; instead, the beautifully tan Siegfried -- or is it Roy? -- impales himself on what appears to be a giant thumb tack. 
 Bright lights, once the famous Strip's trademark, will not cut it in 1997. A lumpy Empire State Building and a chunky Statue of Liberty, facades at one of the newer theme hotels, share a neon skyline with a black-glass Great Pyramid, a fairy tale castle and even a water theme park. Soon a half-scale Eiffel Tower will sprout from signs for $10 surf-and-turf dinners, the new Las Vegas ascending from the old.
"I love it," said Danny Torres, a 13-year-old from the San Francisco Bay area, after seeing his first showgirl in the lobby of the Las Vegas Hilton on a recent weekend. In the new Las Vegas, tourism, hotel construction and the population are booming as civic boosters trumpet once-unheard-of ideas: come to Las Vegas and bring the children; come and retire, come and build a plant. Las Vegas is not just for gamblers anymore, the ad writers promise.
But in this city, which almost invented sleight of hand, it is natural to question how a trick is done. The people who know Las Vegas, the people who run the blackjack tables, pour the drinks and dance behind the beads and feathers, say the new Las Vegas is powered by the same machine that pushed the old one. Gambling dictates the future here.
The rest is sideshow, however grand, however loud.
"It is still a very adult Disneyland," said Ann Yendrek, a Las Vegas greeter who stands with one spiked heel planted firmly in the city's future, the other in its past. A 6-foot vision in fishnet tights, top hat and tails, she welcomed people to a boxing match at the Hilton in a voice that could make centurions at Caesars Palace throw themselves on their swords.
Aging gamblers, although accustomed to such sights, still contemplated her through a veil of cigarette smoke, even as Danny and others his age gazed at her in what seemed to be awe. Like Las Vegas wants to be, she was all things to all men.
Gambling made Las Vegas, but the city has tried hard to alter its glitter-speckled image of limousine-riding big shots, stone-eyed card players and forlorn losers with pawn shop tickets in their pockets. It is popular to talk about family entertainment and economic diversity in what has become the nation's fastest growing metropolitan area.
It is so popular that Steve Wynn, a leader of the Las Vegas resurgence, is more than a little weary of talking about it, because there is no great secret to this city's success.
"A larger version of the same game," said Mr. Wynn, chief executive of Mirage Resorts, which includes the Mirage hotel and casino and a prototype of the new, family-style hotel-casinos, Treasure Island.
"The pitch," he said, "has been modified."
Las Vegas is booming because the gambling industry is booming, because -- now that slot machines ring on Mississippi's Gulf Coast, on the New Orleans riverfront and on Indian reservations across the country -- the most over-the-top city in America has been forced to become more sensational, more accommodating. Four huge hotels have opened in the past year, and some $6 billion in hotel and casino construction is planned for the next three years. Last year, hotel occupancy rates here were around 90 percent.
"If you build it, they'll come -- if it's good enough," Mr. Wynn said.
The Las Vegas Hilton, for example, is building a virtual casino, a star ship with slot machines. It used to be Sammy Davis Jr., doing "Candy Man."
The need to be bigger and better feeds this new construction, this employment boom, so Las Vegas grows, said entrepreneurs and experts on city planning here. Some 3,000 people move to Las Vegas each month, most of them in construction, casino work or service jobs related to gambling. Suburbs have sprung up like tent cities in the desert.
"Las Vegas has shown a great deal of agility," Mr. Wynn said. "It has met change and seemed to thrive on it. That shows no sign of abatement."
"But," he added, "it is what it is."
A place to pay your money and take your chances.
"I don't come for the show," said 70-year-old Ralph Beahler, waiting for luck to smile on him, one rattling token at a time, at the $1 slots.
Mr. Beahler, a retired aircraft worker from Seattle, said he has been coming here since 1945, when he was on furlough from the Navy. It was not much fun then because he did not have any money to risk. It is that thrill, of risking a little and winning a lot, maybe enough to change his life, that brings him back.
Luck is the only magic he is looking for. What does it say about America when Las Vegas is the nation's fastest growing city?
"It tells us gambling is a very successful business," said Anthony Downs, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, a public-policy research organization in Washington.
Earl Shorter learned it early, in the back room of his Aunt Ida Lee's little nightclub in Louisiana, not far from Lake Providence.
Every Saturday night, "depending on who the sheriff was at the time," Mr. Shorter said, men gathered there with fistfuls of $1 bills and played craps. The dice tumbled across the floor, and something grand -- a palpable excitement -- swirled like mosquitoes around the room.
"I saw how people were fascinated by this game," said Mr. Shorter, a 68-year-old dealer at the craps table in the Mirage casino. "And I knew it was a business that was here to stay."
Now you can play quarter slots in Tunica, Miss., and bet the house payment in Marksville, La. Instead of being hurt by that influx of gambling, Las Vegas has prospered from it, said Mike Clauretie, a real estate professor at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas.
"You have many states that have now said gaming is O.K.," he said, adding that the nationwide acceptance of gambling has lifted the taboo once associated with Las Vegas.
People who live here do not wonder why anyone would fly across the country to gamble in the desert when most people now live within driving distance of legalized gambling.
"If you see your first baseball game on a sandlot, sooner or later you'll want to see the World Series," said Don Payne, a historian.
So instead of shrinking, Las Vegas exploded with color and choices. The casinos, more or less assured of keeping a certain number of hard-core gamblers, also reached out for the tourists who may gamble only a little or not at all. People line up by the hundreds to see the volcano explode outside the Mirage or to see the mock sea battle, complete with pirates and booming cannon, at Treasure Island, which makes only about half its money from its casino.
Las Vegas lured better restaurants -- including expensive places like Wolfgang Puck's Spago -- to supplement the conventional cheap buffets. Casinos opened bigger and better arcades as baby sitters for older children while parents played their own games. "You can send the kids their way, then sit, relax and lose lots of money," said Oscar Torres, who brought his family here from the Bay area for a short vacation. Danny Torres is his nephew.
No other state has come close to matching Nevada's population growth, and Las Vegas is the overwhelming destination of the newcomers. From July 1, 1995, to last July 1, the state's population increased 4.5 percent, some 70,000 people, the Census Bureau said. Since 1990, Nevada's population has grown more than 33 percent; the nation as a whole grew just 6.7 percent. The population of Clark County, which includes Las Vegas and the unincorporated area of the Strip, is expected to grow by another 300,000 by the year 2000.
The growth has brought the usual downside. Gridlock brings traffic to a dead stop at 3:45 P.M. on a weekday, two blocks off the Strip. Crime, including gang violence imported from Los Angeles, is at a record high. The county's court dockets are filled with lawsuits against builders for shoddy construction. Water remains a long-term concern.
Economic diversity is still more a dream than a reality.
Several companies, from Levi Strauss to Ocean Spray, have opened plants or distribution warehouses here. But those jobs, in the hundreds, disappear into the massive gambling work force.
"No, I don't think people say to themselves, 'Gee, let's go live in Las Vegas,' the way they used to say, 'Let's go live in California,' " said Mr. Downs of the Brookings Institution. "I don't think it has that same kind of attraction or aesthetics. People are moving there specifically to work in these businesses," gaming and construction.
Heather Richardson, a 21-year-old hotel clerk here, said she left Saratoga Springs, N.Y., because she heard there were good jobs available in a city where the living was affordable and taxes were low. Nevada has no state income tax.
"The money and atmosphere -- I love it," she said. Even hotel maids here make $10 an hour.
No one seems to care that there are mountains here but no trees, or that the landscape is what some people would call downright ugly. People keep coming. The work is steady and the weather is good, except in the summer, when the sun bores down like it is angry at the world.
Away from the fancy part of the Strip, as the city begins to peter out into Federal stockades, military bases and older casinos, the old Las Vegas hangs on.
A sign outside the Poker Palace promises a "$3.99 Easter ham dinner." The pawn shops are open at 10 A.M. on Sunday, for the people whose luck was sleeping. In a Superpawn, a young man is trying to hock his CD's for traveling money.
Maybe the secret is to just keep trying, as Las Vegas has.

HEADLINE: A Divided Jersey City Prepares for an Election

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, May 3

 BODY:
Voters here, by most accounts, are an unyielding and unforgiving lot. In nearly three decades, no mayor has been elected to two successive full terms. But this is politics at its most pragmatic, and candidates are more likely to be judged by what they can deliver than by where they have been.
So few eyebrows were raised when a former Jersey City Mayor, Gerald McCann, still on parole from a Federal bank fraud conviction, made it known that he would be seeking his old job in next month's election. Mr. McCann was forced from office in 1992, shortly before going to the penitentiary. 
 And it seemed more from concern for the city's image than from moral indignation that people of differing political allegiances breathed easier when Mr. McCann was thrown off the ballot. The courts found him ineligible to run for office because he remains under supervised release, the Federal system's equivalent of parole.
But even after he had left the race, the former Mayor appeared to be hovering over the election like Banquo's ghost. Mayor Bret D. Schundler, who is seeking a second full term, had to be reminded during an interview that he was no longer running against Mr. McCann, a combative, strong-willed Democrat who helped jump-start the city's waterfront development during the 1980's.
With the field narrowed, the election on May 13 will be a referendum on Mr. Schundler's performance after more than four years of presiding over New Jersey's second most populous city, after Newark. It will also be a test of whether the young Mayor, once considered one of the Republican Party's brightest hopes, has recaptured some of the popularity he lost when he began making frequent out-of-town trips only months after his spectacular showing in the 1993 election.
The city Mr. Schundler runs is marked by stark contrasts, leading James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, to describe it as "a microcosm of our two-tier economy nationally."
The upper tier is represented by the gleaming office towers along the waterfront, which are occupied to near-capacity by employees in the financial services, insurance and real estate industries. From 1992 through 1995, more than 10,000 new jobs were created in Jersey City, accounting for 91 percent of the total employment growth in New Jersey's six biggest cities, according to a study by Professor Hughes and Joseph J. Seneca, a Rutgers economist, that was published in October.
Some of these workers live in new luxury apartment complexes facing the Manhattan skyline, but many are nonresidents whose offices were transferred here.
Virtually unseen by these workers as they make their way home by ferry or PATH train is the other, grittier multiethnic tier, which has lost more than 10,000 manufacturing jobs since 1975, 350 of them as recently as April 14, when a Mueller's pasta plant closed. Overall, unemployment in the city averaged 11 percent last year; the schools have not been allowed to operate autonomously since they were taken over by the state in 1989, and most job-seekers lack the education or skills to compete for office work on the waterfront. This Jersey City is trying to remain solvent in the face of an ever-shrinking property-tax base.
With Mr. McCann out of the race, Mr. Schundler will face only two opponents, both Democrats. Jaime Vasquez, a 12-year veteran of the City Council, has been a persistent gadfly but has not raised enough money to pose a serious challenge. The other candidate, Jerramiah T. Healy, former chief judge of the Jersey City Municipal Court, has the support of the Hudson County Democratic Party but has never before sought elective office. He has raised $240,000 to Mr. Schundler's nearly $1 million.
Mr. Schundler dismisses the candidacy of Judge Healy, 46, as inconsequential. But given that only 7 percent of the voters are registered Republicans and that the last Mayor to win a second successive four-year term was Thomas J. Whelan in 1969, it is possible that Mr. Schundler will be forced into a runoff. In the most recent Jersey Journal poll, conducted in early March before the campaign was under way, Mr. McCann drew 12 percent, to 38 percent for Mr. Schundler, 11 percent for Mr. Vasquez and 6 percent for Mr. Healy. The other respondents were undecided.
The powerful Hudson County Executive, Robert C. Janiszewski, recently raised $100,000 for Mr. Healy at a benefit dinner, but even some of the judge's supporters have wondered just how much enthusiasm Mr. Janiszewski has mustered for his fellow Democrat.
Publicly, at least, Mr. Janiszewski contends that Mr. Schundler is vulnerable. "The people here don't consider their neighborhoods safe, their schools good or their taxes low," he said recently. "That's a prescription for questioning what the incumbent has done."
Mr. Schundler, a former Wall Street bond trader with the build of the school linebacker he once was, became the city's first Republican Mayor since World War I by beating 18 candidates in a special election in November 1992 to fill the remainder of Mr. McCann's term. Six months later, Mr. Schundler won a full term with 68 percent of the vote, thanks in part to a large decrease in property taxes.
Initially, the Harvard-educated Mayor, now 38, twinkled in the Republican firmament, along with New Jersey's new Governor, Christine Todd Whitman. Some of that luster dimmed, however, as Mr. Schundler went on the road to promote House Speaker Newt Gingrich's Contract with America and to crusade for school vouchers.
In 1995, Mr. Schundler ran his own candidate against Mr. Janiszewski, and was defeated by a ratio of 3 to 1 when the Democrats successfully tarred him with the Gingrich connection. He also irritated Mrs. Whitman with an ill-fated effort to impose a payroll tax, and the two remain distant.
Judge Healy, a plain-spoken Jersey City native who recently serenaded a crowd of elderly people with a rendition of "Under the Boardwalk," is also running as much against Mr. Gingrich as against Mr. Schundler. He has portrayed the Mayor as a carpetbagger surrounded by people who "look down their noses at the folks of Jersey City." The Mayor was raised 15 miles away, in the affluent suburb of Westfield, but has lived in Jersey City since he was 25.
"In a lot of ways, Jersey City is a very provincial town," said Thomas A. DeGise, the president of the City Council, who is running for re-election on the Schundler slate. "If you didn't go to one of the high schools here, you're not cool."
As a former prosecutor, Mr. Healy has called attention to Mr. Schundler's poor relationship with the Police Department, blaming it for low morale among the ranks, a crime rate that is worse than New York's and an increased murder rate since his first year in office. (True enough, but a recent analysis of crime statistics by The New York Times found that the violent-crime rate in Jersey City declined 17 percent from 1993 to 1996.)
"The police have been angry at me for years," Mr. Schundler acknowledged, shrugging off the animosity as a predictable reaction to some of the tough measures he has imposed, including deploying more officers on the street and making them work 14 days more a year.
Mr. Healy has also accused his Republican rival of focusing on trivial matters -- dotting sidewalks with concrete planters, for example, or issuing a policy on stolen shopping carts -- while not working hard enough to lure more investors to Jersey City.
"If you look at where we're located and what we have here, the development that's gone on in the last four years has certainly been negligible," Judge Healy said.
In defense of his record, Mr. Schundler cites, among other projects, the opening last year of a printing plant for The Daily News of New York, which added 700 jobs; plans for two new hotels, and a big spurt in new housing. One of the area's biggest developers, the Applied Companies, for example, is planning to break ground next year on 1,200 condominiums and townhouses in the luxurious Port Liberte complex on Caven Point, said Joseph Barry, the company's chief executive officer.
Mr. Barry said that Mr. Schundler does not let politics interfere with business decisions, a rare trait in Hudson County. "But sometimes he doesn't understand how much the city has to get involved," Mr. Barry said. "He's learning that. His people are very competent and honest, but he needs more staff."
Leaders of the city's merchant associations also give the Mayor high marks, saying he has encouraged them to upgrade their shopping districts through a combination of private and state funds.
But even Mayor Schundler concedes that some voters may not be happy with his plan to plug a budget hole by selling a 19-acre site south of Liberty State Park -- including five playing fields and a 5,000-seat stadium -- to the Jersey City Board of Education. The city owns the site, and the fields are already heavily used by school teams.
Mr. Healy has labeled the plan "a dirty deal," and "an outrage, a boondoggle and a scam" because the sale will be financed through bonds, and taxpayers will be paying debt service on property they already own.
But Mr. Schundler describes his plan as an ingenious alternative to the unthinkable prospect of raising property taxes. Once the ball fields are in the hands of the schools, he points out, the state will incur part of the cost of keeping them up.
"If I didn't need the money, I'd give them to the schools for free," he said. "The fact is I do need the money. And any way I can reduce the overburden on the property-taxpayers of this city, I'm going to do it."

HEADLINE: BOATING;
Grueling Race Reborn After 8-Year Absence

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

 BODY:
It has been an eight-year hiatus for the Worrell 1000, a grueling catamaran race along 1,000 miles of coastline from Florida to Virginia. But now it's back, with 13 teams expecting to push off from the beach tomorrow at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The realists among them are expecting the worst.
"You never want to enter this race with a lackadaisical attitude," said Randy Smyth, a two-time Olympic silver medalist who has won the Worrell 1000 twice. "I try to do as much preparation as I can. But you have to accept that you're a human being. In this race, you can't be overconfident." 
 The fleet of 20-foot catamarans, each with two crew members, is scheduled to finish the 13-day ocean marathon May 17 at Virginia Beach. At least one other team member is required to follow along on shore to manage gear and supplies for the twin-hulled sailboats.
With 12 checkpoints along the way, the schedule calls for mostly daylight sailing. But two overnight stages are built into the race. Lightning storms, gale-force winds and shoals lined with sandbars and rocks are common obstacles along the way. But unexpected hurdles at night are often the most terrifying of all.
"In 1987, we crashed into a shark at midnight off the coast of Georgia," the 42-year-old Smyth said. "The coastline was all dark and swampy, and we saw no lights. The impact kicked back our boat's daggerboard, which sliced a three-foot hole through the bottom of the hull. We were very unhappy." The team guided the broken boat back to shore and withdrew from the race.
Smyth and a former crewmate, Jay Glaser, still hold the race record of 99 hours 45 minutes, set in 1985. Smyth is sailing this time with 25-year-old Jason Sneed, his neighbor in Fort Walton Beach, Fla.
The race has attracted other world-class yachtsmen too. They include Gerard Loos, a European multihull champion from Holland, and Vladimir Kulinichenko, a native of Ukraine who is a veteran of two Whitbread Round the World campaigns and is now a sailmaker in Tampa, Fla. Other Worrell 1000 competitors include sailors with jobs as varied as a computer engineer, an upholsterer, a dental technician, an executive chef, a graphics designer and a private investigator.
As a sailmaker and veteran Tornado Class sailor, Smyth knows about the long, exhausting hours strapped in a catamaran's trapeze harness. The gear allows him to leverage his weight out over the side of the cat for better sailboat performance. But the stance is as unnatural as rappelling down a cliff on the end of a rope.
Smyth has learned to bag his lunch -- maybe a peanut butter and jelly sandwich -- in plastic and fasten it to the mast's rigging so it's within arm's reach. And he knows that he will constantly be doused with sea water on the trampoline-like deck of the open catamaran. Smyth wears a drysuit, a one-piece waterproof garment, most of the time.
Michael Worrell, a restaurateur from Virginia Beach who started the competition in 1976, said recently that sailors hounded him to resurrect the defunct race. For business reasons, he sold rights to the race in 1987. Two years later it fizzled out in an economic downturn.
One of the more zealous among the competitors this time is Al Levine, a fire and burglar alarm technician from Centerport, N.Y. Levine has spent the last five years raising money for cancer by putting himself out on the proverbial limb.
In 1992, he tried sailing up the coast by himself, and nearly died trying. His trapeze hiking line broke, and Levine had forgotten to clip into a safety line. He fell into the water and watched as the boat sailed away. He swam from noon until dusk.
"I got lucky because the wind was blowing on shore," he said recently. "I got to a barrier island off Charleston, and said, 'Jesus, God, you put me ashore, but there's nothing here.' I looked around, and couldn't find anyone.
"I was getting crabby by then," he added. Eventually, Levine said he flagged down a passing motorboat.
He's determined to try raising money for cancer again. But this time, it will be in the Worrell 1000.
 
MAKING WAVES
Seventeen superyachts are expected to gather in New York Harbor May 17 for the start of a 3,000-mile race from Sandy Hook, N.J., to England. The Atlantic Challenge Cup regatta is being organized in part by the New York Yacht Club. The 85-to-192-foot yachts participating will be docked ahead of time at Chelsea Piers, at 23d Street and the Hudson River in Manhattan.
