HEADLINE: A Move to Restore Benefits to Some Immigrants

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
President Clinton forced reluctant Republicans to restore disability and health benefits to several hundred thousand legal immigrants as part of the budget agreement announced this week.
Budget negotiators said the agreement would provide $10 billion over the next five years to aid the immigrants, whose benefits were cut by the welfare bill that Republicans pushed through Congress last year. The immigrants' plight had become a source of increasing political embarrassment for the Republicans and for Mr. Clinton, who signed the welfare bill on Aug. 22. 
 In addition, Administration officials said, the budget agreement would provide $4.5 billion for new initiatives to move people from welfare to work. Some of the money is intended to create jobs for able-bodied adults who, under the welfare law, may receive food stamps for only three months in any 36-month period unless they are working.
In December, the Congressional Budget Office estimated that the welfare law would save $55 billion from 1997 to 2002. So the budget agreement, by restoring $14.5 billion, would wipe out slightly more than one-fourth of the expected savings.
Clinton Administration officials described the restoration of benefits for immigrants as "a pretty significant victory for us." And a Republican on Capitol Hill said "a lot of Republicans will be upset" by the proposal, but he predicted that they would "swallow hard" and approve it as part of a far-reaching plan to balance the budget and cut taxes.
Under the new welfare law, legal immigrants who have not become citizens are generally ineligible for food stamps and Supplemental Security Income, a form of cash assistance for poor people who are aged, blind or disabled.
Some of the immigrants losing benefits are nursing home residents. Many have been in the United States for more than 15 years. Some fled persecution in Russia, Cuba or other countries.
The budget agreement would allow the Government to provide Supplemental Security Income to noncitizens who were in the United States before Aug. 22, 1996, and who were either receiving disability benefits at that time or became disabled at a later date. The agreement is expected to help two-thirds of the 500,000 immigrants facing loss of Supplemental Security Income benefits. It would not help new immigrants, and it would not restore food stamps for any immigrants.
Representative Xavier Becerra, Democrat of California, who is chairman of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, said he was disappointed that the budget negotiators could not find a few billion dollars more to preserve benefits for all immigrants.
The Government had already sent notices to many immigrants informing them that they might lose Supplemental Security Income benefits this summer. At first, Congressional Republicans categorically rejected Mr. Clinton's proposals to restore money cut by the welfare law.
But Congressional Republicans came under pressure from many quarters. Republican governors, including George E. Pataki of New York, appealed for help. Large groups of immigrants filed lawsuits challenging the constitutionality of the ban on benefits for noncitizens.
And Hispanic groups cited several cases in which they said immigrants had committed suicide because they were distraught at the prospect of losing benefits.
Advocates for immigrants and refugees and officials in states like New York, California and Florida, with many noncitizens, welcomed the agreement. "This doesn't help everybody who needs help, but it is an important first step," said Cecilia Munoz, deputy vice president of the National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic civil rights organization.
The Congressional Budget Office had estimated that the restrictions on benefits for immigrants would save $24 billion from 1997 to 2002. The restoration of $10 billion, as envisioned in the budget agreement, would undo more than 40 percent of those savings.
Administration officials said the agreement provided $2.5 billion over the next five years for grants to the states to help create jobs for welfare recipients in areas with high levels of poverty and unemployment. Also, they said, the agreement includes $500 million for tax credits for businesses that hire long-term welfare recipients.

INTERNATIONAL 3-20
 
Zaire's Leader Tells U.S. That He Plans to Resign
With rebel forces reported within 100 miles of the capital, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire decided to resign, American diplomats said. He and the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, again failed to meet, and the stage seemed set for Mr. Mobutu to abandon power, and for Mr. Kabila, backed by Angola, to take the capital by force if necessary. 1

Canada's recent arrest of a Saudi linked to a bombing at an American military base last year has provided a glimpse, officials say, of how a largely hidden network of militant groups uses Canada to raise money, recruit members and plan attacks. 8

NEW YORK/REGION 37-43
 
Becoming the 500-lb. Gorilla
A yearlong party starts today, honoring the 100th anniversary of the melding of more than 40 local governments into the huge and populous municipality known as New York City. The three-inch thick document officially known as "Chapter 378 of the Laws of 1897," signed into law on May 4, 1897, redefined New York to embrace not just Manhattan and the Bronx but also Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. 1

Flight 800 Inquiry Nears End
Nearly 10 months after the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 off Long Island unleashed strong suspicions of terrorism, law enforcement officials in the last stages of their criminal investigation have still found no evidence of sabotage. The likelihood that none will be found is forcing them to confront another question: will the public accept the conclusion that no criminal activity was involved in the crash? 37

Summer in the Country
Thousands of New York City children are preparing for summer with the help of the Fresh Air Fund, a charity that has been giving rural vacations to poor city children for 121 years. 37
 
The Eagles Are Breeding
Bald eagles have made a stirring comeback across North America in the last two decades, with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service taking the species down a notch last year to threatened from endangered. In New York State, where one breeding pair was documented in 1976, there are now 29 nesting pairs, with 37 eaglets hatched last year. But along the Hudson River, where some 40 eagles regularly spend the winter, the birds had failed to breed -- until now. 37

HEADLINE: AT&T Takes Lead on a Plan To Cut Long-Distance Rates

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
Residential long-distance telephone rates will fall significantly in the next several years under a new plan negotiated by the AT&T Corporation and the Federal Communications Commission, officials said today.
AT&T, the nation's largest provider of long-distance service, said that it would cut residential rates by $500 million in the year beginning July 1, the first substantial cut in long-distance charges in the 1990's. That translates into reductions in residential long-distance bills of 5 percent to 15 percent, the company said. 
 Sprint and MCI Communications, the two other major long-distance carriers, are expected to follow but have not yet announced the size of their reductions, F.C.C. officials said.
The rate reductions are the last major piece of a complex compromise hammered out over several weeks in intense negotiations between telecommunications lobbyists and F.C.C. officials.
The regulatory agency is to issue new rules this week that will begin to change the economics of the nation's telephone business. It will also create a multibillion-dollar fund to connect schools, libraries and health care centers to the Internet.
Reed Hundt, the F.C.C. chairman, called the pledge by AT&T to cut household long-distance charges "a huge breakthrough."
"We have been in a firefight with AT&T behind closed doors, and now the smoke has cleared," Mr. Hundt said in an interview. He said that over the next five years, after major carriers reduced their rates, 85 percent of households would see their phone bills go down and that rates for the other 15 percent would remain about where they are today.
The rate reductions by AT&T will apply to households that do not subscribe to discount packages for long-distance usage, roughly half of AT&T's 75 million customers. The cost of long-distance calls placed during the day and evening will fall by 5 percent, while late-night and weekend charges will decline 15 percent, the company said.
Mr. Hundt estimated that long-distance charges would fall by a total of $30 billion in five years.
AT&T and the other long-distance companies will get a windfall as a result of the broader plan that the communications commission is preparing to issue this week.
Access charges -- the fees that long-distance companies pay local phone exchanges for access to their customers -- -- would fall $1.7 billion in the first year of the F.C.C. plan. A large portion of that money will be reflected in lower rates, in part because the companies hope for much larger reductions in access charges in the future and in part because Mr. Hundt threatened to seek new regulations on long-distance rates if the companies did not use at least part of their savings to benefit consumers.
Although several elements of the new regulatory plan are still in flux, F.C.C. and industry officials indicated that the commission was likely to take a number of steps this week:
*It is expected to create a relatively small "universal service fund," of $3 billion to $4 billion a year, to begin paying for basic telephone service for poor, disabled and rural customers, as well as for wiring schools, libraries and isolated health care centers. The money will come from higher charges for additional phone lines in homes and businesses, as well as from new levies on wireless telephone and paging services.
*It is likely to shift roughly $4 billion in long-distance access charges, now based on per-minute rates, to flat monthly charges, which would benefit many heavy long-distance users and Internet surfers. The losers will be small businesses that make few interstate calls.
*It is expected to increase the cost of second residential phone lines by $1 a month, from $3.50, and to raise the cost of multiple business lines by $1 to $2 a month, from $5.50.
Despite all the tinkering with the plan in the last several weeks, Mr. Hundt has stood firm to avoid an increase in the cost of basic local telephone service.
Consumer advocates cheered today's announcement. Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Washington office of Consumers Union, said the plan marked the first dividend from the sweeping Telecommunications Act passed Congress 18 months ago.
"This is the first big long-distance rate cut for the average consumer in many years," he said. "We're hoping it's the first stage of cutting all the fat out of the pricing in the telephone system, both long-distance and local."

HEADLINE: New York City Celebrates A Century of Uneasy Unity

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
The Mayors of Brooklyn and New York vetoed the idea, only to be overridden by the State Legislature. Preachers in Brooklyn railed against it. The State Senate defeated it, then changed its mind.
Clearly, the welding of the modern New York City from more than 40 local governments a century ago was not easy. But as the city begins a yearlong 100th birthday party for itself today, there is a strong view that it was historically inevitable. Ruth Abram, president of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, sees the creation of the new city as a direct reaction to social, political and economic strife that had torn America since the Civil War. 
 "This deep-seated yearning for union may explain why the opponents of the consolidation of New York simply could not prevail," she said.
To be sure, there are other views, not the least being that consolidation represented a last-ditch effort by the ruling elite to cement its power in the face of waves of immigrants.
But the importance of Gov. Frank S. Black's signature on what is known as "Chapter 378 of the Laws of 1897," a three-inch thick document dated May 4, 1897, is incontrovertible.
It redefined New York from being just Manhattan and the Bronx, both then part of New York County, to include the other three boroughs -- Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island -- which were already separate counties.
The effect was an unprecedentedly large American city of 359 square miles, one whose population had instantly rocketed to 3.4 million from 2 million.
Only London, of all the world's cities, was larger. Chicago, proudly resurgent after its 1871 fire, no longer threatened to become the nation's first city.
Indeed, the new city suddenly had more people than any of the states abutting the Atlantic Ocean, and more than the rest of New York State.
"Consolidation is a tame word for such a magnificent moment," Robert Caro, the historian, said. "What we're celebrating is the moment the city received critical mass."
"It instantly created the greatest metropolis in the Western Hemisphere at the time," said Kenneth T. Jackson, chairman of Columbia University's history department. "Without this, New York would have been much less of a grand spot."
But from the perspective of some urban planners, the occasion marks nothing so much as a stalled, not to say failed, dream. Mr. Caro noted that Robert Moses, the great builder of this region's infrastructure, was one of the last to think expansively of connecting the city to great reaches in the suburbs and beyond.
Others go so far as to suggest that the lack of a mechanism to enlarge New York -- perhaps by including ever more boroughs -- has made the current city something of a museum piece at a time other American cities are pushing their boundaries farther and farther outward.
"New York was designed as a regional government," said Robert Yaro of the Regional Plan Association. "Within a generation, it was clear this region had gone beyond the five boroughs. There was and is a need for elastic boundaries."
 
Debates Will Continue Beyond the Events
 The debates will continue well beyond the flurry of events that begin today with a small ceremony at 2 P.M. at the Museum of the City of New York, where the Charter is being displayed for what is thought to be the first public exhibition of the document. An event at 11:30 A.M. tomorrow at City Hall will include as many 100-year-old New Yorkers as can be rustled up, as well as a big birthday cake.
More events will follow next year. There will be museum exhibitions, lectures, seminars and an official tourism campaign. A 10-hour documentary on New York history, produced by Ric Burns, will be shown on the Public Broadcasting System. The Board of Education plans special courses on New York City history.
The Convention and Visitors Bureau has created a logo and plans a national ad campaign for "New York History Year."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani boasts that the celebration comes at a time when New York has bounced back, citing lower crime and increased tourism. "This is a very wonderful time for the city," he said. "At the time of our hundredth birthday, we are witnessing a great renaissance."
Plans for a performance of the "Jubilee March of the Greater New-York" by W. C. Parker, believed to have been performed only once, have been reluctantly postponed until Jan. 1, 1998, the centennial of the date on which consolidation became effective.
"Put it this way," explained Schuyler G. Chapin, Commissioner of Cultural Affairs. "The piece cannot be learned overnight."
Nor can the many questions still swirling around consolidation be easily answered. The basic arguments of proponents were that greater population would increase business opportunities, lead to lower taxes because of economies of scale and create employment through more extensive public works. The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York was the strongest supporter.
"Consolidation was pushed by people who wanted to have a business-led development of the region," said David C. Hammack, a professor at Case Western University and a respected student of the period.
 
Hard to Exaggerate The State of Disorder
 Mr. Hammack said that it was hard to exaggerate the disorder of New York at the end of the 19th century. All of Manhattan south of Canal Street was a smelly traffic jam of horse-drawn carts. Brooklyn and the Bronx lacked paved roads. Queens and Staten Island were agricultural lands desperate for development money.
But to 19th-century reformers, cleaning up politics was as urgent as improving the physical structure of the city. Instead of 40 separate municipalities, it was felt one city would be easier for legislative and journalistic watchdogs to monitor for corruption. Moreover, a specific problem in a single locality might be repeated elsewhere. As a current example, Mr. Hammack cited the way the tragic fire at the Happy Land Social Club, in which 87 people died in March 1990, led to a crackdown on such establishments all over the city.
On the other side, some of the opponents were people content with smaller, more localized government. Some distrusted the repeated arguments that they would pay lower taxes. Brooklynites, in particular, did not want to lose an identity whose roots extended into the 17th century, almost as far back as Manhattan's.
Some of this opposition was rooted in nativist disdain of immigrants. "We don't need the political sewage of Europe," proclaimed Richard Salter Storrs, a prominent Brooklyn Congregationalist minister.
There are questions about what if any difference consolidation made in the lives of ordinary people. "For the average person in New York in 1897, working-class tenement dwellers, it's not clear to me it made much difference," said Daniel Czitrom, a Mount Holyoke College history professor who is writing a book about the period.
But the issues surrounding consolidation have never vanished. Robert R. Macdonald, director of the Museum of the City of New York, says he intends to use the anniversary as an opportunity "to think about New York -- past, present and future."
He wants to examine why people have always left New York, even as others have come. Why, he asks, do people in Queens and Brooklyn still refer to Manhattan as "the city"? Why does New York City charge tolls on some of the bridges within its city limits, something Mr. Macdonald believes may be unique?
All these questions come down to municipal identity, something people in this city either take for granted or joke about.
Robert A. M. Stern, the architect, noted that the competition with Chicago was important. That city had just staged the Columbian Exposition in 1893, an enormously influential event New York was first supposed to host, then botched because it could not come up with a site.
Chicago's population, already 1.7 million, seemed to be growing faster than New York's, a particular annoyance because the Great Lakes economy had been stoked by the Erie Canal, financed by New York capitalists.
Even more important, Mr. Stern said, was the establishment of "the centrality of New York," which he said was reflected in the new homes of such grand institutions as the New York Public Library, whose founder, Andrew Haswell Green, was also the most prominent mover behind the new city.
But what Mr. Stern called "a grand civicism" was not without its darker side. "The old WASP establishment was recognizing that for the first time it wasn't in the driver's seat," he said. "This was a last-gasp attempt to impose the Anglo culture on the whole city."
Consolidation is also an example of the sort of forward thinking, often not a little grandiose, that has long characterized the city. Mr. Burns, the film maker, points out that in 1811, the city mapped the whole city in grid pattern, even though it was almost entirely farmland. Then in 1857, it created Central Park when the site was the northern point of habitation. From 1924 on, Robert Moses, holding a succession of state and city jobs, remade the parks, roadways and bridges of the metro area.
"This city was created by great extra-territorial thinkers," Mr. Burns said. "It was done on a macro-cosmic scale."
It is the sense of grand design that Brendan Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society, suggested is lacking today, although he thinks great ideas are urgently needed in areas from new rail tunnels to parks. "It's no longer fashionable or encouraged to have grand visions," he said. "If being so huge is to be worth it to New Yorkers, then massive new visions for the future have to be articulated."
Whether this means an even bigger city, or just better means of regional cooperation, is unclear. Mr. Yaro points out that three of the state's largest cities are now in the process of moving many governmental functions to the county level.
"Buffalo, Utica and Syracuse are saying their cities don't work anymore," Mr. Yaro said. "Their metropolitan regions are much bigger, and they don't have the tax base."
As a collection of counties, New York City is clearly different than cities that are smaller than their counties. But Mr. Yaro noted that cities like Houston, San Diego and Phoenix have become the nation's trend-setters in continually expanding their boundaries so as not to lose their populations.
At the same time, Mr. Yaro said, the fact that one-third of the region's population resides in the city, an effect of consolidation, guarantees the city more political clout. By contrast, he said, the proportion is one-tenth or less in Detroit, Boston and other cities. "This means New York hasn't been marginalized," he said.
The question before New Yorkers is whether they can keep the spirit that prevailed when the city came together as one a century ago.
On Jan. 1, 1898, The New York Tribune proclaimed, "The sun will rise this morning upon the greatest experiment in municipal government that the world has ever known."

HEADLINE: April 27-May 3;
A Compromise for 2002: Balancing the Federal Budget

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
President Clinton agreed on Friday to a compromise plan with Republicans to balance the Federal budget by 2002. Whether the plan will be enacted as written remains unclear, and murkier still is the question of whether it would actually eliminate the deficit in five years.
But as a political document, the agreement was quite an accomplishment, encompassing compromises on sweeping ideological issues like the size and role of the Government (it will get slightly smaller) and on specific programs. 
 Mr. Clinton gave up $58 billion in spending on domestic programs, $12 billion more than he wanted, but got money for his main priorities, including health insurance for poor children, restoring welfare benefits to legal immigrants, expanding the Head Start program and providing tax breaks for college students. Republicans got the tax cuts they have been clamoring for, including breaks for families with children and a reduction in the capital gains tax.
Where's the pain? Most of it was masked by a rapid decline in the size of the deficit, which this year is running at $75 billion, the lowest level in more than two decades, thanks largely to a booming economy.
"Under this budget agreement," said Senator Trent Lott, the Republican majority leader, "official Washington must learn to make do with less, while Americans will keep more of what they earn, and they will be able to save it and invest it in their own families." RICHARD W. STEVENSON

HEADLINE: April 27-May 3;
U.S. Economy Keeps Booming

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
The economy has been chugging along recession-free for more than six years, but it is now roaring down the track. Economic output grew 5.6 percent in the first quarter, the strongest performance since 1987, the Government said last week. The momentum carried over into April, pushing the unemployment rate down to 4.9 percent, the lowest rate in 24 years. 
 Remarkably, inflation has remained contained. But with the jobless rate so low, employers will likely raise wages to attract workers, putting upward pressure on prices. The result will almost certainly be more interest rate increases from the Federal Reserve to cool things down. RICHARD W. STEVENSON

HEADLINE: In Budget Battle, Advantage Goes to G.O.P. Chairmen

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
With a broad agreement in hand that promises a balanced budget, the deal-making has shifted from President Clinton and Republican leaders to a new set of negotiators, the Capitol Hill tax writers and appropriators who will make it law.
For weeks, leaders of both parties have wrangled over the budget, but in the next few months, control of that process will rest solely with the Republicans who control Congress. And it is at this point that interest groups will turn on the real pressure. 
 Much of what happens next will depend on the guidance of four Republican committee chairmen in the House and Senate, each of whom brings a different style, temperament and agenda to the table.
And none will attract more attention than Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, who will have considerable control over important issues like the size of cuts in the capital gains tax and the estate tax.
Mr. Archer, who represents one of the nation's six wealthiest districts and who prepares his own tax returns, will have the principal responsibility for writing some of the most sweeping Federal tax cuts in recent history.
He has already made his presence felt. Budget negotiators said that as their talks reached a crucial point this week, Mr. Archer stepped in and flexed his political muscle by insisting that his committee have the largest say on the size of certain tax breaks, a move that temporarily stalled a final agreement.
After more than a quarter-century on Capitol Hill, Mr. Archer is the longest-serving Republican in the House of Representatives. He is a savvy veteran of budget fights and one of the most passionate anti-tax crusaders in Washington.
"Crucial tasks lie ahead," Mr. Archer said. "The Ways and Means Committee will write the policies and determine the details necessary to carry its part of the budget resolution into law."
In his radio address today, President Clinton asked Congress to approve a balanced budget plan worked out in negotiations with leaders of the Republican-led Congress.
 "Let us now reach across party lines and seize our chance to balance the budget," he said of the plan reached on Friday to balance the budget by 2002 and cut some taxes.
 Under current budget rules, whenever Congress makes a tax cut, the resulting loss in revenue must be made up by either raising another tax or by cutting entitlements.
The negotiators agreed to offset $50 billion of the proposed tax cuts by renewing the airline ticket tax and airport fees -- which would generate about $30 billion in revenue -- and by closing some tax loopholes.
The rest would have to be taken from entitlement programs. Senior Democratic aides with the Ways and Means Committee have said that Mr. Archer has already informed his Republican committee members that he is considering making up some of the money by trimming the low-income housing credit. The program, which gives tax credits for investments in low-income housing, could provide up to $17 billion in savings, Democratic aides said.
The Constitution dictates that all tax legislation must originate in the House of Representatives. And because the Ways and Means Committee is the tax-writing panel for the House, its chairman has traditionally exercised wide latitude over what legislation gets beyond the committee and the size of any tax cuts.
Spending plans also originate in the House, and that means that the Appropriations Committee and its chairman, Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, will share the spotlight.
Mr. Livingston talks tough and is given to boisterous, arm-flailing outbursts, but he has also shown a knack for rigorous fiscal belt-tightening. In the previous Congress, the so-called "cardinals" who controlled the 13 appropriations subcommittees under his direction saved $50 billion by cutting spending on social, housing and education programs. They killed nearly 300 such programs. Mr. Livingston has said he does not expect deep cuts in discretionary programs other than defense this year. But he warned of some cuts this week.
Both Mr. Archer's and Mr. Livingston's tasks will be complicated, but not stopped, by the senior Democrats on their committees.
"I do not believe a majority of the Democrats in this caucus are going to vote for this turkey," Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the Democratic leader on the Appropriations Committee, thundered after Administration officials floated the tentative plan at midweek.
Even after seeing the sweetened finished product, Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, the senior Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, was still unconvinced. "The people who benefit from the tax cuts are not my constituents," Mr. Rangel said.
In the Senate, which usually looks to the House appropriations bill as its spending blueprint, Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, the Republican chairman of appropriations, will hold sway over spending.
Mr. Stevens is often hot-tempered and eager to battle the Democrats over spending.
The Finance Committee, led by Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, will help with tax-writing on the budget.
Mr. Roth is a kindred spirit to Mr. Archer when it comes to cutting taxes. He and former Representative Jack Kemp co-wrote the 1981 Kemp-Roth tax-reduction bill. He was named chairman of the Finance Committee in September of 1995.
Robert D. Reischauer of the Brookings Institution, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office, said the greatest problem area for these men might be Medicare payments. Under the agreement, projected spending on Medicare would be reduced by $115 billion, or 8.5 percent, in the next five years, mostly by cutting payments to medical providers and increasing many Medicare premiums by $1 a month.
"Here you can expect to see the Ways and Means, Finance and Commerce committees struggle," he said. "They are going to be under immense pressure from the provider interests. The only significant blood that has been drawn in this budget deal is from hospitals, doctors and other medical providers."
In the new lineup, it is Mr. Archer who will have the most control and command the most attention.
Chosen in 1970 to succeed Representative George H. Bush in the reliably Republican, highly affluent Seventh District of suburban Houston, the affable and quiet-spoken Mr. Archer has always shown a zeal for tax-cutting.
"The less taxes the better; the smaller Government the better" is a favorite political mantra of Mr. Archer, a 69-year-old lawyer who boasts of his frugality and of paying cash for his houses.
Mr. Archer took a back seat to Speaker Newt Gingrich and others in the bruising budget fights of the last Congress. But in late December, he went to the White House for a one-on-one meeting with President Clinton that both men described as a "courtesy call" and not a budget negotiation.
Still, Mr. Archer's visit gave notice to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gingrich and all other interested parties that he was an important player.
The Clinton Administration and the Republican budget negotiators have agreed on how much they should cut taxes, a maximum of $85 billion in the first five years and about $165 billion in the ensuing five years. They have agreed to cut the capital gains tax and estate taxes, and to implement a $500-per-child tax credit, an Administration-backed tuition tax credit, credits for companies to clean up abandoned industrial sites and a tax break of some sort for District of Columbia residents.
But officials involved in the first round of the budget talks said that one of the last sticking points was Mr. Archer's demand that his committee have the right to set the size of the various proposed tax cuts.
That impasse was broken when Republicans agreed to guarantee that $35 billion of the tax cuts would go toward the Administration's tuition tax credit plan and that Mr. Archer's committee would decide how the remaining $50 billion in tax cuts should be appropriated.
Mr. Archer has been one of the most vocal advocates of reducing the capital gains tax and the Federal inheritance tax. But he has been ambivalent about the $500-per-child tax credit. Mr. Archer is also one of the leading proponents in Congress of replacing the Federal income tax with a national sales tax, although that issue is not part of the current package of tax proposals.

LENGTH: 1245 words

HEADLINE: Opening a Window to the Inner Souls of Artists, in a New Novel

BYLINE: By MARJORIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
FERNANDA EBERSTADT grew up with a gold Marilyn Monroe silkscreen by Andy Warhol in her parents' Victorian living room on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
Warhol was a close friend of her parents, Frederick, a fashion photographer, and Isabel, a writer and the daughter of the poet Ogden Nash. 
 One summer when she was 16, Warhol employed Ms. Eberstadt at his "Factory" to write for Interview magazine. "The Factory was my intensive introduction to the New York art world's ruthless merchandising of talent," Ms. Eberstadt recounted in a recent interview.
Although not a painter, art is important in her life. "Eberstadt loves art, all sorts of art," said Roxana Robinson in a very favorable critique in The New York Times Book Review on March 30, "and writes about it with joyful comprehension."
Religious imagery, like her childhood collection of icons from trips to Europe, resembles the art created by the protagonist of her third novel, "When the Sons of Heaven Meet the Daughters of the Earth" (Knopf).
The figure, Isaac Hooker, 26, from a provincial New Hampshire town, is a Harvard dropout writer who becomes an artist in the 1980's glitzy art scene in New York. He finds a benefactor and a lover in the wealthy Dolly Gebler, who runs an arts foundation with her husband, Alfred.
Speaking in Huntington, near where her father grew up at Target Rock, Ms. Eberstadt said the Geblers were not based on her parents. But in the book, New York's high society art world becomes a metaphor for the relation of art to religion.
"Unlike other forms of culture," she said, "art has become a commodity, and it has a religious side. People trade art, but they also worship it."
A sequel to "Isaac and His Devils" (Knopf, 1991), "Sons of Heaven" is as much Dolly Gebler's story. She is a woman who sees artists as messiahs. "She had acquired the belief that money must redeem itself from its gross origins and be converted into the immortal tender of lasting works," the writer said.
By the novel's end Isaac offers "a cautionary tale to young artists, don't come out of nowhere and burn too bright, learn to last."
"Jean Michel Basquiat," Ms. Eberstadt said, "was an artist who began his career sleeping in a cardboard box and spray painting graffiti in subways and who died at age 28 from a heroin overdose. I remember seeing him once at a party. I've never forgotten it. He was blocking a staircase, making out with a blond girl. No one could go up or down the steps. There was such magnetism about him. He was so magical."
Although Isaac may seem like "a white Basquiat," Ms. Eberstadt said, she invented him more from sources like Samuel Johnson. In 1982, Ms. Eberstadt was one of the first women to graduate from Magdalen College at Oxford, achieving the highest degree awarded that year in English literature.
"Oxford was a revelation to me," she said. "I had been an alternately wild and dowdy teen-ager, daydreaming, morbid, overshadowed by hipster parents and a brilliant older brother, Nick, who, modeling himself after our paternal grandfather, had become an economist at Harvard."
Religious overtones pervade not only her fictional world. "Consciousness of divine presence is a tune that always runs through my head," she said. "Sometimes a drone, sometimes in perfect pitch."
Art, words and religious imagery collide in a brilliant burst of color, texture and truth in "When the Sons of Heaven Meet the Daughters of the Earth." The title, taken from Genesis, is a nod to the biblical metaphors of another period. "Throughout the book," Ms. Eberstadt said, "there are many references to the Old Testament's time of excess before the Flood, when the heavenly creatures mated with the earthly." It is also the title of Isaac's first series of allegorical drawings.
Dolly is an example of "how a patron can kill an artist's work by becoming too proprietary." She provides Issac with the luxury of time and paint at her summer home on the North Fork, Goose Neck, and converts him into a salable success in SoHo, but at the same time jeopardizes his creative vision.
Ms. Eberstadt wrote part of the novel while in a rented house in Southold. Her descriptions of driving between the East End and Manhattan combine wit and lyric: "Then like a musical composition introducing a new motif, the first burst of farmland asserted itself, vying with shopping mall."
The view across the Peconic from the North Fork becomes "a benign semi-sequesteredness, a blurred ambidexterity of land and sea."
But the center of the book, Ms. Eberstadt, said is not so much a satire of what occurs when a hefty price tag is placed on artistic vision as much as it is a story of revelation, and where it comes from and how it disappears. "If you inflate a living artist's reputation," the writer said, "the exposure can destroy the work."
To prepare, Ms. Eberstadt, enrolled in a drawing class in London, where she and her husband, Alaistar Bruton, a British political journalist, and their daughter Maud, 2, named for the Tennyson poem, live in addition to New York.
The couple met in 1992 in Istanbul, where Ms. Eberstadt was on assignment for The New Yorker, and were married the following year. She also writes literary criticism and essays.
"The drawing class was the most physically demanding experience I have ever had," she said. Writing about painting was probably the most challenging, she said, because painters and writers see the world so differently.
The only thing clear in Ms. Eberstadt's alternately solemn and wild childhood was that she would be a writer. Her parents were a mixture of uptown high society and downtown funk, she said. As patrons of avant-garde theater, film and music in the 60's, their parties went down in social history, and her mother's dresses of feathers, vinyl and fur hang in the Museum of the City of New York.
"Very early," the writer said, "I saw writing as my job. School always got in the way. I just never got it, was never good at it."
But her parents always took her writing seriously. "Even before I was old enough to write," she said, "my mother used to write my words down."
At 11, Ms. Eberstadt dropped out of the Brearley School. "That year we lived in the Bahamas," she said, "and I completed my first novel. I read and read and read, everything, including the entire Bible. I made intricate lists of the characters' genealogy."
Growing up without parental guidance or boundaries for religion, sex or drugs was scary, she said.
Words were the only sure thing she knew. "I remember always having a fascination with words and playing word games with Papa [Ogden Nash]," Ms. Eberstadt said. " Words, words in love with them, wanting to swallow the dictionary. We spent summers in New Hampshire, and every day he would read out loud what he had written that morning. He also read out loud "The Hobbit," wonderful old fairy tales and books by Lloyd Alexander, to me, my brother and our cousins. He was a very gentle, sweet mild man with a beautiful gentle voice."
"Sons of Heaven" is written not so much as a satire on pretentiousness in the New York art world as a lush kaleidoscopic "journal to God," she said.
"Isaac," Ms. Eberstadt wrote, "was learning to paint in a way that showed the faith, the tenderness, the suffering in things. To capture the inner radiance. Which meant learning how to see with the heart's inward eye. Painting to make people believe."

HEADLINE: Coalition to Gather Food in Drive on Hunger

BYLINE: By LINDA TAGLIAFERRO 

 BODY:
SAYING that unemployment, budget cuts and welfare changes are straining hunger-relief efforts, a coalition of groups is planning to participate, for the first time, in the third Stamp Out Hunger Food Drive, on Saturday.
The drive is being organized by the National Association of Letter Carriers as part of a national effort. 
 The Long Island groups include Help for the Poor, the Interfaith Nutrition Network, Island Harvest, Long Island Cares and the Long Island Volunteer Center. A spokesman for the agencies, Msgr. Thomas Hartman of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, said:
"Long Islanders more readily associate hunger with New York City. But in fact there are 600 soup kitchens on the Island. The need for food will be even greater when welfare reforms come through. The nature of this need cries out for all the agencies to help each other."
Lynn Needleman of Long Island Cares, a food bank that started in 1980, said that when Long Island suffered through a recession in the 1990's she noticed that her agency was increasingly helping recipients from the middle classes.
"Unemployment figures can be misleading," Ms. Needleman said. "Even if unemployed workers find new jobs, they may be offered lesser salaries. After they pay their rent or mortgage, many people are finding that they are in need of food."
Social agencies today, she added, are frequently sought out by people who had been donors, meaning that donations have decreased while the demand has increased.
Based on her experience, she said, at least 300,000 Long Islanders need food.
Contributors are asked to leave new nonperishable foods in cans or plastic containers in bags near their mailboxes for letter carriers to collect. The items will be taken to warehouses for sorting for the charities.
All post offices on Long Island will also have donation bins.
The chairman of the drive for the letter carriers, Rick Hubert, said, "We are looking for staple foods such as pasta, soups, tuna fish, cereals and vegetables."
In 1995, Long Island led the nation in donations, with 1.4 million pounds. Last year donations reached 1.9 million pounds, and the goal for Saturday is two million pounds.
More than one million postcards are being delivered on Long Island to notify residents about the drive.
"There will also be 26,000 posters announcing this event," Mr. Hubert added. "The letter carriers' union has 5,000 active members on Long Island. And they look forward to this drive every year. They start planning in November, and some workers even come in to help on their days off."
The Long Island district manager for the Postal Service, Thomas Rossati, said:
"This is a cooperative effort, and we're utilizing our people to network, to facilitate the spirit of giving on Long Island. Our drivers, clerks, supervisors and mail handlers will all facilitate this phenomenal effort."
Linda Breitstone of Island Harvest thanked a number of companies and organizations for their assistance.
"Lilco gave us volunteers and their media expertise," Ms. Breitstone said. "Danny Lehner, who owns Inflight Newspapers, managed to get a donation of a forklift for us. Waldbaum's and King Kullen are donating hundreds of thousands of plastic bags, and Jack Price of Price Paper is giving us an additional 5,000 bags. The Nassau County Bar Association's We Care Fund donated $3,000 for milk crates."
Warehouses are needed, and Picone Realty is donating the use of one in Calverton. Reckson Associates, the real estate giant, is donating the use of a warehouse in Hicksville for two months.
"This is a huge donation," Ms. Breitstone said, "because the site contains over 175,000 square feet, and there are 12 loading areas."
People who want to volunteer to help can call the Long Island Volunteer Center at 294-5482.
"We have to make sure that we don't send baby food to senior citizens or gourmet foods to children," Ms. Breitstone said. "This is a massive effort, and we need the warehouses to store the food until it can be delivered to the respective agencies.
"I used to have a faceless concept of who these needy people were, and then I realized that they're all my neighbors and just like me. We would all want someone to reach out to us, and we should all reach out to them now."
Information about the food drive is available from Island Harvest at 294-8528 and Long Island Cares at 435-1936.
In a related collection, a group called Rock and Wrap It Up! is gathering food for the remainder of the school year on Thursdays and Fridays at George Hewlett High School in Hewlett.
Hewlett is the first school in what the group hopes will be a national effort to raise food for the needy. The organization was started by Syd Mandelbaum of Lawrence, who began by collecting leftover food from musical groups at rock concerts.

HEADLINE: DEVELOPMENT;
Taking the State Master Plan Beyond Paper, Into Action

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN

 BODY:
When the New Jersey Development and Redevelopment Plan was adopted in 1992, it was widely hailed as a pioneering blueprint for managed growth, one of the most advanced of several statewide efforts in the country. The plan, which was nonbinding, offered local governments the tools they needed to turn the tide of suburban sprawl, concentrate development in town and city centers and preserve vanishing farmland and open space.
Five years later, the only thing that seems to have changed in New Jersey is that not too many people are excited about the state plan anymore. Farms are still disappearing at a rate of 10,000 or so acres a year, developers are still happy to show towns just how permissive their zoning ordinances really are and cities are still complaining that all the economic development is going to their suburbs. Only about 5 percent of towns have tried to make their own master plans consistent with the principles of the state plan. And despite the fact that state put the plan together based, among other things, on suggestions from each of the 567 municipalities, most local governments don't seem to know quite what to do with it. 
 Now, in accordance with state law, the plan-making process is about to begin all over again. Later this month, the staff of the State Planning Office expects to finish a draft of a new version of the plan. The draft will be sent to every local and county government, and for the next two years, state and local officials, developers and environmentalists will work out the details, tussling over the definitions of "environmentally sensitive" and "town center" and expanding "principles" into "key concepts."
But critics of the plan say that without any enforcement power and without sufficient state money to help towns achieve the plan's goals, the next version is not likely to change (or preserve) the landscape too much more than the present plan has.
"The state absolutely must get more proactive," said Barbara Wolfe, a former mayor and current planning board chairman in East Amwell, a Hunterdon County township that is trying to hold on to its largely agrarian identity. Without state-imposed tax incentives and penalties to keep growth where it should be, the township has very little leverage, she said. And without the state backing it up, she said, East Amwell dare not tighten its zoning for fear of sparking lawsuits from farmers and other landowners whose property values would plummet if a 30-acre tract zoned for 10 homes was suddenly allowed only one.
On Monday, the New Jersey Audubon Society and the state Federation of Sportsmen's Clubs started a petition drive for a state plan that would make areas designated "rural" or "environmentally sensitive" not just places where local governments might want to consider discouraging development, but also places where the state will not tolerate development.
In New Jersey, with its fierce tradition of home rule (not to mention a powerful builders' lobby), such a proposal is about as likely to win broad support as a turnpike toll increase. But Bill Neil, the Audubon Society's Assistant Director for Conservation, said that extreme situations demand extreme solutions.
"The voluntary people have had their day," he said. "They've had a model out there for five years and it hasn't worked."
Thomas Dallessio, the Public Affairs Manager for the State Planning Commission, which is coordinating the plan revision, said, "If the public truly believes that there's a role of state government to limit the development in rural areas, they need to let us know."
The current state plan is a 185-page book of land-use guidelines accompanied by volumes of technical papers. It gives chunks of land one of five planning designations, from densely populated urban districts to environmentally sensitive, off-limits areas. It encourages local governments to designate "centers," concentrate public investment in sewers and roads in those centers and discourage growth outside the centers.
The state has passed laws to make the plan work better. One passed last year allows landowners to transfer density from parcels in low-growth areas to parcels better suited for growth, even if they are not contiguous. And in 1995, Governor Whitman ordered state agencies to use the state plan as the basis of their decisions whenever possible -- giving preference, for example, to sewer permit applications or requests for street upgrades within town centers.
In the next version of the plan, Mr. Dallessio said, the commission hopes to include specific goals -- to preserve a certain amount or percentage of farmland or natural habitat, for example.
But whatever happens, Mr. Dallessio said, will be the product of statewide consensus. "That's the beauty of the process," he said. "We cannot mandate from the state what planning gets done on the local level. The public will implement the plan because the public helped write the plan."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 18, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 4 about the state master plan paraphrased the position of Bill Neil, the Assistant Director of Conservation for the New Jersey Audubon Society, incorrectly. He did not say that problems with enforcement of the state plan had created extreme situations requiring extreme solutions. A letter explaining the society's position appears today on page 19.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 28; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1871 words

HEADLINE: Pursued by Fashionable Furies

BYLINE: By Carol Tavris; Carol Tavris, a social psychologist and author of "The Mismeasure of Woman," writes often on behavioral research and pseudoscience.

 BODY:

HYSTORIES
 Hysterical Epidemics and Modern Culture.
 By Elaine Showalter.
 244 pp. New York:
 Columbia University Press. $24.95. 
 The theories of Sigmund Freud are the crabgrass in the lawn of cultural criticism. Scientists, philosophers and research psychologists have been trying for decades to dynamite the tenacious stuff, poison it or pull it up by its roots, but it keeps coming back. The plump and juicy metaphors of Freudian analysis are just too appealing to many literary critics, because they account nicely for any topic under scrutiny -- on a post hoc basis, that is. The fact that three Freudians will analyze the same person or phenomenon in three different ways never fazes Freud's supporters, any more than does the fact that three movie critics will review the same movie in three different ways. But that is precisely why Freudian metaphors appeal to literary critics and exasperate scientists, and why this book will do the same.
Elaine Showalter, a professor of English and president-elect of the Modern Language Association, has written a spirited Freudo-literary analysis of what she calls hysterical epidemics and what social scientists call emotional contagions or mass psychogenic illnesses. Her six examples are chronic fatigue syndrome, gulf war syndrome, recovered memories of sexual abuse, multiple personality disorder, satanic ritual abuse and alien abduction. She knows full well that throwing the first three into the mix will "infuriate thousands of people who believe they are suffering from unidentified organic disorders or the aftereffects of trauma." She braves not only their wrath, but also that of the feminist therapists and writers whose "credulous endorsements of recovered memory and satanic abuse" have contributed to these epidemics. This attitude alone is worth the price of the book.
It may seem odd and unduly provocative that a scholar who has written about misogynistic attitudes in medicine would retain the word "hysteria," laden as it is with muddled meanings and antiwoman baggage. But Ms. Showalter wants to reclaim "hysteria" as a universal human response to conflict, anxiety or sexual desire. When these strong feelings cannot be expressed directly, she argues, they are transformed into a vast and shifting array of physical symptoms or delusional beliefs. Hysteria is a culturally permissible language of distress, used by those who are otherwise mute or silenced. A man who cannot admit he is afraid can legitimately complain of having a headache; a woman who is afraid to acknowledge her sexual fantasies can legitimately claim she was abducted by aliens who subjected her to "probes."
Hysteria becomes epidemic, Ms. Showalter maintains, through the spread of culturally fashionable narratives, which she calls "hystories." A hystory is picked up by the news media, talk shows, self-help books and the Internet; named and validated by medical or psychological experts; and given a congenial reception by society. "Multiple personality disorder," for example, was sparked by the media's obsession with sensational cases, like that of "Sybil"; endorsed by psychiatrists, who then went looking for it in their patients; perpetuated by the growth of professional groups, journals and treatment centers devoted to it; and welcomed by feminists who saw it as the ultimate consequence of women's victimization and loss of self.
Some aspects of these epidemics do lend themselves beautifully to literary study. For example, Ms. Showalter traces the similarity between popular forms of women's pornography, such as the "soft-core rape fantasies of bodice busters," and the erotic scenarios of women who say they have been abducted by aliens. And she shows that when therapists and doctors express surprise that their patients independently tell the same story -- of what an alien looks like, of "memories" of a ritual massacre of babies and goats -- they are failing to recognize how common these "plot lines" are in our culture.
The "hysterical narrative," Ms. Showalter tells us, has become a growth industry in literary criticism, emerging "at the busy crossroad where psychoanalytic theory, narratology, feminist criticism and the history of medicine intersect." Normally I would think it unfair to fault her for staying in the ethereal territory she knows and not moving on down the road. But the Freudo-literary tradition is not just an intellectual exercise for the flexing of academic muscles; it has had powerful and pernicious effects on people's lives. Indeed, discredited Freudian theories and invalidated methods, along with the widespread ignorance of the difference between scientific research and clinical/literary opinion, have contributed to three of the very epidemics she discusses -- recovered memory, multiple personality and satanic ritual abuse. This is why Ms. Showalter's approach, while often informative, suffers from three fundamental flaws.
The first is that it loses its grounding in the circumstances and realities of people's lives. Sometimes a headache is a "language of distress," and sometimes it's a tumor. Because Ms. Showalter sees hystories as an unwitting collusion between troubled victims and sympathetic experts who offer a clear reason for the patient's unhappiness (it's all due to your dad, the aliens, a yet-unnamed disease, a government conspiracy), she allocates no blame to either side. "Hystories are constructed," she writes, "by suffering patients, caring psychologists, dedicated clergy, devoted parents, hardworking police, concerned feminists and anxious communities."
Indeed, but such narratives are also constructed by vested interests protecting their professions and incomes, ignorant psychologists, greedy opportunists who see a way to make a fast buck on the insecurities of the vulnerable, ideologues of the right and left, and clergy and politicians drunk on the elixir of moral righteousness. By not also identifying the venal motives that support epidemics, let alone their economic, social and political supports, Ms. Showalter implies that they are merely psychological phenomena, reflecting people's efforts in scary times to reduce anxiety. So they are -- but they are also big business.
Second, while Ms. Showalter correctly alerts us to the medicalizing of problems caused by strong emotions and psychological stresses, she overlooks an equally common diagnostic error: the psychologizing of problems with organic causes. Until the bacillus that causes tuberculosis was identified, TB was thought to be a result of having a "tubercular personality." Until the bacterium that causes peptic ulcers was identified, ulcers were said to be caused by repressed anger -- still a favorite psychoanalytic culprit. In California, a woman spent 12 years in therapy, her muscles getting steadily weaker until she couldn't lift her hand to brush her teeth. The psychiatrist said that her problem was her "repressed rage" at her parents; she turned out to have myasthenia gravis, a progressive muscular disease.
In this context, Ms. Showalter's discussion of gulf war syndrome is both informative and limited. "War makes people sick," she says succinctly. The sickness has had different names -- shell shock, war neurosis, post-traumatic stress disorder -- and taken different forms, but it is caused by the terror, stress and unpredictability of battle. After World War I, she writes, men across Europe complained of "limps, loss of voice, paralyzed limbs, headaches, amnesia, incapacitating insomnia and emotional distress." An English military doctor, not wanting to accuse British soldiers of being "hysterical" (i.e., weak and womanly), suggested that the symptoms were caused by the physical or chemical effects of exposure to an exploding shell; hence the term shell shock. Today, as then, Ms. Showalter argues, veterans are hostile to the idea that any aspect of their suffering might be psychological.
By tracing the similarity of veterans' symptoms -- so vague, so diverse -- across time, Ms. Showalter makes a convincing argument that emotional contagion and panic are a big part of gulf war syndrome. For example, some veterans attribute their babies' respiratory problems to the syndrome, but studies find the rate of these infants' problems to be no higher than usual.
Yet, as recent news reports have shown, it is not irrational or hysterical for veterans to believe that they might have been exposed to chemical toxins in the gulf war and that the Government has been lying to them. (Government agencies do not have a sterling record of voluntarily revealing their deadly blunders.) Similarly, although many of the people who claim to have chronic fatigue syndrome are probably suffering from depression and other normal maladies of modern life, it is unlikely that all of them are. In the absence of medical certainty, the belief that all such symptoms are psychological in origin is no improvement over the belief that none of them are.
Finally, the deepest flaw in Ms. Showalter's book stems from her confusion about the difference between the empirical tradition of psychology and the literary one of Freudianism, and her persistent mistaken equation of psychotherapy with psychoanalysis. She acknowledges the devastating new criticism of Freud and his work, agreeing that he pressured his patients "to produce narratives congruent with his theories," thereby eliciting "confabulations rather than actual memories"; and that his treatment of Dora, the classic case of hysteria, was bullying and unethical. But then, in a dazzling non sequitur, she attacks the critics who made the world aware of Freud's failings as "anti-Freudian zealots," concluding that "whatever the assaults of academics and renegades, artists and writers will continue to cherish Freudian insights." This is like saying, "Whatever the evidence of biologists and physicians, artists and writers will continue to think that repressed anger causes ulcers."
The Freudian-literary alliance thus perpetuates a fuzzy-headed antipathy to evidence and logic in the name of post-modern relativism and "narrative analysis": if all stories are equally therapeutic and valid from the storyteller's point of view, who am I to judge them? In the final analysis, so to speak, that is the attitude that contributes most to the spread of hysterical epidemics. "I have no idea if my client was really subjected to satanic ritual abuse," one therapist told her colleagues at a conference. "My job is to believe her." This is nonsense. Therapists don't have to believe their clients, or believe that there is only one truth, in order to teach their clients to think critically about their lives, to look for the evidence for their beliefs and to examine many reasons for their unhappiness.
Ironically, Ms. Showalter makes a vigorous case that not all narratives are equally therapeutic or true, that we must rely on clear thinking and evidence to protect us from the lure of emotional contagions and irrational beliefs. For all the problems I had with the specifics of her argument, therefore, I am grateful for her resounding call to arms against the witch hunts, delusions and follies of our times.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Hands Off the Globe

BYLINE: By David Fromkin; David Fromkin is the chairman of the department of international relations at Boston University.

 BODY:

PROMISED LAND,
 CRUSADER STATE
 The American Encounter
 With the World Since 1776.
 By Walter A. McDougall.
 286 pp. Boston:
 Houghton Mifflin Company. $26. 
 In the 1990's the United States does pretty much what it pleases in world affairs. No longer do conflicts with Nazi Germany or the Soviet Union compel one choice rather than another. No longer does another superpower's possible reaction have to be taken into account; all rivals for global reach have fallen by the way.
Like a successful businessman when he retires, the United States is faced for the first time in a long time with the question of what it wants to do. It isn't just that we wonder whether to intervene in one trouble spot or another abroad, or whether to extend NATO's boundaries. It's that we haven't decided what foreign policy goals we think we can achieve, or that we think we ought to be trying to achieve, now that we can more or less do as we like.
The United States does have foreign policy traditions to guide it. But they sometimes contradict one another. Another problem, according to Walter A. McDougall, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian, is that Americans persist in being mistaken as to what their traditions are. In "Promised Land, Crusader State: The American Encounter With the World Since 1776," he sets out to disentangle, clarify, restate and reassess the fundamental principles of American foreign policy. He is aware that others have been down this path before him: that explanations, though made clearly, have been almost immediately muddled, ignored or forgotten. So it is on a note somewhere between weariness and exasperation that he writes: "Let us try, one more time, to set the record straight." And he does so vividly and powerfully in this first-rate book. Mr. McDougall's sensible account of American foreign policy from Washington to Clinton tells it as it is, and as it was.
Mr. McDougall explains that the United States in the first century of its existence pursued four sound but misunderstood doctrines in the realm of foreign affairs. The first was to build a uniquely good society: the city on a hill, setting an example for the rest of the world. Mr. McDougall claims that it was in this respect -- in domestic policy -- that the Founding Fathers intended us to be exceptional. According to him, they did not expect us to be exceptional in foreign policy. In a dog-eat-dog world, they themselves played as rough and tough as anybody else, and meant for us to do the same.
The second doctrine was to contract alliances with other countries only on a temporary basis. The Founding Fathers warned that we can't entirely rely on allies. Allies don't share our particular domestic politics and interests. Over the long term, therefore, America must play a lone hand. This is unilateralism, Mr. McDougall points out, not isolationism.
The third and fourth of our original doctrines were to expand within the Western Hemisphere and its oceanic approaches, and to forbid the European states to do so. Of course, in the 19th century we weren't powerful enough to effectively warn off the Europeans, even within our own hemisphere; but Secretary of State John Quincy Adams was shrewd enough to realize that in their own interest the British, though gnashing their teeth the whole time, would do it for us.
These four doctrines take us to the 1890's. Mr. McDougall approves of them all because they showed such a keen realization of our limitations and of the realities of the world in which we lived. But in the 1898 war with Spain, we started to go wrong. Those in the realist tradition, Walter Lippmann and George Kennan among them, have thought so too. Where Mr. McDougall departs from them is in what he thinks President William McKinley and his colleagues did wrong. He argues that their mistake was to crusade to free Cuba. His basic theme is that in foreign policy the United States should not try to right the wrongs done by others to others.
What he approves of is what many have deplored: the taking of the Philippines and the acquiring of coaling stations to project American naval power across the Pacific. But he doesn't believe the United States should have pretended to be acting unselfishly. He can justify the policy of imperialism but not the hypocrisy in which it came wrapped.
Mr. McDougall discerns the emergence of three more American policy doctrines in the century between McKinley's 90's and ours, and finds them more of a mixed bag than the previous five. Wilsonianism, by which he means the preaching and launching of crusades to change the politics of other countries, he regards as an almost unmitigated disaster. On the other hand, he approves of our defense of the balance of power in Europe and Asia, in the two world wars and the cold war. But he has no sympathy at all for the policy he calls "global meliorism": the attempt by our Government to bring market economies and other elements of our domestic polity to foreign countries. These, he argues, are things they must do for themselves. Taking his stand with those like George Kennan and J. W. Fulbright, who have urged that we cut back on what they perceive as overcommitment on our part, he stresses the limitations of our wisdom, of our power and of our ability either to understand or to change others. He recommends that our Government "abolish all its do-gooder agencies."
Maybe Mr. McDougall is right in arguing that we can't remake other countries. But what if it is in our vital interests to do so? What if it turns out that unless we see to it that Mexico achieves honest, effective government and fairly distributed wealth, tens of millions of Mexicans in the next century will flood across the frontier and bring down the southern United States in chaos? Or what if we must force other countries to put environmental concerns ahead of enriching themselves in order to keep them from poisoning our part of the planet as well as theirs? Or if, in our own interests, we need to keep murderous fanatics in the Balkans or the Middle East from behaving like themselves?
In other words, what do we do if we find -- as I think that we will, more and more, in the years to come -- that to protect ourselves and our interests we have to do what Mr. McDougall tells us we can't do? That the author can't, or at any rate doesn't, answer the question reflects no discredit upon him. That he doesn't ask it is perhaps a shortcoming.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: Taking In the Sites;
Factions Weigh In on Hong Kong Under Chinese Rule

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
There must be a reason so many of the World Wide Web sites about Hong Kong open with a scene of that city's skyline.
Not that there is anything tedious about the view south from Kowloon toward downtown Hong Kong. Despite the prohibition on big blinking lights (to avoid distracting airline pilots), Hong Kong's panorama of steel and glass has long been one of the more beautifully crowded urban vistas. 
 But as the jewel of the British Empire prepares to be remounted in a Chinese setting, Hong Kong's skyline may be one of the few aspects of the place that is certain not to be changed after sovereignty shifts to Beijing on June 30.
And the fact that perhaps not everything is up for grabs may be a comforting thought to Web designers of all political flavors.
As put in a candid and readable essay on the American Chamber of Commerce's Hong Kong site: "In Hong Kong, there is widespread cynicism about the real intentions and agenda of the British colonial rulers in the final days of the transition. Paradoxically, there is also concern that Hong Kong will become a de facto colonial outpost of P.R.C. interests, with less autonomy than hoped and agreed."
P.R.C. stands for People's Republic of China, and China's official Hong Kong Web site, when it can be reached, makes quite clear the view that the territory should have been part of the P.R.C. a long time ago.
But beyond the flattering portraits of China's hand-picked leaders for the new Special Administrative Region, the press releases showing popular support for cutbacks in civil liberties and the clock counting down to the hand-over, the most interesting thing about the official China site is its roster of advertisers.
One day last week Intel, I.B.M., Eastman Kodak, Microsoft and U.S. Robotics all offered "warmest wishes for the prosperity of Hong Kong." Bay Networks and Oracle went further, "commemorating the return of Hong Kong to the motherland."
The ad for Mitsubishi Motors, a Japanese company, was pointedly different, "commemorating the return of Hong Kong to China."
Whether or not China is the motherland appears to be of little concern to the British Government's Foreign and Commonwealth Office, which runs a Web site that is almost wry in its resigned but dubious attitude about the hand-over.
Hong Kong's civil authorities are much more enthusiastic. The Hong Kong Government and Trade Office's in San Francisco has a Web site that offers a wealth of business information and gives the impression that the hand-over will be little more than an administrative detail. Likewise, the Hong Kong Tourist Association assures visitors that English will remain on street signs and that visa requirements will not change.
The Hong Kong Government's information site offers next to nothing of the territory's history, but includes a long section dedicated to explaining "myths and facts" about the change-over.
For example, fact 16 says (in part) that "public demand for the democratic process to stay on course and develop after 1997 will be irresistible."
That is not much comfort to those who fear Chinese rule.
Emily Lau, a pro-democracy Hong Kong legislator who is almost certain to lose her job after the change-over, runs a site that is half personal campaign literature and half general human rights advocacy. The Hong Kong Democratic Foundation, which appears to be more libertarian think tank than political action group, also has a site.
The Hong Kong Democratic Party and pro-democracy groups called Frontier and the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of the Patriotic and Democratic Movement in China, among others, run extensive Chinese-language sites.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
All About Maggie

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
There are only two facts to keep in mind about the British election: The winner was Margaret Thatcher. The loser was Margaret Thatcher. Everything else is just commentary.
How so? The ultimate triumph in an ideological war is when you convert your opponent, and if there is one theme that ran through this election it was the degree to which the British Labor Party has been converted to the basic principles laid down by Mrs. Thatcher since 1979, when she began transforming Britain from a sluggish welfare state to a fast, market-driven economy. Almost all the principles of Thatcherism -- breaking the unions, privatizing state industries, lowering income taxes, catering to the bond markets, improving competitiveness for a global economy, and fiscal austerity -- were shared by both Conservative and Labor candidates. Paddy Ashdown, leader of the Liberal Democrats, had it right when he remarked that Labor's Tony Blair and the Conservatives' John Major were engaged in "synchronized swimming." 
 It was by adopting the basic economic principles of moderate Conservatism that Mr. Blair was able to win back, in a landslide, the working-class voters who had abandoned Labor-socialism for Thatcherism in the 1980's. The Sunday Times reported that at a Blair rally in Leicester a heckler from the old socialist wing of Labor shouted at Mr. Blair, "You're a Tory!" (a Conservative). A Blair campaign aide responded by directing his staff toward the heckler: "Try to get the cameras on him. He's worth a thousand votes."
Mr. Blair is not alone. Mrs. Thatcher's basic model is being mimicked all over the globe now, and for that reason she belongs in the pantheon of great revolutionaries of this century. Mrs. Thatcher should be remembered as "The Seamstress of the Golden Straitjacket." The golden straitjacket consists of all the Thatcherite principles that a country has to adopt today if it wants to tailor its economy to the demands of the local and global markets. But what happens when a country puts on the golden straitjacket is that its economy grows and its politics shrinks -- all political choices are reduced to Pepsi or Coke, nuances of style, tone and substance.
That's why politics in every industrial democracy today consists of two trends: There is anti-straitjacket politics, which is Buchanan in America, or the Communists in France. They refuse to put on the Thatcherite straitjacket, because they believe their countries will lose their identities or their workers will be too tightly squeezed. Or there is straitjacket politics, which is Labor and Conservatives, Democrats and Republicans: They agree that the straitjacket is the only way to survive economically, and what they fight about is how much, if at all, to adjust the straitjacket to ease the pain on those most pinched by it.
Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party lost this election because while they had the big things right on the economy, they lost sight of the many adjustments that were needed to sustain the political base for their economics. They were unwilling to adapt the straitjacket at all. Mr. Major was quoted in one campaign diary as complaining that he was "bored to death saying his mission was to help the have-nots." It showed.
Exit polls found that a key reason voters switched to Labor was their concern about the widening gap between rich and poor in this country. They know they need Thatcherism to thrive in a global economy, but they want more social checks built into it to reduce the cruelty of markets and to preserve a sense of community. And Mr. Blair played to that by promising to stop Conservative efforts to privatize communal institutions -- from public education to health care to the London subway. Mr. Blair says he will invest more in these institutions, establish a minimum wage and maintain fiscal discipline.
Just as President Clinton has tried to come up with a kinder, gentler Reaganism, Mr. Blair has promised a kinder, gentler Thatcherism -- a straitjacket with elbow room and padded shoulders. Many would argue that President Clinton failed to find that new synthesis -- that market forces were simply too powerful -- so he was reduced to volunteerism summits and balanced budgets. Mr. Blair will now try his hand. This is a big experiment. If he can succeed -- a big if -- he can be as much a model for others as Mrs. Thatcher was in her heyday.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Jacob M. Snyder, 80; Aided Jewish Causes

 BODY:
Jacob M. Snyder, an advocate of Israeli and Jewish causes and a former administrator of the Board of Jewish Education of Greater New York, died on April 22 at New York University Medical Center.
He was 80 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. 
 Mr. Snyder became the board's administrator in 1973. The board serves more than 700 schools, camps and community centers throughout the metropolitan region.
He retired from the board in 1985.
He was a native of Philadelphia and a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, where he received a law degree.
In the 1940's he was director of the Zionist Youth Commission. He interviewed young people wishing to settle in Palestine.
In 1948 he joined the economic department of the Jewish Agency to help plan a pharmaceutical plant in Israel. He then managed the plant for three years.
He returned to the United States, where he headed an office developing real estate in Israel for 10 years and was a principal lecturer and fund-raiser for the Zionist Organization of America.
Mr. Snyder is survived by his wife of 50 years, Faigal Hinitz Snyder; a daughter, Ilana Snyder Dannheiser of London; two sons, Avi, of St. Louis, and Ron, of Westfield, N.J.; a brother, Martin, of Tucson, Ariz., and five grandchildren.
