HEADLINE: Bucharest Journal;
TV Makeover in Romania: It's Not Just Cosmetic

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania

 BODY:
On Anca Toada's first day back at her former television station, she received what in the old days would have been a routine though unwelcome telephone call. The parliamentary protocol officer demanded that the nightly news remind legislators to show up for the next day's session.
Ms. Toada, once a prominent news anchor who, with her crisp look and smart presence, is as familiar to Romanians as Diane Sawyer is to Americans, curtly refused. 
 "I told him television wasn't responsible for keeping the legislature's day book," said Ms. Toada, who quit her job as anchor in disgust three years ago and has returned as the national editor at the station for what she hopes will be a new era in Romanian broadcast journalism.
Several months into remolding the news programs on the Government-financed television station, Ms. Toada, 29, and her boss, Alina Mungiu, 32, are counting the small victories. The big ones are coming hard.
In few other countries in Eastern Europe was television so heavily manipulated by the Government, and so much despised by viewers, as in Romania when it was ruled by the Communist dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu.
Turgid pictures and droning coverage of the dour Mr. Ceausescu and his iron-fisted wife, Elena, provided much of the fare. Pseudo-cheerful folk dances provided ersatz contrast.
For some heady days during Mr. Ceausescu's violent overthrow in December 1989, it seemed that TV Romania, as the station is known, might become a model of freedom of speech. The news studio broadcast the revolution live. But after a street battle that spilled into the lobby of the station, the forces of another Communist, Ion Iliescu, took
over the Government -- and the station.
For seven years, Mr. Iliescu's television was not much different from Mr. Ceausescu's. Perhaps nowhere else in Eastern Europe had Government television changed so little after the fall of Communism.
One of the first pledges of the new President, Emil Constantinescu, a staunch anti-Communist who defeated Mr. Iliescu last November, was to give TV Romania a free hand.
But Ms. Toada and Ms. Mungiu are finding that old habits persist. The parliamentary committee in charge of the communication media demanded that all news conferences of political parties be broadcast, no matter how much propagandizing there is.
When Ms. Mungiu moved into her corner office soon after Mr. Constantinescu's victory, she discovered a telephone, decorated with a decal of the national emblem. A holdover from Communism, it served as a hot line from the presidency and Parliament, an easy way for politicians to badger editors while the news was still on air. In April, in another small victory, the line was finally cut.
Ms. Toada, who started as an idealistic young reporter after Mr. Ceausescu's ouster, rose to be the star news reader on TV Romania. She abruptly quit in 1994 when she became so embarrassed by the propaganda that passed as news that she said she was "ashamed to go out."
"On one occasion I had to read seven pages from the Foreign Ministry on why they were upset with the Hungarians," she said.
Ms. Toada went to France for a while and came back to Romania to work at a small commercial channel. When Ms. Mungiu, a prominent anti-Iliescu journalist who recently completed a year's study at Harvard University's government department, was appointed news chief, Ms. Toada decided to return to TV Romania with expanded editorial responsibilities, although she still sometimes appears as anchor.
"I returned because public television has to regain its credibility and prestige," she said, as she looked over the story list for the next newscast. (It included coverage of King Michael, who had been barred from entering the country by the previous Government.)
For the most part, Ms. Mungiu and Ms. Toada said, many of the reporters and editors at the station were holdovers from the Ceausescu era, trained to be subservient to the Government and, in the cases of some, to report to the domestic intelligence services.
Many viewed their calling in life as keeping Mr. Iliescu in power, or at the very least faithfully reporting his policies, Ms. Mungiu said. The station's correspondent covering the Balkan war, for example, invariably appeared on camera wearing a Serbian military uniform. The Iliescu Government backed the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic.
But, Ms. Mungiu mused, the Communist training also taught people to be "very opportunistic." When she took charge at the station, the anti-Milosevic street demonstrations in Belgrade had been in full swing for a week, but not a word or picture had appeared on the news in Romania. After Ms. Mungiu assigned the reporter to go back to Serbia and cover the protests, he did so, she said, using the same compliant behavior he learned in the past.
Extremely low salaries presented another problem: an ingrained tradition of accepting gifts to supplement poor pay.
"There was a big fuss when we said reporters could not accept presents worth more than 10,000 lei" -- about $1.25, Ms. Toada said. "One reporter got up and said, 'I.B.M. offered me a personal computer and I accepted it because I can't afford it on my salary.' "
For much of what they want to do -- carry live broadcasts, raise salaries -- the two editors are hamstrung by limited financing from the Government, a legacy from the Communist era that is difficult to change as Mr. Constantinescu tries to salvage the Romanian economy, Ms. Toada said.
"A rich television is an independent television," she said. "A poor television station can be exploited."
For TV Romania, 70 percent of the budget comes from the Government and 30 percent comes from viewers' license fees.
Ms. Mungiu was able to attract a new face as anchor for the nightly news, a sprightly, 22-year-old computer programmer, Andreea Gheorghita. But the studio where she delivers the news -- the same place where the December 1989 battle went on -- feels much like a dungeon. The walls are painted black, and the lighting equipment is more than 20 years old. The result does not put Ms. Gheorghita in her best light on camera. Some money was actually found in the budget for new cameras.
"They are the latest, and very fine quality, but they are designed for cold light and good makeup," Ms. Toada said. "We had hot lights and cheap makeup, which when you put it on tends to melt."
Another small victory: the makeup was improved, helping Ms. Gheorghita live up to her potential.

HEADLINE: Worldwide, People Live Longer, Often in Poor Health, U.N. Says

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 4

 BODY:
Medical advances mean more people around the world are living longer lives, but bad habits mean they are not necessarily healthier and happier ones, a new United Nations report said.
The World Health Organization, a United Nations agency, warned that what it calls "diseases of the rich" -- cancers, heart attacks, strokes and other illnesses in which diet and lack of exercise are often believed to play a part -- are on the rise in poorer countries. The increase, it said, could be attributed to longer lives and changing life styles. 
 "Longer life can be a penalty as well as a prize," the group said in its World Health Report 1997. "A large part of the price to be paid is in the currency of chronic disease."
Thanks to medical progress, life expectancy is averaging 64 years in third-world countries and reaching 80 years in some industrialized nations, the report said. But it added that millions of people throw away the chance of a healthy old age because of sedentary life styles, bad diet, smoking and alcohol abuse.
Trying to improve the health of the elderly is of crucial economic importance, it said. In the next 25 years, the population of people older than 65 is likely to grow by 82 percent, compared with 46 percent in the working-age population and only 3 percent in newborns.
Still struggling with ailments linked to poverty, third-world countries are now facing the added burden of increased rates of heart disease and strokes, which killed 15.3 million people last year and are already the leading cause of death in many industrialized nations.
Cancers killed 6.3 million people worldwide in 1996, and there were 10 million new cases reported, not all of them fatal. The number of cases is expected to at least double in most countries in the next 25 years, the report said.
The agency said the increase in cancer was caused in part by the elimination of other fatal diseases, which lengthened lives and increased the odds of getting cancer. But it also said much of the cause was diet and, above all, cigarettes.
Smoking is on the increase throughout the third world and accounts for one in seven cancer cases worldwide, it said.
Long the leading cancer killer among men in industrialized countries, lung cancer is now the top cause of cancer deaths among women in the United States, killing 375,000 of them in 1996. The number of cases among women in the European Union is expected to increase by a third in less than 10 years, it said.
The agency said the risks of getting cancer in third-world countries were smaller but growing. The reasons for the rise are unclear, it said, although the main factor appears to be longer life expectancies.
The report also said that from 1995 to 2025 the number of people with diabetes will grow from 135 million to 300 million, with a resulting increase in kidney failure and blindness, a rise it again attributed to more sedentary life styles.

HEADLINE: Roll Film! Action! Cut! Edit, Edit, Edit.;
Turning Rough Takes Into Summer's Big Hits

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
Jan De Bont, the director of "Speed 2: Cruise Control," a mega-budget action sequel due this summer, was at a film lab in Los Angeles at 7 A.M. last Thursday, to review color corrections.
It was the start of a 15-hour day, about the 60th consecutive workday for Mr. De Bont since filming ended in late February. From the lab, he drove to a Hollywood scoring stage where a 70-piece orchestra was recording music for "Speed 2." 
 The director had a working lunch in an editing suite in Santa Monica, returned across town to the scoring stage, then hurried back to the editing suite. There, he reviewed film of computer-generated effects shots generated by two specialty companies for the film, which stars Sandra Bullock and Jason Patric and is set on a hijacked cruise ship instead of the can't-stop bus of the original 1994 "Speed."
"By that time it was 10 o'clock, you're exhausted and have to go to bed," Mr. De Bont said. "At the end of each day, I have a major headache."
These are Hell Weeks in the movie business, the frenzied period before the release of summer blockbusters, when armies of workers perform the technical tasks that go by the name of post-production: editing, scoring, sound mixing, digital effects.
Little understood outside the industry, post-production is essential if raw footage shot on a set is to be alchemized into a polished movie. The laborious process has traditionally taken longer than the 20 or so weeks of actual filming on a major studio release.
But in recent years, the incentive to crunch post-production schedules has increased as studios, like Oklahoma claim jumpers, advance the release dates of movies to avoid competition from other films, or to earn a quicker return on investments. And digital technology has given some studios the impression -- falsely, according to many involved -- that the pace can easily be quickened.
The panic is greater than ever this year, as the major studios plan to release 15 or more films, many heavy with digital effects, between mid-May and August.
Post-production for "Speed 2" was squeezed to 15 weeks when the release date was advanced from late July to June 13. "It's enormous pressure," Mr. De Bont said. "You have to double the crew size."
The director said 20th Century Fox, the distributor, was worried that movies opening later in the summer would have little chance to find audiences or even theater screens.
Post-production is also causing migraines for the $180 million "Titanic," the most expensive movie ever made. Workers on the film, which is directed by James Cameron, say its July 2 release date cannot help but be pushed back by the demands of editing miles of footage.
"We're going to bring in the tents and the cots," said Gloria Borders, the general manager of George Lucas's Skywalker Sound in northern California, who plans to hire 50 sound editors next month instead of the customary 6 to work on "Titanic." "It'll be like going to work on Desert Storm."
Still, not all summer "event" movies are producing the same kind of stress as "Speed 2" and "Titanic."
"Men in Black," a $90 million science fiction adventure comedy starring Will Smith and Tommy Lee Jones, finished filming last July and has had a comfortable post-production schedule. "You can speed up post-production, hire more guys and stay up 20 hours a day," said Barry Sonnenfeld, the director. "But you won't do as good a job."
But an 11-month post-production such as that for "Men in Black," which will open July 2, is a luxury almost unknown in the summer-movie business today.
Instead, at special-effects shops like Mr. Lucas's Industrial Light and Magic, in editing rooms at Hollywood studios, and at independent "post" houses throughout the Los Angeles area, the same work habits common to Silicon Valley prevail: 80-hour weeks, catnaps on office cots, trips home lasting only long enough to assure spouses that the film worker has not run off.
Although there is a general sequence to post-production, the tasks overlap, particularly on films with shortened schedules.
Ideally, once the director has shouted, "It's a wrap!" an editor reviews the multiple takes of each scene and splices them together. A rough version of the film then goes to a composer, who writes a score; to digital-effects houses, which insert computer-generated aliens or tornadoes into filmed scenes with actors, and to sound editors, who clean up background noises and re-record muddy dialogue with the actors in a studio.
Finally, sound mixers marry the many tracks of dialogue, sound effects and music together.
In these high-speed days, these tasks routinely are shortened by hiring more people and renting more equipment, dividing up the work among teams. The problem then is coordination: with many tasks proceeding at once, changes made by one team must be instantly accommodated by the others.
Like the end man in a game of snap the whip, those at the tail end of the post-production process, like composers and mixers, find it hard to hold on for the ride.
"While we're working, every day they're cutting," said Chris Ward, a music arranger on "Speed 2," who must revise the score to fit each newly edited scene. "It makes the process a little crazy."
"Everybody is frantically trying to get pictures into the marketplace," said Ron Burdett, chairman of the International Teleproduction Society, a trade group of 300 companies in the United States involved in the technical end of film-making.
No statistics on post-production are kept, but the number of workers in both production and post-production in Los Angeles climbed to 30,000 last year from 22,000 in 1993, according to the American Association of Motion Picture and Television Producers.
Not all are pleased with this situation. "People are working more consecutive days and longer days, to the point where it has serious health ramifications as well as serious home-life ramifications," said Ron Kutak, executive director of the Motion Picture Editors Guild.
The risk of long days was dramatized in March by the death of an assistant cameraman, Brent Hershman, who drove into a telephone pole after a 19-hour workday on a set near Los Angeles. Petitions to limit days to 14 hours have been signed by many post-production workers as well as those involved in shooting.
But the campaign for a 14-hour day remains controversial in an industry where most workers are freelancers who welcome the chance to earn overtime. "I think more people are opposed to capping hours at 14 hours a day than in favor of it, even in the wake of this tragic accident," Mr. Kutak said.
Sitting amid the technical clutter of his trade in his temporary "offices" in a post-production house in New York, Mr. Sonnenfeld said recently that the pressure to shorten post-production is driven in part by the studios' need to recoup high costs. "More and more films rely on visual effects, and they cost more money," said Mr. Sonnenfeld, whose films include "Get Shorty." "Because they cost more, they have to be released sooner because of the carrying costs of the money."
Several studio executives disputed this. "We try and make our films as economically as possible, but we don't try and finish a movie quickly in order to recoup our investment," said David McCann, senior vice president of post-production for Walt Disney Motion Pictures and Television. The post-production schedule for Disney films -- 22 weeks for most live-action films, 26 weeks for musicals or films with visual effects -- has not changed in a decade, he said.
Others in Hollywood said the studios that most often squeeze post-production are Warner Brothers, Fox and Paramount, the ones best known for big-budget action movies.
Post-production crews working on "Titanic" are being told to aim for a late-July release, even though the two studios making the movie, Paramount and 20th Century Fox, have not yet announced the expected delay. The July 4 weekend is one of the year's busiest moviegoing periods; when "True Lies," Mr. Cameron's last movie, missed its July 4 opening in 1994 and was delayed until late July, the estimated loss was $30 million, according to Steve Newman, the film's former publicist.
Mr. De Bont said that when he started making "Speed 2" for Fox last year, the studio set an approximate release date of late July. When the studio decided to open in early June, it figured the overtime and other expenses to rush out the movie would be close to $5 million, including $3 million added to the approximately $15 million budget for computer-generated effects. Other costs included renting three sound-editing stages instead of one, additional computer work stations, and overtime for almost all involved.
But the expense is justified in the studio's eyes, the director said, because of the potential gain in ticket sales if the movie can be established as an early hit, setting up a long summer run.
To make the earlier opening, Mr. De Bont had to give up a 10-week grace period that is granted directors as basic editing time, under rules laid down by the Directors Guild. "I had to basically make a cut in 4 weeks, otherwise nobody else could start anything," he said.
And the omnipresence of computers, once billed as a time-saving boon, has not helped much.
In the old days -- three or four years ago -- editors cut and spliced strips of celluloid on motorized machines like the Moviola. Now, at Sound One, the largest post-production house in Manhattan, which fills six floors in the Brill Building, several Moviolas gather dust in a corridor, as quaint-looking as foot-treadle sewing machines. Today the process is almost all digital.
Once film is shot and processed by a lab, it is scanned by a computer and converted to digital files. Almost all picture editing now is done at computer work stations made by one of two companies, Avid Technology and Lightworks.
"Directors are given the Avid and told, 'Because of release schedules we want you to deliver your cut in four weeks,' " he said. "Studios made large investments in electronic editing systems and they were sold a bill of goods because they were told films could be cut faster. Films cannot be cut faster because human beings don't think any faster."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barry Sonnenfeld, the director of "Men in Black," a $90 million science fiction adventure comedy starring Will Smith and Tommy Lee Jones, doing post-production work at an editing studio in New York. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)(pg. D13)
 
Chart: "It's Crunch Time for Movies"
When the cameras stop rolling, post-production work begins. In "Speed 2: Cruise Control," this polishing time was cut by about three weeks. Here are the steps that must be completed before its June 13 release.
 
Editing
Film editors make a "rough cut" for the sound and visual effects specialists while editors continue to work on the final cut.
 
Visual Effects
While filming is going on, artists build computer models of elements, such as the ship. These visual effects must later be integrated into the film.
 
Sound
New sound effects, dialogue and music enhance or replace the sound recorded during filming. These sounds are blended to fit the action.
 
Processing
The original negative is spliced. Dust and scratches are removed, color is corrected and the sound track is attached to the film before thousands of prints are made to be rushed to theaters. (Sources: Glenn Salloum, associate producer of "Speed 2"; 20th Century Fox [movie stills])

HEADLINE: Lobstermen See Threat in Whale Protection Plan

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

 BODY:
Federal fishing authorities have thrown Maine's lobster industry into an uproar by proposing costly changes in lobster traps to insure that whales can easily escape if they become entangled in the ropes.
During a week of hearings in Maine ending on Friday, indignant lobstermen packed the halls to protest the proposed rules, which are intended especially to protect right whales, the most endangered of all the world's large whales. 
 The angry fishermen in one Portland high school auditorium alone easily outnumbered all the right whales found in the North Atlantic, where fewer than 300 of the great mammals survive.
Most of those right whales bear rope scars telling of narrow escapes from fishing gear, scientists at the National Marine Fisheries Service say, and every few years a right whale dies in the Atlantic Ocean after becoming entangled with lobster pots or gillnets.
As rare as these accidents are -- and they are almost unheard of along the coast of Maine -- when combined with the number of whales injured by ship propellers or by other causes, they are enough to threaten the species' survival. So last month, the agency said the Federal law protecting marine mammals gave it no option but to change the way the lobster industry operated.
But the industry, supported by many scientists and by state officials, argues that the proposal, which calls for the fishermen to use breakaway lines that would come undone when an entangled whale tugged forcefully on the ropes, is unworkable and too expensive. Lobster traps would have to be attached to buoys with sinking lines that would break under 150 pounds of pressure.
"Basically, it is overkill," said Dan Fernald, a seventh-generation islander from Somesville who runs about 400 lobster traps.
"When I vote, I usually vote Green Party," he said. "I am very environmentally conscious, as a lot of fishermen are. But it is not the fishermen who are hurting the right whale."
Like other lobstermen, Mr. Fernald, who said he had never seen a right whale, said that the sinking lines would chafe and snag on underwater rocks and break under the ordinary stresses of waves and wind in the violent waters off Maine. The modifications and the loss of gear would cost thousands of dollars and would put many independent fishermen out of business, they say.
And they seethe at the agency's own admission that it is "difficult or impossible to demonstrate conclusively" that the modifications would solve the whales' problem.
"In most parts of Maine," said Robin Alden, Maine's commissioner of marine resources, "it simply would not be possible to go lobster fishing using the gear required by the rule."
The fishery agency estimated the cost of the changes at $12,000 a boat. The state estimated that the whole industry would end up spending $40 million to $70 million.
Maine's two Senators are demanding that the agency overturn the rules and are threatening to rewrite the Marine Mammal Protection Act if that is what is needed.
"I am completely astounded by and extremely disappointed in the agency's efforts to date," said Senator Olympia J. Snowe, chairwoman of the Senate subcommittee that supervises fisheries. "This rule fails on nearly every major count by which a reasonable person would measure the actions of a Federal regulatory agency."
The widely held view in Maine is that few right whales are ever at risk in waters near the state's rocky shoreline, where its lobster boats work. None of the areas designated by the Federal fisheries agency as critical habitat for the species is in Maine's waters. Although large whales pass through the Gulf of Maine and, at times, through the state's waters, only about 30 of the 10,000 sightings of the whale were in waters within three miles of Maine's shoreline, plus 60 more seen 3 to 12 miles from shore.
Restrictions have also been imposed on lobstering off Massachusetts, but the debate over them has been much more intense in Maine, where the lobster is far more important to the state's economy. Maine's lobstermen argue that it is one thing to restrict operations in the whale's critical habitat areas off Massachusetts, but quite another to impose changes in Maine's waters, where the whales transit more briefly.
"Relatively speaking, the incidence of right whales is low in Maine state waters and the near-shore Gulf of Maine, where more than 90 percent of the lobster gear is fished," Ms. Alden said.
But Nancy Foster, deputy assistant administrator of the fisheries service, said that the agency had no choice under the law but to take action that would cut injuries and deaths among right whales to a third of current levels within six months.
That meant one of two things, she said: modifying the gear or prohibiting it from certain waters.
"Inaction is not an option, nor can we take action in some places where these whales occur but not in others," she said. Her testimony drew jeers from the crowd in Portland.
Jennifer Atkinson, a staff lawyer for the Conservation Law Foundation, a New England environmental advocacy group, said it was important to bring the lobstermen into the effort to conserve right whales.
"They can act as the 'eyes and ears' for the whales at sea," she said, and they must be kept at the bargaining table as an effective conservation plan for the whales is devised.
But the opportunity for reasoned discussion, she warned, "has been all but lost in the scramble to create a solid wall of state opposition to this proposed Federal action."
Bob Bowman, a whale expert who is a research associate at the College of the Atlantic in Bar Harbor, agreed with the agency that modifying fishing gear and methods was the best solution in the long run. But he agreed with the lobstermen that it made little sense to rush changes into effect without tests proving that they were effective and practical.
Mr. Bowman is the only person in Maine with the necessary Federal authorization to disentangle a whale in distress. It is a tricky process, dangerous for man and whale alike, but he said that if it was done correctly, the animal usually survived and the gear was recovered.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Mexico Wrangle: Closeness Breeds Friction

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 4

 BODY:
A labor leader unintentionally insulted President Ernesto Zedillo during May Day ceremonies here, showing something about how rocky relations are between the United States and its southern neighbor.
Whistles and catcalls forced Victor Flores, the head of Mexico's main labor congress, to cut short his speech to an auditorium filled with workers after he accidentally addressed Mr. Zedillo as "the President of the United States." 
 Even though it was an obvious slip, Mr. Flores's remark rankled the workers because to them it suggested some American encroachment on Mexico's sovereignty and identity. His gaffe was especially conspicuous because President Clinton is to arrive here on Monday for his first visit to Latin America since he took office, a visit regarded by Mexicans as long overdue.
The episode reflected how vulnerable Mexicans continue to feel to United States power and how deeply they distrust Washington's intentions.
Recent events have shown that even when the two Governments want to get along, turbulence is the normal state of relations. The peculiar logic of the marriage of geography and convenience between the United States and Mexico seems to be that the closer the relationship gets, the more tensions arise.
In many ways, ties across the 2,000-mile border have never been stronger. Presidents Clinton and Zedillo like each other. They are both relatively young leaders who studied at Yale University, both aspiring reformers whose ideas have been sharply tempered by political realities at home.
Through sessions of a commission set up in 1981, Cabinet members from the two countries meet regularly to jaw over disputes. For a commission meeting on Monday, eight Cabinet secretaries from Washington will come to Mexico along with President Clinton.
In addition, the Clinton Administration has gone much further than recent American Governments in heaping praise on Mexico's President and his Government.
In comments last week, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin pointed to "the quite remarkable political courage and resolve of the Mexican leadership." Barry McCaffrey, the retired general who heads the Administration's anti-drug efforts, spoke of "unprecedented cooperation" on narcotics issues.
Mr. Zedillo has responded in kind, recently calling Mr. Clinton "the American President who has shown the most respect for Mexico."
Despite the friendliness, relations between the countries are more tense and abrasive than they have been in at least a decade.
There are sharp divisions over the war against increasingly powerful Mexican drug cartels and the presence of an estimated two million illegal immigrants from Mexico in the United States.
Although the North American Free Trade Agreement has increased cross-border trade to record levels, sticky disputes have arisen about trucking, several agricultural products and the move by the United States to punish some Mexican companies doing business in Cuba.
Anti-Washington feeling surged here after the bitter debate in the United States Congress this spring over whether to recertify Mexico as an ally in the drug war, and because of a new American law to curb illegal immigration. Anti-Mexican feeling in the United States is growing in parts of the Southwest and California.
The inequality between the world's most powerful nation and Mexico, which is struggling out of an economic depression in the midst of a disorderly transition to democracy, makes for chronic differences of view.
"The tighter the connection between the two societies, the greater the friction," said Peter H. Smith, director of Latin American studies at the University of California at San Diego.
Part of the problem, Mr. Smith said, is that "the issues that continue to bedevil the relationship, like drugs and immigration, are not ones that can be resolved easily by cooperation between the two Governments."
"They respond to the classic incentives of supply and demand and resist Government action," he said.
Mexicans complain that despite their country's strategic importance for the United States, Washington's policies are increasingly determined by the vagaries of domestic politics on drugs, immigration and trade.
"America's ignorance and disdain for learning the ways and customs of its neighbor seems to be endless," said Jorge Montano, who served for two and a half years as Mexico's Ambassador in Washington. "The way they deal with us is by turning us into one more item on the domestic agenda."
At the same time, many Mexicans are intensely ambivalent about the United States. The mixed feelings were abundant one holiday afternoon last week at a bustling McDonald's restaurant in a middle-class neighborhood where scores of families took their children for a distinctly American-style lunch.
"It is not easy for us to be the weak ones," said Maria Guadalupe Ramirez Ornelas, a high school teacher. "We become Americanized. We bring our children to eat American fast food. But underneath, there is a lot of rancor."
Francisco Olivares, 23, an accountant, said: "Mexicans in general are always going to have doubts about the United States. We don't know whether the Americans' intentions toward us are really healthy."
Opinion surveys conducted from June 1996 to May 1 of this year among city-dwelling Mexicans by the United States Information Agency reflect the conflicted views. About half those polled have a high opinion of the United States and about half have a poor one.
According to the polls, about two-thirds of Mexicans think relations are good. But only 38 percent think the United States treats Mexico more fairly than it did five years ago. Seven in 10 Mexicans approved of United States efforts to help Mexico fight drug trafficking and solve economic problems. But 6 in 10 said the United States wielded too much influence in Mexican affairs and expected Mexico to bow to United States wishes.
Mexicans are largely enthusiastic about President Clinton, giving him a 69 percent favorable rating in a May 1 poll.
However, the customers at McDonald's were concerned that President Zedillo had not been an especially forceful President, and they worried that he might yield to pressures from Mr. Clinton.
For Mexicans, one of Mr. Clinton's most signficant meetings will be the 15-minute sessions scheduled for Tuesday with leaders of the two major opposition parties. It will be first such meetings for an American President.
But Foreign Minister Angel Gurria said the major impact of the visit would come from the mood and body language, "the image and feeling President Clinton will take away about what Mexico can represent for the United States and vice versa."
"Just the fact that the President of the United States is visiting Mexico already makes the visit a success," Mr. Gurria said.

HEADLINE: Glick Joins Borough Race In Manhattan As 5th Entry

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
In an atmosphere similar to an old-fashioned political rally, Deborah J. Glick, an Assemblywoman from Greenwich Village, yesterday became the fifth candidate to officially enter the Democratic primary for Manhattan borough president.
Ms. Glick is widely considered to be one of two leading contenders in the Democratic primary, along with City Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields, of central Harlem and the Upper West Side. The incumbent Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, is running for mayor. 
 The others seeking to succeed Ms. Messinger include two members of the City Council -- Adam Clayton Powell 4th of East Harlem and Antonio Pagan of the Lower East Side -- and George N. Spitz, a retired state auditor with a reputation as a political gadfly.
While her rivals announced their candidacies on the steps of City Hall, Ms. Glick stood on a stage in the ballroom of the Sheraton New York Hotel, surrounded by a dozen politicians and facing more than 150 cheering supporters holding placards with the Assemblywoman's name emblazoned in aqua letters.
"As borough president, I will lead and advocate for the diverse interests of Manhattan communities," said Ms. Glick, 46, the first open lesbian to win election to the Assembly. She said that she would "work to unite people and neighborhoods behind a common agenda: making Manhattan a better place to live and making city government more responsive to our needs."
The Democratic primary, which is tantamount to election in Manhattan, has already become a crowded, contentious affair with the candidates seeking to portray themselves as capable of winning broad-based support.
Ms. Glick's opponents have taken pains to cast her as a one-issue candidate, suggesting that she is most responsive to issues concerning gay New Yorkers.
At yesterday's announcement, Ms. Glick was clearly attempting to distance herself from that image, with speaker after speaker on the platform praising her record on economic development, mass transit and environmental protection issues.
In her remarks, she cast herself as a champion of Manhattan neighborhoods and residents, rather than developers.
"The people of this borough deserve someone in public office who is on their side," she said. "Someone who has stood up to developers who've gone too far by trying to take another piece of our sky and another stretch of our riverfront."
Ms. Glick, having amassed nearly $500,000 in contributions so far, has raised more money than any of her opponents, and her political consultant, Hank Morris, said her campaign would likely raise the $1 million limit under the campaign-finance laws.
How Ms. Glick will do in Manhattan's racial and ethnic political calculus remains to be seen. Ms. Glick, who is white, is expected to do well among liberal white voters as well as gay Manhattanites. Ms. Fields, who is black, is expected to do well among black voters and is campaigning heavily for liberal white votes.
Mr. Powell, whose mother is Puerto Rican and whose father was a black political icon, is expected to draw some support from black voters but more heavily from Hispanics. But he is generally expected to share that Hispanic support with Mr. Pagan, who is Puerto Rican and gay.
Last week, Ms. Fields's campaign received two high-profile endorsements, from former Mayors Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins. Yesterday, Ms. Glick brought out her own political guns with speeches by Representative Nydia M. Velazquez, the first Puerto Rican woman elected to Congress, and Representative Jerrold L. Nadler.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Deborah J. Glick entered the Democratic primary yesterday for borough president of Manhattan. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
To Win Half the Time Has Become a Noble Goal

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

 BODY:
Major League Baseball, making a parody of parity, saw 11 of its 28 teams, including the Mets and the Yankees, enter play yesterday residing in the vicinity of .500.
In baseball, .500 for a team is roughly the equivalent of a batter hitting .250, and in either instance it's certainly nothing to get excited about. Yet for too many teams, it's really all that is left. And because inflation is what it is, and because the expanded playoffs are what they are, .500 is now viewed by far too many clubs as the doorway not only to respectability, but also to contention, as something to shout about and applaud. 
 The heretofore anonymous Pittsburgh Pirates are being praised these days because of their 15-14 record. A pulse was detected in Flushing on Saturday night when the Mets climbed to 14-15 and stirred the slumbering interest of the die-hard fans still left to them.
The Yankees? They could only hope their perch at 16-14 after yesterday's victory will keep George Steinbrenner's harsh glare off them and on poor Concerto, his Kentucky Derby loser, for just a little longer.
Sadly, for baseball purists, low rungs in the standings don't necessarily bury teams anymore. Just ask the Chicago White Sox. Losers of 18 of their first 27, the Sox were just five games out of first place when they awoke yesterday morning. The Chicago Cubs, losers of 21 of 28, were within eight and a half games of first place.
If the Pirates keep it up, they can end up leading the National League Central. As it is, the Central divisions in both leagues combined had just 2 teams out of 10 above .500 at the conclusion of play yesterday. Alas, this is not 1973, when having teams make the post-season while barely clinging to a winning record -- as the 82-79 Mets did -- raised eyebrows. These days, all .500 does is raise hopes. Mainly false hopes.
Such is the plight of the Mets, a team trying not to founder in the wake of the Atlanta Braves, the one franchise above all others that will simply not allow room for mediocrity in its division.
The Mets, no fools, don't talk in terms of catching the Braves. Nor do they walk any longer with the kind of wild-card swagger that embarrassed them two years ago. Rather, the Mets talk of taking baby steps, of reaching .500 because, outfielder Carl Everett said: "From where we've been, that's a start. You can't go farther if you haven't been there yet."
The Mets haven't been there at this late date in a season since 1994. Yesterday, they tried to write history, having climbed within a game of .500 thanks to 8 victories in their previous 11 games. But, alas, the club that has gallantly, and rather surprisingly, come back from a 3-9 start to the season despite all sorts of medical calamities, could not reach that level.
Instead, the Mets lost, returning to early season form in an 8-2 defeat at the hands of Todd Stottlemyre and the St. Louis Cardinals at Shea Stadium. And with one loss, one could almost feel the weight falling back onto the Mets' shoulders.
"Being one game under, I wanted to throw six or seven good innings, but unfortunately that didn't happen," said Mark Clark, the Mets' starter, who ultimately pitched four poor ones (eight hits, six runs) before a line drive off his pitching hand forced him from the game.
Manager Bobby Valentine didn't fret over missing the brass ring. "Five hundred is not a goal right now," he said. "We're just trying to play good baseball. I like what we've been doing. I hope we can keep on doing it."
The Mets had just won two from the Cardinals, snapping St. Louis's five-game winning streak. They have pulled together a respectable starting staff despite the continued loss of Pete Harnisch, Jason Isringhausen, Bill Pulsipher and Paul Wilson. They have managed to resuscitate Carlos Baerga's bat and, thus far, have survived the first disabling injury of Lance Johnson's career.
Yet the victory the Mets needed to prove something to someone, anyone, proved elusive. And the kind of Bronx cheers that have relocated to Flushing remain close to the surface, as a reminder that there are still questions for this team. Indeed, "Ordonez, you stink!" and "Everett, you bum!" could be heard yesterday as the leather lungs among the crowd of 17,652 got louder as a bad day got worse and worse.
Because yesterday deteriorated so completely, the Mets woke to a harsher reality today, knowing that their pursuit of respectability must now hit the road, where they play 16 of their next 22 games. That hunt begins tonight in Colorado, where the Rockies -- one of the elites -- wait.
"We want to get to .500, but it's not a .500 thing -- we know we're better than .500," said Todd Hundley, reflecting the confounded nature of such a chase.
"We're going to get there," said Butch Huskey, trying to make a wistful statement sound like a promise. "We really needed the win. It would have been big. But it's not the end of the world."
Just the end of the dream, for now. The only dream teams like the Mets get to entertain these days.

HEADLINE: Beckoned by Promise, Felled by a Short Cut;
Plight of Four Polish Immigrants Comes to Light After a Fatal Fire

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
Jan Kamieniec moved into the house in Maspeth, Queens, because the price was right: $250 a month for a room and kitchen privileges in someone else's third-floor apartment.
He could have afforded something better and safer, his friends and sister said. His hourly wage making stone counter tops had risen in recent years to more than $10 from $6.50. 
 But Mr. Kamieniec, 43, was supporting an 80-year-old mother he had left behind in Poland in 1991 and was trying to save for the future. The bargain rent helped.
Janusz Kosmowski, 39, paid even less, but all he got was a space in the cellar.
Neighbors disagreed about whether he stayed there occasionally or regularly, for nothing or for a token pittance. But they concurred that he had hit tough times, and that the balm of alcohol was making them tougher still.
"I can't figure out how it happened," his wife, Jadwiga, said after the fire, in an interview in her apartment in Pisz, Poland, where a faux Persian carpet on the living room floor and terra cotta tiles in the bathroom were measures of how much money Mr. Kosmowski had sent home during a decade in America. "I thought everything was all right."
Mr. Kamieniec, whose fortunes seemed to be rising, and Mr. Kosmowski, whose luck was ebbing, were among four Polish immigrants killed two weeks ago when flames engulfed 60-01 56th Road in Maspeth.
Both were living on the cheap in a house that had been sliced and diced to accommodate more tenants. The fire drew attention not only to such illegal conversions throughout Queens, but also to the immigrants who rely on these makeshift, dangerous accommodations.
The stories of the dead men, and of scores of Polish immigrants like them in Maspeth, are varied. They are dreamers tripping on obstacles they cannot control and drifters hitting snags of their own making. They are ascetics essentially volunteering for deprivation so that far-away relatives can know glimmers of luxury, and they are vagrants with no other choice.
They are, in other words, like millions of immigrants before them and millions since, beckoned by a promise that turned out to be more complicated than they had imagined.
A problem almost all of them face is finding inexpensive shelter. Basic one-bedroom apartments cost $700 to $800 a month, and the landlords of those legal units do not want to rent to groups of single men who plan to share the space. So the men burrow into illicit corners and cubicles.
"It's either that or living in the park," Teresa Vavak Sanchez, a Polish-American social worker in Maspeth, said. "A lot of the guys, what happens to them is they break down emotionally and start drinking. Then their lives really go to ruins."
Mr. Kamieniec, Mr. Kosmowski and Frank Glowacki -- who owned the house and was socializing with Mr. Kosmowski in the cellar when the fire started around 9:20 P.M. on April 20th -- were all drunk when they died, according to autopsy results.
Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, the New York City Medical Examiner, said he could not release specific blood alcohol levels, but described the three men as "far beyond what would be considered impaired for the purposes of driving a car."
The fourth victim, Kazimierz Cielas, 41, who shared the cellar with Mr. Kosmowski and also died there, was sober, his autopsy showed.
But Mr. Cielas's acquaintances said that he, along with Mr. Kosmowski, drank frequently, a fact these acquaintances characterized as a cause, or perhaps consequence, of the men's diminished fortunes in recent years.
Like Mr. Kosmowski, Mr. Cielas had come from Pisz, also in 1986, and he, too, had left behind a wife. He told her he would be back as soon as he had earned enough for a car, according to his mother, Anna.
But months turned to years and years to a decade, and her son did not return, Mrs. Cielas said. She, like Mrs. Kosmowski, expressed ignorance of just how badly he was living in Maspeth.
"Oh, God, how could I imagine it: all those people living in a black hole in the basement?" Mrs. Cielas said in her apartment in Pisz.
Mr. Glowacki, 44, was an immigrant of much longer standing. He lived with his wife, Barbara, and two children, ages 13 and 9, in Port Chester, a suburb in Westchester County.
Barbara Glowacki said that he had come to America in 1971 and, over the years, had owned and operated Polish delicatessens in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens. When he bought one at 60-01 56th Road in Maspeth in 1984, Mrs. Glowacki said, it came with two stories of housing above it. She said she knew little about her husband's dealings as a landlord.
According to city records, there should have been only two apartments, one on each of the upper floors. But former residents of the building, which was demolished after the fire, said that the third floor had been illegally split into a two-bedroom apartment with a rent of $650 a month and a one-bedroom apartment with a rent of $550. Mr. Kamieniec subleased a room from a Polish couple in the larger apartment.
Mr. Glowacki never registered the building as the de facto multiple dwelling it had become, which would have required him to install a fire escape. When flames swept up the staircase, tenants had to fling themselves and their children out of windows. Mr. Kamieniec, who was on the third floor, did not escape.
In the cellar, where the other men died, partitions had been illegally erected and a common kitchen and bathroom had been illegally installed, city officials said. Here, too, there was only one way out, and it, too, was blocked by fire.
But if the men who perished in Mr. Glowacki's house were not, as a group, completely unwitting victims, Mr. Glowacki was not a simply portrayed villain. Neighbors said that he provided cheap -- and sometimes free -- housing to people with no other options.
"None of us are perfect," Mrs. Glowacki said in her Port Chester home last week. "We all have good and bad sides of us. We all have faults. But Frank was a good person. He was a gentleman."
He was also not the only landlord in Maspeth whose property had been illegally converted. Across the street and less than 100 yards from his house stands a three-story brick building, at No. 60-30, that is infamous in the neighborhood because of the combination garage and pigeon coop behind it. This two-story shanty has been carved into a dreary warren of five rooms, many without windows, with a squalid common kitchen.
Neighborhood residents said that men pay between $100 and $250 a month to stay there, although its owner, a Polish immigrant named Charles Mardula, said through a translator last week that the men lived there free and were all his cousins.
A visit to the structure last week found just one man, Jan Karpinski, 60, who said that three others had scattered when city inspectors descended on the neighborhood after the fatal fire. Mr. Karpinski was packing his belongings.
Speaking through a translator, he said that while the other men paid rent to Mr. Mardula, he did not, because he was helping Mr. Mardula renovate another building two blocks away. He said he knew Mr. Mardula from Mt. Zion Cemetery, where they both made headstones and dug graves.
"He's a hero," Mr. Karpinski said of Mr. Mardula. "He's helping us."
Although Mr. Karpinski's job at the cemetery pays $500 a week, he said it was important for him to spend as little of that as possible on rent and to send as much as $12,000 a year to his wife and 18-year-old daughter in Poland.
"I have no choice but to live like this," Mr. Karpinski said, without a trace of self-pity. "My daughter is in school. There is not much money in Poland and it's spent very, very quickly."
Mr. Karpinski left Grajewo, Poland, in 1990, as the mass migration of the 1980's petered out. Mr. Kosmowski and Mr. Cielas, by contrast, came from Pisz during the height of that emigration, when the economy in Poland was particularly bleak.
For many families, the solution to staggeringly high unemployment and abysmal wages was to send one breadwinner abroad, especially to America, where a meager salary in dollars could translate into significant buying power in Polish zloties.
In fact, one of Pisz's wealthiest neighborhoods is nicknamed "Reagan Land" because its houses were said to be built with money that Polish emigres made in America during Ronald Reagan's Presidency in the 1980's.
Mr. Kosmowski, who was 27 when he departed Pisz in 1986, had been a manager at a lumber mill and was leaving behind a wife and infant daughter. Mr. Cielas, then 30, had done odd jobs in construction. He was leaving his second wife and a 13-year-old son who lived with his first wife.
The men planned their trips separately, arriving in New York City three months apart. They found construction, carpentry and woodworking jobs, and apparently did well enough at first. Mr. Cielas sent back about $100 a month for child support. Mr. Kosmowski sent back much more -- apparently, thousands of dollars over the years.
That money helped purchase a new car for his wife and an 18-gear mountain bike for his 11-year-old daughter, Malgosia. In addition, Mrs. Kosmowski said: "I could afford to buy nicer clothes. We took vacations by the sea."
But at some point, both men's lives took a downturn. Their only recent employment, some neighbors said, was helping Mr. Glowacki smoke sausages in a shed behind the house.
Their lives here were making less sense than in the old days. Poland's economy had improved dramatically in the 1990's, and the dollar-zloty ratio was not nearly as favorable as it had been. Mrs. Kosmowski had employment of her own in Pisz as a town clerk.
But Mr. Kosmowski and Mr. Cielas stayed in Maspeth. Neighbors said it may have been a matter of stubborn pride; ironically, the less money Polish immigrants had, the less likely they were to abandon their dream.
"You don't go back empty-handed," explained a friend who declined to give his name.
Mr. Kamieniec, however, was doing better than ever.
In the rural town of Cewkowo, Poland, he had eked out an existence on a family farm. In America, his income grew steadily.
He had become so expert at polishing and carving granite and marble surfaces that on April 1, his boss at Granite Tops, a Mount Vernon, N.Y., company, had given Mr Kamieniec a big raise.
"You could tell he was really happy," Chris Sanzaro, the company's owner, said. "He was almost in tears."
Mr. Kamieniec, Mr. Cielas, Mr. Kosmowski and Mr. Glowacki were mourned in a special memorial service one week ago at Holy Cross Church on 56th Road in Maspeth. About 150 people attended, offering tearful prayers not only for the dead, but also for the living.
One beseeched Mother Mary in a Polish hymn.
"Oh Maria," he sang, "beg the Lord for plenty of mercy for your children, so the world will be better."

HEADLINE: Nothing Worth Mining Found on Bre-X Site

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: OTTAWA, May 4

 BODY:
An independent consulting company has found no sign that there is gold worth mining at the Indonesian site discovered by Bre-X Minerals Ltd. of Canada, which had contended that it had found the gold strike of the century.
Moreover, the independent audit concluded that initial drilling results had been deliberately doctored in an elaborate scheme to make the finds appear far richer than they actually were. 
 The audit showed "trace amounts of gold," according to the report, released today in Indonesia. But there is "virtually no possibility of an economic gold deposit" at the Busang jungle site, on the island of Borneo, which a bit more than a month ago had been widely thought to contain from 70 million to 200 million ounces of gold, worth billions of dollars.
The consulting company, Strathcona Mineral Services of Toronto, had been hired by Bre-X to clear up confusion about the drilling results, after a prospective American partner for Bre-X, Freeport-McMoran Copper and Gold of New Orleans, said that its preliminary tests indicated the claims of a vast gold deposit at Busang seemed false.
Strathcona concluded that the inaccurate estimates of the gold deposits had been based on "falsified data," and said that there had been "tampering with samples delivered to the labs."
"The magnitude of the tampering with core samples that we believe has occurred and resulting falsification of assay values at Busang is of a scale and over a period of time and with a precision that, to our knowledge, is without precedent in the history of mining anywhere in the world," Strathcona concluded.
The damaging report is likely to doom any chance Bre-X might have had to go forward with the project, which had made company officials millionaires without producing a single commercial ounce of gold.
Instead, the small company, based in Calgary, Alberta, is likely to be hounded by infuriated stockholders, both large and small, who have seen the value of their shares plummet since the first doubts were raised in late March about the validity of Bre-X's initial findings.
Several shareholder groups have already filed lawsuits in the United States and Canada against Bre-X. The Toronto Stock Exchange said it would halt trading in Bre-X stock when the session opens on Monday.
The chairman of Bre-X, David G. Walsh, said he was devastated by the consultant's report. "We share the shock and dismay of our shareholders and others that the gold we thought we had at Busang now appears not to be there," Mr. Walsh said tonight.
"We are determined to gain a full understanding for the shareholders, for Bre-X's business partners and for others, of how the earlier data came to exist," he said.
Late last week, in apparent anticipation of a negative report by the consultant, Bre-X officials were talking freely about the need for large-scale bulk samples to accurately determine how much gold lies under the jungle floor at a difficult site like Busang. Bre-X had drilled 300 test holes over the course of more than two years in coming up with its initial results. Both Freeport's and Strathcona's testings were limited to a handful of holes. Bre-X is likely to try to defend itself by insisting that more thorough testing needs to be done.
Mr. Walsh had planned to release the results of the Strathcona audit before the opening of trading on Monday morning. The results were first disclosed in Indonesia today.
The scene at the Toronto Stock Exchange when Bre-X trading resumes could not be as frantic as it was a month ago when the doubts first arose about the deposit, if only because the stock has already lost more than 80 percent of its value.
On March 26, Freeport McMoran said that the seven test holes drilled near supposedly rich holes made by Bre-X had found only "insignificant amounts of gold." Within minutes after trading resumed the following day, the stock had dived to $2.50 (Canadian) a share from $15.50, with a volume of trading so great that it repeatedly knocked out the main computer at the exchange.
Freeport McMoran has repeatedly said that it would pull out of the project if it was not economically feasible to drill for the gold. Company officials reiterated that threat as recently as last Tuesday, when they held their annual meeting in New Orleans.
There was heavy trading in Bre-X on Friday as investors placed their last bets on whether there really was gold at Busang, believers buying up cheap shares and disbelievers dumping whatever they could while the stock still had some value.
The mystery surrounding Bre-X and its tenuous grip on the Busang site has puzzled even the most experienced investors, including large mutual funds and pension managers who all seemed to have bought into Mr. Walsh's dream about Busang being El Dorado.
In March, one of Bre-X's chief geologists, Michael de Guzman, plunged to his death from a helicopter en route to a meeting with Freeport-McMoran officials who were reportedly seeking answers about the discrepancies in results between their drillings and those of Bre-X.
In February, Freeport, which has had a 30-year history of mining in Indonesia, beat out competing companies to win a 15 percent share of the Busang mine.
The company agreed to spend as much as $400 million building the mining site, but conditioned its participation on satisfactory results from its own testing.

HEADLINE: Culture's 2 Personas Face Off In a Shop

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER

 BODY:
A small bookstore fights with its landlord, which wants to maximize its profits from a valuable storefront. The bookstore says it cannot pay such high rents and will close. The landlord says sorry, we're not in the business of subsidizing poor booksellers and prepares to rent the bookstore's space to a fancy boutique instead.
It's a familiar story, although this time the property owner is not some greedy slumlord but the Whitney Museum of American Art, which owns the building that for the last 20 years has housed Books & Company, the well-stocked, immensely comfortable bookstore that has long been on Madison Avenue but has never quite been of it. 
 The two institutions have had an unusually contentious relationship for the past few years, culminating in the Whitney's decision last week not to offer a lease at a below-market rent to a group of investors who were prepared to take over the store from its founder, Jeannette Watson. As a consequence, the store has announced its intention to close on May 31.
The Whitney has been widely portrayed as a villain, squeezing out one of New York's most respected and beloved bookstores to further its own economic ambitions. That's not entirely wrong, but what is it about this moment in history that gives museums such ambitions and creates a David and Goliath story in which a cultural institution is the Goliath? The struggle between the Whitney and Books & Company is very much a tale of a cultural institution behaving like a business, and of a business behaving like a cultural institution.
The Whitney, like most museums today desperate to maintain a steady stream of income in the face of declining government and corporate support, argues that if it is to fulfill its mission of mounting exhibitions and acquiring art it needs to gain as much money as it can from the property it owns. And Books & Company, which like most independent bookstores has been reeling from the impact of large bookselling chains, says it needs the subsidy of low rent to survive.
The institutions have traded charges and countercharges. The Whitney claims that Ms. Watson, who says she has been subsidizing Books & Company with cash infusions of as much as $100,000 annually in recent years and cannot continue, does not run the store in a sufficiently businesslike fashion. (There are no computerized inventory lists at Books & Company, and since its founding the store has sold books to established writers at deep discount, bringing their loyalty but cutting sharply into the bottom line.)
Ms. Watson and her manager, Steven Varni, claim that the Whitney misled them with promises that it would join with them in partnership to keep the store open, and that the museum fails to understand the value of having one of the city's most respected bookstores right down the block.
Ms. Watson, who plans to concentrate on a publishing venture once the store is closed, says she would cooperate with any viable plan to recreate the store in a new location with the support of other investors, or even to reconstitute it as a nonprofit foundation.
Whatever happens, alas, Books & Company is surely finished in its present location, two floors in an old brownstone whose creaky floors, exposed brick walls and simple, dark-stained bookcases bespeak an unself-consciousness that is entirely at odds with almost everything else on Madison Avenue today. Books & Company's strength may have been in the intellectual depth of its stock, but its greatest appeal was always the way the place felt: It is a store designed to wallow in, not to gawk at. From Books & Company to Prada may be only five blocks, but so far as sensibility goes, it is a million miles.
And from Books & Company to the Whitney is only about 50 feet, but it feels like two million miles. It is difficult to imagine two organizations with more different world views than this bookstore and its landlord: the laid-back bookstore that was created to replicate the casual, earnest ambiance of the idyllic bookstores of old, serving bibliophiles and caring little about how many people pass through its door, and the aggressive museum that has made audience-building, fund-raising and high-fashion parties its stock in trade.
If Books & Company were a museum, it would be the Frick Collection, not the Whitney. And if the Whitney were a bookstore, it would be Barnes & Noble, not Books & Company.
Books & Company has no computers; the Whitney was one of the first museums to establish a Web page. The staff at Books & Company ordered books on the basis of intellectual appeal; the Whitney plans its exhibitions with an eye to how much attendance they will bring. While Books & Company is technically a business, it is, of course, woefully unbusinesslike, while the Whitney, nonprofit institution though it is, could not be more corporate.
Books & Company could never have survived as a conventional business. It began when Ms. Watson, whose family founded the I.B.M. Corporation, decided in 1977 to realize her dream of an Upper East Side bookshop whose feeling would be casual but whose inventory would be as deep as a university bookstore's.
She found space in one of a small group of brownstones owned by the Whitney, which leased it to her at a modest rent, in part because the slow-moving 1970's were nothing like the 80's or the 90's in the New York real-estate market, and in part because the museum assumed that sooner or later it would be tearing the buildings down anyway. Indeed, a few years after Books & Company opened, the Whitney announced a plan to build an extravagant addition by Michael Graves beside its present building.
When wide-ranging opposition to the Graves building led to its postponement and eventual cancellation, the brownstones remained. Books & Company became all the more entrenched, and at a level of rent that seemed to be farther below the market with each passing year. The Whitney was giving the store what amounted to a de facto subsidy, and one that in effect became bigger every year as the potential rent of a Madison Avenue storefront continued to grow.
At the same time, other forces began to play havoc with both the book business and the structure of museums. Independent bookselling became more and more difficult as large chains grew powerful. Museums were facing a whole set of economic and social pressures of their own, and they tried to respond to the curtailment of government support by marketing themselves more and more aggressively to younger audiences eager for entertainment. This is a trend that the Whitney has often seemed to embrace with an enthusiasm that exceeded that of many more conservative institutions.
The cultural differences between the Whitney and Books & Company come down, in a way, to the words like "entertainment" and "audience," words that the Whitney found it could live with more comfortably than Books & Company could. For two years Ms. Watson and the Whitney negotiated over a possible partnership, but the cultural differences between them were ultimately unbridgeable: in the end, the Whitney wanted a business, and Ms. Watson did not.
The misunderstandings grew deeper in recent weeks, after Ms. Watson asked the museum to let her out of her lease at the end of May, even though it was to have run to October. The museum agreed and immediately began to seek higher-paying tenants for the space. When some investors who admired Books & Company offered to support the store if the Whitney would grant them the same favorable lease terms it had once offered to Ms. Watson, the museum refused, saying the die was cast, that it had traveled too far down the road toward maximizing its financial assets to turn back now.
That was the decision that sent shock waves through the city's literary community. "Subtract Books & Company from New York and New York loses a part of its soul," wrote Paul Auster, whose comments have been posted in the store's window, along with a lament by Norman Mailer over the store's expected end and Grace Schulman's statement that to close Books & Company would be "no less atrocious than to demolish a cathedral."

HEADLINE: Unesco Award to Imprisoned Chinese Journalist Angers Beijing

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 5

 BODY:
Unesco, an agency attacked by Western nations little more than a decade ago for its involvement in efforts to regulate the world's news organizations, is now under threat of retaliation from China because of a press freedom award it presented on Saturday to an imprisoned Chinese journalist.
Unesco's resistance to demands from China that it dissociate itself from the award to the journalist, Gao Yu, is unusual in the United Nations system, where the Chinese, ever vigilant for potential criticism, have frequently had their way in censoring or altering events. 
 In 1995, during the 50th anniversary of the United Nations, China did not allow the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan leader, to take any part in the celebrations, including an interfaith service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York.
This weekend Ms. Gao, 52, who was sent to jail for six years in 1994 for reporting on how Communist Party leaders controlled Government decision-making, received the first Unesco/Guillermo Cano World Press Freedom Prize intended to honor journalists whose work brought risk or punishment.
As late as last week, Chinese officials were warning Unesco's Director General, Federico Mayor of Spain, that Beijing regarded the press award as "gross interference" in Chinese affairs that would damage relations between Beijing and the organization.
Chinese diplomats say Ms. Gao is a criminal, not a journalist. Mr. Mayor rejected repeated requests from China that the award be withdrawn and went to an international conference in Bilbao, Spain, on Saturday, to make the presentation himself.
Ms. Gao was represented by the World Association of Journalists, which had nominated her. The conference was sponsored by the International Federation of Journalists.
In a statement sent to the meeting by her family, who told her of the prize during a visit with her in prison, Ms. Gao called the award a mark of recognition that should be shared with all Chinese intellectuals. She quoted from the poet Pablo Neruda, who had written: "Deny me bread, deny me light, and spring. But never your laugh, for I would surely die." Ms. Gao added, "I think I have found Neruda's laugh from this faraway international conference hall."
The Chinese are expected to raise the issue of the award to Ms. Gao at a Unesco executive board meeting beginning on May 26. Rumors are circulating in Paris, where Unesco is based, that Beijing might withdraw from the organization or cease taking part in its activities. China could also close a Unesco office in Beijing.
In Paris, a Chinese diplomat, Zhao Changxing, told journalists that the award was "illegal." Calls to the Chinese Mission in New York were not returned.
Ms. Gao, a journalist of 20 years' experience with the China News Service and then the Economics Weekly in Beijing, also published some reports abroad, including in a Hong Kong magazine, Mirror Monthly, analyzing how the Chinese Government worked.
She was arrested in October 1993, two days before she was to leave China for a year at Columbia University. She had also been detained for 14 months after the violent suppression of the protests in Beijing in 1989.
The Unesco/Guillermo Cano World Press Freedom Prize is named for a Colombian editor, Guillermo Cano Isaza, who was assassinated in Bogota in 1986 at the offices of his newspaper, El Espectador. The attack was believed to be related to the paper's campaign against drug trafficking.The recipient of the $25,000 annual award is chosen by an independent panel of journalists.

HEADLINE: Growth's Limits in Latin America

 BODY:
When President Clinton meets Central American and Caribbean leaders later this week, he will find that some basic economic assumptions have changed. A few years ago, despite warnings from many economists, politicians in Latin America and Washington assumed that economic growth alone would take care of even the poorest Latin Americans. Many people believed them. They do not anymore. Growth has been too slow, and in Latin America, which has the largest gap between rich and poor, the gains have gone mainly to the rich, buying too many cell phones and not enough rice.
Because of inequality and high population growth, there are more poor people in Latin America than ever before. Market reforms have removed many disastrous policies and bureaucratic obstacles to long-term growth and possibly long-term relief for the poor. But Latin governments are now realizing that even with market economies, they need sound social policies and stronger education and health systems to reduce poverty on a broad scale. The Inter-American Development Bank is now focusing on such programs. Mr. Clinton will mention poverty, but the issue deserves more emphasis than it will get. 
 Latin America's economies have grown 3 percent a year in this decade, a welcome contrast to the sharp decline during the debt crisis of the 1980's. But many forget that from World War II to 1980, Latin America grew 5.5 percent each year. Its swift population growth requires economic growth of at least 6 percent.
The picture is not uniformly bleak. Several countries have reduced poverty since 1990, mainly by taming inflation, which is hardest on the poor. Brazil is the most recent success. But this is a dividend that only pays out once. To sustain the decrease in poverty levels, countries would do well to copy Chile's example. Chile has not only enjoyed steady growth but has moved to attack poverty in ways the market cannot. Among its important initiatives have been reforms in the education system, including special emphasis on better elementary schooling for poor children. Bolivia has also made important reforms. Social security is now more accessible to the poor, and new banks specialize in very small loans.
Other nations have been less innovative. In general, Latin countries need to invest much more than they have in basic health and primary education, which have been slighted in favor of universities and high-tech urban hospitals that largely help the middle class. They should also focus on women and girls, who are the poorest. Many needed reforms, such as widening access to credit or land titles, cost very little.
These reforms would benefit the United States as well. Middle-class Latin Americans will be less likely to emigrate. The wealthier people become, the more they will buy American exports. The United States now exports more to Central America than it does to the whole of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.
Mr. Clinton will hear complaints next week from leaders who have watched with dismay as the United States shifted its trade and investment to Mexico after the signing of the North American Free Trade Agreement. The World Bank estimated that the Caribbean could see Mexico take over a third of its exports to the United States. Mr. Clinton should renew efforts in Congress to give hard-hit exports from the Caribbean the same entry to the United States that Mexico enjoys.
The United States is also $20 million in arrears to a special fund at the Inter-American Development Bank that finances anti-poverty projects in Latin America's five poorest countries. Congress should promptly pay off that shortfall.
Mr. Clinton has a lot to talk about during his journey, including migration, environmental protection and drugs. But he should make time to talk about fighting poverty. Washington played a major role in persuading Latin America to institute free-market reforms. It can now usefully promote a second wave of reforms to extend the market's benefits to the poor.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances on Report Of Unemployment in Germany

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar touched a 38-month high against the mark yesterday and settled mostly stronger in other foreign exchange dealings on leaked Government data from Germany showing persistently weak employment.
But the dollar was slightly lower against the yen, reflecting trader reluctance to sell the Japanese currency ahead of potentially market-moving trade data to be released by Japan this week. 
 A late afternoon surge in the United States stock market also contributed to the dollar's strength.
But currency traders said the lack of volume in foreign exchange market exaggerated price movements, so they did not read much significance into the dollar's behavior. Financial markets in Tokyo and London were closed for holidays.
"There wasn't a whole lot to get your teeth around today," said Tom Hoge, vice president of corporate foreign exchange trading at the Bank of New York.
The dollar reached an intraday high of 1.7386 marks in Asian dealings, the strongest since February 1994, before settling in New York at 1.7324 marks, up from 1.7293 Friday.
Against the yen, the dollar initially rose as high as 127.08 yen before dropping to settle in New York at 126.53 yen, down from 126.57 yen Friday. The pound rose to $1.6228 from $1.6210.
The broad strength of the dollar early in the trading day was partly an extension of its rally Friday on healthy United States employment data. Traders said news from Germany suggesting more economic anemia was a further reason to buy dollars and sell marks.
Over the weekend and yesterday, parts of the German Federal Labor Office's April unemployment report were disclosed by the local German news media, showing joblessness remained at record highs.
Although the leaked reports said the overall unemployment rate fell to 11.3 percent, from 11.7 percent in March, the data still showed 4.35 million Germans were out of work, a postwar record for the month. The official employment report is scheduled to be released today.
The dollar's decline also reflected some fear that official Japanese data to be released today would show a further widening of Japan's trade surplus with the United States.
