HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Marriott International is switching to a much broader reward program for its frequent guests.

BYLINE: By Paul Burnham Finney 

 BODY:
WITH frequent-travel awards practically a second national currency, Marriott International is scrapping its popular 14-year-old Honored Guest Awards program and starting a much broader one called Marriott Rewards.
The hotel and resort chain's nine million frequent-guest members will now be able to earn and use points at some 1,000 hotels worldwide. That's an increase of 700, thanks to the inclusion of the budget Fairfield Inns and Courtyards, as well as Marriott's suites, conference centers and time-share villas. 
 Even though luxury hotels tend to look down their noses at frequent-guest incentives, Marriott is using its leverage as controlling owner of the Ritz-Carlton chain to bring eight Ritzes into the program. And they are some of the chain's best hotels -- in Atlanta; Maui, one of the Hawaiian Islands; Kansas City, Mo.; Marina del Rey, Calif.; Naples, Fla.; Philadelphia, and St. Thomas, V.I.
This fall Marriott will add its newest brand, Executive Residences, to the program. And in all likelihood the company's 230 longer-stay Residence Inns and 150 newly acquired Renaissance hotels will join the Marriott Rewards crowd next year.
 
Saving Lives Aloft
Right now, AMR's American Airlines is installing fixtures on 278 aircraft -- about 40 percent of its fleet -- to hold defibrillators, the medical devices for reviving victims of sudden cardiac arrest
. "Two to three dozen times a year we'll make an emergency landing because a passenger is experiencing a heart problem," said John Hotard, an American spokesman. "Even that won't be soon enough if your heart stops."
That's why defibrillation aloft rather than on the ground can be truly lifesaving. "For each minute that it's delayed, the chance of survival decreases 7 percent," said David K. McKenas, the corporate medical director for the airline. More than a thousand people a day in the United States suffer sudden cardiac arrest, according to the American Heart Association.
Only three carriers worldwide -- Australia's Qantas Airways, the Virgin Group's Virgin Atlantic and Air Zimbabwe -- now carry defibrillators, which administer an electric shock to the victim's heart. American's devices, which will be initially installed in aircraft that fly over-the-water routes far from land, are about the same size and weight as a laptop computer. They include printed and voice prompts, but American is training 2,300 cabin attendants to operate them.
By July 1 approximately 300 defibrillators on American's planes and at its hubs and other key locations will be ready to go into action.
 
Beating Hotel Inflation
With hotel space tight and rates escalating, business travelers -- particularly those who work for smaller companies or are self-employed -- can beat inflation by booking through hotel discount services.
One that many travelers have found to be reliable and worthwhile is Quikbook, which is based in New York and has a toll-free number (800 789-9887) and World Wide Web site (www.quikbook.com). For example, a single at Loews New York that costs $235 at the standard rate is available through Quikbook for $129. And if you shop around, that's anywhere from $10 to $96 lower than the rates of competing discounters. At the Hotel Nikko in San Francisco, Quikbook can bring in a single with a $245 regular rate for $150. Such deals are available at about 100 upscale hotels in Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, New York, San Francisco and Washington.
There's no magic in Quikbook's method: it simply passes along a volume discount of 40 to 60 percent that it negotiates with hotels, just as companies do to obtain lower corporate rates. Quikbook does not nickel-and-dime its clients with membership fees and charges for canceling or changing reservations. And there is no prepayment -- guests only need to provide a credit card number that is not used until they check in.
Other nationwide discount services include Hotel Reservations Network (800 964-6835), Room Exchange (800 846-7000) and Central Reservation Service (800 548-3311).
 
Long-Haul Luxury
One of the few things that can help make up for the mind-numbing boredom of long overseas flights is the high quality of service, if the latest Zagat Airline Survey of 10,000 frequent fliers is any guide. Of the 10 top-rated airlines, 7 fly long-distance Pacific Rim and trans-Pacific routes. The winners (in the order they were rated), with only one United States carrier among them, were: Singapore Airlines, Cathay Pacific, Swissair, Midwest Express, Japan Airlines, Thai International Airways, All Nippon Airways, Qantas, Air New Zealand and S.A.S..
Most of the survey participants were business travelers and travel industry professionals who were not likely to be flying in the back of the bus. They might have taken a dimmer view of their airline favorites sitting in a cramped 3-4-3 (or worse) configuration in economy class.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 10.83, to 7,225.32, but Most Indexes Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average struggled to another new high, but most stock measures dipped yesterday as investors secured some profits from the market's stunning rebound of recent weeks.
The Dow pulled back into positive territory just before the close, rising 10.83 points, to 7,225.32, after surrendering an afternoon gain of 55 points. 
 Broader indicators edged lower on heavy volume, with the technology-laden Nasdaq market snapping a six-session winning streak.
"With the explosive gains over the past six days or so, it's normal to see some profit taking," said Steven Goldman, market strategist at Weeden & Company of Greenwich, Conn. "To expect that type of explosive mood to continue, one would have to be extremely bullish."
On Monday, the Dow surged by 143.29 points, or 2.03 percent, shooting above 7,200 for the first time. It closed at 7,214.49.
The mood dampened yesterday, however, as investors considered whether a market that seemed overpriced at these levels in March has more potential to move higher now.
Notably, stocks were pressured throughout the session by the bond market, where interest rates edged higher amid indications of strong retail activity. The report on chain store sales also suggested that April's retail sales were hurt more by the weather than waning consumer demand.
That countered last week's burst of enthusiasm that the economy would slow enough to keep inflationary pressures under control, said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist for Legg Mason of Baltimore.
Investors have been worried that the Federal Reserve, trying to protect against rapid inflation by slowing the pace of borrowing and spending, will raise interest rates too aggressively and hurt company profits.
The central bank raised one of its key lending rates in late March, fueling the market's steep selloff, and is widely expected to increase rates again at a May 20 policy meeting.
Reinforcing the optimism that the vigorous economic pace may be slowing, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that orders to United States factories slipped 1.6 percent in March, the largest drop in seven months.
The number of advancing issues was about even with decliners on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 603.7 million shares, the seventh-busiest day in the exchange's history.
The Standard & Poor's 500 list -- up nearly 65 points, or 8.5 percent, over the previous six sessions -- fell 2.48, to 827.76, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.66, to 430.77. Both measures closed at record highs in Monday's rally.
The Nasdaq composite index, which rose more than 5 percent in the prior two sessions and nearly 11 percent in the previous six, fell 10.94, to 1,328.30. Among the bellwether technology issues that led the recent Nasdaq advance, Intel fell 4 1/2, to 158. Intel's stock was hurt by reports of a possible flaw in its new Pentium II chip.
Cisco Systems fell 1 1/8, to 57 3/4, in advance of an earnings report. The stock had rallied for several previous sessions.
Prominent among the Dow's gainers were cyclical issues, which are more dependent on the economic pace and had not risen as sharply in the recent rally. Du Pont rose 2 1/4, to 110 1/4; Alcoa rose 1 3/4, to 72 3/8; General Motors rose 1, to 58 5/8, and Union Carbide rose 1, to 49 3/4.
Philip Morris was the Dow's weakest issue, falling 2 3/8, to 41 3/4. The cigarette maker's stock surged Monday on news that a Florida jury had cleared RJR Nabisco of liability for the death of a lifelong smoker. RJR also gave back part of Monday's big gain, falling 2 3/8, to 30 1/4.
Among other issues, America Online, fell 2 1/2, to 49. The stock retreated after jumping 9 percent on Monday in advance of its earnings report.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Declined 1.6% in March

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
Orders placed with factories fell 1.6 percent in March, the largest decline in seven months, indicating that the manufacturing economy might be cooling.
Today's report from the Commerce Department also showed that inventories increased two-tenths of 1 percent in March after having risen four-tenths of 1 percent in February, suggesting production may have outpaced demand. 
 In a separate report, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its latest survey of purchasing managers found that they expected corporate revenue to rise 7 percent this year as the economy continued to grow solidly with only modest inflation.
The Commerce Department said much of the 1.6 percent decline in March factory orders was caused by weaker demand for aircraft, autos, electronics and industrial hardware. In February, orders rose a revised four-tenths of 1 percent.
"If orders and shipments fail to rebound next month, then the alarm bells should start ringing -- but not just yet," said Ian Shepherdson, an economist at HSBC Securities Inc. in New York.
The March decline was the largest since a 2.1 percent drop in August 1996. It may set the stage for somewhat slower economic growth in the second quarter; in the first quarter, the economy expanded at a 5.6 percent annual rate, the fastest pace in more than nine years.
Many economists expect Federal Reserve policy makers will raise the overnight bank lending rate again at their meeting later this month. In March, concerned about the pace of economic expansion, they increased the interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent.
Taking a different view, Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said factory orders fell in all major categories in March. It was an "unmistakable sign" of less rapid economic growth, he said. "The economy is already slowing down, and the Federal Reserve doesn't need to hit the brakes any harder," he added.
Outside of the volatile category of aircraft and other transportation equipment, factory orders decreased 1.2 percent during March. Excluding the military industry, they declined 1.4 percent.
 By category, orders for durable goods, which are made to last three or more years, declined 2.6 percent after having increased 1 percent in February. In an advance report on April 29, the Commerce Department had said orders for durable goods fell 3 percent in March.
 Orders for nondurable goods, like food and clothing, decreased three-tenths of 1 percent in March.
Shipments, a gauge of current demand, fell one-tenth of 1 percent during March. Unfilled factory orders, a measure of pent-up demand, decreased four-tenths of 1 percent.
The purchasing managers' prediction that corporate revenues would rise 7 percent this year represented an increase from the previous survey, last December, when they put 1997 revenue growth at 5.4 percent. In 1996, revenues grew 4.9 percent.
The latest semiannual survey found that the purchasing managers expected no major slowdown in business conditions later this year. About 48 percent of the managers said their companies would have more business in the second half than in the first half, while 13 percent expected weaker business conditions and the remaining 39 percent expected no change. Seventy-five percent expected higher business output this year.
The managers said they expected the prices of the goods they buy for their corporations to rise seven-tenths of 1 percent this year, a signal that inflation is not likely to accelerate sharply. In the December survey, they had predicted no change in those costs this year.
The managers also expect the costs of labor and fringe benefits to rise a net 2.4 percent this year, below the 2.8 percent increase in employment costs that they expected in the December survey.
The survey found that manufacturers increased production capacity 5.3 percent in 1996 and are likely to add a further 4.9 percent this year. Newer, more efficient plant and equipment often permit corporations to cut product costs, reducing the threat of inflation.

HEADLINE: California to Let Small Customers Pick Their Power Suppliers in '98

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
California regulators said yesterday that they would speed up a plan to allow utility customers to buy electricity from any supplier of their choosing by 1998.
The decision by the California Public Utilities Commission is expected to put pressure on a number of states, including New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and New Hampshire, that are also in the process of deregulating their utility markets. 
 California has become a model -- the first state to devise a system allowing in outside, low-cost producers while at the same time protecting local utilities that will still transmit power and maintain the distribution system.
Under an earlier timetable put into effect by the State Legislature last fall, large industrial and commercial customers would have been able to buy their own electricity beginning in 1998, with smaller customers getting that right by 2002.
The commission, however, recently began to favor opening the market to everyone more quickly. Its administrative law judge recommended the faster pace in a decision on March 12.
"They reached a consensus to move fast," Steve Kline, vice president for regulation of Pacific Gas and Electric, the state's largest utility, said in an interview. He said that his company, a unit of the P.G.& E. Corporation, and other utilities supported the commission's decision.
The decision comes amid growing criticism by consumer advocates, who have said that larger industrial and commercial customers, many of which have already received big rate reductions from their utilities, would get further breaks under deregulation.
The State Legislature, however, has worked out an elaborate financing mechanism under which smaller residential and commercial customers will get a rate reduction of 10 percent beginning in 1998.
Thus, smaller customers who decide to do nothing and still get their power from the state's major utilities in 1998 will be guaranteed a rate reduction of 10 percent.
Also, customers who want to take their chances with an outside supplier and and are not satisfied will be able to go back to their utility after giving adequate notice.
Some pilot programs, where customers are getting experience with choosing their own power supplier, such as one now in progress in New Hampshire, have found that many customers become confused by all the different pitches made by marketers and decide to stay with their utility.
California's millions of customers can expect to be deluged by phone calls from telemarketers and to receive numerous mailings from power marketers. About 1,000 marketers ranging from sales subsidiaries of utilities to independent power producers to small entrepreneurs have contacted the commission about setting up shop in the state.
"Consumers will have trouble eating their dinner," Mr. Kline of Pacific Gas and Electric said. "On top of the current load of phone companies that are calling, you will have a bunch of power marketers."
Customers will be able to put in requests to buy from other sources beginning on Nov. 1. Those who will want at least half their load supplied from renewable sources will be processed first.
Marketers of electricity are expected to try to put together larger groups of customers -- for example, around a town government or a complex of buildings -- to make it worth their while since it will be difficult to make money chasing individual small customers.
California was one of the first states to begin the complex process of deregulating its utilities beginning in 1995.
A variety of interests in the state -- utilities, large industries, groups representing smaller consumers, and the independent power producers -- sought to work out their differences and to a degree succeeded in fashioning a compromise that became the basis for the current plan.
One of the hardest issues was how to deal with the $20 billion to $30 billion of what are called stranded costs. Under competition, many power plants of utilities will no longer be economical, and past contracts signed with independent power producers guaranteeing them high prices cannot be continued.
The question was how to pay back the utilities for such costs. The Legislature worked out a mechanism that resembles a Rube Goldberg contraption.
To reimburse part of the stranded costs, the state will issue bonds to be paid off through special fees charged to the smaller residential and commercial consumers using electricity.
Once the utilities get the money from the bonds, they will be able to reduce rates by 10 percent for smaller residential and commercial customers. In effect, these customers will finance their own rate reduction.

HEADLINE: BRITAIN'S NEW TACK: THE BANKER;
Veteran Governor to Have Freer Invisible Hand on Rate Policy

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
It's Eddie's show now.
Britons used to refer jokingly to the polite public sparring over interest rate policy between Kenneth Clarke, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Edward A. J. George, the governor of the Bank of England, as "The Ken and Eddie Show." 
 Thanks to Gordon Brown, the new Labor Government's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Mr. George, 58, a solid central banker with a reputation for reliability and toughness, should have more leeway in adjusting interest rates to try to achieve greater price stability without Government interference.
Mr. Brown, as he announced yesterday, is giving Mr. George and the Bank of England full operational independence, something the bank has quietly but unofficially wanted for many years. It is eager to insure that "the right decisions are taken on interest rates," as one insider put it yesterday.
Eddie George, as the 35-year veteran of the Bank of England is generally known, was appointed governor for a five-year term that began July 1, 1993. He is expected to use the bank's greater independence to continue pursuing a vigorous anti-inflation policy that to his delight the Government gave the Bank of England as a mandate when he was appointed.
But there has been friction between the bank and the Government over when to raise interest rates and by how much. In the weeks before Britain's general election last Thursday, for example, Mr. George was apparently eager to raise interest rates to head off inflationary pressure, but the Conservative Government balked at such a measure just before an election.
Nevertheless, the views of Mr. George, who has managed to preserve a reputation both for loyalty and for skepticism, became widely known. Unlike some previous bank governors, Mr. George has made his own way in life. The son of a postal clerk, he won a local government scholarship to Dulwich College, a respected London secondary school, from which he went on to study economics at Cambridge University. After graduating in 1962, he joined the Bank of England, rising first on the international side and then through its markets division.
The greater independence being given Mr. George and the Bank of England is expected to bring Britain more into line with American and German central banking traditions. The Federal Reserve Board and the Bundesbank have both long enjoyed greater freedom from political interference. Until now, Mr. George and his colleagues have advised the Treasury on rate policy. Now through a proposed monetary policy committee, they should be freer to carry out those policies themselves.
"It's the establishment of a Federal Reserve-type system," said Geoffrey E. Dennis, a British economist who is a global emerging market strategist at the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation. He expects Mr. George to continue to try to squeeze inflation out of the British economy. "From the tone of those meetings," between Mr. Clarke and Mr. George, "he's come across as pretty tough, showing all the signs of being a a very tough central bank governor," he said.
Particularly since the pound was forced out of the European exchange rate mechanism in September 1992, Mr. George has been cautious and is very likely to use the new independence to argue that there must be much greater convergence of national economic policies before Britain can seriously plan to join the European Monetary Union. "Our concern," Mr. George said in a speech last month to the Foreign Bankers Association in Amsterdam, "is that premature monetary union," between countries with insufficiently convergent economic policies, "would put European prosperity at unnecessary risk."
Not that Mr. George is an isolationist or a Euroskeptic. Early in his career at the Bank of England in the mid-1960's, he attended Moscow State University to learn Russian and worked on Eastern European matters. He also worked three years in Basel, Switzerland, at the Bank for International Settlements, the central bankers' bank, and two years at the International Monetary Fund in Washington.
The Labor Government, however, is not giving all the cards to Mr. George, a keen bridge player. Under the prospective changes outlined by Mr. Brown yesterday, a monetary policy committee would be set up; it would include Mr. George; Howard Davies, the deputy governor; a second deputy governor, who has yet to be appointed; two other senior Bank of England executives, and four other officials appointed from outside the Bank of England.
By proposing greater independence for the bank, the Labor Government is effectively saying it will not be so directly involved in monetary policy. If so, it would end several decades when successive governments -- both Conservative and Labor -- have frequently meddled with interest rate policy, often to improve their short-term political fortunes without much regard for the longer-term economic consequences.
That, as Mr. George said in his speech in Amsterdam last month, has left Britain with "a fairly checkered monetary history since the Second World War," often contributing to Britain's "exaggerated boom-bust economic cycle."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eddie George, 58, has a reputation for reliability and toughness. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: GTE Discloses 3 Big Deals In Growth Bid

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Bidding to become a major operator of corporate data networks, the GTE Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $616 million in cash to acquire the BBN Corporation, one of the nation's biggest Internet service companies.
The acquisition announcement was part of three deals so far this week that are meant to reposition GTE, the nation's largest local telephone company, as a leader in data networks with a national reach. If the friendly takeover is approved by shareholders of both companies, GTE will be set to open a new round of fierce competition against the big long-distance companies, including the AT&T Corporation. 
 "We are undergoing very dramatic, fundamental change in our industry," Charles R. Lee, GTE's chairman, said yesterday in an interview. "We are becoming a nationwide provider of telecommunications services -- voice, data and video."
Besides the BBN deal, GTE on Monday announced a $485 million agreement to buy 25 percent of a new national fiber optic network being built by the Qwest Communications Corporation, a unit of the Anschutz Corporation. Yesterday, GTE said it had also formed an alliance with Cisco Systems Inc., the leading maker of data networking equipment, to develop new products and services and buy as much as $1 billion in products from Cisco over the next five years.
"They are targeting the bread and butter of business networks, like Exxon connecting all its gas stations or Merrill Lynch connecting all of its offices," said David Goodtree, an analyst with Forrester Research in Boston. "These are contracts that range from thousands of dollars a year to tens of millions of dollars a year, and local telcos don't play there -- until now."
Mr. Goodtree said that AT&T is the leader in running national corporate networks, with about 60 percent of a $12 billion market, followed by the MCI Communications Corporation, the Sprint Corporation and Worldcom Inc.
In BBN, GTE is acquiring Internet expertise but not huge market share. The deregulation and consolidation of the telecommunications industry have left the company a burly midget in an arena of giants. BBN stagnated recently as it scraped for capital to expand its already-extensive network.
"It's obvious that we don't have global scale or reach or the necessary financial resources to compete going forward," said George H. Conrades, BBN's chairman. "Together we are an almost perfect strategic fit -- our technology and their resources."
A former I.B.M. executive who has been with BBN only three years, Mr. Conrades provided no details of his future plans yesterday.
GTE will offer BBN's stockholders $29 a share and would assume BBN's debt of about $70 million.
In trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, shares of BBN soared $6.25, to $28.875, while GTE shares lost $1.125, falling to $45.
Some investors sold their GTE stock on the company's forecast that as a result of the BBN and Qwest deals it no longer expected to meet Wall Street's estimates for 1997 earnings. Analysts polled by First Call Inc. before the merger announcement had been predicting full-year earnings of $3.18 a share.
But GTE said yesterday that it expected 1997 earnings to be "flat to slightly positive" relative to the 1996 figure of $2.92 a share. A person close to the company said that the 1997 figure would be no more than $3 a share.
Separately, BBN announced its financial results yesterday for the quarter that ended March 31. The company lost $12.2 million, or 58 cents a share, on revenue of $95.9 million -- an improvement over the comparable period last year, when the company lost $29.1 million on sales of $60.8 million.
Mr. Lee said that the deals announced yesterday would enable GTE to demonstrate consistent annual earnings growth of 13 to 15 percent by 1999, up from the 10 percent target the company had adopted in recent years. He predicted that in 2001 the company will have annual revenue of at least $34 billion, up from 1996 revenue of $21.3 billion.
Wall Street was also concerned that GTE may have to sweeten its offer for BBN to fend off a rival bid from AT&T, which currently carries most of its own customers' corporate private data traffic but subcontracts much of its Internet business to BBN's network. AT&T, however, said it had no plans to bid for BBN.
"No, we're not going to do it," said Mike Miller, an AT&T spokesman, adding that AT&T considers its own network sufficient for its needs. "It's not true."
Mr. Miller, however, called back a short time later to say that AT&T's policy was to decline to comment on market rumors.
But if GTE succeeds in buying BBN, it would complicate AT&T's data-networking business. BBN, one of the inventors of the Internet by dint of having built and managed the predecessor Arpanet for the Pentagon in the 1960's and 1970's, now carries most of the network traffic for AT&T's Internet service, among other clients.
BBN's three-year contract with AT&T runs through the summer of 1998and has a value of $120 million. And though AT&T has an option to legally withdraw from the deal if BBN changes hands, Mr. Miller, the AT&T spokesman, said his company had not yet decided whether it would exercise that option.
GTE is not the first telephone company to buy a big Internet operator. In April 1996 MFS Communications, a competitor in many cities to the local telephone company for business customers, bought Uunet Technologies, a company that was similar to BBN, only bigger. Later that year MFS was acquired by Worldcom, the fourth-largest long-distance carrier.

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Happy in Free Fall

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
So how weird is this? The Clinton Presidency that began with such grandiose designs has become so becalmed, so shrunken, so defeated, so aimless, so anomic, so technical that George Bush now looms as a giant who bestrode the earth.
Clinton White House reporters tell me they "envy" my time covering Mr. Bush, that he seems more "interesting." The Bush domestic policy, known as "status-quo plus," suddenly looks retroactively ambitious, compared with Clinton drift. 
 "It turns out that was an activist Presidency," says Michael Duffy, a Time reporter who co-wrote a book on the Bush years called "Marching in Place." "After briefings with Erskine Bowles, you begin to yearn for five minutes of good, old-fashioned abuse from John Sununu."
Compared with the listless President hobbled by crutches and investigations, paralyzed by the fear of offending anyone, his 72-year-old predecessor appears the master of his fate -- skydiving and holding up rabbit ears behind his wife's head at the Gerald Ford museum rededication.
Mr. Bush laid the groundwork for the new budget deal. And Points of Light, much mocked by Democrats in '92, is practically all that remains of Bill Clinton's social policy.
I faxed the ex-President in Houston to tell him he was looming large.
"Looming Large? With whom, for whom?" he faxed back, in one of his famous free-form letters ("self typed I might add"). He requested that I read the note and then "eat it."
Before addressing my questions, Mr. Bush asked about a biting description of him in '88. "But why am I like every girl's first husband? Unfair!"
I wondered if he was appalled that Mr. Clinton was reduced to purloining conservative premises.
"I'm glad about that," he faxed back. "Volunteerism, less government, China, Haiti boat people, Nafta -- I like it that our policies made some sense to those who came along after me. . . . We did leave a very strong economy in 1992, but didn't your colleagues want 'change' and wasn't I, to them, 'out of touch'?"
I was curious about the deeper meaning of those rabbit ears.
"Fun, strictly fun, and I don't have to worry now how the press corps will analyze this. I used to. But now, I am free at last -- make that relatively free at last. I don't want the Washington/NY corps charging down to Texas and Florida saying to my boys 'Defend your old man/Has he lost it these days?' Yesterday at a Maui photo op, the Silver Fox rabbit eared me -- couldn't even let me go one up without retaliation."
So what did he learn at the conference on his Presidency at Hofstra?
"I learned there are some real whacko professors scattered out around the country. Mistakes? I wish I had been a Reaganesque communicator -- but then do I?; for life is good now, it really is."
He said he had not expected so much fascination about his jump at 12,500 feet out of a plane.
"The only fear I felt was fear itself . . . but once in free fall it was heaven. I'd do it again but I'm not sure this second one wouldn't be written off by the wispy libs and oh so serious pundits as 'Look at the old guy, trying to garner more good press.' "
Asked about Bob Dole's comment that he had considered asking Mr. Bush to help pay off Newt Gingrich's debt, he said he "probably would have if asked."
Did he give any advice to Mr. Clinton at the volunteerism summit? "Are you kidding?" he asked.
As for Democrats arguing, at news of the Clintons auctioning off the Lincoln Bedroom and Air Force One, that both parties did that sort of fund-raising, Mr. Bush noted: "Everybody did not do it. Honest!"
He said he missed some things about Washington -- the White House staff and Camp David. "To some degree, I miss making decisions that matter. But, BPB and I are both very happy. I have no desire to shape history -- none. No memoirs lie ahead. Only the Scowcroft-Bush treatise, which will interest foreign policy wonks and name droppers. I think it will be OK, though I expect some critics will trash us. It will say what it was like dealing with Gorby, MT, Mitterrand, Major, Mulroney, Kaifu and Miyazawa, the guy I threw up on! It will explain why I think Saddam Hussein is a really nice guy and why I regret not 'letting sanctions work.' No, no -- wrong book."

HEADLINE: BRITAIN'S NEW TACK: LABOR'S INITIATIVE;
BRITAIN SHIFTING MONETARY POLICY TO CENTRAL BANK

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 6

 BODY:
Britain's newly elected Labor Government, signaling a historic change in economic policy, granted control over interest rates to the central bank today, a move that cheered its opposition, European leaders and financial executives, some of whom had been skeptical of Labor's resolve.
Only five days after a landslide victory in which Britain took on faith the Labor pledge to abandon its Socialist cloak and continue the free market policies of the defeated Conservative Government, Prime Minister Tony Blair, in a single masterstroke, sought to bolster his credibility and ease concerns that a trend of economic growth would be reversed. 
 By giving the Bank of England the power to set short-term interest rates, Mr. Blair instantly removed politics from interest rate decisions and went further than either of his Conservative predecessors, Margaret Thatcher or John Major, had been willing to go.
Enhanced power for the central bank had not been part of Labor's agenda and had not figured in the campaign. Whatever the political significance of the move, the change clearly gives Mr. Blair somebody to blame should the robust British economy stall.
It also gives Mr. Blair some degree of support from European leaders who want Britain to move closer to integration with Europe. While Mr. Blair has repeatedly said that it is unlikely that Britain will join with Europe in the first wave of monetary union, scheduled for 1999, today's action was clearly a nod toward the Continent. Early in the week, the Labor Government formally embraced a European Union package of worker protections that the previous British Government had opposed.
Today's move came as the Government said it would raise short-term interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, to 6.25 percent, as a means to dampen consumer spending, rising wages and inflation.
The higher rate had been anticipated for months but had been put off during the election campaign. The surprise came in the swiftness of the decision to let the central bank set rates from here on. Announced in late morning, the decision set off rallies in the stock and bond markets in London and helped the pound strengthen against both the dollar and the German mark.
"It will insure that decisions are taken for the long-term interests of the economy and not on the basis of short-term political pressures," said Gordon Brown, the newly appointed Chancellor of the Exchequer who announced the decision today.
Unlike the Federal Reserve in the United States or the Bundesbank in Germany, the Bank of England has never had complete freedom to set short-term interest rates. Rather the Government controlled both budgetary and monetary policy by setting Government spending and a target rate of inflation. While the Bank of England advised the Government on how best to meet the inflation goal, the ultimate say over interest rates rested with the politicians.
Now, the Government will still set a target inflation rate, currently 2.5 percent. While some consider it a fine point, retaining that degree of political involvement means that Britain still does not meet the definition of central bank freedom envisioned by Europe's plan for monetary union and the creation of a single currency.
"This is a welcome move; while the objectives of monetary policy are a proper matter for Government, the technicalities and detail of monetary policy are for central bankers, and not for politicians," said Sir David Walker, chairman and executive director of Morgan Stanley Group (Europe) P.L.C., who is a former senior official at the Bank of England.
The actions continue a shower of initiatives intended to solidify the Labor victory last week that was based on support among business, women, minorities and the middle class.
Since the election, Mr. Blair has said he intends to bring a gradual end to Britain's estrangement from Europe and to strengthen the social safety net for the working poor and the long-term unemployed.
The Government has announced plans to revive the minimum wage, which was abolished by the Conservatives, and told the European Union this week that it would sign the so-called Social Chapter to the treaty on European unity, which provides a modest level of worker protection.
Domestically, business executives have worried that the economy, which had a 3.3 percent rise in first-quarter gross domestic product, was overheating. "My judgment is that we have inherited a situation in which, in the absence of corrective action, inflation will overshoot the Government's inflation target next year," said Mr. Brown, the Chancellor.
Labor has adopted the 2.5 percent inflationary target set by the Conservative Government; the inflation rate in March was 2.7 percent.
The swift increase in interest rates, a move normally associated with prudent fiscal policies, was cited by Labor Party spokesmen as proof that the party meant it when it said it had broken with its "tax and spend" reputation .
"It shows we will shrink from no decision that helps the long-term prosperity of Britain and its people," aides quoted Mr. Blair as saying today, his 44th birthday.
The interest rate increase prompted commercial banks to raise their base lending rates to 6.25 percent, in line with the increase, while rates on home loans rose to 7.6 percent. Since most mortgage loans here have adjustable interest rates, the rise would add about $27 to monthly payments on a mortgage of $128,000.
The decision to endorse the Social Chapter goes a long way to soothe relations with Europe. Ties with the Continent had been strained by the bickering in the Conservative Party, where many members used the prospect of European integration as a political punching bag. In addition there have been trade disagreements, such as the episode involving "mad cow" disease that resulted in severe restrictions on British beef exports to the Continent.
The main beneficiary of the decision on the Bank of England is Eddie George, a 58-year-old, chain-smoking economic technocrat who was appointed to a five-year term as governor of the bank in 1993. A nonpartisan economist who has spent his entire career at the bank, Mr. George advocates greater integration with Europe and is likely to pursue a tight monetary policy.
Under the new rules for setting interest rates, a committee of nine that comprises the bank's governor, two deputy governors, four outside members and two chosen by the governor, will set the interest rate by majority vote. Minutes of the meeting will be published six weeks after decisions are adopted. "The whole thing is very forward- looking and is positive for the U.K. markets," said Tim Fox, an economist at Standard Chartered bank.
But one prominent critic, Kenneth Clarke, the former Chancellor of the Exchequer, said giving the Bank of England control over interest rates was "unwise and precipitate.," He added, "What you are going to see is, undoubtedly, tighter monetary policy than you might otherwise have."
The fiscal measures announced today were seen by many business executives as necessary to slow an economy that is growing at a rate of nearly 3 percent -- largely fed by its service sector even as manufacturing lags behind.
"Anything that keeps the economy on a keel is obviously welcome," said Martin Coleman, head banking analyst at Merrill Lynch here.
The Chancellor, Mr. Brown, told reporters that controlling inflation is seen as a crucial issue. "Price stability is an essential precondition for the Government's objective of high and sustainable growth and employment," he said.
The rise in interest rates was welcomed by the Confederation of British Industry. "The move will enhance the credibility of the U.K.'s monetary policy," the group said in a statement. It strongly suggested, however, that it expected the Government to move toward a modest tax increase if further tightening was necessary -- something the Prime Minister has vowed not to do. The business group wants the Labor Government to avoid further increases in interest rates, which would tend to bolster the already-strong pound and make British exports more costly.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Drop Slightly For 2d Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities were slightly lower for a second day yesterday, as the market had difficulty absorbing the first of two legs of the Government's quarterly debt refunding this week.
Weakness in the dollar has also undermined prices. A strong dollar makes investments denominated in the United States currency, like Treasury securities, more attractive to foreign investors because of the potential gains in currency translation. 
 The decline in bond prices came despite weaker-than-expected reports on weekly retail sales and on factory orders, which normally would be bullish indicators for the bond market.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond slipped 2/32, to 96 26/32, yesterday. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction to the price, was 6.88 percent, unchanged from Monday and Friday.
Analysts had expected strong demand for the new three-year securities, figuring that investors were still optimistic after last week's rally in the bond market.
Anthony Chan, chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said another reason for the expected strong demand was the fact that the size of the refunding was significantly less than the February total.
But instead of coming in strong, demand was surprisingly slack.
"The unexpectedly weak or lethargic auction left a sour taste in many investors' minds," Mr. Chan said.
The bid-to-cover ratio, or the total amount of bids made versus the total amount of securities available, was 2.08 to 1, the lowest of the last four quarterly auctions and lower than the 2.63-to-1 average from August 1988 through now.
The average yield for the new three-year note was 6.438 percent, up from 5.997 percent at the last refunding, but lower than the 6.442 percent some traders expected. The Government plans to sell $12 billion of 10-year notes today, and in when-issued trading yesterday, they were offered at a price to yield 6.66 percent.
Mr. Chan said investors failed to cheer yesterday's slightly weaker-than-expected economic reports primarily because "much of the caviar had already been consumed during the past several days, when yields moved significantly lower."
In general, signs of economic weakening are favorable for the bond market because they lessen concerns about inflation, which erodes the value of bonds.
"We truly needed an outsized decline in factory orders to capture the attention of the remaining buyers," Mr. Chan said.
Mr. Chan said that the market was weighed down after comments from Gail Fosler, chief economist of the Conference Board, were reported; in a speech at the National Association of Purchasing Management convention she said that an increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve on May 20 was all but guaranteed.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three-year notes:

HEADLINE: Not One of Your Big Jump-Starts;
G.M. Is Trying to Make a Go Of Its Electric Car

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., May 6

 BODY:
It has been five months since General Motors introduced the country's first mass-produced electric vehicle in Southern California and Arizona, and demand is just about what the company said it would be: lackluster at best.
The world's biggest auto maker has found just 176 takers for its New Age $34,000 two-seater, known as the EV1. Hoping to stir up consumer interest, it cut monthly lease payments by $100, or 25 percent, last Friday for the zippy little coupe, to a range of $399 to $549. But for that, a car shopper could get a sporty Honda Prelude. 
 For years car makers, including General Motors, tenaciously fought California's mandate that they build zero-emission vehicles, warning that battery technology was not up to snuff and that there was only a tiny market for something as costly and inconvenient as an electric car. The EV1, for example, not only runs out of power every 70 to 90 miles but also requires an hour or two to be recharged.
So is G.M. simply fulfilling its unenthusiastic prophecy?
In its view, quite the contrary. Rather, the company is carefully managing the initial leasing of EV1's -- the cars are not available for purchase -- to make sure the first batch of customers like what they get. The result has been that many EV1 drivers tend to be electric car enthusiasts who have been wanting for such a vehicle for years.
G.M.'s first step is to screen potential EV1 drivers, sending electricians to their homes to figure out how to wire up a recharger (at an extra $1,000), and warning of the dangers of being stranded in the mountains. To make sure they get the point, it does free calculations of would-be customers' commuting routes and provides a map of public charging stations, which remain sparse. For good measure, it points out that EV1 drivers can expect an endless stream of curbside gawk.
G.M. talks roughly 80 percent of applicants out of taking possession of an EV1. But those who make the grade -- mostly well-to-do males -- get the royal treatment. The 25 Saturn dealerships marketing the EV1 in metropolitan Los Angeles, San Diego, Tucson and Phoenix offer customer-pleasing extras more common to luxury cars, like life-of-lease repair warranties and 24-hour roadside aid. And they make monthly calls to buyers, similar to protective parents checking on a college freshman.
By hooking a small group of technology-minded devotees and pampering them at every step, General Motors not only gets good press and creates a mystique about the EV1, it also buys time to iron out kinks and find ways to broaden the vehicle's appeal, notably with new battery technology that will power it for longer distances.
"We passionately believe the enthusiasm of the initial owners is crucial to the success of the vehicle and the development of the market," said J. Joseph Kennedy, vice president for sales at Saturn.
And generally, buyers are singing the praises of the EV1.
"Everywhere you look on this car, there is technology that's extraordinary," said Marvin V. Rush, 43, of Los Angeles, a cinematographer for the "Star Trek" television series. He cited the EV1's system for partly recharging its batteries by capturing energy created by braking, actually a new use of an old technology.
"You can't argue that's not kind of neat," agreed Jeff Church, of San Dimas, Calif., a commercial pilot who was considering leasing an EV1 but was waiting for its price to fall. Mr. Church, who drives a Chevy Suburban, especially likes the EVI's powerful acceleration.
The EV1, developed at a cost of $350 million to satisfy California's push for less air pollution, also appeals to environmentalists and energy conservationists. Originally, California required that 2 percent of 1998 model cars sold in the state produce zero emissions; last year it backed off, though it still mandates 10 percent zero emissions by 2003.
So far, two other states, New York and Massachusetts, have said they want to require electric vehicles, with New York following California's original mandate. Last June, General Motors began working with Boston Edison to start developing charging stations to support electric vehicles in Massachusetts.
"The reason I like this car is I'm an eco-freak," said Rick Ostrov, a salesman at a dealership that carries EV1's here in Santa Ana. He drives a demonstration vehicle. "It's like a little rocket ship from the 21st century," he said. Even so, he added, the cars' limited range stops a sizable percentage of like-minded thinkers.
For all the plaudits, many doubts remain about the EV1. Some critics question the need for electric cars, arguing they will never be much more than souped-up golf carts and that cleaner oil-powered cars could be developed at half the cost.
John G. Rettie, editor of a monthly report on the California car market by J. D. Power Associates, an auto-research company in Westlake Village, Calif., said the market for electric cars was bound to remain minuscule as long as cheap gasoline was plentiful to power the gas-guzzlers now in vogue. Indeed, most people who lease the EV1 already own two or three gasoline-powered cars. And, Mr. Rettie added, "Southern California is one of the worst areas for an electric car because people drive distances that are so great."
Not surprisingly, interests with a stake in the status quo have joined in the attack. Anita Mangels, executive director of Californians Against Hidden Taxes, of Laguna Beach, which is financed by the oil industry, scorns the EV1 as a toy for the rich. "The cars are only being sold to high-earners," Ms. Mangels said. 'It's a product they wouldn't buy if they weren't subsidized." She estimated that lessees got an average subsidy of $7,500, including Federal and state tax credits, reductions in vehicle license fees and public spending for recharging stations.
And even with sluggish demand for electric cars, the EV1 will soon face formidable competition. The Honda Motor Company's electric version of a compact mini-van will be on the road this month, and the Toyota Motor Corporation's electric sport utility vehicle is scheduled to be introduced in the fall. The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation are farther behind, though Ford announced plans last month to build a prototype electric car that gets its power from a fuel cell rather than the old-fashioned lead-acid batteries that power the EV1.
There is also skepticism about G.M.'s long-term commitment. The auto maker halted its development effort once before, during a board room revolt in 1992. Most of the big car makers, reluctant to step up to California's zero-emission mandates, worked with lobbyists for the oil industry to push back the requirements.
For all the doubts, though, G.M. really seems determined. Expansion is being considered, Harry J. Pearce, the company's vice chairman, said through a spokesman, who would not say where. In addition to New York and Massachusetts, the areas that are most likely to be considered include several Southern states with mild temperatures and flat terrains that are less taxing on batteries.
Moreover, G.M. is busily perfecting and promoting its futuristic four-wheeler. Advanced batteries, which would nearly double the EV1's range to 150 miles for each charge, are to be introduced as early as this fall, and current drivers can have their vehicles retrofitted for a fee. After an introductory TV campaign featuring the EV1 being welcomed by animated home appliances, new commercials are being prepared for broadcasting in parts of the Southwest by the summer.
Whether G.M. is serious about the electric car or just trying to placate regulators, Mr. Rettie of J. D. Power says it stands to reap considerable benefits from its efforts. "It's a showroom stopper; its like a Corvette," he said. Besides winning bragging rights for being the first with an electric car, it should gain engineering expertise that will result in improvements in other cars, he said.
G.M. professes nonchalance about the slow sales. "We all knew going in that we were not going to see high volumes in this vehicle," said Mr. Pearce, the vice chairman. And as the auto maker steps up its marketing, others are joining to help. Some EV1 lovers recently staged an old-fashioned road rally, a freeway caravan across Ventura County in Southern California to show their gratitude to Price/Costco Inc., a chain of warehouse stores that installed battery-recharging stations at its outlets in the cities of Oxnard and Simi Valley. The retailer sees economic opportunity in catering to EV1 drivers.
Moreover, utilities are seeking to quell consumer concerns over the scarcity of charging stations. For $1,000, they already wire drivers' homes with a 220-volt outlet that repowers the cars' batteries in three hours.
Recharging stations that look like gasoline pumps are going up outside restaurants and malls, places where people linger for the 60 minutes needed for an 80 percent refill. So far, there are just 47 stations in California and 22 in Arizona, most at Saturn dealerships and utility offices. Local smog regulators are supposed to help pay for building another 150 sites in California by the end of the year. And last week, G.M. agreed to underwrite an additional 50 sites in Southern California the next two months.
For the first few years, at least, public chargers will not be metered and recharges will be free, said Edward Kjaer, director of marketing and sales for Edison EV, a unit of Edison International, operator of Southern California Edison. One potential customer calculated that a daily charge of the EV1 at home would cost him $16 a month compared with $60 a month he spends on gasoline.
David L. Hardin, an executive at Hawthorne Savings in Los Angeles, installed a recharging station at the the savings institution's office as a marketing device. "I'm more of a capitalist than an environmentalist," he said. "It's a great attention getter."
Even at low volume, the EV1 is proof California's mandate works, according to Jerry A. Martin, a spokesman for the state's Air Resources Board in Sacramento. "We're pleased with the introduction," he said. "It's two years earlier than we required." Regulators estimate that auto makers can make 14,000 electric cars a year. G.M. declines to release capacity figures for its EV1 plant in Lansing, Mich., where 100 workers assemble nothing else.
Like aficionados of other cars, EV1 fans started a club that had its first meeting at an Earth Day event in Torrance, south of Los Angeles, on April 19. "Twenty years from now, when we're all breathing cleaner air, I can say I had a hand in it," said Mr. Rush, the cinematographer, one of 18 people who attended.
Some drivers contend the EV1 fails to attain the 70 to 90 miles a charge cited by General Motors. But Eric J. Luebben, an engineer from Lake Forest, Calif., says the complaint is usually made by people with a lead foot. "You can easily achieve that mileage," he said. "You just can't jump on the throttle."
Mr. Luebben estimated he will spend $489 to power his EV1 for three years, compared with $7,592 he would have to pay for gasoline for his 13-mile-a-gallon Chevy truck. For maximum freeway mileage, he has determined that the wake of a pickup truck is the best spot to capitalize on the EV1's aerodynamic design. "You're going 65 with the energy of 45," he boasted.

HEADLINE: BRITAIN'S NEW TACK: A GLOBAL TREND;
Divorcing Central Banks and Politics: Independence Helps in Inflation Fight

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
In granting more independence to the Bank of England, the new British Government is a late entrant in a trend that has seen nations give increasing autonomy to their central banks, distancing monetary policy from direct political control. The practice has spread across the globe in response to demands from investors in financial markets for proof that governments will remain committed to inflation-fighting.
Japan, whose central bank long operated under the direct authority of the finance ministry, is enacting legislation to give its Bank of Japan more autonomy, though not complete independence. France has removed its central bank from direct government control in recent years. Even developing nations like Chile and smaller countries like New Zealand that were once plagued with inflation have set up independent central banks as they battle to bring upward price spirals under control and stabilize their economies. 
 "It's all about credibility," said C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics, a research group in Washington. "There are a lot of studies that show that independence of central banks correlates very closely with achieving price stability."
The Bundesbank in Germany is generally considered the most independent of all central banks, and the model for nations seeking to insulate monetary policy from politics. The Federal Reserve also ranks high, although unlike the Bundesbank, which by law is focused solely on price stability, the Fed's mandate extends to supporting full employment as well.
New Zealand has won considerable attention for setting up an independent central bank where the governor is bound through a public contract with the Government to meet specified inflation goals, an innovation that has largely succeeded.
The trend toward independence is rapidly eroding the practice, common only a few years ago in nearly all nations except the United States and Germany, of regarding monetary policy as the responsibility and right of the government of the day. And it is accelerating at a time when global investors are also insisting on fiscal austerity, effectively stripping governments of their other traditional economic tool, using deficit spending to stimulate expansion.
The impetus for the change comes in part from a recognition that allowing politicians to set interest rates can yield bad policy, undermining efforts to keep inflation under control by avoiding the short-term pain that higher interest rates can cause. It also stems from a growing consensus among experts that low inflation is a precondition to achieving low unemployment and not necessarily an obstacle to that goal.
In the "imperfect world in which most central bankers ply their trade, political systems tend to behave myopically, favoring inflationary policies with short-run benefits and discounting excessively their long-run costs," Stanley Fischer, the first deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund, wrote in an article several months ago. "An independent central bank, given responsibility for price stability, can overcome this inflationary bias."
In Europe, the move toward central bank independence is being speeded by plans for monetary union among members of the European Union. The nations that would enter a monetary union, which encompasses a single currency and a single monetary policy to be set by a European Central Bank, are loosening government control of their central banks -- some faster than others.
France, which along with Germany would be at the core of a single currency, has severed many of the ties between the Government and the Bank of France, although economists said the bank had yet to develop a completely independent culture. Italy has moved more slowly.
The planned European Central Bank, scheduled to begin operation in 1999, will perform its duties with no direct control from any of the member nations. While the central bankers would be appointed by political leaders, the degree of power that would be ceded to the institution is so great that there are questions about whether citizens will ultimately get cold feet and postpone the move.
As they grant more independence to their central banks, more nations are setting explicit inflation targets, or encouraging monetary policy makers to do so. Canada, Sweden and Britain as well as New Zealand now set annual goals and expect monetary policy to be adjusted to keep inflation within those bounds. In Britain, for example, the current goal is 2.5 percent inflation.
"The setting of explicit goals promotes accountability, making it more likely that the central bank will come close to the target," Mr. Fischer said. "Accountability and the need to explain deviations from targets should promote transparency, allowing the public to understand the basis for monetary policy decisions and thus to form more accurate expectations."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Bank of England, known in London as the Old Lady of Threadneedle Street, will have greater autonomy. (The Financial Times)

HEADLINE: Brazil Awards Big Mining Stake To Group Bidding $3.13 Billion

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 6

 BODY:
The on-again, off-again privatization of Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the Brazilian state-owned mining giant, proceeded today, with a group financed by the Nationsbank Corporation emerging as the winning bidder.
Nationsbank provided a $1.1 billion loan for the purchase, which was led by the Brazilian steelmaker Companhia Siderurgica Nacional. The group is taking a 41.73 percent stake in the company for 3.34 billion reals, or $3.13 billion. 
 But the privatization -- the largest sale of a state asset in Latin America -- was completed only after the Government managed to throw out a last-minute injunction that had been granted today at the request of the mining company's workers. The auction proceeded late this afternoon and was completed in four minutes.
"No one believed in our proposal, but we were able to pull it together," said Benjamin Steinbruch, the chairman of Siderurgica Nacional. That company, Brazil's largest steelmaker, was itself sold by the Government to private investors in 1992.
Vale do Rio Doce, or C.V.R.D., was sold at a 20 percent premium above the minimum price of 2.782 billion reals.
"We're pleasantly surprised by the premium that was paid," the Planning Minister, Antonio Kandir, said.
The court order that the Government managed to overturn was the latest in an avalanche of legal obstacles erected by opponents to the sale, who argued that Brazil was selling off a piece of its natural wealth for a pittance. C.V.R.D. is the world's largest exporter of iron ore and the largest gold producer in Latin America.
Today's injunction actually interrupted the bidding after it began, and delayed its completion for several hours.
And the legal wrangling over the auction may yet continue. Brazil's highest appeals court raised doubts about the auction after its completion, and scheduled a session to discuss a lawsuit filed by a legal professor challenging the process.
The completion of the auction was greeted by a round of applause and the singing of the Brazilian national anthem on the floor of the stock exchange here, while the sale's opponents protested outside.
Last week, hundreds of people demonstrated nationwide in a bid to derail the sale of C.V.R.D., a company that spearheaded development of a large swath of the Amazon and helped put Brazil on the map of industrialized nations.
The winning bid beat out one by a group led by the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa and S.A. Industrias Votorantim, the largest industrial group in Brazil.
Siderurgica Nacional bought the largest block of shares, a 16.3 percent stake, for 1.3 billion reals. In addition to providing the financing, Nationsbank also purchased a 5 percent stake in C.V.R.D. for 400 million reals, through a company called Sweet River Investments Ltd. Vale do Rio Doce translates to "Valley of the Sweet River."
The investment is a big step for Nationsbank, whose Latin American operations are dwarfed by those of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the BankBoston Corporation, Citicorp and other foreign banks.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk
