HEADLINE: Borderline Working Class;
In Texas, Labor Is Feeling Trade Accord's Pinch

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: EL PASO

 BODY:
Even after 15 years of work, Maria Consuelo Garcia made only slightly more than the $4.75 minimum wage stitching together Polo, Fila and Sassoon jeans in the Sun Apparel Inc. factory here. Seeing friends laid off at her plant and others, she kept her sewing machine whirring to beat her quotas.
But that was not good enough. Company managers said their costs were still too high. Early in April, Ms. Garcia and 297 others were let go. Though Sun Apparel had no comment, the Labor Department said that these workers, and 320 others about two years ago, lost their jobs because the company is bringing in more goods from Mexico, where garment workers usually get less than $1 an hour. 
 Such job losses to Mexico are accelerating, especially among workers already at the bottom in pay and skills, according to economists and Government statistics. Since the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect at the beginning of 1994, the losses, mostly to Mexico but some to Canada, have grown by more than a third each year. The Labor Department total of 124,000 includes a record 7,600 jobs lost in April alone.
Administration officials say that lower trade barriers with Mexico and higher American exports still leave Americans with far more new jobs than they are losing. They say the layoffs are more the result of the peso's crash in late 1994 and the lowered cost of Mexican labor than of the trade agreement, which they say kept Mexico's market open.
"In a economy as strong as ours, Nafta certainly hasn't had the negative impact that critics feared," said Ira S. Shapiro, a senior negotiator for the United States trade representative.
[President Clinton underlined the importance of economic ties with Mexico, the nation's third-largest trading partner, on his visit there this week.]
But even as the nation as a whole is basking in nearly full employment, workers in areas where dominant employers have cut back because of Mexican trade can find themselves living through a depression. While a side agreement to the free trade accord guarantees retraining, the Government has no idea how many have found new jobs. Officials call some programs outright failures.
What is more, a study that the Labor Department itself financed says that the count of 124,000 workers who qualified for training understates the true job drain. Some major companies have refused to acknowledge that they shifted or lost jobs to Mexico.
Johnson Controls Inc. tried repeatedly to block benefits for 276 workers laid off at its Bennington, Vt., auto battery plant in 1994 and still disputes the Labor Department's finding that its employees qualified for training. The department's standards for counting losses are tight, with more than two of every five retraining applications denied. Many workers and employers do not know to apply for assistance. Though dozens of the 4,000 apparel plants in Los Angeles have closed, workers at no more than four of the factories qualified.
Mexican trade, however, like trade in general, is less likely to cost American jobs than to restrain wages, explained Alan B. Krueger, a former Labor Department chief economist now at Princeton. "Trade does create winners and losers," he said.
The damage is most visible here in El Paso, a border metropolis of 700,000 whose economy has already become fully integrated with Mexico's and whose workers are therefore willing to accept the minimum wage. Also visible here, given the stark limits of the Government's retraining effort, is a community's struggle to find solutions of its own.
With an average unemployment rate of 11.7 percent last year, up about two percentage points since 1994, El Paso has lost more than 5,600 jobs to Mexican trade over three years, more than anywhere else. Most of those laid off are of Mexican background -- a third to a half of them American citizens, most of the rest legal residents.
More workers are having to seek jobs elsewhere. The Census Bureau reports that in 1995, almost 15,000 more people left El Paso than arrived, up from a loss of 1,400 residents in 1993, the year before the trade pact took effect.
Although a few workers left for Mexico, far more hunt for a paycheck elsewhere in the United States. From the Texas Workforce Commission offices downtown here, weekly buses have carried hundreds of workers away to temporary jobs, many in slaughterhouses, in states as distant as Iowa, Nebraska and even Alaska.
About 1,500 who stayed in El Paso found that the retraining program left them with no new skills or jobs. After spending $18 million on the program here over three years, Washington is spending another $4.5 million to retrain many of these workers yet again.
As a political theme, anger over foreign trade, especially with Mexico, is already in national previews. The House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, considering a Presidential run in 2000, is preparing to use the trade issue as a weapon against Vice President Al Gore, a vocal defender of Nafta. The Administration's plan to extend the free trade pact to Chile is bringing further attention to how well the side agreement on labor has worked.
In El Paso, unemployed workers regularly picket city and state offices and camp out for weeks by border bridges, demanding better retraining and jobs. Rather than bashing Mexico, they and their organization -- called La Mujer Obrera (the Working Woman) -- attack American corporations and politicians.
The outcry has helped turn Mayor Larry Francis, who once owned plants across the border, into a trade agreement critic. "When Nafta started surfacing, I supported it," he said at his office, whose view includes the border and the factories beyond. He now scolds El Paso's border-hopping executives for bleeding away employment and pulverizing roads and bridges with their truck traffic but doing little that benefits the city.
The city's business people consider the Mayor a traitor. Veronica K. Callaghan, an industrial park developer who just finished a term as president of the national Border Trade Alliance, told him at a meeting several months ago that the Mexican maquiladoras -- twin plants that handle assembly, usually with parts made in the United States -- were still El Paso's major source of new jobs. "What's behind this?" she asked the Mayor. "It's just doom and gloom."
The trade pact's defenders say that exports to Mexico have fully rebounded since the peso's collapse and are now at their highest level ever. But labor leaders, some economists and the workers themselves say that freer trade with Mexico has speeded the skewing of American incomes, hurting low-paid workers with few skills the most.
"I lost my job, my health insurance and all my other benefits," one laid-off apparel worker, Romana Melendez, told a raucous labor rally in April on the tiled central square here. "It's an injustice."
The job losses, though spread across the nation, have been concentrated in industries like apparel, auto parts and electronics. Many of those jobs have gone to the maquiladoras, whose payrolls have expanded by 300,000 in two years, to more than 800,000.
In its sprawling industrial parks, Ciudad Juarez, just across the border from El Paso, had 177,000 maquiladora jobs by the end of last year, the most of any Mexican city and a gain of 77,000 in two years, according to Twin Plant News, published here. American officials hope that the boom on the Mexican side will reduce illegal immigration.
Some of those jobs came from Johnson & Johnson, which laid off 110 El Paso workers who had been cutting fabric for surgical gowns, drapes and other materials. Their jobs were added to the company's payroll of 3,000 in Juarez, leaving only about 25 Johnson & Johnson employees in a sterilization shop in El Paso.
Import restrictions long kept the cutting jobs in the United States, the company said. But with the trade agreement, the shift to Mexico became essential. "All of our competitors in that business are there," a spokesman said.
El Paso, having marketed itself for decades as a low-wage haven, is responding to the loss of low-skill employment by having its schools train workers in metal stamping, plastic injection molding and other trades. These programs have helped attract several companies that make parts for the auto and electronics plants across the border.
Even these jobs are becoming vulnerable to competition, though. Juarez schools, like those elsewhere in Mexico, are likewise improving their training, and Juarez plants are doing more molding and stamping of their own.
"The employers coming in could be using El Paso as a trampoline," before jumping off to Mexico, said Cindy Arnold, a La Mujer Obrera organizer.
In the face of rising unemployment, those here with little schooling have few hopes. Even workers used to getting by on little more than the minimum wage are finding that their checks from the retraining program, which average $146 every other week, are hardly adequate.
For Ms. Garcia applied for retraining after losing her job at Sun Apparel, those checks will come at the cost of self-respect.
"I have 30 years of living in the United States," she said, "and I have never asked for welfare or food stamps. But right now, what am I going to do? All I want is a job."

SECTION: Section D; Page 23; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 622 words

HEADLINE: Efforts at Retraining Have a Blurry Impact

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: EL PASO

 BODY:
When President Clinton decided in 1992 to support the North American Free Trade Agreement, he said that a side accord on labor was crucial. The accord guaranteed retraining for those who lost their jobs to Mexico.
"Nothing like this has ever been found in a trade agreement before," Mr. Clinton has said. "It insures that workers on both sides of the border can benefit." 
 But finding workers who benefited in El Paso, which has lost more jobs than any other city to Mexico, is difficult. Nationally, the results of the training program are at best unclear, since the Labor Department has turned responsibility over to the states with scant monitoring of whether anyone gets jobs.
Department officials say that many who lost their jobs to Mexican trade are retrained under broader, older programs. Although these programs generally have high success rates, the officials do not know how many workers who qualified under the trade accord have actually found new jobs.
In El Paso, the Texas Workforce Commission spent $18 million from Washington retraining 1,500 workers over three years. Many workers say they were simply dumped into crowded English classes that were meant more for general adult education than serious workplace preparation.
The workers are eligible for two years of retraining, receiving unemployment checks for the first six months, then, under the trade accord, an added year of payments at the same level. But as their benefits expire, workers say that the program has left them without new marketable skills.
Irma Montoya was laid off in July 1995 after eight years as an assembler and inspector at a thermostat plant operated by the Robertshaw Controls Company. Robertshaw, a unit of Siebe P.L.C., was shifting jobs to Mexico, but Ms. Montoya's only "retraining" came in English classes that failed to give her enough proficiency for a new job. Now that her benefits have run out, she says, "I'm on a diet."
One morning in April, Ms. Montoya joined a restive group of 75 others to hear Texas Workforce Commission officials say how they plan to make amends.
"We know that the training you have received has been of no benefit to you," said Juan Garcia, a retraining specialist with the commission, as Ms. Montoya nodded.
Mr. Garcia, speaking in Spanish, explained that the state now planned to provide another year of support and training under a new program offering the technical skills that employers said they seek. The workers will receive improved English instruction at the same time. "Businesses are demanding you know English," even for jobs where it is not necessary, Mr. Garcia said.
After the session, Linda J. Williamson, a state training administrator, said that Washington had only asked whether workers had received retraining, not whether it was appropriate or resulted in jobs. "There are no performance standards," she said. In El Paso, she added, "The past program has failed, without question."
The new program, costing another $4.5 million in Federal money, was devised only under pressure from community groups and local politicians.
But even belated efforts to provide some technical training are falling short.
Arturo Robles was laid off a year ago by an El Paso plant that made automotive wiring harnesses. Some fellow workers stayed on the payroll several months longer only by training workers in Mexico to do their jobs.
Not until January, Mr. Robles said, did he get any technical training. But his class in basic electronics was meant for troubled, disruptive high school students and stressed discipline ahead of learning. Teachers in these classes, pointing to the layoff victims, told the students, "You'd better work or you'll end up like them."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The budget deficit problem will be back, with a vengeance.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
SOMEBODY up there must like Bill Clinton, Trent Lott and Newt Gingrich. The last-minute projection that the Federal deficit would be $225 billion smaller over the next five years than previously estimated smoothed the way to a painless deal on the budget and may have spared the leaders the embarrassment of ideological rebellions among the troops.
But this gift from the gods may yet prove to be poisoned fruit, for while the accord should balance the budget in 2002 (assuming no recessions along the way), there will be little time to savor the triumph before Washington is again choking on deficits. Indeed, by postponing the reckoning, the deal could make the awful task of bringing long-run order to the nation's fiscal house far more difficult. "We needed at least a beginning on containing entitlements," argued Van Doorn Ooms, research director of the Committee for Economic Development, "and we didn't get it." 
 This has been a hard few years for deficit pessimists. The buoyant economy has generated far more tax revenue than expected, while the accompanying decline in unemployment and welfare caseloads has reduced the cost of the social safety net. Even without an agreement to cut spending, the budget deficit would have fallen to $75 billion this year -- the lowest as a percentage of gross domestic product since the 1970's.
Accordingly, the once-Herculean task of balancing the budget in 2002 has been downsized to the proportions of a vigorous spring cleanup. The deal would reduce outlays by about $250 billion across five years -- real money certainly, but just 3 percent of Federal spending over the period, and smaller, in real terms, than several past deficit-reduction packages. And even this figure exaggerates the sacrifice involved since the deal includes up to $35 billion in tax breaks for college costs, $50 billion in capital gains relief and $50 billion in unspecified tax cuts.
So why the grousing? Jack Kemp, the supply-sider's supply-sider, argues that the Republicans caved in on taxes. He wants to eliminate all taxes on capital gains and inheritances and make payroll taxes deductible.
The heavy-duty keening, though, is coming from analysts who are looking beyond 2002. Two months ago the Congressional Budget Office forecast that the deficit would equal 2 percent of the G.D.P. in 2002. In 2007 the office estimated that Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid outlays would total 10.3 percent of G.D.P. (up from 8.4 percent in 1997) and that the deficit would creep up to 3 percent of G.D.P.
By 2020, when the baby boomers are heading en masse to Florida, the big entitlements would account for 14 percent of G.D.P., and the deficit would reach 7 percent of G.D.P. Then things really get out of hand. By 2050 the deficit reaches 18 percent of G.D.P. -- meaning that unless policies change, Federal spending will be almost twice as large as revenues.
Of course, those estimates are now slightly dated. But that does not change the fundamentals. Indeed, Robert D. Reischauer of the Brookings Institution, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office, argues that the deal paradoxically helps lock in the deficit trajectory. That's because some of the "solutions" negotiators came up with to achieve a balanced budget in the near term actually make it harder to overcome the longer-range problem.
The Clinton Administration had agreed to clip an extra 0.15 percentage point off the cost of living adjustments for Social Security, generating savings that would have continued to accumulate past 2002. The negotiators were also close to capping the growth of Medicaid spending.
But both hot potatoes were dropped when the $225 billion windfall was announced. "It was a missed opportunity," Mr. Reischauer lamented -- one that could have been used as the matrix for the more difficult choices down the road. By contrast, the tax cuts will swell in future years.
All that is left of the assault on entitlements is a one-time cut in the Federal bill for medical services, virtually all of which will come from providers. "If you're a Medicare beneficiary, this deal should make you very, very happy," he concluded.
Politics is, of course, the art of the possible. "Three weeks ago I was convinced there wouldn't be a deal at all," recalled Rudolph G. Penner, a managing director of the Barents Group. Besides, mediocrity sometimes conceals quietly gestating achievement. "I'm hopeful the terms of the deficit debate are shifting," said Isabel Sawhill of the Urban Institute.
Someday, someway, though, Americans will have to find a way to reconcile the baby boomers' demands for a comfortable retirement and cheap medical care with the next generation's unwillingness to cover the cost. While Washington has put the deficit to sleep, it is bound to come back rested and ready to wreak political havoc.

LENGTH: 764 words

HEADLINE: The Stain of Nazi Gold

 BODY:
The honest excavation of history can bring sobering discoveries, as the American Government has now found in an examination of Nazi Germany's stolen gold and its redistribution after the war. No nation emerges unscathed from this investigation, including the United States, and many are disgraced. It is saddening but not altogether surprising to learn that morality and justice, especially the international obligation to look after the survivors of the Holocaust, were swiftly sacrificed to expediency when the gold was divvied up after the war. Remedying this failure, as the report rightly notes, is the unfinished business of World War II.
The extraordinary inquiry, which involved the declassification of nearly one million pages of documents, was initiated by President Clinton after Switzerland coldly rebuffed Jews seeking to recover gold and other assets their families had deposited in Swiss banks before the war. Under the determined direction of Stuart Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of Commerce, and William Slany, a State Department historian, it touches on wartime economic collaboration with Germany but deals mainly with the anemic postwar effort to restore gold and other valuables to the nations and peoples from which they had been stolen. 
 Sweden, Portugal, Spain, Turkey and Argentina will want to take notice. The extent of their economic cooperation with the Nazis has been slowly unfolding in recent years, but Mr. Eizenstat makes clear they profited from their neutrality. Even as the threat of German invasion waned in the last years of the war, Sweden sold Germany iron ore and ball bearings, Portugal provided tungsten for steelmaking, Spain traded goods and raw materials and Turkey shipped chrome. Argentina defied efforts to prevent the transfer of German funds there from Europe.
Switzerland is properly singled out. Though helpful to the Allies as a base for spying, it served as Nazi banker, gold keeper and financial broker. Switzerland provided Germany with arms, ammunition, aluminum and agricultural products.
These countries made only a fitful effort after the war to return the looted gold and other assets they received in payments from Germany during the war. Here America bears considerable responsibility. It led the postwar effort to recover and distribute the gold. Yet only a small portion of the $580 million in gold stolen from conquered governments, worth some $5.6 billion today, was ever recovered. Even less of the millions of dollars in gold and other assets taken from individuals was returned.
Switzerland was aggressively unhelpful, resisting accounting and recovery efforts for years and not honoring agreements to liquidate German assets held in Switzerland. The American report estimates that as much as $400 million in German-looted gold remained in the Swiss National Bank at the end of the war, but no more than $58 million was returned.
The task of tracing and apportioning the gold and other assets was daunting, but American officials tolerated intransigence by other nations and accepted pitiful restitution agreements in the name of cold-war solidarity. Eager to obtain access to an Azores air base in the 1950's, Washington let Portugal surrender only about one-tenth of the German gold it held at the end of the war. Spain eventually returned just $114,000 in looted gold from a stockpile of $30 million. Turkey, which held $44 million in Nazi assets and $5 million in looted gold, made no restitution. Only Sweden paid up.
The victims of this dismal record were the survivors of the Holocaust and others left homeless and stateless by the war. Assets that could have been used to help them were never returned to the countries plundered by Germany. Worse still, gold and other valuables found in Germany that had been seized from millions of individuals and households across Europe were knowingly mingled with assets stolen from European governments by the Nazis. As a result, gold that should have gone to help individuals through relief and compensation programs ended up in European and American government vaults, where some remains today.
These matters remained too long obscured from public view, shielded by excessive secrecy and national pride. It is late to redress the wrongs, but every effort should now be made to return gold and other assets to those with a legitimate claim. Switzerland, after long delay, is finally making an effort to trace and return assets deposited before the war. Mr. Eizenstat and Mr. Slany have performed a high public service by digging for the truth.

HEADLINE: As Chrysler Strike Ends, Other Walkouts Loom in Auto Industry

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 7

 BODY:
The United Automobile Workers publicly agreed today to end its biggest strike against the Chrysler Corporation in 30 years, but further strikes seemed likely soon in the auto industry, notably against the General Motors Corporation.
Nearly 1,900 engine factory workers went on strike here on April 10, forcing Chrysler to shut down five assembly plants that needed the engines for pickups and Jeep Grand Cherokees. The engine workers were alarmed by Chrysler's plans to buy certain drive-shaft parts from the Dana Corporation, based in Toledo, Ohio, instead of continuing to produce them here. 
 The agreement concluded today is subject to a ratification vote at noon on Friday by the engine workers, but approval is nearly certain given the union's history of tight discipline.
The pact calls for Chrysler to keep production of its next generation of the auto parts here, said Roger Barham, a shop steward at U.A.W. Local 51. Chrysler also agreed that the workers here would have the right to transfer with full seniority to a second engine factory under construction nearby, which will supplement the current factory's output of V-8 and V-6 engines, Mr. Barham said.
Chrysler officials declined to comment on the pact until it was ratified.
But people close to the negotiations said Chrysler had won the right to proceed with plans to buy at least some of the current generation of drive-shaft parts from Dana. Chrysler had guaranteed all along that existing engine workers would not lose their jobs, but the union had feared that overall employment would fall through attrition if the auto maker signed long-term contracts with outside suppliers.
Top U.A.W. and Chrysler officials actually resolved the engine parts issue in negotiations late Monday and Tuesday morning. But some technical details and other minor issues, like procedures for workers to follow in scheduling their vacation time, were not settled until early this afternoon, delaying the announcement of the settlement.
Chrysler, General Motors and the Ford Motor Company all reached three-year national agreements with the union last year, but Chrysler and General Motors have had trouble since in working out factory-level agreements with local units of the U.A.W. In addition to the Chrysler strike, workers at two General Motors assembly plants are on strike, and another local strike at a G.M. assembly plant has been settled.
People close to the union said today that the union's national leadership was now making it easier for factory-level union locals to win permission to strike. The U.A.W.'s worry is that General Motors, in particular, has been trying to reduce employment by buying more parts from outside supplierss and redesigning assembly lines, and the union is determined to resist many of these moves at the factory level.
General Motors executives have insisted that they need to continue cutting costs to stay competitive with foreign auto makers operating nonunion factories in the United States.
U.A.W. locals are not allowed to go on strike without permission from the union's national leadership here, partly because a strike at a critical auto parts factory can force the temporary layoff of workers at assembly plants elsewhere. Chrysler, for example, has temporarily laid off 17,000 union members because of the engine factory strike and has filed legal petitions in Michigan, Wisconsin and Ohio asking that these workers be declared ineligible for unemployment benefits because they are indirectly linked to the strike.
Worries about the long-term financial health of General Motors prompted the union to authorize only assembly plant strikes so far this year, instead of strikes at parts factory, which could cripple the company's North American operations.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities' Prices Tumble

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
A disappointing conclusion to the Government's quarterly refunding of the nation's debt weighed down on the Treasury securities market yesterday, cutting prices sharply.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond dropped 31/32, to 95 27/32, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.96 percent, from 6.88 percent on Tuesday. For bond investors the loss amounted to about $9.96 for each $1,000. The second part of the Treasury auction, in which 10-year notes were sold, was received with similarly low demand as the first part, of three-year notes, on Tuesday. 
 Before the auction, dealers had maneuvered to make yields of the new securities more attractive to investors in hopes of drawing buyers to the sale. But among the factors discouraging buyers from entering the market yesterday were the dollar's weakness and fresh data suggesting that the Fed could again raise short-term rates to tame an economy that may not be slowing fast enough to suit the central bank. A weak dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury issues less attractive to foreign investors. Dave Shabelman, Treasury market analyst at MMS International in San Francisco, called yesterday's sale of $12 billion of 10-year notes weak, with the average yield at 6.740 percent, up from 6.374 percent in February and the highest since 7.016 percent in July 1996.
He said the bid to cover ratio, or the ratio of total bids to the total amount of the auction, was 1.86 to 1, with noncompetitive bids totaling $383 million. Both of those figures indicate weak demand. Over the 12 previous auctions, the bid-to-cover ratio has averaged 2.24 to 1 and the noncompetive bidding has averaged $465 million, he said.
Still, Mr. Shabelman said the overall market could get a lift next week from new economic reports on inflation and retail sales. "Expectations of friendly data next week could provide some support once supply is distributed," he said. He said a Fed report yesterday on regional economic conditions contained few surprises, showing a continuation of moderate growth in most areas.
Investors, some of whom had waited for the report to gain clues to the intentions of the Fed on interest rates for its meeting on May 20, generally found little to steer the debate either away. But with the policy-making meeting so close, the report received a bit more of attention than it normally would have, and the mood remained cautious. Investors are waiting for possible hints today when the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, gives a speech at New York University. Some traders said expectations for a rate increase had already been priced into Treasury securities with short maturities.
More bearish for the bond market was a Government report that productivity of American workers during the first quarter grew at a 2 percent annual rate, slightly less than expected, and that unit labor costs rose at a 2.7 percent rate. The rise in unit labor costs, which was considerably above expectations, could presage future inflation, which erodes the value of bonds.

HEADLINE: Wage Pressures Accompany Growth in Productivity

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
The pro ductivity of American businesses ultimately the main factor determining the nation's standard of living -- grew at an annual pace of 2 percent in the first quarter, the best performance in more than three years, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
The rise was less than most analysts expected after last week's report of a sizzling pace of economic activity during the winter. Still, such a solid productivity gain for an economy in its seventh year of expansion is clearly "good news," said Edwin R. Dean, associate commissioner for productivity and technology. 
 On the worrisome side, the report contained some unsettling evidence of wage pressures. That increased the already strong likelihood that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again at its policy meeting on May 20, some analysts said.
Hourly compensation at nonfarm businesses rose at an annual pace of 4.7 percent, while unit labor costs, another gauge of inflation pressure, edged up to a rate of 2.7 percent.
In a related development, a Federal Reserve survey of economic conditions throughout the country found fresh instances of rising wages during March and April even though overall "upward wage pressures remained generally subdued."
The anecdotal findings, compiled in anticipation of the central bank's meeting on May 20, resulted in a summary description of continued "moderate" expansion for the 12 district economies. New York, however, was singled out for retail sales, which show "considerable slowing."
A second Fed report today showed that consumers added to outstanding installment debt at a 2 percent annual pace in March, the smallest since September and less than one-quarter as fast as the average of the first two months of the year.
But it was the productivity report, published in midmorning, that prompted the most scrutiny and helped set the tone for a day of significant retreat in the bond and stock markets.
The 4.7 percent surge in hourly compensation, which includes benefits and pay, appeared at odds with the bureau's Employment Cost Index, which was reported last week. It showed only a small increase in wages and salaries that was more than offset by a sharp deceleration -- to virtually nothing -- in the rise of benefits.
Joseph Liro, an economist at CIBC Wood Gundy Securities in New York, called this a "stunning" rise even allowing for the fact that the two statistical series differed in their treatment of overtime and in the constant shifting in the numbers of workers in high-paid and low-paid jobs.
Both sets of numbers could be "right," said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at Morgan Guaranty Trust, but he also said it was possible that the Employment Cost Index, usually considered the more accurate gauge, failed to pick up wage pressure captured by today's report.
Diane C. Swonk, deputy chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago, advised taking today's surge with "a grain of salt" and suggested it would not significantly affect the deliberations of the Federal Reserve.
"They're still struggling with growth," she said, referring to the unsustainably fast 5.6 percent pace of economic expansion in the first three months of this year and an unemployment rate that fell in April to its lowest level since 1973. She predicted the Fed, lacking evidence of significantly faster inflation, would content itself with one final tightening of credit this month.
 Unit labor costs, another gauge of inflation pressure, climbed at a 2.7 percent annual rate, today's report also showed, up from 2.5 percent in the fourth quarter but below the 3.3 percent pace recorded in both the spring and summer of last year. For the latest 12 months, the increase is 2.9 percent, the report showed.
The Fed's beige book survey, based on information collected before April 28, said the main exceptions to subdued wage pressures were in "areas and occupations where serious shortages" existed. Minneapolis, for example, reported more bidding up of factory pay, while the Boston, Cleveland and Atlanta districts had higher rates of turnover. Employers in the Dallas and Cleveland areas were relying increasingly on bonuses to attract workers.
New York and Chicago reported "further tightening" of their labor markets even though economic growth in New York, which includes northern New Jersey and a small piece of Connecticut, "has slowed from the brisk pace" of the preceding report covering a period through early March.
The Fed's tally of consumer credit showed a sharp reduction in growth -- to a 3.7 percent annual rate from 12.7 percent -- in credit cards and other revolving credit, the largest category, and a contraction, at a 3.3 percent pace, in automotive credit that came after a tiny increase in February.

A roundup of regional economic conditions in recent months for the Federal Reserve's 12 districts, according to the quarterly beige book report issued by the Fed yesterday.

Cleveland -- Business conditions were still strong overall. Construction activity rose. Manufacturing activity remained strong, fueled by new orders.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Withdraws Tax Break for Developer of Coliseum Site

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has decided to withdraw a generous tax break originally promised to the builder that wins the right to develop the New York Coliseum site, one of the most prized pieces of real estate in Manhattan.
The move surprised the five teams of developers still vying to buy the site, some of whom complained angrily that the Mayor was changing the rules in the middle of the competition. Some developers said that without the tax break -- worth up to $50 million -- they might have to revamp their plans and consider lowering their bids. 
 The cancellation of the tax break is another indication that Mr. Giuliani is trying to scale back such incentives as the city's economy strengthens. The Mayor agreed five months ago to award the tax break to the winner of the Coliseum competition.
But in recent weeks he has contended that it is becoming easier for the city to retain and encourage business. Last month, for instance, when he announced a deal to keep Standard & Poor's in Manhattan, Mr. Giuliani said he was putting more pressure on companies to create new jobs in return for tax incentives.
Yesterday, the Mayor's aides said he had concluded that with a rebound in the real estate market, there was no longer any need to offer inducements to lure a developer to a site as valuable as the Coliseum.
"We don't think that it makes any sense to have a new building with luxury apartments get that tax break," said John S. Dyson, a senior economic adviser to Mr. Giuliani.
Senior officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the state agency that owns the site and is conducting the sale in cooperation with the Giuliani administration, said they supported the Mayor's decision to withdraw the tax break.
Mr. Giuliani and the City Council agreed in December to include the Coliseum site in a program that reduces property taxes for developers of expensive residential properties who also construct or rehabilitate low- and moderate-income housing, either as part of the residential properties or elsewhere in the city.
All the developers competing to buy the site have luxury apartments in their plans, which also include 750-foot towers, offices, retail space and hotels. The developers who wanted the tax abatement said they would build lower-income housing elsewhere in the city.
The agreement on the tax breaks drew criticism from some Council members and from Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President and Democrat mayoral candidate. She said the city was foolishly sacrificing tax dollars on a site that was easy to sell. Giuliani aides and Council leaders said at the time that considering the troubled history of the project, the city had to insure that it would go forward.
Mr. Dyson said the administration had calculated that the tax break would have been worth $30 million to $50 million over 10 years. Technically, the Mayor does not have the authority to unilaterally cancel the abatement without the Council's approval. Instead, he is requiring that the winner of the competition sign an agreement not to seek the abatement, Mr. Dyson said.
The withdrawal of the break is likely to inject a new dispute into the long-contentious effort to build on the Coliseum site, which is at the south end of Columbus Circle, one of the most poorly developed crossroads in New York City.
Last week, after a delay of more than two months, the transportation authority announced five finalists in the Coliseum competition. Four said they had been certain to seek the abatement. The fifth, Tishman-Speyer Properties, said it had not been planning to seek the tax break, apparently because of the requirement that it build low-income housing.
Donald J. Trump, one of the four developers who had hoped to get the tax break, said it was difficult to build new apartments without it. He added that the tax abatement program helped the city in many ways, particularly because it required developers to build low-income housing in return for the abatement
"It's doesn't make me happy because I am the king of tax abatements," Mr. Trump said. "It is a big change, a significant change, and it is coming very late in the cycle."

HEADLINE: BIG RESTRUCTURING OF PHONE CHARGES APPROVED BY F.C.C.

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
In the most sweeping effort yet to set the ground rules for a coming battle in telecommunications, the Federal Communications Commission took steps yesterday to reshuffle billions of dollars of telephone rates -- raising prices for some services and lowering them for others.
The new rules, which were approved unanimously, will generally keep a lid on local phone rates for consumers while lifting rates for businesses. Long-distance rates for all customers will decline by 5 percent to 15 percent, under a related agreement between the commission and the AT&T Corporation, the nation's dominant long-distance provider. 
 The commission's chairman, Reed E. Hundt, said in an interview yesterday that the new rules would deregulate the industry even as they promoted a cherished goal of the Clinton Administration: connecting the nation's schools and libraries to the Internet.
"What we did today is to realize the impossible dream of connecting every single American to the information highway, while figuring out how to pay for it," a jubilant Mr. Hundt said.
But some lawmakers and industry experts said that the F.C.C., in trying to appease all potential opponents of the plan, had fallen short of its stated mission: to strip decades of subsidies from the nation's telephone industry and move it closer to a free-market model.
"The commission is doing less, and postponing it longer, than people ever expected," said Scott Cleland, an analyst with Schwab Washington Research Group, an investment advisory firm.
Mr. Cleland said the commission had tackled only a fraction of the $23 billion in subsidies that undergird the telephone industry. And the commission deferred until next year the thorny question of how to provide affordable phone service to rural areas, which are expensive to serve.
Still, yesterday's rules were a historic step in unraveling six decades of Government regulation. And they elicited a generally approving response from consumer advocates and industry leaders.
"Our great fear was that as you opened telephone markets, there would be a big rate increase," said Gene Kimmelman, the co-director of Consumers Union, a lobbying group in Washington. "This sends the right message that we want to put downward pressure on rates."
Robert E. Allen, the chief executive of AT&T, said in a statement, "The F.C.C. has crafted a good compromise that will result in tangible benefits for American consumers."
These are some of the main components of the F.C.C.'s plan:
*It will sharply cut the charges that long-distance carriers pay to local phone companies for access to their customers by $1.7 billion in 1997 and $18.5 billion over five years. Access charges are set artificially high so that local phone companies can charge less for residential phone service than it costs them to provide it.
*It will establish a relatively small Universal Service Fund of $4.65 billion. The proceeds will go to equip schools and libraries with high-speed connections to the Internet, to provide rural health care centers with phone service and to continue to serve rural customers while the F.C.C. devises a new system of rural subsidies.
*It will impose an additional fixed charge of $1.50 a month on second residential phone lines, and an extra $3 fixed charge on business lines to help the local companies recoup the lost access revenue.
*It will allow the local companies to charge long-distance carriers a flat monthly fee of $2.75 a line for every business customer. Analysts expect the long-distance carriers to pass along that charge in the form of higher long-distance bills.
The MCI Communications Corporation and other long-distance carriers had argued that the F.C.C. ought to slash access charges by $10 billion in one fell swoop. The regional Bell companies warned that doing so would force them to raise rates for local service.
In the end, Mr. Hundt sided more with the Bells -- reducing the charges by only $1.7 billion in the first year. He said that a more Draconian cut was unnecessary because access charges would fall naturally as new rivals invaded the markets of the local companies.
Even the more modest cuts in access charges did not mollify some companies. GTE and BellSouth both harshly criticized the rules, saying that they would lead to higher local rates.
For now though, the F.C.C. seems to have heeded the call of several senators from rural states who publicly warned Mr. Hundt in Congressional hearings not to raise local rates.
Mr. Hundt even got a bonus over the weekend when AT&T signed an agreement with the F.C.C. to pass along all the savings it derived from lower access charges to customers in the form of lower long-distance rates. Based on AT&T's market share, that would amount to $900 million -- or a 5 percent decline in daytime and evening rates and a 15 percent decline in night and weekend rates.
Yesterday, people familiar with MCI said it, too, would pass along savings of $340 million; Sprint is also expected to follow suit.
Despite the F.C.C.'s delicate balancing act, there were clear winners and losers in the rules. Residential customers with one phone line will see no upward spike in their monthly local bill and may even pay less over all, since their long-distance rates will drop.
But people who order a second line will pay an extra $1.50 a month charge, in addition to the $3.50 charge for each line that all customers now pay. Some Internet service providers complained that this could dampen use of the Internet, since many people use second lines for on-line connections.
Stephen M. Case, the chairman of America Online Inc., said he was worried that a few consumers would drop his service. But he said he was relieved that the F.C.C. ignored the requests of the Bell companies to impose a whole new set of access charges on Internet service providers.
Businesses with multiple lines will also have to pay more: $3 a month for each line over the $6 a line they already pay. In addition, they are likely to absorb the $2.75 in flat fees that long-distance carriers will be charged by local companies for every business line.
The decision to load the new costs on businesses provoked a storm of protest from lobbyists for business customers. A day before the rules were issued, Mr. Hundt capitulated to their request to lower the flat fee to $2.75 a line from $4.50 a line.
"Businesses are going to continue to underwrite too many costs, but I praise the F.C.C. for taking out the worst of anti-business regulations," said Brian Moir, a Washington lawyer who represents the International Communications Association, a trade group for business customers.
Clearly, the sweetest moment for Mr. Hundt came yesterday afternoon at the National Geographic Society in Washington, where he and Vice President Al Gore celebrated the schools and libraries initiative with a coalition of educators and librarians.
Yet some experts said it was precisely the extra money for schools and libraries that would make the F.C.C.'s rules difficult to sustain over the long haul. In effect, the Government is adding new costs at the same time that it is trying to squeeze out existing subsidies.
"The Universal Service Fund is simply too big to encourage competition and deregulation," said Thomas Duesterberg, a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute who specializes in telecommunications issues.
Sharon L. Nelson, the chairman of the Washington State Utilities and Transportation Commission, said she was worried that the F.C.C. could wind up shifting the onus for rate increases to the states.
Mr. Hundt acknowledged that the F.C.C. faced a hard slog as it began the next phase of deregulation: determining the cost of providing affordable phone service to rural areas.
But given the whirlpool of competing economic, political and commercial interests that the F.C.C. escaped this time around, Mr. Hundt was allowing himself to savor yesterday's achievement.
"Unlike Houdini, we did not do this in a locked safe underwater," he said. "We did this in full public view."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Shifting Burdens"
Proposed changes in the fees phone companies charge customers and each other would shift costs away from long-distance callers and onto customers with more than one phone line, especially businesses. Here is a summary of the major changes announced by the Federal Communications Commission yesterday, most of which would take effect on Jan. 1. SETH SCHIESEL
 
Customers will pay lower long-distance rates, but higher monthly charges if they have more than one line
 
Long-distance carriers will pay much less to local phone companies, and will use the savings to lower their rates.
 
Local phone companies will be paid for access to their networks mostly in flat monthly fees, which more closely reflect their costs, instead of being paid mostly by the minute for calls.
 
SUBSCRIBER LINE CHARGES
Customers pay these directly to local telephone companies. Fees listed are maximums allowed; some companies may charge less.
 
AS THEY ARE NOW
 
$3.50 a month per line for residences and single-line businesses.
$6.00 a month per line for multiple-line businesses
 
UNDER THE NEW PLAN
 
Unchanged for single-line customers.
For additional residential lines after the first line, raised to $5.00 a month.
For multiple-line businesses, raised to $9.00 a month per line.
 
PER-LINE ACCESS FEES
Technically, these fees are paid by long-distance carriers. In practice, the cost is often passed on to callers.
 
AS THEY ARE NOW
$0.53 a month per line for all customers.
 
UNDER THE NEW PLAN
 
Unchanged at $0.53 a month for single-line customers.
Raised to $1.50 a month per line for additional residential lines.
Raised to $2.75 a month per line (all lines) for businesses with multiple lines.
 
PER-MINUTE ACCESS FEES
Long-distance carriers pay local phone companies a per-minute fee for calls they complete, and build the cost into rates callers pay.
 
AS THEY ARE NOW
 
An average of 2.8 cents per minute to the local phone company on each end of a call (a total of about $23 billion a year).
 
UNDER THE NEW PLAN
Reduced over 5 years to at least offset, in the aggregate, the increases in per-line access fees and subscriber line charges. The exact amount of the reduction is not yet known, but may be up to 80 percent of the fees now charged.
 
The F.C.C. also announced changes in the way money flows to the Universal Service Fund, which subsidizes service for rural areas and the poor. The fund would get the proceeds of a new tax, expected to be 1 to 2 percent, on phone carriers' total sales, both local and long-distance. Per-line access fees formerly turned over to the fund would be retained by local phone companies. (pg. D6)

HEADLINE: Caribbean Policy Has Gone Into Hiding

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Caribbean Blues," your May 4 Week in Review article before President Clinton's visit to Central America and the Caribbean, hit the mark in describing the aimless way the Administration and Congress deal with near neighbors. 
 It may be unfashionable to say it in our self-absorbed times, but United States involvement in these countries -- in which I took part -- carried with it a duty to help, which has not been discharged.
True, no grand threat exists, like that which drove President Kennedy's Alliance for Progress and President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative. But as your article suggests, regional ghettos from which stream poor migrants and drugs (and the criminal semi-states that profit from them) should provide fear enough.
Instead, the organizing principle for policy -- support for democracy and economic growth -- has gone into hiding. Trade had been at the center of the Clinton policy; now the Administration vacillates about extending the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The region can't wait until 2005; its leaders press for Nafta-style arrangements soon. Among other virtues, a staged approach, focusing first on these small neighbors, is more likely to facilitate negotiating authority from Congress.
When Congress effectively killed foreign aid for these regions, it had strange results. To control narcotics, the United States gives millions to police and military but can do nothing to help these countries educate their people, grow crops or wisely use their environment, which President Clinton rightly described as key to long-term growth and stability.
Perhaps President Clinton's visit will serve as a wake-up call, prompting a sense of urgency and a more vigorous and coherent effort. Otherwise history will find a way to bring home the consequences in places north.
 
FRANK MC NEIL
Boca Raton, Fla., May 6, 1997
 
The writer was United States Ambassador to Costa Rica from 1980 to 1983.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Olbermann Still Visible Despite a Forced Exile

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
Keith Olbermann yesterday marked his ninth day of involuntary exile from ESPN's "Sportscenter" for a rap sheet of alleged naughtiness against the network that culminated on April 16, when he appeared on Comedy Central's "The Daily Show" without ESPN's say-so.
Olbermann probably irked ESPN further by informing Craig Kilborn, the host, that Bristol, Conn., the bustling capital of the ESPN empire, was the most godforsaken place on earth. Such impudence! Why hasn't Boston Market dumped Olbermann as its spokesman and stripped him of his Chicken Carver rights? 
 All this occurs as Olbermann -- a witty, intelligent wisecracker, who recently linked the planned exhumation of Checkers, Richard Nixon's dog, to the woeful Chicago White Sox -- looks beyond his ESPN contract, which runs through Dec. 31.
Surely, Fox Sports Net would crave Olbermann's style and following for its sports news operation; maybe CNN/SI would, too. Perhaps ABC News would like him as Peter Jennings's heir apparent; why not keep the job in the Disney corporate family? It's not farfetched: Roone Arledge, the ABC News chairman, came from sports.
"Everything is up in the air," Olbermann said before his house arrest. "Right now, I can only talk to ESPN. I don't have a burning desire to leave, but five years is time to reflect, 'Do I want to continue doing this?' "
 Even if Olbermann cannot be seen on ESPN until at least Tuesday, he remains visible in his Boston Market commercials and in "The Big Show: Inside ESPN's Sportscenter" (Pocket Books), a new book co-authored with Patrick.
The book is an informative hoot, especially after you grow accustomed to the dueling typefaces that signify when Olbermann talks and when Dan Patrick, his "Sportscenter partner, talks. (Olbermann said he chose the typefaces, forcing Patrick into a bland, sans serif style.) The format offers the pair of scamps a platform to offer advice, barbs and behind-the-scenes anecdotes, and to explain why Olbermann cannot drive a car yet lives in a most godforsaken place without mass transportation.
Advising future sportscasters, they write: "Don't say, 'Welcome back.' The viewer didn't go anywhere: you did." Nowhere do they advise their brethren to ask for permission to make appearances on any network but their own.
Although they advise against doing infomercials, they do not caution against making commercials, as in Olbermann's Boston Market spots. (He insists he eats plenty of Boston Market chicken, which gets delivered to his Bristol desk.)
Who could guess that a job he took for money would mean something substantial to viewers, other than being aware of the second-chicken-for-a-buck deal? Usually, Olbermann specializes in phrases that connect meaningful pop culture ephemera to sports news, erudite stuff like "Niedermeyer: Dead."
But two words from Olbermann -- "Eat something!" -- to the waifish models in the commercials provoked a positive response from eating disorder groups.
Jeff Beckman, a spokesman for Boston Market, said: "A couple of groups have asked for copies to show to conventions."
The other impact of the ads? "They're very well paying," Olbermann said.
 
 
Channel 11 Is the Right Choice
 In the end, the smart path was taken: Channel 11, not Channel 31, has 40 Yankee games this season and 50 next year. "PIX offered certainty; BIS did not," said Joe Cohen, who runs the MSG Network, and controls 150 Yankee telecasts per season. MSG could not risk a deal with Channel 31, a weak UHF station that needs to upgrade its antenna strength.
Now, after six years of being paid by MSG to carry 50 games a season to maintain a free broadcast outlet, Channel 11 is paying a hefty per game fee. The station can now sell the advertising time, which it could not before, and promote its WB Network programming to the heavily male Yankee demographic.
Cohen would not say what Channel 11 was paying. But inflation and the Yankees' success surely drove the price above $147,000 per game, which is what Channel 11 paid for 75 games in 1990, when it last paid a rights fee.

HEADLINE: Fuji to Start Making Film at U.S. Plant

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 8

 BODY:
The Fuji Photo Film Company said today that it would begin manufacturing photographic film in the United States.
Fuji plans to invest $200 million in a plant in Greenwood, S.C., to make 35-millimeter color film. It will also expand capacity for color-photographic paper at the plant by 50 percent to meet growing demand. 
 Fuji is embroiled in a dispute with the Eastman Kodak Company, which has complained to the World Trade Organization that Fuji and the Japanese Government have conspired to limit the American company's share of Japan's market. Analysts said Fuji's plan to make film in the United States for the first time was unrelated to the trade fight.
Toshihiko Ginbayashi, an analyst for Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd., said Fuji's strategy had been to make photographic products in Japan, Europe and the United States. "This capacity expansion is independent of the W.T.O. problem," he said. Fuji will hire 100 workers, bringing the total at the plant to 1,200.
Kodak has about 70 percent of the American market for photo film and only about 10 percent of Japan's market. Likewise, Fuji has about 70 percent of Japan's market and 10 percent of the American market, a Fuji spokesman said.

HEADLINE: April Sales Show Retailers Still Lag Behind Economy

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Are American retail stores operating in the same economy as the rest of the country?
It would seem not, given the relative sluggishness of their sales this year. Yesterday proved no different when retailers reported their monthly same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year. The results were somewhat weak, lagging behind other recently released economic data. 
 The Goldman, Sachs & Company Retail Composite Index rose 3 percent in April over a year earlier, when it inched up a mere 1.5 percent. Given the extra shopping day that made April 1997 an easy comparison with April 1996, and the fact that certain companies have outperformed their peers each month, it would seem that too many stores continue to flirt with too few shoppers, dragging sales down for all.
As a result, many mutual fund managers, who in previous years filled their portfolios with retail stocks, have developed an aversion to the group. "I would say in general retail is not a terrific place," Diane Sobin, a portfolio manager at Oppenheimer Funds, said. "You have to be really selective."
Lower-priced stores outperformed other retailers last month, as they have all year. Ross Stores Inc. reported gains of 10 percent, up from gains of 9 percent a year earlier. The TJX Companies, a Ross peer, saw its sales rise 7 percent, but sales fell 2 percent at the Filene's Basement Corporation and 5 percent at Value City Department Stores Inc. The two stronger retailers have generally outperformed their weaker peers all year, perhaps underscoring that there is a player or two too many in the segment.
Department store results were mixed, with stores that cater to slimmer wallets faring better than the luxury segment. For example, Federated Department Stores Inc. reported a sales gain of 6.2 percent, and J. C. Penney & Company's sales rose 5.7 percent. The May Department Stores Company reported a 3 percent rise. Kohl's Department Stores, another lower-end department store and a unit of the Kohls Corporation, gained 9.5 percent, continuing that company's stellar run this year.
In contrast, Saks Holdings Inc., which owns Saks Fifth Avenue, reported that sales rose a mere six-tenths of 1 percent, and the Neiman Marcus Group, a unit of Harcourt General Inc., lost three-tenths of 1 percent.
Particularly poor performers were specialty clothing retailers, a group that has been hammered for years and still cannot seem to maintain long-term strength. Almost every specialty apparel store that Goldman, Sachs follows reported sales declines: Gap Inc. said its sales fell 6 percent, The Limited Inc. lost 5 percent, Talbots Inc. dropped a whopping 16.6 percent, and Eddie Bauer Inc., a unit of Spiegel Inc., reported a 2 percent loss.
Many analysts and retail executives cited cool weather for the poor apparel results. While the Midwest and Northeast have experienced some unseasonably cool temperatures, department and off-price stores were able to report strong numbers without special access to higher temperatures.
The soft retail sales figures are confounding when juxtaposed with other recently released economic data. Unemployment fell below 5 percent in April for the first time in nearly 25 years, and consumer spending grew at an annual rate of 4.9 percent in the six months ended in March, its highest rate since 1988. Economic growth was 5.6 percent in the first quarter of the year, well above forecasts. During the same period, productivity of American businesses grew at an annual clip of 2 percent, a three-year high.
There is additional evidence that would seem to bode well for retail sales. Consumer confidence in April, measured by the Conference Board's index, fell to 116.8 from 118.5 in March, but it had been close to an eight-year high. And consumer installment debt grew at a 2 percent annual pace in March, the smallest monthly rise since September. Analysts had been attributing torpid sales to consumer debt for months -- so by their logic, shoppers should be ready for another trip to the dressing rooms.
So what is the reason? One theory is that stores have slowly been raising prices to improve profit margins while weaning consumers from bargains. "I have a sense that there is a certain amount of inflation creeping into the economy, although I don't think people are seeing it as inflation," David Blitzer, chief economist at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said. "There is slightly less sale merchandise out there, and consumers are doing what they have learned to do very well, which is bargain hunt."
Clearly, raising prices would be a lot easier if there were fewer players on the field to mark down prices when sales turn sluggish. "One thing about overcapacity," Mr. Blitzer said, "is you have to compete a little harder."
All of this makes retail stocks a tough sell. One portfolio manager, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said this week: "We generally look at things from the big picture, and retail has suffered from over-capacity for many years. If the Fed tries to slow the economy down, the longer term is not that great for retail. I won't let myself own the group."
Retail analysts tend to be more hopeful about the group. "We don't think that one should generalize that retail sales are slowing," Richard N. Baum, a retail analyst at Goldman, Sachs, said. "We are late in the cycle, and that is not the time when retail stocks outperform. The best time to buy the group is when you are coming out of a recession.
"Overcapacity is definitely one of the factors," Mr. Baum added. "But marginal companies don't go out overnight."

HEADLINE: Late Selloff Blunts Sharp Rise as the Dow Ends Up 50.97

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
If investors want volatility, they have it.
Following a drop Wednesday of 139.67 points, the Dow Jones industrial average responded through much of yesterday with a sharp rise -- at one point advancing nearly 130 points, or 1.8 percent. Other major indexes were also rebounding strongly, with the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks up almost 1.7 percent. 
 But all that came before a late afternoon selloff, in which the Dow and S.& P. gave up much of the day's gains. At the close, the Dow was up 50.97 points, or 0.72 percent, at 7,136.62; the S.& P. finished at 820.26, up 4.64 points, or 0.57 percent.
Technology stocks fared better, and the Nasdaq 100 index, heavy with technology issues, held onto its gains, closing up 10.06 points, or 1.1 percent, to 919.35.
What remained of the early rally was led by I.B.M., up 5 1/4 a share, to 167 3/8; Intel, up 2 7/8, to 158 3/4, and Microsoft, up 1, to 116 1/2.
A drop in interest rates in the bond market bolstered financial stocks. The rate drop, with the yield on the 30-year bond slipping to 6.93 percent from 6.96 percent, erased part of the jump of 8 basis points on Wednesday. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Also moving sharply yesterday was the dollar, which fell against the German mark and the Japanese yen, continuing a three-day slide. Currency traders debated whether that decline, with the dollar down 2.4 percent against the yen and 1.5 percent against the mark for the three days, signaled an end to the dollar's yearlong rally.
Audrey McNiff, a vice president in foreign exchange sales at Goldman,Sachs & Company, said that it was still too early to come to that conclusion, especially because the large flow of Japanese investment to the United States continues. The dollar's decline did not appear to have an impact on the stock or bond markets.
The recent sharp swings in the stock market -- there have been 13 100-point moves in the Dow up or down this year alone -- has led some analysts to wonder just what is going on.
"It has been such a strange market," said Melissa R. Brown, director of quantitative research at Prudential Securities. "It reminds me of a cartoon. Everybody rushes to the side of the ship and it tilts one way and then everybody rushes to the other side and it tilts the other way."
Whether it is rational or irrational, even bullish analysts like Joseph V. Battapaglia, the chief investment strategist at Gruntal & Company, are surprised by the rush to new highs that the Dow and the S.& P. have made this week. He thinks that the prospect of an interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve when its policy-setting committee meets May 20 should have kept these indexes from setting new records.
"I am assuming there is one coming," he said of a rate increase, "and I felt that the market would not rally back to new highs with that in mind."
He said that he expects both smaller-company and technology issues to outperform the 30 stocks in the Dow in the near future. Both sectors have underperformed this year, especially small-capitalization stocks. While the Dow is up 10.7 percent this year, the Russell index of 2000 small-cap stocks is down three-hundredths of 1 percent. Yesterday, the Russell slipped 0.12 point, to 360.10.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs and one of Wall Street's most influential bullish analysts, has been issuing notes of caution about the near-term outlook for stocks.
In her most recent note to clients, she said that "hindrances to further dramatic price increases in the short term" include a May 20 rate rise by the Fed; the need for investors to become more confident about the outlook for 1998 corporate earnings, and the lack of details in the deficit-reduction package announced last week by the White House and Congressional Republican leaders.

HEADLINE: Trade Storm Imperils Caribbean Banana Crops

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MORNE PANACHE, St. Lucia

 BODY:
For 20 years, Alfred Prosper has earned a living growing bananas on a six-acre plot that he owns near here. He is not a rich man, he will tell you, and the work is hard, but he has always made enough money to feed his family and to hire half a dozen workers to help him.
But now Mr. Prosper, like thousands of other banana farmers throughout the Windward Islands, finds himself at the center of a bitter international trade dispute that threatens his livelihood. At the urging of Chiquita Brands, a unit of the American Financial Corporation and the world's largest banana producer, the Clinton Administration is seeking to overturn an agreement that guarantees small Caribbean banana farmers special access to the European Union market. 
 "Why is America doing this to us?" Mr. Prosper, 53, asked as his crop was being boxed at a weighing station here the other day. "This is a little place, and this is all that we know, and what we depend on. We have nothing else and we hurt nobody, but now they want to take even this from us."
Much as in neighboring Dominica and St. Vincent and the Grenadines, one-quarter of the labor force in this country of 145,000 people is employed in the banana industry, either growing, processing or shipping the fruit. In contrast to Central America, where workers paid as little as $2 a day grow most of Chiquita's bananas, Caribbean banana workers are mostly independent growers who own the small plots they farm.
"We have avoided the strife and turmoil that has plagued Latin America precisely because we don't have a plantation economy and our distribution of income is better," said Rupert Gajadhar, who grows bananas on 15 acres and is the chairman of the St. Lucia Banana Growers Association. "What do the Americans want to do -- reduce us to another Haiti?"
The Caribbean banana industry has long had special access to the European market, but the current dispute dates back to 1993, when the European Union adopted a system of preferences that guarantees banana producers in current or former British and French colonies a share of the European Union market, which has the highest per capita consumption of bananas in the world. In turn, a quota was placed on imports of bananas grown in Central and South America, where American producers like Chiquita and Dole Food have led the industry for a century.
Those preferences are scheduled to expire by 2002, and are unlikely to be renewed even if the American attempt to eliminate the quotas for Central and South American bananas ultimately fails. But in a preliminary judgment in late March, the World Trade Organization largely endorsed Washington's position, which is that the quota system unfairly restricts the American companies' access to the European market. A formal ruling is expected soon.
Thomas F. McLarty, Mr. Clinton's special adviser for Latin American and Caribbean affairs, said the Administration's policy was based on national interest and belief in free trade. The Clinton Administration recognizes there are "very deeply felt concerns among those countries that produce bananas," but "there are much better ways to solve this problem than just letting it ride."
"In terms of our primary goal of fair trade, you can't have discriminatory practices and not exercise your rights," Mr. McLarty said in a recent interview in Barbados. "It gets to the very principle of how you conduct your business."
American military officials who are directly involved in combating the flow of cocaine and marijuana through the islands of the eastern Caribbean have expressed concern that broader American interests could be damaged if the Caribbean banana industry is crippled. Gen. John Sheehan, chief of the Atlantic Command, has warned that a likely result will be an increase in drug cultivation and trafficking and emigration from the region.
"If you start deteriorating the economic infrastructure in the region, it is going to become my problem," General Sheehan said at a forum in Washington last year.
Aware that their preferential trade arrangement is probably coming to an end by 2002 anyway, the governments of the Caribbean have been seeking help from London and Washington in an effort to become more efficient and develop new crops and industries. But the American attempt to accelerate the cutoff of market preferences, they argue, undermines such efforts.
"The W.T.O. has cut off some of the space we had to play with and to get ready for the big change we know is coming," said Patrick Joseph, a leader of the Banana Salvation Committee, a lobbying group formed by banana farmers here.
Theresa Alexander-Louise, an economist at the Windward Islands Banana Exporting and Development Company, a consortium whose headquarters is in St. Lucia, said: "We are used to coming back from natural calamities like hurricanes, flood or drought. But if the markets for our bananas are taken away, that will be a disaster greater than any hurricane we have ever experienced."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Sony Posts Huge Increases In Net for Quarter and Year

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 8

 BODY:
The Sony Corporation said today that earnings surged more than tenfold in its fiscal fourth quarter, helped by the weak yen and sales of its Playstation video game.
The company earned 12.34 billion yen ($99.5 million), or 23 cents a share, in the quarter ended March 31, up from 1.03 billion yen ($8.23 million), or 3 cents a share, in the 1996 quarter. Revenue rose 23.5 percent, to 1.4 trillion yen, or $11.82 billion. 
 The results of the consumer electronics giant were among the first of many earnings reports scheduled for the next two weeks that are expected to show that Japan's export-oriented electronics and automobile companies have largely recovered from the slump of the last few years. The turnabout is partly a result of the companies' restructuring and partly because of the weakening of the yen, which makes Japanese products more competitive overseas.
Some of the strongest companies, like Toyota, Honda, Canon and TDK, are expected to report extremely robust earnings. Even troubled companies should do better, with Nissan expecting to report its first consolidated profit in five years and Mazda hoping to break even.
Japan's consumer electronics industry over all is expected to report 82 percent growth in operating profits in the last year, almost entirely because of the weaker yen, according to estimates by ING Baring Securities. But some huge general electronics companies, like Hitachi and Toshiba, will see their earnings hurt by the severe drop in the price of computer memory chips.
Over all, analysts say, with Japan's years of rapid growth behind it, not all companies can prosper. The Japanese business world is dividing into winners -- mainly internationally competitive companies -- and losers, with stock prices diverging accordingly.
For its fiscal year ended March 31, Sony said its consolidated net income rose to 139.5 billion yen ($1.12 billion), a gain of 157.1 percent from the year before, surpassing its previous peak earnings set in the early 1990's before Japan's economy entered a prolonged slump. Revenue rose 23.3 percent, to 5.66 trillion yen, or $45.67 billion.
The yen's 15 percent year-over-year decline versus the dollar gave Sony a big boost; the company obtains about 70 percent of its revenue outside Japan. Had currency rates not changed, the company said, its revenue would have been the yen equivalent of $4.2 billion lower than reported, and its operating income would have dropped 6.9 percent rather than risen 57.4 percent.
Sony's earnings in the United States were dragged down by a substantial loss at the Materials Research Corporation, a company based in Orangeburg, N.Y., which Sony acquired in 1989 for about $60 million. Materials Research, which makes equipment used to manufacture semiconductors, appears to have lost more than $100 million; Sony said it might sell it.
Sony, however, has been helped worldwide by its Playstation video game. Some 13.5 million units have been sold worldwide since its introduction in 1995. Sales of video game hardware and software reached about 400 billion yen ($3.2 billion) last year, said Joseph Osha, an analyst for Merrill Lynch in Tokyo. That is roughly even with the expected sales of Nintendo, long the leader in home video games.
Sony's revenue in Japan, where the company was not helped by the weakening yen, still rose 15.3 percent, with sales of its mini-disk music system growing sharply and digital camcorders selling well.
Sony's movie business, which has been plagued the last few years by box office failures, cost overruns and management turmoil, registered an increase in sales of 37.8 percent, to 438.5 billion yen ($3.54 billion), partly because of currency rates.
While movies released by its Columbia and Tri-Star studios had "disappointing results" at theaters, the company said, this was more than offset by proceeds from television programs, videocassettes, movie licensing and by the box office hit "Jerry Maguire."
Sony does not provide a profit figure for the movie operation but said operating income for its entertainment business over all, which includes records, rose 20.8 percent, to 66.3 billion yen ($534.5 million). Sales of its music group rose 14 percent, to 585.0 billion yen ($4.7 billion).
But if the Hollywood business now seems to be stabilizing, Sony was hit by the loss from Materials Research. Without that problem, executives said, Sony would have seen its operating income from United States operations rise 40 percent instead of falling 4.5 percent, implying a loss at Materials Research of $116 million.
Sumio Sano, Sony's director of corporate affairs, said that "a sale is one of the options" being considered for the subsidiary, which is in the midst of a revamping to prevent further losses. But Kenji Tamiya, a senior managing director, said Sony would prefer to nurse Materials Research back to health.
Mr. Tamiya said Materials Research had fallen behind in technology, and that Sony's semiconductor strategy had changed.
