HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Report on Jobless Claims Aids a Rally in Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices recovered yesterday from Wednesday's selloff, helped by a report that showed initial claims for unemployment benefits remain at a five-month high.
The data suggested that the economy might be slowing enough to keep inflation at bay and the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates. 
 As a result, short-sellers, who had bet that Treasury prices would continue to fall, surged back into the market to limit their losses. Short- sellers sell borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back later at lower prices, pocketing the difference.
But if prices begin to rise instead of fall -- as they did yesterday -- these participants have to cover their short positions and buy back the securities to limit losses.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond ended yesterday up 11/32at 96 6/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.93 percent, from 6.96 on Wednesday. Bond prices fell sharply on Wednesday, hurt by disappointing auctions of new Treasury notes, and the yield rose 8 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
"You're facing a market that has done a good job whipsawing some traders, but hasn't really generated a lot of casualties," said Dave Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston. "There's a growing belief that the anomaly of the week was Wednesday's negative price action, which was merely an auction trade. There has been some solid buying through the session.
"There isn't a substantial bias to the upside from these levels," Mr. Burtnick continued, "but you've clearly left the bears in a tough position going forward."
In yesterday's weekly unemployment claims report, the number of workers applying for state jobless benefits for the first time held steady last week at a seasonally adjusted 347,000. Analysts had expected a decline of 13,000, to 334,000.
Traders said bond prices were also supported by the Federal Reserve, which came into the market as a buyer. The central bank bought $733.8 million of Treasury securities for its own account in what is called a coupon pass, a move that permanently adds cash reserves to the banking system. The Fed said it bought securities with maturities ranging from 2002 to 2007.
But the dollar continued to weaken yesterday, and that in turn limited bonds' gains. A strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors.
In the corporate market, the Ford Motor Company sold $500 million of 100-year bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. The bonds were priced at 98.591 to yield 7.81 percent, or about 85 basis points more than a 30-year Treasury bond.
Rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's Corporation and Duff & Phelps, the bonds are noncallable by the issuer.
The Norfolk Southern Corporation is expected to sell about $3 billion of bonds in four maturities next week.
Analysts said that the company would sell the debt in maturities of 5, 10, 30 and 40 years. The 40-year maturity will have an option that allows the buyer to sell it back to the issuer in seven years.
The proceeds of the debt sale will be used to pay for Norfolk's purchase of 58 percent of Conrail Inc. Last week, the CSX Corporation sold $2.5 billion of bonds to buy 42 percent of Conrail.
Two days ago, Moody's lowered its credit rating on Norfolk one notch to Baa1, its second cut in three months. S.& P. rates Norfolk AA- with a negative outlook.
Merrill Lynch & Company and J. P. Morgan will lead underwriters on the sale.

HEADLINE: Tiny Tribe in Remote Arctic Is Jolting Alaska

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: VENETIE, Alaska

 BODY:
From this log-built bogland village of barely 200 Athabaskan Indian souls, high in the Arctic Circle, deep in the Alaskan interior, a snowball began to roll.
It started small, here on the Chandalar River. In 1987, the tribal leaders of the Native Village of Venetie (pronounced VEEN-ih-tye) asserted their right to tax a contractor who was building a school here. The state fought it. It argues that under the laws governing Alaskan natives, the village's tribal government had authority over its own people, but not the power to tax or regulate their land. 
 Then it got bigger. The case advanced to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, which ruled last fall that the natives had the right to tax businesses on their land, about the size of Delaware, because it qualified as "Indian Country," much like the reservations in the lower 48 states.
Now, the challenge that Venetie set into motion has such mammoth implications that the State of Alaska has apportioned $1 million for an appeal to the United States Supreme Court. At stake, alarmed state officials say, is the ability to tax and regulate not only Venetie's territory but also a total of 44 million acres of native-owned land -- or more than a tenth of Alaska. The total area almost rivals the 56 million acres occupied by Indian reservations in the rest of the country.
"We've used the word chaos to describe it," said Bruce Botelho, the Attorney General of Alaska. "This impacts primarily rural Alaska, but you're talking in excess of 200 communities who may have a claim that they're occupying Indian Country."
In their petition to the Supreme Court, which is to decide soon whether to take the case, Mr. Botelho and other officials describe the widespread uncertainty the state has been thrown into and predict a blizzard of litigation over myriad issues.
They include whether state taxes and motor vehicle rules still apply on native lands, whether state hunting, fishing and environmental rules must still be obeyed there and whether thousands of non-natives living there are now subject to tribal laws.
A particularly daunting prospect -- one that lawyers for the natives say is highly unlikely -- is that tribal governments could try to tax oil and gas drilling on their lands as well, state officials say.
"In practically every area of government," the petition asserts, "Alaskans -- native and non-native alike -- must now ask themselves the basic question: who is in charge?"
The people of Venetie, many of them increasingly disillusioned with the state government, have no doubt what the answer should be. They say they are simply asserting their control over land they have inhabited since thousands of years before the Supreme Court existed, the land at the core of their tribe's identity.
"Our forefathers claimed this country and said, 'This is our hunting grounds,' " said Larry Williams, a Venetie laborer. "Everybody knows it's true."
Eddie Frank, another villager, said, "If we don't fight, it's like turning our backs on our ancestors."
But legally, little about the Venetie case is simple. It is complicated both by the knotty laws governing native Americans that have troubled the Federal Government since 1776 and by a social experiment that was uniquely Alaskan: the Alaskan Native Claims Settlement Act, passed by Congress in 1971 to free up land for the building of the Alaskan oil pipeline.
Under the act, the Indians, Eskimos and Aleuts of Alaska relinquished their aboriginal rights to the land and received nearly $1 billion and title to 44 million acres, with the right to sell and develop the land. That land was transferred to state-chartered native corporations, which have rights like businesses or property owners, rather than governmental powers like taxation and regulation.
The idea was that the corporations would make profits through developing the land and pass on the benefits to the people. But in practice, results have been mixed, with widespread complaints that corporation officials have mismanaged money and taken too much for themselves. The act also created an an unwieldy bureaucracy that aid workers say has often hindered the very development it was meant to encourage.
Despite some economic improvement in the last few decades, many natives, who make up nearly one-fifth of Alaska's population, are still living in poverty, their alienation from state government mounting. They remain far more likely than non-natives to commit suicide, to require government aid and to drop out of school.
Venetie, too, depends partly on welfare and suffers from its remoteness; nearly 150 miles north of Fairbanks on the Yukon Flats, it is not accessible by road or rail, and the village runway remains rough dirt. Food in the village store costs double or triple what it would in Fairbanks, and there is little work to be had but seasonal construction labor.
Villagers say, however, that it has long been a proud place, and part of a proud people, the Gwich'in, who number several thousand and are spread across vast swaths of northeast Alaska into western Canada. Alcohol is banned here, and villagers' yards bear evidence of their labor: drying strips of moose meat, caches holding the thawing bodies of recently trapped foxes, wolves and lynxes, hidebound toboggans and carts for hauling wood.
Now, "We have a window of opportunity and we are trying to open the door to other tribes," said Walter John Jr., a member of the tribal government. "It's time people start talking about their rights."
Villagers, who are backed in the struggle by lawyers from the Native American Rights Fund, said they did not expect much concrete change if the Indian Country ruling stood. Already they are little interfered with by the state, they said. But in this community without zoning and without property lines, where the main rules villagers cite concern age-old requirements to use all of what you kill, they are used to a full freedom that they want to maintain, they said. The tax on the school builder, they said, was both an assertion of their sovereignty and a defensive move to protect the land against any future misuse by the state.
"We want to keep this land clean," said Ernest Erick, a tribal judge, "and protect it and the wildlife and the burying grounds -- these are the backbone of the Gwich'in people."
Back in the labyrinthine corridors of the law, the questions the Supreme Court would have to decide are more arcane than the balancing of freedom and control. In the appeals court ruling last fall, it found that the 1971 Claims Settlement Act did not rule out the possibility of "Indian Country" in Alaska.
That issue, Attorney General Botelho said, would be the crux of the state's argument: that Indian Country has never existed in Alaska and that the settlement act was not intended to change that.
Lawyers on both sides say it is impossible to predict whether the Supreme Court will take the case. If it does not, and the Indian Country decision stands, Alaska's delegation to Congress has said it will try to seek limits on Alaskan tribal sovereignty through legislation. Such a move, however, would risk touching off opposition not only from Alaska's natives but from native Americans around the country.
Rather, Mr. Botelho said, he hopes the state will enter a broad dialogue in an effort to resolve the divisions between native and non-native, rural and urban, divisions that have festered in recent years over such issues as who should get hunting and fishing preferences.
"We can do a lot together as a state government to heal the divisions in the state and the gap in our vision for what Alaska should be," Mr. Botelho said.
Venetie villagers' predict that what comes next will not be nearly so peaceful. So do their lawyers, who also argue that the state is exaggerating the case's potential effect and that at most, 22 million acres could be classified as Indian Country.
"The state has made it very, very clear it will no way, no how accept the notion of tribal power in Alaska," said Heather Kendall-Miller, a lawyer for the Native American Rights Fund. "If dialogue were in fact their interest, that dialogue would be occurring right now."
Regardless of the ultimate legal outcome, Venetie, like the mouse that roared, is proud of the effect it has already had on establishing Native American rights.
"Whether we lose or not," said Mr. Frank, a talented trapper and toboggan maker, "the state will be fighting everyone else now because the Circuit Court decision opened the door for that. Even a small tribe like us of 300 people really rocked the boat for the state, and it scares the heck out of them. It's going to be a long battle."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Choice: Press the Swiss, or Close Books

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May

 BODY:
A half-century ago President Truman faced the question of whether to force Switzerland to disgorge millions in Nazi plunder. In a decision that a Government report concluded on Wednesday was an enormous blunder, he decided that the United States had bigger interests at stake -- rebuilding Europe and fighting Communism -- and settled for token reparations for the victims of Nazism.
Today the Clinton Administration faces an eerily similar choice. While much of the Nazi booty was sold off or returned to German citizens, Switzerland's banks clearly benefited from a large amount of what remained, even if it has since been melted down, traded off, and buried in balance sheets. 
 Now the United States must decide how hard to press Switzerland to pay up, and at what cost to relations with a major trading and financial partner, one that is feeling bruised by the intense scrutiny of an ugly chapter of history.
That question leads to long pauses and clenched teeth here. "It's something we can't answer at this point," said Stuart E. Eizenstat, an Under Secretary of Commerce who headed the 11-agency study that concluded that Switzerland evaded its responsibilities for 50 years and that the United States failed to use the economic leverage it had over the Swiss to force different behavior.
"We haven't excluded any option," Mr. Eizenstat insists, measuring his words with care. "We're not suggesting that what the Swiss have done in recent months is sufficient. It is important that the Swiss and other neutrals have time to absorb these facts, and that we take a look at what action is forthcoming before making any definitive judgments."
Behind Mr. Eizenstat's comments is a debate within the Administration that echoes the disputes that broke out a half-century ago.
Then the Treasury wanted to freeze Swiss assets in the United States and threaten economic sanctions if Switzerland failed to return hundreds of millions of dollars in looted gold, stolen art work, and Nazi industrial properties that were falsely being operated as Swiss firms. It was overruled. The State Department won the day, warning that sanctions were the equivalent of economic war, and that Switzerland would react badly to "being bullied by the greatest power in the world."
Today the divisions are far blurrier. The Treasury, portrayed by Government historians as the hero of the 1946 argument, will not declare publicly whether it will stick to the same hard-line position and be willing to freeze part of the $86 billion in public and private funds that Switzerland invests here. That excludes Swiss investments in factories and other businesses.
But one senior Administration official marveled the other day, "It's the same conversation."
"It's just that 50 years ago we were worried about Nazis and Commies, and now the worry is that we want the Swiss to help root out drug dealers and money launderers. The issues are different but the trade-offs are just the same."
Clearly the Administration is hoping that no such confrontation arises. But if Switzerland fails to pass a national referendum, scheduled for next year, to create a major fund for Holocaust victims, their heirs, and other humanitarian causes, the political pressure to act will clearly rise.
The referendum's failure is a real possibility: Already nationalists in Switzerland are arguing that the United States is attempting to blackmail the Swiss. That echoes comments by the former Swiss president who complained last year that the United States and Britain were using the Nazi gold issue to destroy Switzerland as a financial center.
"On the one hand this report will help the referendum effort because it puts out the facts," said Thomas Borer, Switzerland's envoy on the Nazi gold issue, who is pleading his country's cause here this week. "But over time, it may engender a lot of negative feeling, especially from those who say this is just an attack on Switzerland. When does it stop? When do we say simply that we reached agreement in 1946, and this will not be renegotiated?"
The issue at hand is whether to re-open the 1946 agreement called the "Washington Accord." Under that agreement Switzerland turned over gold worth $58 million (or roughly $564 million at today's prices) to the Allies for distribution to central banks that were looted by the Nazis. But at the time the Swiss held more than $200 million -- some say the figure was closer to $300 million -- in gold that the Nazis had looted as they raced through Europe, then traded to the Swiss for war material. In short, the Swiss paid only a fourth or less of the gold that the report concluded that they knew was stolen goods.
Under the same agreement, Switzerland was supposed to liquidate and turn over to the Allies half of the non-gold assets the Nazis kept in Switzerland, which ranged in value from $250 million to $500 million at the time -- billions by today's measures. But Switzerland never delivered.
Some, led by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, declare that the solution is simple: Force Switzerland to pay up now. "We should re-open all of this," he said on Wednesday.
But as a matter of logistics, law and politics, it is not that easy.
Many of the assets have seeped away over years of negotiations. Others were declared "exempt from liquidation" in subsequent negotiations.
The 1952 agreement to accept a token payment from Switzerland was motivated by the sudden urgency of stabilizing the West German economy against encroaching Communist powers.
That may have been "a bad bargain" for Holocaust victims, Mr. Eizenstat noted on Wednesday. "But it is a reminder that we participated in this. We accepted this."
And finally there is the question of alienating a partner, though not a particularly close one. Just a few weeks ago the Clinton Administration decided it would not impose sanctions on Mexico for its failures in cracking down on the drug trade because it feared jeopardizing future cooperation. Switzerland, officials note, has recently become significantly more cooperative in helping track the funds of drug lords and financial criminals.
"This will not be an easy decision," a top State Department official said today. "It was tough in 1946, and it will be tough this time, too."

HEADLINE: After Outcry, Agency Drops Housing Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Facing staunch opposition from public housing tenants and their advocates, the New York City Housing Authority retreated yesterday from a plan to seek a waiver from Federal regulations that restrict the rents it charges, the kind of people it houses and the way it spends huge but shrinking Government subsidies.
The authority, confronting deep cuts in Federal aid and searching for ways to survive an era of austerity, said the waiver from the Department of Housing and Urban Development would have been used experimentally in 16 of the city's 341 housing projects only to train and place welfare tenants in jobs, enabling them eventually to become more self sufficient and pay more rent. 
 Ruben Franco, the authority chairman, insisted that tenant fears that the authority would have used the waiver to raise rents, evict residents or sell, demolish or privatize some projects that house large numbers of impoverished welfare recipients were based on rumor and misinformation.
But he conceded that the plan, which had been strongly supported by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, could not have succeeded without wide tenant support, and he said the authority's three-member board, facing a May 19 Federal deadline, had decided yesterday to abandon the waiver application.
"Our initial interest in applying to participate in this pilot program was to provide greater economic opportunity and security to our most vulnerable residents," Mr. Franco said. "However, in a series of public and private meetings with our residents, I found much anxiety and strong opposition, caused in part by considerable misinformation about the program's purpose and confusion and concern about the deregulation provisions."
Tenant advocates, however, hailed the authority's decision as a victory for the city's 600,000 public housing residents and contended that the waiver would have conferred substantial powers on the authority to raise rents, change the ratio of poor to working-class tenants, remove Federal safeguards and radically change or even abandon its historic mission of providing housing for those with no place else to go.
"The idea that New York City, with the largest public housing program in the country, might seek to deregulate or change the conditions under which hundreds of thousands of people live was very frightening to people," said David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society.
As for assertions that misinformation had alarmed tenants, Mr. Jones said the authority had only itself to blame. He said officials had known since last December of HUD's program to relax regulations for up to 30 of the nation's public housing authorities but had failed for months to communicate its intentions to tenants and had held only one public hearing -- last Tuesday night -- only to find wide tenant dissatisfaction with the plan.
"We began asking them in February when they were going to hold hearings to discuss all ramifications of the program," Mr. Jones said. "We never got a response. We think tenants and the entire public have to be involved in this issue. Any changes in this invaluable city asset have to be carefully looked at. They were trying to do it weeks before the deadline, and tenants were not sure what the deal was."
New York's Housing Authority, long the nation's largest and most successful public housing agency, has been hit hard by a loss of hundreds of millions of dollars in subsidies from Washington in recent years. Moreover, welfare recipients, who make up 30 percent of the city housing residents, face large cuts and an eventual cutoff of aid under federally mandated welfare changes, which will, in turn, make it more difficult for them to pay rent.
Like housing agencies in Boston, Washington, Newark and other cities, the New York authority is grappling to cut costs and take in more revenue to make up for the dwindling Federal subsidies, 90 percent of which come from HUD.
Last December, HUD announced a Moving to Work demonstration project and invited 30 housing authorities from across the nation to apply for waivers from longstanding rules that limit rents, determine the mix of poor and working class residents in projects and restrict the ways that housing authorities spend money and run their projects.
Among other ways to generate money, the waiver would allow housing authorities to turn over some high-rise buildings to private managers, increase the number of tenants with jobs and charge tenants more than 30 percent of their income for rent, requiring only that rents be reasonable. Fixed rents are seen by some as a disincentive to work.
In addition, the waivers would let housing authorities use of their subsidies to establish job-training and placement programs for tenants who are welfare recipients and to provide them with transportation to jobs, day care and other benefits that would help them toward self-sufficiency.
Only the most successful housing authorities were invited to apply, and New York's authority, with a reputation for good management, was widely regarded as having an excellent chance of acceptance. While a March 18 deadline was originally set for the applications, the New York authority did not announce until April 9 that it intended to apply, and HUD put the deadline back to May 19. The city's announcement stirred opposition from some tenant advocacy groups, which expressed fears that the waivers might be misused.
Mr. Franco, in response, said the authority wanted the waiver to help train and place welfare recipients in jobs, saying it would be "something positive for the residents of public housing," and "not negative." He conceded that the authority might try to generate more money for its budget by raising the rents of some tenants who were paying far less than the 30 percent cap.
While residents may have been consulted privately, there was no public hearing until last Tuesday at the Fashion Institute of Technology at Seventh Avenue and 27th Street, where hundreds of angry tenants gathered and denounced the plan and the authority for failing to tell them of its intentions.
 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (94%);

HEADLINE: Greenspan Defends Fed's Rate Policy

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
Clearly stung by widespread criticism that the Federal Reserve had been too quick to raise interest rates six weeks ago, Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, aggressively defended the action last night, saying that failure to act would have constituted "a threat to the job security and standards of living of too many Americans."
Addressing head-on the argument that the Federal Reserve had put the brakes on the economy without clear evidence of accelerating inflation, Mr. Greenspan offered what for him was an unusually direct rebuttal, saying the quarter-point rate increase on March 25 had been a carefully calibrated form of insurance for an economy that has been growing steadily for more than six years. 
 "The Federal Reserve, of late, has been criticized as being too focused on subduing nonexistent inflation and, in the process, being willing to suppress economic growth, retard job expansion and inhibit real wage gains," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan during an awards dinner of the New York University Stern School of Business. "On the contrary, our actions to tighten money market conditions in 1994, and again in March of this year, were directed at sustaining and fostering growth in economic activity, jobs and real wages."
Mr. Greenspan did not say whether he would push for another rate increase when the Fed meets to consider monetary policy on May 20, although he warned that further rate increase might be necessary if the economy did not slow.
But his speech laid out a rationale for central bankers to take unpopular actions in pursuit of low inflation, especially when, as now, there is no clear political consensus to curb growth before inflation breaks out.
"Those who wish for us, in the current environment, to await clearly visible signs of emerging inflation before acting are recommending we return to a failed regime of monetary policy that cost jobs and living standards," Mr. Greenspan said.
Mr. Greenspan's speech comes at a time when policy makers at the Fed, as well as economists generally, are struggling to explain why inflation has remained largely dormant despite a combination of strong growth and low unemployment that traditional theory holds would lead inevitably to rising wages and prices.
The economy grew at a 5.6 percent rate in the first quarter, its fastest pace in more than nine years, and unemployment in April stood at 4.9 percent, its lowest rate in 23 years. Yet wages are rising only modestly -- the Employment Cost Index for the first quarter rose just six-tenths of 1 percent -- and measures of overall inflation have remained subdued.
Mr. Greenspan has consistently advocated the need to fight inflation pre-emptively -- that is, before it infects the economy and becomes much more difficult to root out. But until the Fed's March meeting, Mr. Greenspan held off raising rates the previous year despite periodic surges in growth and a steadily declining unemployment rate.
In raising its target for the Federal funds rate to 5.5 percent from 5.25 percent at the March meeting, the Fed took the smallest step it could to keep the economy from overheating. Still, the decision brought widespread complaints from many business executives and from politicians at both ends of the ideological spectrum that the Fed was exaggerating the inflation threat at the cost of jobs and economic growth.
They argued that the Fed had not taken sufficient note of fundamental changes to the economy, from the improvements in productivity generated by investments in technology to increasing global competition, that have combined to allow higher rates of economic growth while keeping wage and pressure increases in check.
"Raising interest rates in a pre-emptive strike against inflation risks damaging our economic growth and prosperity, and is unwarranted," said a letter sent to Mr. Greenspan last month by 59 members of Congress, most of them Democrats.
The rate increase -- or the threat of a protracted rise in rates -- was also cited as a reason for the stock market slump that began in March. The market has recovered sharply from the selloff as economic reports have indicated a moderation of economic growth -- data that have been interpreted by some analysts as making future rate increases less likely.
In his speech last night, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed carefully weighed both the costs of raising interest rates and the risks of not raising rates in deciding when and whether to act against inflation. In the case of the March meeting, he said, the balance tipped toward acting.
"In the same sense that it would be folly not to endure the small immediate discomfort of a vaccination against the possibility of getting a serious disease, it would have been folly not to take this small prudent step last March to reduce the probabilities that destabilizing inflation would re-emerge," Mr. Greenspan said. "The risk to the economy from inaction came to outweigh the risk from action."
Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that there is a "substantial element of truth" in the argument that "conventional notions of capacity are becoming increasingly outmoded, and that domestic resources can be used much more intensively than in the past without added price pressures."
But he went on to say that "any inference that our productive capacity is essentially unlimited is clearly unwarranted."
Mr. Greenspan said that while there is "scant evidence of any imminent resurgence of inflation at the moment, there also appears to be little slack in our capacity to produce."
In the closest he came to a warning that the Fed might have to raise rates again this month, he added, "Should the expected slowing in the growth of demand fail to materialize, we would need to address any emerging pressures in product and credit markets."

HEADLINE: White House and Senate Clash On a Cash-Poor Loan Program

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
The White House has refused to give a Senate committee three documents on a popular small-business loan program that is running short of money, and Republicans responded today by accusing the Administration of simply trying to avoid political embarrassment.
Administration officials said the documents were memorandums to President Clinton or senior White House aides about problems with the loan program. They said the White House was holding on to them solely to protect the confidentiality of its decision-making process. 
 The fight over the documents comes at a time when Republican Congressional leaders have also complained that the White House is trying to hold back crucial records from House investigators examining Democratic fund-raising practices.
Republican senators maintained today that the Administration was using similar tactics in the unrelated tiff over who is to blame for a shortage in the lending program, which guarantees the repayment of commercial loans to small businesses.
The Senate Committee on Small Business asked for the documents after the Small Business Administration announced last month that it would lower the limit on the size of the loan guarantees to $500,000 from $1 million to keep the program from running out of money before the Government's fiscal year ends on Sept. 30.
Bankers and other lenders have asked both the Administration and Congress to find an additional $43 million to enable the agency to guarantee about $9 billion in loans this year.
Given the drive to eliminate the Federal budget deficit, any extra money would be hard to find, although neither Congress nor the White House wants to seem responsible for turning borrowers away from a program that both parties have hailed as a way to create jobs and nurture fledging businesses.
Administration officials said the problem had cropped up because Congress had slashed their original request for enough money to guarantee $11 billion in loans this year.
But the White House itself has decided not to push now for any extra money, which it could get only by cutting other programs.
Senator Christopher S. Bond, the chairman of the Small Business Committee, said Administration officials had failed to warn Congress about the shortage soon enough for lawmakers to find the money needed to meet the soaring loan demand.
Officials at the Small Business Administration denied that, but Senator Bond said he had "serious concerns" about their candor.

HEADLINE: Bruce Willis Drops Project, Leaving Town More Troubled

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

DATELINE: PENNS GROVE, N.J., May 8

 BODY:
While thousands of fans waited to catch a glimpse of the actor Bruce Willis as he opened a Planet Hollywood in France today, residents here in his hometown could talk of little but how he had just let them down.
Just two years ago, a mystery buyer spent $1 million on waterfront acreage in this tiny, hard-pressed borough, raising hopes and curiosity. The curiosity was satisfied: the buyer was Mr. Willis's company, Screwball Inc. 
 And the hopes grew. Mr. Willis had plans, big plans: a $50 million riverfront development to include a marina, a large cinema, a 90-room hotel, shops and much more.
But today, borough officials confirmed that the dream was dead: the actor had lost interest and planned to put the land up for sale.
Mr. Willis could not be reached today. He was at the Cannes Film Festival, which opened with a screening of his latest film, Luc Bresson's futuristic action movie "The Fifth Element."
But Stephen R. Spector, a lawyer for Screwball, said that company executives had told him that "the project is not proceeding."
"I can't believe he did this," said Carol Evans, 24, as she stopped to talk to a visitor in front of the red brick post office. "I was all excited that jobs would open up."
Like many people here, she said she was confused by Mr. Willis's abandonment. And she said she felt he was also abandoning his roots. "I want to know why," she said. "Why did he say, 'I'll forget where I came from?' "
Mr. Willis spent about $1 million in 1995 to buy 11 acres along the Delaware River and said that he planned to build on it. Mr. Willis's developers planned to draw thousands of people here, where the dozens of boarded up buildings and "for sale" signs are clues to its official distinction as the state's second most economically distressed municipality after Newark.
Today, the borough solicitor pulled Mr. Willis's development plans out of a cardboard box stored behind some chairs in the town's small courtroom. "They're now just old news."
"We're disappointed, but we want to stay positive," said the solicitor, Anthony J. Crescenzi. "A lot of people think there's a chance that he might change his mind."
Added Mayor Paul J. Morris, "We will see that property developed one way or another."
But the borough now has no prospective buyers for the land, most of which is a grassy, trash-strewn lot with a stunning view of the Delaware Memorial Bridge leading to Wilmington and a not-so-nice view of a rusted Delaware power plant.
Since the actor announced his plans, real estate prices have crept up and new businesses have opened in anticipation of the thousands of new visitors. Some residents near the property have found tourists in their front yards taking photographs of the "land that Bruce bought."
But some people here said today that they were not surprised that Mr. Willis had decided to pull out. They had watched for any sign of activity on the property and, so far, the only renovations had been to a huge gray stone house where Mr. Willis's father now lives.
"I just couldn't see it," said Adele Stalcup, who runs Bancos Deli at the foot of the weed-covered pier that Mr. Willis planned to rebuild so that a ferry could stop there. "The scale was all wrong. You can't take a $52 million development and plunk it into a nine-tenths of a one-square-mile town."
Jim Bundy, who was fishing today on the banks of the Delaware on Mr. Willis's property, was a little more bitter. "It had to happen," he said of the actor's decision to leave. "Good things don't happen here."
Indeed, the unemployment rate in Penns Grove is about 15 percent -- almost three times the current statewide rate of 5.5 percent. The borough's economy has been in a tailspin ever since the Du Pont chemical plant in neighboring Carneys Point began laying off blue-collar workers decades ago. The population is now about 4,800, down from 5,200 in 1990.
The project needed approval from both Penns Grove and the state of Delaware, since the state line runs along the low tide mark of the New Jersey bank of the river, and Mr. Willis's marina and pier would have been on the Delaware side.
Mr. Willis had started making a film, "The Broadway Brawler," in Wilmington earlier this year, a move that some of Penns Grove's residents said they believed was meant to win that city's support. But the filming was halted almost immediately because the producer and director left.
In early 1996, Mr. Willis met with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, leaving his limousine in front of the New Jersey State House while they discussed his plan. Pete McDonough, the Governor's press secretary, said Mrs. Whitman took the opportunity to tell Mr. Willis that she would do all she could to help insure that the project stayed on course and that the state and local government would cooperate to make the project a reality.
Yesterday, Mr. McDonough said, Mrs. Whitman was "disappointed that Mr. Willis has made a decision not to pursue the project and hopes that he will reconsider."
Mr. Willis grew up in Carneys Point, attended Penns Grove High School and even worked in one of the Du Pont factories before he found fame on the television series "Moonlighting" and through his "Die Hard" films.
Borough officials said today that Mr. Willis had stressed to them early in the project that his hope was to create jobs. The development company planned to hire local people and firms to do much of the work, Mr. Crescenzi said.
But while some business people said they were certain that the town could turn itself around with or without Mr. Willis, others were not so sure.
At Bobby's Place, a small supermarket that opened across from Mr. Willis's property last year, the owner, Christine Kern, said this afternoon that she may soon close up shop. Not a customer was in the store, despite the smell of Ms. Kerns fresh-baked doughnuts.
"I won't be able to stay here," Ms. Kern said. "There's not enough money to pay the bills."

HEADLINE: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: ALBANY;
A Familiar Complaint For an Election Year

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
After four years of relative silence on the subject, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani unleashed a surprisingly pointed attack yesterday on the many ways in which the state shortchanges the city, placing a demand for fairness at the very heart of his election-year budget.
Although he has occasionally taken Albany to task before, the Mayor for the first time actually began to echo the ancient cry of his predecessors, railing at the state's failure to give the city its fair share of money for education, transportation, health care and welfare. He was particularly critical of Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to recalculate the state's property tax formula, claiming it fails to recognize the city's importance to the rest of the state. 
 And, just two years after asking state legislators for less welfare and Medicaid money -- which would have allowed him to cut the city's share of spending in those areas -- he complained yesterday that the Governor plans to keep hundreds of millions of Federal dollars provided by the new welfare law, which the Mayor believes is due the city.
Mr. Giuliani's oratorical turnabout was the most striking element of his annual budget presentation, constituting a substantial portion of his speech to city officials and reporters, and aides said it was deliberately highlighted to convey the Mayor's growing irritation with spending formulas that he contends are tilted against the city. The speech was accompanied by eight charts on the subject, with titles like "Historical Inequity of New York City Share of State Education Aid," showing how the city loses more than $4 billion a year to a series of such imbalances.
"I want to make a very strong argument for our share of tax revenues," he said when asked about his new direction. "And I think it's important to put out on the agenda precisely how much we contribute to the economy of the state and areas in which we're not getting back our proportionate share."
Most of these inequities, of course, have existed for years, and Mr. Giuliani has until now chosen to suppress his frustration. His decision to speak out about them now, a few months before the end of his term and in a re-election year, reflects a series of calculations, some political, some purely practical.
At one level, the Mayor has been under attack by his political opponents for failing to achieve more in Albany, particularly after his decision in 1995 to ask for less. Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President and a candidate for mayor, said yesterday it was a bit late for Mr. Giuliani suddenly to begin requesting more money from the state.
"I'm glad that in the last six months of his term in office he has come to realize the gross inequities around which he ought to have been organizing coalitions," she said. "That ought to have been one of the first points in his annual Albany lobbying trips." Whatever dim memories a few voters may have of the 1995 incident, Mr. Giuliani will now be in a position to drown them out with a never-fail populist roar against the state capital.
The timing is also in his favor. The Mayor had to spend several years in the wilderness after endorsing Mr. Pataki's Democratic opponent in 1994, Mario M. Cuomo; he clearly felt constrained about pushing his relationship with the Republican Governor by asking him to rewrite the state's political rules in New York City's favor.
Now that he is in a sturdier political position, Mr. Giuliani is apparently willing to assume a few risks, particularly at a time when the Governor is himself beginning to consider re-election and is thus more concerned about his image in the city, aides said.
With the state enjoying a surplus of $1 billion to $2 billion, the Mayor is urging the Governor to revise his proposal to reduce state property taxes paid to schools. The Giuliani administration contends that the Governor's plan would primarily benefit rural and suburban areas, because city schools do not rely on property taxes as much as schools elsewhere in the state. He also said that the state plans to keep far too much of the $730 million in surplus Federal money flowing from the new welfare law, and that it should return three or four times as much to cities and counties around the state.
"It is natural that there would be the difference of opinion, because when you run a city, you focus on the needs of the city, and when you run a state you have to look at the entire state," the Mayor said. "I don't expect that we are going to cure every one of these, but I think that they offer perspective on why we should be getting more than 12 percent of the tax relief that is being given out all over the state. New York City is the engine that drives the entire economy of the state."
For good measure, the Mayor threw in assorted complaints about the benefits of the Port Authority and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and he noted that New York State was one of only two states that require localities to split the costs of Medicare with them.
The Pataki administration seemed to know what was coming, having issued a news release on Wednesday defending its generosity to the city. Yesterday, the Governor said that critics should consider the impact of programs on the entire state.
"If we do it that way," he said at a Manhattan appearance, "if we stop 'upstate, downstate,' if we stop the suburbs against the city and recognize that we all do well if all parts of the state do well and we have to do what's right for all parts of the state, then we're going to continue to do very well as a state."
The Mayor, however, has the luxury of being concerned only with downstate voters. Although his aides had recently been boasting about their success using a new approach in Albany, the Mayor's sudden turn seems to indicate that the old songs still sound best in an election year.

HEADLINE: In Victory for U.S., Europe Ban On Treated Beef Is Ruled Illegal

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 8

 BODY:
The European Union's ban on hormone-treated beef is illegal, a panel of the World Trade Organization has decided, potentially giving the American cattle industry a big victory but also turning over new ground on issues of national sovereignty.
In a preliminary report, which has not yet been released to the public, the organization says that Europe's import ban on beef produced with growth-enhancing hormones is illegal because it has no scientific justification, according to American officials who have seen it. 
 If it is upheld, and experts on both sides said they believed that it would be, it is likely to set an important precedent for attacking scores of other trade barriers -- from Japanese certification of apples to European rules for poultry inspection -- that are based on health concerns.
The effects of the decision may not be directly felt because, through negotiation, the Europeans might be able to keep the ban, which has wide popular support, by making trade-offs in other areas. But it nonetheless reinforces the shift in emphasis toward international trade law and away from traditional unilateral decisions or bilateral trade agreements, even when internal policies are at stake.
And a ruling by the trade organization could someday cut the other way as well, calling on the United States to drop health or environmental regulations that have broad popular appeal but that do not pass scientific muster in an international tribunal. It was that very possibility that galvanized some American conservatives to campaign against the formation of the group three years ago, contending that the organization would imperil American sovereignty by subjecting United States regulations to a group consisting of representatives of more than 100 other countries.
Unlike many import restrictions, the European ban on hormone-treated beef was not erected to protect local farmers but rather to assuage widespread popular angst among European consumers over chemicals in food and it applies equally to European and non-European farmers. The United States was joined in its complaint by several other big beef producers -- Argentina, Canada, Australia and New Zealand -- that also use growth hormones.
The issue before the three-member panel of the World Trade Organization was whether the beef ban, which was enacted in 1988, was grounded on any scientific evidence that the use of hormones might endanger health. American farmers routinely use five hormones, including progesterone and testosterone, to make cattle grow faster and produce more milk.
The overwhelming consensus among scientific experts was that there is no such evidence, and the five hormones used by American farmers were specifically approved by a standards-setting body within the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.
United States Government officials who have seen the 60-page ruling by the trade panel said it firmly concluded that the European Union failed to satisfy the new standard for trade restrictions based on health.
"From our analysis, the preliminary decision comes down squarely on our side, based on the issue that food safety criteria have to be grounded on the basis of scientific principles," said one official, who spoke on the condition of not being identified.
European experts and diplomats said they were not surprised by the ruling, which was delivered to both sides shortly after midnight this morning in Geneva. The scientific consensus was simply too clear, they said.
Nonetheless, the ban on hormone-treated beef is grounded in powerful popular suspicions across much of Europe about chemical additives in food. European news media are full of reports about the decline in male fertility rates, with much of the speculation focusing on chemicals that people are absorbing from their environments. European foods routinely use fewer preservatives than American foods.
And when news reports periodically appear that cattle farmers in one country or another have been illegally using hormones, the reports generate angry popular outbursts and sometimes lead to brief but noticeable declines in beef consumption.
The issue of meat safety has become even more sensitive for Europeans in the last year, because of the furor over British cattle infected with "mad cow disease." Fear of contaminated beef prompted other countries in the European Union to block imports of British meat, igniting a bitter trade battle between Britain and the rest of Europe.
Today's decision is the first involving the agreement that restrictions based on health and safety of food products must be based on scientific evidence that they protect human health.
"The trouble with the W.T.O. agreement is that it does not provide for any measures that are based on consumer concerns," said Stefan Tangermann, a professor of agricultural economics at the University of Gottingen in Germany. "It only provides for measures that are based on scientific concerns."
The ruling could also have a direct bearing on potential disputes in the future over genetically engineered crops, which raise some of the same political issues as hormone-treated beef. American companies are already marketing genetically altered corn that resists root worms and soybeans that are impervious to powerful pesticides, and both products have already generated intense political opposition in some European quarters.
The decision on the beef rules is almost certain to ignite a backlash among consumer groups and political leaders in much of Europe. The United States and the European Union both have one month to review the report and press for changes, but experts on both sides say the final decision is not likely to differ much from the preliminary report.
The issue is so sensitive, in fact, that European officials in Brussels have suggested they might well prefer to pay compensation to the United States rather than lift the ban, in the event that they ultimately lost the legal fight.
Many experts on both sides of the Atlantic said today that they expected the Europeans to seek some sort of negotiated solution that would allow them to keep their ban intact. Under the rules of the World Trade Organization, a country can choose to maintain its restriction if it gives up something of comparable value -- by cutting tariffs on other products, for example.
The actual volume of American beef exports to Europe is relatively small -- about $250 million, or about 10 percent of America's total beef exports -- cattle industry executives say.
These executives expressed concerns today that their legal victory might not translate into practical benefits, if the European Union tried to negotiate an alternative to dropping the hormone prohibition.
"We do not feel that having the European Union pay compensation is an acceptable alternative," said Mark Armentrout, head of the international markets committee of the National Cattlemen's Beef Association and the owner of Mill Park Feedlot in Oakland, Iowa.
Mr. Armentrout said his association would be willing to accept requirements that beef be labeled as an American product, but he balked at using labels that would get into the subject of hormones.
"We are not willing to have some label that portrays it in a negative light," he said. "But in there somewhere there is room for negotiation."
European Union officials could not be reached today, because it is a holiday in Belgium, where the European Commission is based.
The United States and the European Union both have an opportunity to make comments about the preliminary report, and a final version will be issued in about a month. The European Union can then appeal to the World Trade Organization, but the organization's rules require that the report be approved unless there is a unanimous vote against doing so.
Since it was established, the World Trade Organization has become a very successful forum for the United States to vent its trade disputes. The United States has brought 25 complaints to the Geneva-based organization. Of those, four have been decided, all in favor of the United States.
The most recent was a preliminary decision last month against the European Union's restrictions on banana imports, which favor former European colonies and have been fought for years by American companies like Chiquita Brands International that own banana plantations in Central and South America.
But United States regulations have also come under attack from abroad. The same principle at stake in today's decision on beef -- the validity of internal health rules -- has been invoked in at least one instance, a pending case brought by several Southeast Asian nations. These countries, which include Malaysia and Indonesia, have filed complaints with the trade organization against American restrictions on shrimp that have been harvested in ways that do not meet United States environmental regulations.
And in a similar case, in June 1996, the United States agreed in a complaint brought by Venezuela and Brazil to change how it applies environmental rules to imported gasoline.

HEADLINE: In America;
President Houdini

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Don't ever bet against him. Bill Clinton appears to spend most of his time being pummeled by scandals and other problems. He seems always on the verge of being punched out politically. And then, somehow, to the amazement of his friends and the consternation of his enemies (or vice versa), he comes off the ropes to fashion some dazzling new triumph.
If he were really a boxer, the nickname stitched across his robe would be Houdini. 
 Mr. Clinton's latest big win is the bipartisan agreement to (allegedly) balance the budget by the year 2002. "A balanced budget with balanced values," said Mr. Clinton, which is a really peculiar notion when you think about it. Balanced values. (I imagine a kind of ethical free-trade zone in which people are encouraged to swap some of the things in which they have long believed. It's a concept most easily grasped by those who believe in nothing.)
In any event, the budget agreement was announced on Friday, and when you looked at Saturday's papers you saw that it was part of an extraordinary constellation of good economic news, at least for the short term. The economy was still expanding, inflation was still in hiding, the stock markets were still rising and the official unemployment rate had dropped to an astonishing 24-year low. Economists who had spent years insisting the sky would fall if the jobless rate dipped below 6 percent suddenly found themselves disoriented. Some took to their beds. Others thought the 4.9 percent figure in Saturday's papers was a misprint.
Bill Clinton had come off the ropes with a vengeance.
That's the good news. The bad news has to do with the regressive parlay in the ballyhooed budget agreement -- permanent tax cuts skewed to the rich that inevitably will blow huge holes in future budgets, and the continued willingness of cynical politicians to load the nation's sacrifices onto the backs of those who have the least.
As Robert Greenstein of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities put it: "The problem is the juxtaposition of things like a 10 percent real reduction in the non-defense discretionary part of the budget alongside these big tax cuts for the wealthy. Budget cuts that might be reasonable as part of an everybody-shares-the-pain-for-the-long-term-good package are pretty hard to justify when not only is there no pain at the top, but there are windfall tax cuts."
Mr. Greenstein noted that if you looked ahead just a few years, to 2008 and beyond, the steadily increasing impact of the tax cuts would mean a net revenue loss of $400 billion to $500 billion a year. And that will be happening at the same time that the baby boom vanguard begins filling out its retirement forms. Try to imagine the budget cuts that will be needed then to bring Federal revenues and expenditures anywhere near a balance.
Americans in the second decade of the 21st century will not be happy when they look back at Houdini and his bipartisan budget balancers.
Meanwhile, Senator Paul Wellstone, a liberal Democrat from Minnesota, has decided that the time to get indignant is now. Mr. Wellstone suffers from the belief that there should be limits to the extremes of hypocrisy to which politicians will go.
He noted (as just one example) that he and other Democrats have been complaining loudly about the dilapidated condition of so many of the nation's public schools. "We were going to take a stand on this," he said.
But when the budget agreement was announced, a very modest $5 billion proposal to help renovate schools was gone. "Knocked out," said Mr. Wellstone ruefully. "It was abandoned."
Hundreds of billions of dollars' worth of tax cuts was doable, but not $5 billion to renovate rotting schools.
That kind of betrayal of the interests of the very young and the politically weak is typical of the budget process, the Senator said. "It's deficit reduction based on the path of least political resistance."
He urged his colleagues to at least be honest about what they were doing. "Let's not have any more photo opportunities next to small children," he said. "We all love children in the abstract but we're not willing to invest in the resources they need. It's symbolic politics at its worst."

LENGTH: 585 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Giuliani's Budget Challenge

 BODY:
The $34 billion budget proposed by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani yesterday asked for little change in the way New York City's government runs and little sacrifice from New Yorkers. That is because the city, like the Federal and state governments, is rolling in cash from an improved economy, especially on Wall Street, and has no need for the austerity pushed by the Mayor when he first took office. Nevertheless, he is missing a rare opportunity to put the city's long-term finances in balance.
In one area, the Mayor did throw down the gauntlet. He demanded that Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature use their own surpluses to provide more equitable state funding for the city. His arguments deserve attention in Albany. 
 The case for greater equity lay in the Mayor's complaint that New York City contributes 45.4 percent of the state's revenues and has 38 percent of the state's schoolchildren but receives far less than that proportion in school aid and other programs. Mr. Pataki has promised to rectify the school aid formula but is putting it off. Moreover, Mr. Pataki's plan for property tax relief is still skewed heavily against the city.
The response in Albany has always been that whereas the city receives less than its fair share of school aid and other programs, it receives most of the state's money for welfare and Medicaid. But that is because the city's population is poor, and these programs go to individual recipients, not to the city at large. Running comfortably ahead in his own re-election campaign, Mr. Giuliani can afford to expend some political capital on making his best case in Albany. The timing is good, since the Governor and the Legislature are wrangling right now over how to spend billions of dollars that have turned up since Mr. Pataki presented his own budget in January.
As for the Mayor's budget itself, little is different from the plan he presented in January, except that an optimistic picture on revenues has become even more optimistic. Good economic times have given the Mayor over $1 billion more to play with than he anticipated last year. He has not used this money wisely. For the most part, the money is going for recurring expenses that will remain in the budget long after the current surplus is used up, leaving wide budget gaps in the future. The city might better use the money to retire some of the debt that has been squeezing the budget for years.
When times are good, prudent management would dictate relying less on gimmicks to balance the budget. Instead, Mr. Giuliani is using more gimmicks than ever -- one-shot revenues, asset sales, refinancing of debt -- to pay for ongoing expenses. Moreover, many of those expenses include wage increases and tax cuts that grow in the years ahead, so that the city will never escape from multibillion-dollar deficits as far as the eye can see.
Mr. Giuliani's priorities are not the problem, though the City Council should look carefully to see if some funding for libraries, cultural institutions and children's services needs to be added. The problem is that the Mayor is throwing everything he can into crowd-pleasing initiatives like tax cuts and more spending on sanitation and police rather than looking ruthlessly to save money in the delivery of services. The Mayor's tough and innovative approach in cutting costs in his first three years has been abandoned now that he is positioning himself for re-election. He can boast of many achievements, but this year he could have done better.

HEADLINE: White House Aide Pushed Plan Benefiting Chinese Shipping Concern

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 8

 BODY:
During a tough battle last year over how a closed Navy base in Long Beach, Calif., would be used, a Clinton Administration official made what several people involved describe as highly unusual telephone calls to push for construction there of a container terminal that would be leased to a shipping company owned by the Chinese Government.
The calls were made last November to public officials interested in preserving some historic buildings at the old base, and their disclosure coincides with Federal investigations of whether the Chinese Government tried to make contributions to the Democratic Party last year. 
 The White House official who made the calls, Dorothy Robyn, a member of the National Economic Council, denied in an interview that she had been trying to exert any undue influence over the fate of what had been a major Navy base.
She said that her calls had been made at the request of the Mayor of Long Beach, that they had been intended merely to support the creation of new jobs in an area hit hard by Pentagon cutbacks and that she had never spoken about the project to the shipping concern, the China Ocean Shipping Company, or Cosco.
In the calls, Ms. Robyn urged the preservation officials -- from the Navy, the state and the local government -- to abandon efforts to save any buildings at the base and to allow them to be razed quickly, and the new terminal constructed. Some of those officials had been arguing that Long Beach ought to consider using some buildings for schools, recreation centers or other public uses.
There is no evidence that there was anything improper about the calls, but several officials who received them said it was highly unusual for the White House to intervene on behalf of one side in a local battle like this one, especially when the intervention benefited the cause of a business concern.
Louis J. Freeh, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said earlier this week that the F.B.I. was conducting "a very extensive investigation" into whether the Chinese Government tried to buy influence in last year's elections. While Cosco has not been implicated in the investigation, Hongye Zheng, a senior Chinese Government official who advises the company, attended one of President Clinton's Saturday morning radio broadcasts at the White House last year, as part of a group organized by Johnny Chung.
Mr. Chung is a Chinese-American businessman in Los Angeles who raised $391,000 for the Democratic Party in the last election cycle and enjoyed unusual access to the White House. The propriety of some of those donations is now one subject of the Federal investigation.
Despite the Clinton Administration's push at Long Beach, the plan to pave over the 145-acre base remains stalled because of a court battle between the city and the Long Beach Port Commission, which favor the terminal, and private preservation groups, which oppose it. Several weeks ago a state judge ordered Long Beach to cancel its contract with Cosco and reconsider competing plans for the location, but the Port Commission voted again shortly afterward in favor of the terminal.
As part of the Federal base-closing program, the Government typically cleans up old bases and then hands them over to local governments after they are reviewed for their historical value, and after re-use plans are adopted by the local community.
The Long Beach city preservation officer, the California state preservation officer and a Navy preservation officer have already signed off on the destruction of the buildings at the former Long Beach Naval Station, and officials at the United States Advisory Council on Historic Preservation, who must also review such decisions, appear likely to give their approval soon.
But several of those officials said the White House pressure had been unprecedented.
"We'd never had a phone call like that in this office before," said Lee Keatinge of the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation. "There's no base re-use fight that's come close to Long Beach" for that kind of high-level involvement.
Ruthann Lehrer, Long Beach's preservation official, said: "It was made clear that this container terminal plan was the preference of the White House, not any of the other ideas some people were talking about. This was clearly not something that the White House wanted studied further."
Twenty-nine bases in California have been closed or cut back since 1988, and Long Beach has suffered huge job losses because of the naval base closing and layoffs at several large aerospace plants. The city has said it is pushing for the container terminal because it would create as many as 600 jobs.
The key telephone call occurred the day before the election last November. Ms. Robyn (pronounced ROH-bine) addressed about eight of the people involved in the Long Beach battle and said, as several participants in the conference call remember it, "I think this Administration has been very supportive of historic preservation, but in this case the national interest would be best served if this re-use plan proceeds."
Ms. Robyn called some of the officials two days later and reiterated that the national interest -- the creation of jobs -- demanded that the base be used as a shipping terminal and that the issue be closed quickly.
"I participated in a conference call at the Mayor's request and stated what the Administration's position was," Ms. Robyn recalled. "We said we support the community's re-use plan." That Cosco was the prospective tenant of the terminal was "totally irrelevant," she said, adding that she had had no contact with the company.
Ms. Robyn said she had been involved in such base closings before, but always to push a slow-moving Navy bureaucracy to hand over the sites quickly. She acknowledged that this was the first time she had stepped in when a community was divided over a re-use plan, and when intervention effectively favored one side over the other.
Cosco already operates from an 80-acre terminal at Long Beach's commercial port. Under the plan for the old naval base, the Port Commission would spend $200 million razing the existing structures and building the terminal. Cosco would pay about $14.5 million a year to lease the terminal, which would be used to accommodate a new generation of larger vessel that the company has started sailing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The administration building at the closed Navy base in Long Beach, Calif., is one of many that would be razed to make way for a hotly disputed new container terminal. The terminal would be leased to the China Ocean Shipping Company, owned by the Chinese Government. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Westlake Journal;
A Perot Comes to Town But Then Leaves With It

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

 BODY:
For four years, Ross Perot Jr., son of the two-time Presidential candidate and a multimillionaire in his own right, has owned more than half the land in tiny, once peaceful Westlake, Tex., just north of Dallas and Fort Worth.
Now he has seceded. Along with him have gone the 2,500 acres on which he plans to build offices, housing and golf courses. And most members of Westlake's governing body, the Board of Aldermen, have seceded with their land, too, leaving the town of 250 residents torn to pieces. 
 "You've got a town where everyone is at everyone else's throats," said Pete Geren, a spokesman for Mr. Perot's development company and a former United States representative from Texas. "There are irreconcilable differences here."
The marriage between Mr. Perot and the town of Westlake seemed promising at the start. When he bought the Circle T Ranch in 1993 from the oilman Nelson Bunker Hunt, who was forced to sell it at the bargain price of $20 million after going bankrupt, residents rejoiced that a man with deep pockets had become the owner of 60 percent of the land within Westlake's borders.
"We wanted Perot here because he had the money and the forethought and the planning," said Don Gardner, a three-year resident.
Mr. Perot owns 25,000 acres throughout the United States, and he heads the industrial cargo park at Fort Worth's Alliance Airport, just a few miles from the edge of the Circle T. Cattle are still being raised on the property, which is also home to a herd of bison.
Mr. Perot, residents figured, would bring investment and, by attracting new residents, additional revenue, too, just as he had done elsewhere.
"But then," Mr. Gardner said, "we realized he wanted to use our money to build."
Mr. Perot had pledged he would not saddle Westlake with extra taxes. The ranch property, Mr. Perot's representatives pointed out, contained three municipality districts authorized to sell bonds, and thus could finance its own development.
As outlined by Mr. Perot's representatives, new businesses and residents on the Circle T property could have water, electricity and road improvements financed by bonds sold by the districts. The bonds would be paid off with special taxes assessed on the property owners.
But longtime residents of Westlake feared they would have to pay taxes, too, if newcomers later took control of the Board of Aldermen and sought to spread the burden.
The aldermen seemed to share residents' concerns. But after a transaction last December, residents were no longer sure the aldermen were on their side. In that deal, Mr. Perot bought an additional 500 acres from the Hunt family trust, on which an alderman lived. He paid a reported $10 million for the property, to go with the 2,000 acres he already had.
In a matter of months, four of the five alderman publicly backed Mr. Perot's financing plan, saying that they trusted him to deal in good faith. Many residents noted that the interests of the four aldermen were merging with those of Mr. Perot.
Were other town leaders, residents asked, hoping to sell their land for a princely sum to Mr. Perot? The Mayor, Scott Bradley, said Mr. Perot had offered to buy his property, which Mr. Perot's spokesman confirmed. The offer was rejected. Suspicions deepened. And the town split.
One man who had publicly questioned whether Mr. Perot's plans were in the town's best interests was Don Redding, a retired executive with International Business Machines and a member of the Planning and Zoning Board. In February, he declared that he would run for alderman himself. His candidacy did not last long. Four of the five aldermen voted to declare that Mr. Redding's neighborhood of 64 residents, Stagecoach Hills, had never actually fallen within the town's borders, denying him the right to run for office.
From then on, tensions between pro-Perot and anti-Perot forces worsened. Town meetings were shouting matches, with residents challenging and ridiculing board members. Government was in gridlock. It was a startling turnabout in a place where politics had been so dull that only 21 people showed up to vote in the town election last year.
Early this month, the board, on a vote of 4 to 1, dismissed Mr. Bradley as Mayor. Mr. Bradley, a former assistant district attorney in Dallas, had been a persistent critic of Mr. Perot's plans. In invoking legal provisions that permitted the Mayor's removal for incompetence, the aldermen cited problems with the board's minutes and with scheduling.
And there was another problem: Mr. Bradley had opposed the aldermen's move to prohibit Mr. Redding's candidacy.
"He behaved in a manner unacceptable to anyone else," Al Oien, an alderman and Perot supporter, said after the Mayor's ouster.
Even as Mr. Bradley was being ousted, Mr. Perot requested that the Circle T ranch be excluded from the town's boundaries. Three aldermen, blaming incessant fighting and facing an election in which pro-Perot forces were likely to lose their board majority, requested secession for land they owned, a total of 169 acres, adjacent to the Perot property.
Eleven other residents, with a total of 95 acres, broke away, too, complaining they were tired of the political fighting and the government's telling them what to do.
"This is about classic small-town governance issues," Mr. Perot said in a recent interview. "The founders of the city want to be left alone; they want to live their lives in peace."
That was the situation when 120 residents gathered in a meeting room adjacent to city hall, atop a day-care center in an office center, to watch most of the 41-year-old town's political leaders and its leading landowner secede, or, in the words of Texas, take part in a "disannexation." It had simply required a public posting of the landowners' intentions 72 hours in advance of the meeting, in addition to a majority vote of the aldermen and that of the Mayor. On the day of the secession vote, the board voted 4 to 1 to appoint a new mayor, Dale White, who is retired. With his support, the secession was a foregone conclusion. Mr. White's 22 acres were among those disannexed.
Some residents wept.
Mr. Bradley, the ousted Mayor, has vowed to fight, with the goal of putting the little town back together. He says he will challenge his dismissal in court.
For now, with Westlake a third the size it was last month, many residents feel betrayed by Mr. Perot. "We all went with him because we thought, 'This is Ross Perot, and he's going to do good,' " Mr. Gardner said. "But we found out the big boys play hard."
The day after the secession, the Fort Worth City Council voted to include Mr. Perot's property in its extraterritorial jurisdiction, which means that the city could make the land part of the city. Becoming part of Fort Worth, said Mr. Perot's spokesman, Mr. Geren, would open several options for financing development.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Scott Bradley was Mayor of Westlake, Tex., until he was dismissed recently in a land dispute. At a town meeting this month, he was flanked by his wife, Kelly, and daughter, Brooke Nicolson. When Ross Perot Jr. seceded from Westlake, he took half the land in the small town with him. Mr. Perot plans to build offices, housing and golf courses on part of his ranch, where cattle and bison are now raised. (Photographs by Mark Graham for The New York Times)
